webTitle: Tackle crime and regeneration will follow

fields.headline: Tackle crime and regeneration will follow
fields.standfirst: If we drive out crime on housing estates, we will probably find that we have solved social inclusion and achieved regeneration, writes Steve Harrison
fields.trailText: If we drive out crime on housing estates, we will probably find that we have solved social inclusion and achieved regeneration, writes Steve Harrison
fields.body:
Watching Tony Marchant's Never Never on TV recently, you knew Johnny was heading for a fall when he decided to use the underground car park on the housing estate.

Such places are a potent symbol of the fear of crime on many estates - and the cause is simply design. As we try again to regenerate inner cities, community safety is at the top of the agenda. We hope we won't repeat past mistakes. But are we going to get it right this time?

Regeneration schemes in the new millennium are different from the estate action, housing action trusts and the other schemes during the last government. This time there seems to be more money around.

We are also talking joined-up working and, with regard to crime, this means the Crime and Disorder Act (1998). The police, councils and a host of other agencies are now obliged to work together to reduce crime and disorder. Section 17 of the Act requires local authorities to give "due regard" to preventing crime and disorder in exercising all its functions. The approach now starts to look a little different - perhaps.

Take the new deal for communities (NDC), for example. In the London borough of Lewisham, the NDC project, Aiming High for New Cross Gate, embraces a busy station, the bustling New Cross Road on the A2, a secondary school, as well as a variety of housing.

"Crime and the fear of crime" has emerged as one of five core concerns. What should public agencies do to meet this challenge? If we failed on the simpler schemes what chance do we have when tackling this greater complexity?

There are the obvious, sensible actions, including social housing refurbishment. Designing out crime can extend beyond new construction - for instance upgrading the street lighting on New Cross Road.

There are two main areas for a changed approach. Law and order, traditionally the sole preserve of the police, is now about partnership. Fear of crime may be stoked more by disorder and sub-criminal behaviour than by crime itself: older people may be deterred from venturing out more by graffiti, rundown surroundings and street drinking than by the rate of street robbery. Solutions to graffiti and unkempt surroundings include surveillance (by the police or the council), rapid removal of graffiti and fly-tipping (targeted in Lewisham as enviro-crime), and work with schools and young people to convince them that defacing their environment is wrong.

Where a specific problem area is identified, Lewisham's anti-social behaviour action team can work with the police, social services and others to identify the best solution. This would usually mean tackling enforcement in a structured and coherent way and using the full range of options. For example, would eviction under the Housing Act for drug dealing be a more effective tool for regenerating a neighbourhood than prosecution? Can loitering youths be fined for littering, where policing does not yield easy results?

Partnership is at its best when it tackles the causes of crime. We know about our offenders - for instance, many are low academic achievers - so we know the root causes that we should tackle. National initiatives to improve academic achievement are spread too thin to have a real impact on our target group, but funding that is targeted to local needs and as part of regeneration initiatives could maximise effectiveness.

In addition to preventive work, we also need to deal effectively with people who have already embarked on a course of anti-social behaviour. The small group of joy-riding children and their drug-dependent parents, for example, need preventive intervention that reflects the effect of their actions on the wider community. This is a demand that is not met by mainstream social services budgets.

The danger of a partnership is that life continues as before but with more meetings. In Lewisham, we are trying to avoid this by developing a problem-solving approach borrowed from the police. By analysing a problem and working out the most appropriate role for each agency, we can develop a combination of short-term and longer-term solutions to produce a long-term reduction in offending.

None of this is automatic. The schemes of the 1980s and 1990s were unsuccessful in transforming communities because they were focused on one element, such as housing, or crime. If we define crime more widely, and the term community safety may help here, and consider it with issues such as health, citizenship and housing, then we can start to build cross-cutting responses that enable communities to drive out crime.

And if we drive out crime, we will probably find we have managed to solve social inclusion and achieve the remainder of the regeneration agenda in the process.

 Steve Harrison is a community safety officer at Lewisham council.

fields.headline: Arsenal freeze after sizzling start
fields.standfirst:
Gunners suffer their heaviest away defeat in Europe
Marcao 29, 51, Titov 77, Robson 82 | Silvinho 2
fields.trailText: Arsenal suffered their heaviest away defeat in Europe on a freezing and humiliating night that makes victory against Bayern Munich in two weeks time a virtual imperative.
fields.byline: Jon Brodkin  at the Luzhniki stadium
fields.body:
How far from potential Champions League winners Arsenal will feel this morning. Undermined by unusually poor defending, they collapsed to their heaviest away defeat in Europe last night. On a freezing, humiliating evening there was nothing to warm the few hundred visiting fans.

They will wonder, though, what might have been. Ahead through Silvinho after 118 seconds, Arsenal will look back with regret at a dreadful miss by Nwankwo Kanu minutes later. At 2-0 it could have been game over. Instead they were outclassed by a wonderfully lively, inventive Spartak side.

This was a fantastic game that belied the poor pitch conditions but Arsenal will care little for that. Their match at home to Bayern Munich in a fortnight must surely be won if they are to progress to the quarter-finals and there is hardly margin for error now. Individual mistakes at the back and the ease with which they were torn apart in the second half do not bode well.

The absence of Patrick Vieira and Gilles Grimandi from central midfield hardly helped. But Tony Adams was out of sorts on his return and Martin Keown also failed to handle the outstanding Brazilian forwards Marcao and Robson. On the coldest night of Moscow's winter, when the temperature was -10C at kick-off and falling, it was ironic that boys from Brazil scored three times.

"We conceded stupid goals we are not used to conceding," said Arsenal's manager Arsène Wenger. "My team gave everything to play well but defensively as a team we didn't look as solid as we are used to.

"We should have scored a second goal when we were 1-0 up. Unfortunately we couldn't do it and then we had problems in the second half with the quick collective pace of Spartak's passing and we dropped physically."

Perhaps a heavy schedule is catching up with them. After four games without a win Arsenal must soon correct things or see a promising season end as disappointingly as the previous two. "We shouldn't be too catastrophic," Wenger said. "We lost to a good team and there were some positives. We have to correct certain things quickly."

Disciplined, tough and skilful, Spartak were fantastic to watch. Their passing, pace and movement were excellent, with Vasily Baranov a constant menace down the right. They have won all four of their Champions League matches at this impressive stadium.

Long before the end Arsenal must have wished this match had never started. Freezing temperatures and three inches of snow had put it in doubt and only after a late inspection by the referee Pierluigi Collina did it get the go-ahead. The follically challenged Italian must have been tempted to officiate in an old Soviet soldier's hat, on sale in Red Square for $10. He opted for gloves instead, as did all but Adams and Ray Parlour for Arsenal.

The undersoil heating and pitch cover had done enough to make this playable but an already rutted surface was muddy in places and snowy or icy in others. Not that Arsenal were troubled at the start. They might have had four in the first 10 minutes.

Thierry Henry had already gone clear once before he set up Silvinho's goal. When Henry then finished a fine run and set up Kanu it seemed game over. The Nigerian, though, is out of form and lacking confidence and from a few yards he allowed the keeper to save.

Spartak had already gone close twice when Silvinho failed to clear and Marcao fired a first-time shot beyond Alex Manninger's reach. The excitable crowd of 75,000 went wild and there was better to come. Marcao took advantage of poor marking from a Jerry-Christian Tchuisse cross to slot in from around two yards and, shortly after, the Brazilian set up Yegor Titov to finish unerringly as Adams stumbled. There was still time for Robson to score nine minutes from the end to complete a miserable, humbling night on which Parlour picked up a booking that means he misses the next match. Arsenal's supporters deserved better than to be ignored by so many of their players.

Spartak Moscow (1-3-4-2): Filimonov; Ananko (Bushmanov, 87min); Tchuisse, Parfenov, Kovtun; Baranov, Bulatov, Titov, Bezrodny; Marcao, Robson.

Arsenal (4-4-2): Manninger; Luzhny, Keown, Adams, Silvinho; Ljungberg, Parlour, Vivas, Pires (Lauren, 70); Kanu (Wiltord, 66), Henry.

Referee : P Collina (Italy)

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Emil Zatopek
fields.standfirst: He ran into the record books by winning, in eight days in 1952, Olympic gold medals in all three classic tests of endurance running
fields.trailText: Emil Zatopek, who has died aged 78, was one of the outstanding athletes of the 20th century. In the years following the second world war, he lifted distance running to a new plane, dominating the discipline to a degree achieved only by Paavo Nurmi before him, while at the same time enjoying the awe, respect and affection of his opponents and a popular acclaim that has rarely been matched.
fields.body:
Emil Zatopek, who has died aged 78, was one of the outstanding athletes of the 20th century. In the years following the second world war, he lifted distance running to a new plane, dominating the discipline to a degree achieved only by Paavo Nurmi before him, while at the same time enjoying the awe, respect and affection of his opponents and a popular acclaim that has rarely been matched.

From the week he won his first Olympic title in London in 1948 till his last major race in Melbourne in 1956, he was the most instantly recognisable figure in world sport, sending the back-page colour writers deep into their simile banks as they struggled to describe his tortured running style. He ran "like a man who had been stabbed in the heart", "as if his next step would be his last", "like a man wrestling with an octopus on a conveyor belt". Yet when the races were won and the head stopped rolling, a very different Zatopek emerged - a relaxed, gregarious figure with a captivating boyish smile, an aptitude for languages and an infectious enthusiasm for his sport.

And he sealed his place in history over eight unforgettable days at the Helsinki Olympic Games of 1952, when he achieved the unprecedented (and since unequalled) feat of winning gold medals in all three classic tests of endurance running - the 5,000 metres, the 10,000 metres and the marathon.

Zatopek was born in Koprivnice, in Moravia, the son of a Czech carpenter who had little interest in the boy's passion for running. Away from home, too, the occupying Nazi authorities positively discouraged organised sport; but running tracks were not closed, and in the early 1940s in the town of Zlin, where he worked in the Bata shoe factory, the young Zatopek began to progress slowly in the 1,500 metres.

Soon after the end of the war, by now drafted into the Czechoslovak army, he watched the great Swedish miler Arne Andersson compete in an invitation race in Prague. Andersson's physical condition, and an insight into the Swede's heavy background training, revolutionised Zatopek's own running. He had already trained long; now he trained hard.

He stretched his body and stamina to the limits: on sentry duty he might spend an hour running on the spot, knees high, shoulders straight; in winter, when saner athletes gratefully took time off from training, he would put on heavy baseball shoes, or even army boots, and run through the snow-covered forests, sometimes bounding in long, looping strides for two or three minutes at a stretch.

It was a self-taught and self-imposed regime, which took no account of the niceties of style. But the hours of relentless self-punishment gave him the capacity for sustained speed and the priceless bonus of a reserve tank of energy that would eventually allow him to run flat out for a lap, even at the end of a long, draining race.

In 1946 he was selected for the 5,000 metres in the European championships in Oslo, an unspectacular but promising debut on the big stage which saw him take fifth place behind another runner with a celebrated storming finish, Britain's Sydney Wooderson.

Two years later, in the build-up to the London Olympic Games of 1948, Zatopek's capacity for consistent, high-speed lapping had brought him noteworthy times in a number of invitation races, but the first track final of the Games, the 10,000 metres, was considered the bailiwick of the Finns (they had won five of the last six Olympic finals), and in particular of Viljo Heino, the current world record holder.

No one, certainly not Heino, had been prepared for Zatopek. He took over the lead from the Finn in the 10th of the 25 laps, and five circuits later unleashed a spurt that took him 10 metres clear. Heino simply ground to a halt. Zatopek ran on, unchallenged, as if the devil were at his heels, shoulders hunched, head rolling, face contorted in apparent agony, to the insistent chant of "Zat-o-pek, Zat-o-pek, Zat-o-pek" from his compatriots in the crowd, and won by three-quarters of a lap. It was the first track-and-field gold medal ever won by Czechoslovakia.

Next day he ran the 5,000 metres heats, and lined up for the final two days after that. For 10 laps of the race, through one of London's midsummer downpours, he shared the lead with the Belgian Gaston Reiff and the Dutchman Willem Slijkhuis. Then, either the fatigue finally hit him or he simply lost concentration; he fell hopelessly off the pace and Reiff accelerated for home. On the penultimate bend Reiff was leading by a good 20 metres from Slijkhuis, with Zatopek a further 25 metres back, splashing doggedly through the puddles in Wembley's red cinder track, apparently without a chance.

Suddenly he seemed to wake up, and began a frantic last-ditch sprint. Within 150 metres he had gobbled up Slijkhuis, and in the final straight he closed on Reiff, who was alerted to the danger only when the crowd's roar became hysterical. Reiff lunged desperately for the tape and won by a couple of feet; if the race had been 10 metres longer, Zatopek would have beaten him.

Czechoslovakia had found a national hero, and life could hardly have been better. A few weeks after the Games he married the national javelin champion Dana Ingrova (who, by the most bizarre of coincidences, had been born on the same day as he had) - a stable and happy partnership which visibly sustained both of them in the public years as sporting celebrities, and by all accounts made life a lot more tolerable when, in later life, they fell foul of the Czechoslovak political system. She survives him: they had no children.

For the next three years Zatopek was the undisputed master. From 1949 to 1951 he competed in 69 long-distance races (a schedule that would be simply unthinkable for any elite runner today) and won every one of them. From his first race at 10,000 metres in 1948 to his 38th in 1954 he was unbeaten at the distance. He won the European 10,000 metres championship in Brussels in 1950 by a full lap, and the 5,000 metres by 23 seconds. He broke 18 world records at distances from 5,000 metres to 30 kilometres, and in 1951 he became the first man to run 20 kilometres in under an hour. He was, in short, a phenomenon.

Expectations for success at Helsinki in 1952 were naturally high, but the pressures on him mounted as the Games approached. He had run with a virus at a minor domestic meeting six weeks earlier, and became ill; he recovered, but the slow times in his build-up races were worrying. He also had his first serious brush with the communist authorities in Prague, when a young 1,500 metres runner, Stanislav Jungwirth, was dropped from the Czech Olympic team because his father had been jailed for political offences; Zatopek even threatened to pull out of the Games himself unless Jungwirth were reinstated, and the brinkmanship was successful, though hardly an aid to concentration.

Then there were reports, which he refused to confirm, that he might be persuaded to run the marathon rather than - or, conceivably, as well as - the 5,000 metres.

Furthermore, he was in Finland, the land of Kolehmainen and Nurmi, where for the last 40 years distance running had been meat, drink, mother's milk and a second religion; every step he took would be under the scrutiny of the most knowledgeable athletics audience in the world.

On the first Sunday he took the 10,000 metres gold medal more or less as he pleased, shaking off his opponents one by one with his unwavering pace to win by the length of the straight. On the Tuesday he was visibly relaxed, and came close to clowning his way through the 5,000 metres heats, dropping back down the field, cajoling and pacing lesser runners to qualification once the stragglers had been dropped. Two days later the Olympic stadium was full to bursting, with more than 66,000 spectators for the most eagerly awaited single event of the Games, the 5,000 metres final.

The pace was fast, and no one had the courage to make a decisive break until, well into the final lap, Zatopek accelerated into the lead. In any race during the previous four years, that would have been decisive: if Zatopek led in the final lap, Zatopek won the race. But after a few strides in front he experienced something that had never happened to him in his career before, and which would have devastated a lesser spirit: with 300 metres to go, three men charged past him - the red-headed Christopher Chataway of Great Britain; the bespectacled Herbert Schade of Germany, who had been widely tipped to win the race; and the French-Algerian Alain Mimoun, who had followed Zatopek home in the 10,000 metres. Zatopek was left floundering in fourth place, seemingly outpaced and out of the medals.

On the final bend, Chataway - who was to fall a few strides later - began to tire, Schade moved up to his shoulder, Mimoun pulled out to take them both on the outside... and Zatopek pounced. With 150 metres to go, there were four men abreast on the crown of the bend, and the one in the red vest way out in lane two, his head rolling in agony, was going fastest of all; from that moment there was no question as to who was going to win.

Dana clinched the day's second gold medal for the family by throwing an Olympic record in the first round of the javelin to beat a powerful Russian trio into second, third and fourth places, and Emil, joking that a 2-1 score in the family gold count was too close for comfort, confirmed that he would indeed run in the marathon - the first of his life - the following Sunday.

The story of the Helsinki marathon has entered legend: how Zatopek introduced himself to the favourite, Jim Peters of Great Britain, at the start, and ran with him for the first hour; how - in a genuine search for information rather than a masterly piece of gamesmanship - he asked Peters if the pace was quick enough and, somewhat to his surprise, received the answer "No, too slow"; and how he left Peters and all the other leaders behind him and drew steadily away. As he entered the stadium a full two-and-a-half minutes clear of the field, the expectant buzz exploded into a single welcoming roar, and wave upon wave of cheering rang out across the Helsinki rooftops as he completed the last 300 metres to win his third gold medal in eight momentous days.

His career did not end in Helsinki; two years later he regained his European 10,000 metres title in Berne, but in the 5,000 metres he was beaten into third place by an even more hard-bitten, more relentless and infinitely less appealing competitor, the Ukrainian Vladimir Kuts, who was to assume Zatopek's mantle and win both long-distance track events for the Soviet Union at the Melbourne Games in 1956.

Zatopek was at Melbourne to defend his marathon title, but he was hardly in the best shape to tackle it: one of his more outlandish training sessions, which involved running while carrying Dana on his shoulders, had resulted in a bad strain that had only just cleared up in time. He was never seriously in medal contention, but he trotted home in sixth place without seeming unduly bothered, only to break out in smiles and handshakes and hugs of congratulation when he realised that the winner was Alain Mimoun, the old adversary he had beaten in so many championships in the past.

He retired a national icon and a natural sporting ambassador for Czechoslovakia. He rose steadily to the rank of colonel in the Czech army, gave unstinting advice during coaching visits abroad, and unostentatiously enjoyed the resulting privileges at home. Until 1968 and the Prague Spring, when he publicly welcomed the shift towards democracy promised by the Dubcek regime, and roundly condemned the Soviet response as troops moved into Prague to re-establish communist control.

He was expelled from the Communist party and dismissed from the army. He was consigned to a series of manual jobs for various state departments until, after seven years of this ritual humiliation, he was given a desk at the Ministry of Sport, employing his language skills to monitor and translate sports periodicals from the west.

Occasionally he was put on display at official receptions for visiting teams, when he would be seized upon by foreign journalists more eager just to shake his hand than to record the guarded answers he was obliged to give them. And towards the end of the 1980s, with the ice beginning to thaw and Zatopek long retired from the ministry, he would once in a while receive grudging permission to accept an invitation to an athletics event abroad. Invariably he would find himself at the centre of a crowd of foreigners who knew the face only from old newspapers or grainy archive film, but who had fallen under the spell of the legend; they would flock round him in unashamed awe, proffering scraps of paper for his autograph, hardly daring to offer a handshake in case it might be refused. It never was.

Zatopek's achievements in athletics are indelible, but bare statistics cannot reflect the genuine affection in which he was held by his fellow competitors, men with whom he chatted and joked as he ran them into the ground, men with whom he would willingly and honestly discuss race tactics even if he were due to run against them the next day, men whose insecurities and disappointments he could sympathise with and understand.

Late in 1968 another high-achieving record-breaker, the Australian Ron Clarke, left the Mexico City Olympic Games in deepest gloom: he had been the fastest long-distance runner in the world for a decade, yet in two Olympic Games fate, ill-judgment, altitude, or sheer bad luck had conspired against him, and his career was slipping away without a single gold medal to show for it. On his way home he stopped off in Prague to chat things over with his boyhood idol and long-time friend.

As they parted Zatopek gave the Australian a small parcel, and not wishing to embarrass his host, Clarke did not unwrap it until he was on the plane. It was one of Zatopek's Olympic gold medals, a gift from an athlete who had gloriously won four of them to a fellow athlete he just felt deserved one.

 Emil Zatopek, athlete, born September 19 1922; died November 21 2000

And he sealed his place in history over eight unforgettable days at the Helsinki Olympic Games of 1952, when he achieved the unprecedented (and since unequalled) feat of winning gold medals in all three classic tests of endurance running - the 5,000 metres, the 10,000 metres and the marathon. Zatopek was born in Koprivnice, in Moravia, the son of a Czech carpenter who had little interest in the boy's passion for running. Away from home, too, the occupying Nazi authorities positively discouraged organised sport; but running tracks were not closed, and in the early 1940s in the town of Zlin, where he worked in the Bata shoe factory, the young Zatopek began to progress slowly in the 1,500 metres. Soon after the end of the war, by now drafted into the Czechoslovak army, he watched the great Swedish miler Arne Andersson compete in an invitation race in Prague. Andersson's physical condition, and an insight into the Swede's heavy background training, revolutionised Zatopek's own running. He had already trained long; now he trained hard. He stretched his body and stamina to the limits: on sentry duty he might spend an hour running on the spot, knees high, shoulders straight; in winter, when saner athletes gratefully took time off from training, he would put on heavy baseball shoes, or even army boots, and run through the snow-covered forests, sometimes bounding in long, looping strides for two or three minutes at a stretch. It was a self-taught and self-imposed regime, which took no account of the niceties of style. But the hours of relentless self-punishment gave him the capacity for sustained speed and the priceless bonus of a reserve tank of energy that would eventually allow him to run flat out for a lap, even at the end of a long, draining race. In 1946 he was selected for the 5,000 metres in the European championships in Oslo, an unspectacular but promising debut on the big stage which saw him take fifth place behind another runner with a celebrated storming finish, Britain's Sydney Wooderson. Two years later, in the build-up to the London Olympic Games of 1948, Zatopek's capacity for consistent, high-speed lapping had brought him noteworthy times in a number of invitation races, but the first track final of the Games, the 10,000 metres, was considered the bailiwick of the Finns (they had won five of the last six Olympic finals), and in particular of Viljo Heino, the current world record holder. No one, certainly not Heino, had been prepared for Zatopek. He took over the lead from the Finn in the 10th of the 25 laps, and five circuits later unleashed a spurt that took him 10 metres clear. Heino simply ground to a halt. Zatopek ran on, unchallenged, as if the devil were at his heels, shoulders hunched, head rolling, face contorted in apparent agony, to the insistent chant of "Zat-o-pek, Zat-o-pek, Zat-o-pek" from his compatriots in the crowd, and won by three-quarters of a lap. It was the first track-and-field gold medal ever won by Czechoslovakia. Next day he ran the 5,000 metres heats, and lined up for the final two days after that. For 10 laps of the race, through one of London's midsummer downpours, he shared the lead with the Belgian Gaston Reiff and the Dutchman Willem Slijkhuis. Then, either the fatigue finally hit him or he simply lost concentration; he fell hopelessly off the pace and Reiff accelerated for home. On the penultimate bend Reiff was leading by a good 20 metres from Slijkhuis, with Zatopek a further 25 metres back, splashing doggedly through the puddles in Wembley's red cinder track, apparently without a chance. Suddenly he seemed to wake up, and began a frantic last-ditch sprint. Within 150 metres he had gobbled up Slijkhuis, and in the final straight he closed on Reiff, who was alerted to the danger only when the crowd's roar became hysterical. Reiff lunged desperately for the tape and won by a couple of feet; if the race had been 10 metres longer, Zatopek would have beaten him. Czechoslovakia had found a national hero, and life could hardly have been better. A few weeks after the Games he married the national javelin champion Dana Ingrova (who, by the most bizarre of coincidences, had been born on the same day as he had) - a stable and happy partnership which visibly sustained both of them in the public years as sporting celebrities, and by all accounts made life a lot more tolerable when, in later life, they fell foul of the Czechoslovak political system. She survives him: they had no children. For the next three years Zatopek was the undisputed master. From 1949 to 1951 he competed in 69 long-distance races (a schedule that would be simply unthinkable for any elite runner today) and won every one of them. From his first race at 10,000 metres in 1948 to his 38th in 1954 he was unbeaten at the distance. He won the European 10,000 metres championship in Brussels in 1950 by a full lap, and the 5,000 metres by 23 seconds. He broke 18 world records at distances from 5,000 metres to 30 kilometres, and in 1951 he became the first man to run 20 kilometres in under an hour. He was, in short, a phenomenon. Expectations for success at Helsinki in 1952 were naturally high, but the pressures on him mounted as the Games approached. He had run with a virus at a minor domestic meeting six weeks earlier, and became ill; he recovered, but the slow times in his build-up races were worrying. He also had his first serious brush with the communist authorities in Prague, when a young 1,500 metres runner, Stanislav Jungwirth, was dropped from the Czech Olympic team because his father had been jailed for political offences; Zatopek even threatened to pull out of the Games himself unless Jungwirth were reinstated, and the brinkmanship was successful, though hardly an aid to concentration. Then there were reports, which he refused to confirm, that he might be persuaded to run the marathon rather than - or, conceivably, as well as - the 5,000 metres. Furthermore, he was in Finland, the land of Kolehmainen and Nurmi, where for the last 40 years distance running had been meat, drink, mother's milk and a second religion; every step he took would be under the scrutiny of the most knowledgeable athletics audience in the world. On the first Sunday he took the 10,000 metres gold medal more or less as he pleased, shaking off his opponents one by one with his unwavering pace to win by the length of the straight. On the Tuesday he was visibly relaxed, and came close to clowning his way through the 5,000 metres heats, dropping back down the field, cajoling and pacing lesser runners to qualification once the stragglers had been dropped. Two days later the Olympic stadium was full to bursting, with more than 66,000 spectators for the most eagerly awaited single event of the Games, the 5,000 metres final. The pace was fast, and no one had the courage to make a decisive break until, well into the final lap, Zatopek accelerated into the lead. In any race during the previous four years, that would have been decisive: if Zatopek led in the final lap, Zatopek won the race. But after a few strides in front he experienced something that had never happened to him in his career before, and which would have devastated a lesser spirit: with 300 metres to go, three men charged past him - the red-headed Christopher Chataway of Great Britain; the bespectacled Herbert Schade of Germany, who had been widely tipped to win the race; and the French-Algerian Alain Mimoun, who had followed Zatopek home in the 10,000 metres. Zatopek was left floundering in fourth place, seemingly outpaced and out of the medals. On the final bend, Chataway - who was to fall a few strides later - began to tire, Schade moved up to his shoulder, Mimoun pulled out to take them both on the outside... and Zatopek pounced. With 150 metres to go, there were four men abreast on the crown of the bend, and the one in the red vest way out in lane two, his head rolling in agony, was going fastest of all; from that moment there was no question as to who was going to win. Dana clinched the day's second gold medal for the family by throwing an Olympic record in the first round of the javelin to beat a powerful Russian trio into second, third and fourth places, and Emil, joking that a 2-1 score in the family gold count was too close for comfort, confirmed that he would indeed run in the marathon - the first of his life - the following Sunday. The story of the Helsinki marathon has entered legend: how Zatopek introduced himself to the favourite, Jim Peters of Great Britain, at the start, and ran with him for the first hour; how - in a genuine search for information rather than a masterly piece of gamesmanship - he asked Peters if the pace was quick enough and, somewhat to his surprise, received the answer "No, too slow"; and how he left Peters and all the other leaders behind him and drew steadily away. As he entered the stadium a full two-and-a-half minutes clear of the field, the expectant buzz exploded into a single welcoming roar, and wave upon wave of cheering rang out across the Helsinki rooftops as he completed the last 300 metres to win his third gold medal in eight momentous days. His career did not end in Helsinki; two years later he regained his European 10,000 metres title in Berne, but in the 5,000 metres he was beaten into third place by an even more hard-bitten, more relentless and infinitely less appealing competitor, the Ukrainian Vladimir Kuts, who was to assume Zatopek's mantle and win both long-distance track events for the Soviet Union at the Melbourne Games in 1956. Zatopek was at Melbourne to defend his marathon title, but he was hardly in the best shape to tackle it: one of his more outlandish training sessions, which involved running while carrying Dana on his shoulders, had resulted in a bad strain that had only just cleared up in time. He was never seriously in medal contention, but he trotted home in sixth place without seeming unduly bothered, only to break out in smiles and handshakes and hugs of congratulation when he realised that the winner was Alain Mimoun, the old adversary he had beaten in so many championships in the past. He retired a national icon and a natural sporting ambassador for Czechoslovakia. He rose steadily to the rank of colonel in the Czech army, gave unstinting advice during coaching visits abroad, and unostentatiously enjoyed the resulting privileges at home. Until 1968 and the Prague Spring, when he publicly welcomed the shift towards democracy promised by the Dubcek regime, and roundly condemned the Soviet response as troops moved into Prague to re-establish communist control. He was expelled from the Communist party and dismissed from the army. He was consigned to a series of manual jobs for various state departments until, after seven years of this ritual humiliation, he was given a desk at the Ministry of Sport, employing his language skills to monitor and translate sports periodicals from the west. Occasionally he was put on display at official receptions for visiting teams, when he would be seized upon by foreign journalists more eager just to shake his hand than to record the guarded answers he was obliged to give them. And towards the end of the 1980s, with the ice beginning to thaw and Zatopek long retired from the ministry, he would once in a while receive grudging permission to accept an invitation to an athletics event abroad. Invariably he would find himself at the centre of a crowd of foreigners who knew the face only from old newspapers or grainy archive film, but who had fallen under the spell of the legend; they would flock round him in unashamed awe, proffering scraps of paper for his autograph, hardly daring to offer a handshake in case it might be refused. It never was. Zatopek's achievements in athletics are indelible, but bare statistics cannot reflect the genuine affection in which he was held by his fellow competitors, men with whom he chatted and joked as he ran them into the ground, men with whom he would willingly and honestly discuss race tactics even if he were due to run against them the next day, men whose insecurities and disappointments he could sympathise with and understand. Late in 1968 another high-achieving record-breaker, the Australian Ron Clarke, left the Mexico City Olympic Games in deepest gloom: he had been the fastest long-distance runner in the world for a decade, yet in two Olympic Games fate, ill-judgment, altitude, or sheer bad luck had conspired against him, and his career was slipping away without a single gold medal to show for it. On his way home he stopped off in Prague to chat things over with his boyhood idol and long-time friend. As they parted Zatopek gave the Australian a small parcel, and not wishing to embarrass his host, Clarke did not unwrap it until he was on the plane. It was one of Zatopek's Olympic gold medals, a gift from an athlete who had gloriously won four of them to a fellow athlete he just felt deserved one.  Emil Zatopek, athlete, born September 19 1922; died November 21 2000

webTitle: Hussain back in the frame for three-day match

fields.headline: Hussain back in the frame
fields.trailText: Nasser Hussain, whose participation in the final first-class match before the back-to-back second and third Tests had appeared to be out of the question, was included in a squad of 12 yesterday.
fields.body:
Nasser Hussain, whose participation in the final first-class match before the back-to-back second and third Tests had appeared to be out of the question, was included in a squad of 12 yesterday.

The England captain was determined to start this morning in the three-day game against a Pakistan Cricket Board XI provided there was no reaction to his practice session. Also named in the squad was Michael Vaughan, who missed the first Test with a calf injury.

Hussain, hit on the right wrist by Wasim Akram shortly before the end of the Test and already suffering with a chronic back condition that may require cortisone, had seemed certain to miss the game on the Bagh-e-Jinnah, the ground formerly known as the Lahore Gymkhana, and with it much-needed batting practice. But he batted in the nets at the Gaddafi Stadium without too much discomfort.

Should he not play, however, then in the absence of Graham Thorpe, who led the side in the first warm-up match in Rawalpindi, Alec Stewart will captain England. In that case, it was planned that Michael Atherton or Marcus Trescothick would sit out the game. Paul Nixon will keep wicket.

For Vaughan, it is a chance once more to establish his credentials. He would almost certainly have made the Test side in Lahore and the England management want to see not just runs but competitive off-spin from him.

Vaughan underwent light training yesterday, with the England physiotherapist Dean Conway anxious not to rush what he says is an injury with a high risk of recurrence.

The opposition will not now contain the young leg-spinner Danish Kanaria, who was pulled out of the game after an indifferent Test performance from Mushtaq Ahmed.

 Derbyshire have confirmed the signings of the former England spinner Richard Illingworth, released by Worcestershire two months, ago, and the Warwickshire all-rounder Graeme Welch.

 India beat Zimbabwe in the first Test in Delhi by seven wickets. Chasing 190 after dismissing the tourists for 225, they reached their target with 9.3 overs remaining thanks to an unbeaten 110-run fourth-wicket stand between Rahul Dravid (70 not out) and the captain Saurav Ganguly (65 not out). The second and final Test starts in Nagpur on Saturday.

fields.headline: Olympiakos 2 - 2 Liverpool
fields.body:
1 Olympiakos get the game underway. A big test for Liverpool tonight against a team with a formidable home record.
2 Brazilian Giovanni has an early pop toward the Liverpool goal, but it is difficult to tell whether he was actually aiming at the goal or at an imaginary team-mate in acres of space ahead of him.
5 A tame start so far, with the crowd doing a little whistling but nothing to suggest that the ref might be intimidated into a rash of suspicious decisions (ask Gerard Houllier).
10 Traore attempts to break down the left and plays a one-two with Owen before Liverpool win a throw-in.
11 Traore then does a good job of pinning back Amanatidis as the Greeks try to move up their right flank.
12 The first screams of discontent rise above the constant whine of whistling when the ref fails to award a free-kick to the Olympiakos.
14 First shot on target for the home side when Alexandris finds himself in possession on the edge of the area. Seems almost surprised to be in such a fortunate position and instead of executing a neat curling left-foot shot around Westerveld, he opts to curl it straight at him.
17 Olympiakos win a free-kick 25 yeards out... straight at the wall. Djordjevic gets on to the rebound but puts his shot the wrong side of the crossbar.
20 Heskey does well to hold off three players 25 yards out; Liverpool knock it about before Murphy fails to find Heskey running through on the edge of the area.
22 This is pretty dull stuff, it has to be said. It has to be said also that there is still a lot left to play for, but the prospect of 90 minutes of dirge is not good for the soul. As if to underline the point, Olympiakos push up on the right and deliver a cross of Conference quality.
23 Booking Traore. My heart, such excitement.
24 Could things be livening up? Possibly. Olympiakos have another attempt on goal when Giovanni gets up well in the area for a header, but Westerveld is equal to it.
30 Liverpool manage to get up after a protracted spell pinned back in their half. Westerveld finds Heskey with a long kick, Heskey takes it on his chest and falls over before Gerrard steps up for a snap shot from 30 yards that is sound enough to test the grip of Eleftheropoulos in the Olympiakos goal.
36 Liverpool giving away a lot of free-kicks, thanks in large part to some reckless tackling from Traore.
37 Screams from the crowd as Alexandris is called offside just after being knocked to the ground by Westerveld.
38 GOAL Olympiakos 0 - 1 Liverpool The Greeks go to sleep after this disappointment and in the process serve to wake up the rest of us. Heskey heads on a Carragher throw from the edge of the area and Barmby pops it away from close range while . Simple stuff... game on.
41 Liverpool free-kick from 20 yards. Hamann and Murphy eye the chance, but it is Murphy who finds the gap in the wall to force a fine diving save from keeper Eleftheropoulos.
44 Alexandris gets away into space with only two to beat, but Hyypia reads it and stops him short of the area.
45 Olympiakos finish the half with a move that ends in a shocking cross by Djordjevic. Still, at least we had a goal... half-time.

46 Substitution Staunton on for Traore.
48Still no sign that the game is about to spring to life despite the fact that Olympiakos now have to pull out the stops.
50 First corner of the match and it goes Liverpool's way. Staunton takes, Heskey comes flying in at the near post... and heads wide.
52 Liverpool come close to getting a second. Heskey fashions a chance out of nothing when he whips in a cross towards Barmby at the far post. Barmby has to lean back to shoot and is desperately unluck to see his effort rebound off the underside of the crossbar and land the wrong side of the line.
56 Olympiakos are caught short at the back when a misunderstanding between the keeper and one of his defenders requires some elaborate passing before the ball can be cleared.
58 Substitution The power of the crowd suddenly makes itself felt as the Olympiakos coach tries to take off Djordjevic; the crowd scream their disapproval and the coach backs down immediately, deciding instead to pull off Mavrogenidis.
61 Booking Babbel.
63 Olympiakos appear to be waking up a bit and push up on the left. A corner results, but comes to nothing.
65 GOAL Olympiakos 1 - 1 Liverpool Coming to life was obviously an understatement. Giovanni crosses from the right edge of the area and Alexandris scores the equaliser with a spectacular bicycle kick. The crowd goes wild.
66 Substitution Smicer on for Owen.
67 GOAL Olympiakos 1 - 2 Liverpool So much for that. Heskey, as if to underline his already considerable contribution to this match, wins a corner on the left from and Gerrard glances a header to the far post to regain the lead The crowd falls silent.
72 Substitution Georgatos on for Zetterberg.
74 Heskey is pulled down on the right edge of the area for a free-kick. Staunton takes and goes for goal... bam, off the corner of the crossbar and then away for a corner. Barmby takes and Olympiakos scramble it clear.
79 Heskey wins yet another free-kick just over 20 yards out to the left but it comes to nothing.
82 Testing time for Liverpool as Olympiakos win a corner, but Westerveld claims.
83 Another corner for the Greeks but the make a mess of it and let Liverpool charge out on the break. Smicer, one on one, beats Eleftheropoulos but the ball strikes the post. Ow!
85 Thick and fast from Liverpool at the moment as Heskey battles his way through to the area... and shoots wide. Olympiakos supporters are starting to leave the stadium.
87 Staunton on the left plays in Barmby on the edge of the area; he lays it off for Smicer but the shot heads skywards.
90 Olympiakos have been completely outplayed over the last quarter of the match. Three minutes extra to play. Substitution McAllister on for Murphy. And then the nightmare scenario... GOAL Olympiakos 2 - 2 Liverpool A bit of head tennis on the edge of the Liverpool ends with Alexandris getting his second of the night. Full-time. Liverpool will wonder how they did not wrap this up earlier. Olympiakos were finshed and in danger of total collapse when they equalised. The myth of Olympiakos invincibility at home survives.

fields.headline: Siblings inspire youth drug abuse
fields.trailText: Schoolchildren are eight times as likely to use drugs if a brother or sister does. Linda Steele reports.
fields.body:
Schoolchildren are eight times as likely to use drugs if a brother or sister does, according to official figures.

An Office of National Statistics survey of 11 to 15-year-olds has found that siblings are key. Children whose brothers and sisters did not use drugs were less likely to take them. Peer pressure played a much smaller part in encouraging children to experiment.

The survey of 9,000 secondary school children revealed that children who used drugs were far more likely to steal, get into trouble with the police, skip school and be excluded from school.

Children in rural and middle-class areas were more likely to use drugs than those in deprived areas. And pupils who classed themselves as Asian or Asian British were less likely to have taken drugs in the last year than any other ethnic group.

The figures were published in an ONS survey of pupils from 340 schools in England, conducted in the autumn of 1999 and released today.

The preliminary results of the research, which showed that 11% of pupils had used cannabis in the last year, one in 100 had used crack cocaine or cocaine, and one in 200 had used heroin or methadone, were published in May.

The survey, Drug Use, Smoking and Drinking in Young Teenagers in 1999, showed that:
 as many as 39% of children whose brothers and sisters live at home and take drugs took drugs themselves. This compared to 5% whose siblings live at home but do not take drugs and 9% of those who were either only children or whose brothers and sisters had left home;
 only 17% who used drugs said they did so because their friends were doing it. Some 70% said they used drugs because the effects made them feel "high, fantastic, happy or giggly";
 children who used drugs were four times as likely to have stolen something over the past 12 months as those who did not. They were also five times as likely to have been in trouble with the police, skipped school or been excluded from school;
 10% of children in deprived areas took drugs compared with 13% in non-deprived areas, while children who live in the countryside were just as likely to take drugs as those who live in towns and cities;
 only 7% of pupils who described themselves as Asian or Asian British took drugs compared with 12% who described themselves as white, black or black British;

Keith Hellawell, the government's "drugs tsar" welcomed the information. "Children nowadays have to be told of the full dangers of drugs and have the details spelled out so that they clearly understand the dangers," he said. "They are young adults and a policy of advising 'just say no', which has never been our policy, does not recognise the need for the kind of structured anti-drugs education programmes the government has in place."

Among other findings of the survey:

Peer pressure played a much smaller part in encouraging children to experiment. webTitle: Why US missiles could rain on Afghanistan again

fields.headline: Why US missiles could rain on Afghanistan again
fields.standfirst: Outgoing US president Bill Clinton may launch strikes against terrorist targets in Afghanistan in retaliation for the bombing of USS Cole, writes foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall
fields.trailText: Outgoing US president Bill Clinton may launch strikes against terrorist targets in Afghanistan in retaliation for the bombing of USS Cole, writes foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall
fields.body:
The likelihood is growing that the United States will launch military strikes against targets inside Afghanistan, with tacit or overt Russian backing, before President Bill Clinton leaves office on January 20.

The ostensible justification for the attack, if it comes, will be retaliation for the suicide terrorist bombing of the USS Cole in the Yemeni port of Aden last month which killed 17 American sailors.

Although FBI investigators have made slow progress with the Cole inquiry, amid disagreements with Yemeni authorities, Clinton administration officials in Washington now say they have established links between the Aden attack and the 1998 bombing of US embassies in Nairobi, Kenya, and Dar-es-Salaam, Tanzania.

The 1998 attacks, which killed 224 people, were blamed by the US on an Islamic terrorist network run by Osama bin Laden, a millionaire Saudi renegade who has his principal bases and training camps in Afghanistan (where he enjoys the protection of the fundamentalist Taliban regime).

The network of terrorist cells masterminded by Bin Laden, who has pledged himself in particular to driving US forces out of the Gulf, is now the prime suspect in the Cole attack.

Investigators are said to have found similarities between the Aden and Nairobi bombings in respect of the type of explosive used, the detonation device, and the apparent involvement in both incidents of an unnamed, non-Yemeni explosives expert.

The US launched limited cruise missile strikes against Bin Laden's Afghan bases after the east African bombings. But he himself evaded harm or capture. Three of his alleged henchmen are currently in custody and awaiting trial on terrorist conspiracy charges in New York.

William Cohen, the US defence secretary, said during a recent tour of the Gulf that the Bin Laden link was not yet clear cut. But General Henry Shelton, the chairman of the joint chiefs of staff, has warned that renewed US strikes on Afghanistan are an option under active consideration.

Mr Cohen's visit to Saudi Arabia, and that of the US energy secretary, Bill Richardson, was preceded by another terrorist outrage in which a British man, Christopher Rodway, was killed by a car bomb. Another attack on Britons was reported in Riyadh today. The British embassy in Yemen had also been attacked shortly after the Cole was hit.

Similar terrorist assaults - such as those on US military bases in Saudi Arabia in 1995 and 1996, on western tourists in Yemen and Egypt in 1998, and a failed attack on another US warship in the Gulf last winter - are all blamed on Islamic militant groups, some of which, ironically, were originally trained and funded by the US during the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan.

These "Afghan veterans" have now turned their guns on their former sponsor and its allies (such as Britain) and are linked to religious and ethnic wars and insurgencies ranging from Chechnya on Russia's southern flank to Tajikistan and Uzbekistan (north of Afghanistan) to Pakistan, Kashmir, and the Muslim Uighur areas of western China.

This same loose network of Muslim extremists is even said to have been involved in a thwarted attempt to assassinate Russian President Vladimir Putin while he was in Yalta, in the Crimea, last August.

The network has also been linked, for example, to the discovery of a cache of explosives materiel in Birmingham where two suspected Islamic militants were arrested last week under anti-terrorism laws.

But, as the Americans appear to be determining in Aden, the common thread linking all these groups appears to be Bin Laden and Afghanistan.

The US attack, if it goes ahead, is likely to be far more severe than in 1998, possibly involving conventional air power and special forces as well as cruise missiles.

Apart from the lack of "smoking gun" evidence, factors at present constraining the Clinton administration include worries about further exacerbating tensions across the Middle East (in view of the current Palestinian-Israeli conflict) and domestic political uncertainty in the US.

However, one big constraint may be absent this time: Russian reluctance. Prior to Mr Clinton's summit meeting in Moscow last June, Russia and the US issued a joint statement expressing concern over the "growing influence of extremist groups" in the region centred on Afghanistan.

Separately, Russian officials warned that they might launch "preventive" air strikes against terrorist training camps and bases in Afghanistan. For Moscow, the principal concern is militant backing for Chechen separatists. But like India and China, it is also concerned about the broader issues of rising militant Islamic fundamentalism.

Both the US and Russia have since stepped up military and economic assistance and training to the central Asian republics bordering Afghanistan. These countries, which include Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan, fear destabilisation by Islamic militants backed by Bin Laden and the Taliban, and are particularly worried about a possible spring offensive after suffering violent incursions last summer.

The US may use bases in these countries, which are members of Nato's Partnership for Peace programme, to launch attacks. A top US military commander, General Tommy Franks of Central Command, was recently in the region for discussions.

A US attack would serve several purposes beyond revenge for the USS Cole bombing. It would, in theory, discourage the rise of Islamic militancy in central Asia and beyond, and punish the Taliban for its support for terrorism.

US strikes, especially if backed by Russia and other regional players like India, could also be justified as a way of helping to stem the growing trade in raw opium, used to make heroin, of which Afghanistan is the world's biggest producer.

Drug trafficking via Turkey and Russia to western Europe and the US is believed to be funding the terrorists and is, by itself, seen as a major security threat to the West.

Given the psychology of the American presidency, a US attack is more likely to happen while Mr Clinton is still in office. The east African and USS Cole bombings took place on his watch. The responsibility for a response is his. He will not want to leave the problem to his successor, whoever that may be.

If enough solid evidence and a good moment of opportunity can be found, Mr Clinton will certainly act - to salvage not only America's honour but also his own. After all, with enforced retirement beckoning, he has little to lose now.

webTitle: OK! fails to stop Hello! showing Douglas wedding photos

fields.headline: Hello! wins appeal over wedding photos
fields.trailText: Hello! is free to publish wedding snaps of Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta Jones, the Court of Appeal said today. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Celebrity magazine Hello! is free to publish pictures of the wedding of Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta Jones, the Court of Appeal said today.

The ruling has infuriated arch-rival OK! magazine, which yesterday won a temporary injunction banning the publication of the "surreptitious" photos because they had signed an exclusive £1m deal to cover the wedding in New York last Saturday.

After two days of legal wrangling, Justice Brooke said: "The court proposes to allow the appeal and set aside the injunction."

He added that he would give the reasons for the decision in "due course".

The ruling could mark the end of exclusive celebrity spreads for births, weddings and divorces in magazines and newspapers.

The Hollywood couple, who launched the legal action with OK!, had argued that the photos had been taken "surreptitiously and against their wishes".

They said that the wedding was a personal event and Hello! had breached their privacy and their contract with OK!.

Hello! hit the streets on Monday with its own "exclusive" photos snapped by an undercover camera.

OK!, which comes out tomorrow, won a temporary ban on the magazine on Tuesday.

Hello! was facing the prospect of pulping its 750,000 print run, although around 15,000 lucky readers got to see the snaps before copies were whisked off the shelves.

OK! is owned by publishing tycoon Richard Desmond, who yesterday bought the Express newspapers for £125m.

fields.headline: Wales receives 1,850 jobs boost
fields.trailText: The Welsh economy received a boost yesterday with the announcement of 1,850 new jobs, the majority of which will be at a new call centre in Cardiff.
fields.body:
The Welsh economy received a boost yesterday with the announcement of 1,850 new jobs, the majority of which will be at a new call centre in Cardiff.

The news came as the Thomson holiday group confirmed the creation of 1,000 jobs at its new call centre in Scotland, and speculation was increasing that Ford would expand the workforce at its Bridgend engine plant in south Wales.

Conduit, a teleservices company based in Ireland, said it plans to employ about 1,400 people at its call centre in Cardiff. The centre will open in January with a worforce of 450. The remaining 950 positions will be filled over the following 18 months.

The company, which is listed on Frankfurt's Neuer Markt stock exchange, has linked up with Finnish telecommunications operator Sonera to target the UK market for directory inquiry services.

Rhodri Morgan, the Welsh Assembly's first minister, welcomed Conduit's decision.

"This is another outstanding success in the niche market that Wales is developing in the call centre sector," he said. The Welsh Assembly yesterday approved a £6.3m Welsh development agency grant to Maincourse, a development company planning a £35m transformation of the former Dunlop Semtex factory in Brynmawr, Blaenau, Gwent.

Demolition of the dilapidated and asbestos-contaminated factory and the construction of a housing, leisure and commercial development is expected to create at least 450 permanent jobs.

The Welsh development agency's managing director for south-east Wales, Karen Thomas, said: "We and our partners intend that this development will represent the very best in modern, environmentally friendly, urban design.

"We want it to be recognised as a model of best practice in redevelopment."

A Ford board meeting in the US next month is expected to approve the transfer of V6 petrol engine production from a plant in Ohio to the company's Bridgend factory.

The move would not only secure the Welsh plant's future but also create hundreds of new jobs - both at the plant and among suppliers.

webTitle: Loophole which lets lax GPs retire early is closed

fields.headline: Loophole which lets lax GPs retire early is closed
fields.trailText: 5.15pm: A loophole which allowed NHS GPs to retire early in order to dodge investigation of complaints against them by patients has been closed. Patrick Butler reports.
fields.body:
A loophole which allowed NHS GPs to retire early in order to dodge investigation of complaints against them by patients has been closed.

Royal assent was today expected to be given to a bill that gives the health service ombudsman powers to pursue doctors who in the past could "retire" from the NHS to avoid complaints procedures while continuing to practice privately or as a locum.

The law does not cover doctors who practice privately - and consumer lobbyists have urged MPs to back another bill to regulate private GPs to the same standards as those controlling their NHS counterparts.

The law was welcomed by the parliamentary investigator of NHS complaints, health service ombudsman Michael Buckley, who had called for the loophole to be closed in his 1998-99 annual report. Eight examples of GPs retiring to avoid complaints have been reported by the health service ombudsman in the past two years. The ombudsman has the power to refer particularly worrying cases to the doctor's regulatory body the General Medical Council.

The Health Service Commisioners (Amendment) Act 2000 stems from a private member's bill brought in 1999 by Sir Geoffrey Johnson Smith, Conservative MP for Wealden, Kent. The bill was drafted by the Consumers' Association in the wake of a case highlighted in its Which? magazine about a retired headteacher who died of leukaemia. The headteacher's husband attempted to bring a complaint against her GP on the grounds of misdiagnosis but was told that the complaint would fall because the GP had retired.

Emma Harrison, public affairs officer at the Consumers' Association said: "We are delighted that this bill has become law and that patients with grievances will be able to get justice - even if GP's retire. Unfortunately this Act does not apply to private doctors, and our next bill tackles this. We want private doctors to be regulated to the same high standard as their NHS counterparts. After all, patients should have the right of access to a fair system of complaints."

webTitle: BBC and ITV detente over TV debate

fields.headline: BBC and ITV unite in bid for election head-to-head
fields.standfirst:
Nov 21: ITV gets live interview with PM
Nov 21: ' PM won't get questions before show'
fields.trailText:
3.30pm: BBC and ITV have united to try to persuade Tony Blair and William Hague to make history with a US-style live election TV debate, writes Jason Deans
Nov 21: ITV gets live interview with PM
Nov 21: ' PM won't get questions before show'
fields.body:
The BBC and ITV have today made a joint approach to the leaders of the three main political parties to take part in two live TV debates in the run-up to the next general election.

In an unprecedented move, BBC News director Tony Hall and ITV controller of news and current affairs Steve Anderson have both put their signatures to letters sent to Tony Blair, William Hague and Charles Kennedy.

The two broadcasters have joined forces to try to increase the chances of securing the leader debates.

Before the last general election in 1997 the BBC and ITV made separate approaches, allowing then prime minister John Major to prevaricate and play the two off against each other.

Although Mr Major's lack of confidence was seen as the ultimate deal breaker, the divided approach was a contributing factor.

Mr Hall said: "Televised leader debates are a familiar part of the electoral landscape across the democratic world and it's time British voters had the same opportunity to see the politicians in action."

Mr Anderson added: "That is why we are setting aside the usual trench warfare between news broadcasters and uniting behind this important project."

The joint proposal is for BBC1 and ITV each to broadcast one live, 60-minute debate before a studio audience in peak-time in the last two weeks of the election campaign.

David Dimbleby will chair the BBC1 debate, while his brother Jonathan will host the ITV show, which is to be produced by ITN.

Both programmes will follow the same format and focus on three key subjects. The proposal is for the party leaders to make an initial statement and then be quizzed about it by each other, before being allowed a closing comment.

The BBC and ITV are suggesting that Mr Blair, Mr Hague and Mr Kennedy stand side by side in the studio throughout the programme.

The BBC and ITN will make free feeds available to Sky News, BBC News 24, the ITN News Channel and any other UK broadcasters who want it.

fields.headline: Two die despite peace plea
fields.trailText: An Israeli and a Palestinian were killed in clashes today despite a call from United States secretary of state Madeleine Albright for both sides in the Middle East crisis to break the cycle of violence.
fields.body:
An Israeli and a Palestinian were killed in clashes today despite a call from United States secretary of state Madeleine Albright for both sides in the Middle East crisis to break the cycle of violence.

In separate telephone conversations Mrs Albright told Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat and Israeli foreign minister Shlomo Ben-Ami to come to a truce. According to Mr Ben-Ami, the secretary of state said Mr Arafat was ready to resume contact with the Israelis.

"It could certainly be that this is a signal of distress and of a desire to get out of this cycle," Mr Ben-Ami said. "It is our duty to at least permit the Americans to check that matter."

But the fighting continued. In the Gaza Strip Palestinians lobbed a mortar shell into an Israeli-Palestinian liaison office, killing an Israeli officer.

webTitle: Express to publish OK! 'leftovers' of Zeta Jones wedding

fields.headline: Express to publish OK! 'leftovers' of Zeta Jones wedding
fields.trailText: Thursday 5.45pm: The Daily Express is planning a tie-up with OK! magazine on Monday with the publication of "leftovers" from the magazine's coverage of Catherine Zeta Jones' wedding. By Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
The Daily Express is planning a tie-up with OK! magazine on Monday with the publication in the newspaper of "leftovers" from the celebrity magazine's coverage of Catherine Zeta Jones' wedding to Michael Douglas.

The decision to use photos from the £1m exclusive deal three days after OK! hits the streets has surprised newspaper executives used to quick turnarounds on stories.

The situation could change, however, now that the courts have lifted the ban on rival Hello! magazine, which had snatched pictures of the movie stars' wedding.

Hello! is expected to hit back with a tie-in with the Daily Mail, possibly starting tomorrow with exclusive coverage of the Zeta Jones wedding.

OK! boss Richard Desmond told Express editor Rosie Boycott last night he wanted more syngery between the two titles.

OK! will move from its Docklands headquarters to the Express headquarters at Ludgate House and editor Martin Townsend will attend the daily news conference at the Express.

Mr Desmond also wants journalists to be kept abreast of the company's fortunes. At a dinner with editors last night, he said: "I want everyone to know when we are making money, and when we are losing money. I like sharing my problems."

A source close to Mr Desmond said: "He thinks journalists should know what the implications of their work is. He thinks it will motivate them."

However, insiders predict that Ms Boycott will leave the Express within a month.

Although Mr Desmond and his editorial director, Paul Ashford, have publically given Ms Boycott their full backing, she is unlikely to be happy with the Express sharing the same publisher as top-shelf titles such as Nude Wives and Asian Babes.

Martin Clarke, ex-editor of the Scotsman and the Daily Record and ex-editor of the Scottish Daily Mail, is the latest newspaper executive tipped to take over from Ms Boycott.

Other names in the frame include Mirror deputy editor Tina Weaver and News of the World editor Rebekah Wade.

webTitle: View from Zagreb: Power games at the Balkan summit

fields.headline: Power games in the Balkans
fields.standfirst:
The new leadership in Belgrade doesn't mark the end of politicking at the Balkan summit held in Croatia, writes Ian Traynor
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: View from Zagreb: The new leadership in Belgrade doesn't mark the end of politicking at the Balkan summit held in Croatia, writes Ian Traynor.
fields.body:
Summits can damage the health in the Balkans. Last year, when scores of international leaders from Bill Clinton down descended on Sarajevo to launch the so-called stability pact, the traumatic impact was such that city wits became suddenly nostalgic for the besieging Serb gunners who had kept Sarajevo cut off from the world for almost four years.

This week it is the turn of the Croatian capital, Zagreb, to rue the day it bowed to the French and offered to host an unprecedented summit of European Union and Balkan leaders.

To the dismay of Zagreb's million natives, the entire city centre is virtually inaccessible for the benefit of the Eurocrats who have arrived to talk up the ''historic opportunities'' thrown up by the establishing of peace and democracy in most of the Balkan peninsula and what was Yugoslavia.

If the European leaders arrive waving chequebooks and promising to disburse some £3bn over the next five years to stabilise and reconstruct the shattered Balkans, much of that money has been previously earmarked for Kosovo, Bosnia and the rest.

What's new is Serbia. The purpose of the summit has been turned upside down by Belgrade's October revolution. Originally conceived by the French in June to bring together all of former Yugoslavia bar Serbia, to isolate the then regime in Belgrade and to demonstrate to the public and opposition in Serbia the benefits of peace and democracy, Friday's summit instead finds the new transitional Serbia taking centre stage.

President Vojislav Kostunica will be the most closely watched figure at the summit, his every word and nuance examined. Originally Montenegro's President Milo Djukanovic, built up by the west as a pole of opposition to Slobodan Milosevic, was to take centre stage.

Now Mr Djukanovic insists he will be there as a head of state, although that may entail a row with Mr Kostunica who will demand that the Montenegrin leader be a member of the rump Yugoslav delegation comprising Serbia and Montenegro.

Kosovo, too, will be under-represented, if represented at all, a fact which brought a bitter attack on the summit preparations from Veton Surroi, the liberal Kosovo Albanian leader.

The snubs to Kosovo and Montenegro are part and parcel of the preferential treatment being meted out to the Serbs in deference to their sensitivities. Don't rock Kostunica's boat, says the west, at least not until Serbia's election on December 23 which, it is keenly hoped, could clear out the remainder of the Milosevic regime.

The trouble with this approach is that it alienates every other actor in the region. If the west, the Slovenes, the Croats, the Bosnians and the Albanians all see the Serbs as the core problem in the four wars of the past decade, the non-Serbs are increasingly exasperated at the privileges available to the Serbs and denied to them by the ''international community".

The two sorest points outstanding in the former Yugoslavia are Kosovo's uncertain and unresolved status, and whether a new rump Yugoslav constitutional dispensation can satisfy Montenegro and head off its split with Serbia.

But both potentially explosive issues are being marginalised at the summit in deference to Mr Kostunica and the Serbs. The Croats and the Bosnians are looking for some signal of apology and remorse from Mr Kostunica on behalf of the Serbs for the wars of 1991-95. But when pressed on the issue, the Serb leader talks of 1941-45 and Croatian fascists.

There will be no "unilateral statements and imposed apologies", Mr Kostunica told Serbian television. "The things that have happened in the past 10 years cannot be explained only by these 10 years. There is a prior history, there is 1941.''

Since the Croatian nationalist strongman Franjo Tudjman died last year, Zagreb has been under intense international pressure to cooperate with the war crimes tribunal in The Hague and the new Croatian president, Stipe Mesic, has been unequivocal in denouncing alleged war criminals, risking fierce opposition at home.

But he is peeved at the double standards being applied to the Serbs whose access to aid and funds is not yet at least being tied to willingness to turn over indicted war criminals.

''Yugoslavia [Serbia] must go through a catharsis,'' said Mr Mesic this week.

''It must give up Milosevic's imperialistic policy which claimed that all Serbs must live in one state, therefore, they're allowed to seize other people's territories We're more interested in deeds than words For us it is of primary interest that Yugoslavia prosecute all those who committed war crimes and make it clear...it will extradite those who carried out ethnic cleansing and genocide.''

That a president from Belgrade is in Zagreb at all is a breakthrough inconceivable only a few months ago and a measure of the speed with which things are now changing for the better across the region.

But wariness and suspicion are rife on the fringes of the Zagreb summit. The Croats, the Bosnians and the Albanians are looking for a magnanimous gesture from Mr Kostunica. If the west is happy to give the Serb president the benefit of the doubt, his neighbours in former Yugoslavia have yet to be persuaded to do the same.
