fields.headline: English as an Asian language
fields.standfirst: It is time for East and Southeast Asia to learn its own version of English,  argues Andy Kirkpatrick
fields.trailText: It is impossible to identify and isolate an "English" culture that is common to all speakers of English. The cultures represented by Nigerian, Singaporean, Indian, Scottish, Filipino or Australian Aboriginal English are all very different. So, while a language must be linked to a culture, a language is not inextricably tied to one specific culture. Specific cultural identities can be represented by new varieties of English.
fields.body:
It is impossible to identify and isolate an "English" culture that is common to all speakers of English. The cultures represented by Nigerian, Singaporean, Indian, Scottish, Filipino or Australian Aboriginal English are all very different. So, while a language must be linked to a culture, a language is not inextricably tied to one specific culture. Specific cultural identities can be represented by new varieties of English.

In East and Southeast Asia English plays a major role in the region as a lingua franca of the political elite and the Association of Southast Asian Nations. It is also used as a lingua franca between professionals and the business community.

But what variety of English will serve as the region's lingua franca? I suggest that a variety which reflects local cultural conventions and pragmatic norms is developing to serve this role. I further suggest that it is this regional variety that will be taught in schools, rather than an external "native speaker" variety.

The vast majority of people who are learning English are doing so to be able to use this lingua franca. They are not learning English with the express purpose of communicating with native speakers of English. English is being used by non-native speakers with other non-native speakers. The English that they use need not therefore reflect any "Anglo" cultural values. This emerging role of English was identified by Gordon Wu of Hong Kong's Hopewell Holdings, who told the Far Eastern Economic Review: "English is no longer some colonial language. It is the means [by which] we in Asia communicate with the world and one another."

So regional users of English who are learning English in order to speak to Thais, Koreans, Vietnamese or Japanese do not need teaching materials that promote or discuss "Anglo" cultures. What they need are materials that provide some knowledge of the culture of the people they are dealing with. They also need to be aware of their own cultural norms. The cultural values and daily lives of the people in the region who are using English as a regional lingua franca become more important than the cultural values associated with native speakers.

This has important implications for English language teaching in the region's schools. It is a regional variety of English, not an external model, that needs to be promoted, because it is a regional variety of English that people in the region will want to use. People will be able to maintain their identity while speaking their variety of English. As Tommy Koh, a senior minister in the Singapore government, put it recently, "When I speak English I want the world to know I'm a Singaporean."

The curriculum of a new variety of English should reflect the lives, cultures and values of the learners. Speakers of this new variety will want to preserve their identity by reflecting that identity in the local variety of English they use.

English language teaching materials are needed that promote the local or regional variety and represent the cultures of the speakers of these newly developing varieties. These materials also need to contrast regional cultures, so making the English language curriculum more a curriculum of regional cultures.

This will not only liberate generations of Asian children who have had to learn how to ask what time the next train to Liverpool Street leaves, but will also alter the nature of what represents an authentic text. Japan's current English teaching goals are that learners should become American English speakers. This is unrealistic and damaging to the cause of ELT. Students are fearful of speaking, because they falsely consider themselves to be poor speakers unless they sound like Americans. However, if students were given a regional variety of English to learn, educated speakers of the regional variety could provide the models. Suitably qualified and trained speakers of the regional variety could be the teachers. External models could, of course, be introduced into the classroom, but as examples of external models, not as the model that the learners are expected to acquire.

More research into the development of varieties of English is urgently needed. In particular we need to know what cultural and discourse conventions are being reflected in these new varieties. For example, are compliments being given and received, or requests made, following local cultural values, or following "Anglo" values? Are topics in conversation being broached directly or indirectly? The worldwide domination of an "Anglo" variety of English is not inevitable.

A regional variety of English can reflect local or regional cultures. Governments need not fear that the learning of English will necessarily imbue the learners with inappropriate cultural values or ways of thinking. The best option for regional governments is to promote local varieties of English. Instead of spending large sums of money on importing native-speaking teachers and externally developed materials, funding should be set aside for the professional development of local teachers and for the development of developing regionally appropriate ELT curricula.

Andy Kirkpatrick is research professor at the School of Languages and Intercultural Education, Curtin University of Technology, Perth, Australia, and coordinator of the fifth English in Southeast Asia Conference from December 6-8, 2000.

fields.headline: Highly qualified, multilingual and loyal
fields.standfirst: What the latest Guardian Weekly readers' survey reveals about you
fields.trailText: More than 3,000 readers took the trouble to complete the double-page survey that appeared in the Guardian Weekly a couple of months ago. It provides a fascinating snapshot of who you are and what you think about the paper.
fields.body:
More than 3,000 readers took the trouble to complete the double-page survey that appeared in the Guardian Weekly a couple of months ago. It provides a fascinating snapshot of who you are and what you think about the paper.

From our subscription database we know that we have readers in more than 100 countries around the world. The latest survey reveals that most of you are either nationals or naturalised citizens in the country where you live, while 31% of you describe yourselves as British expatriates. Including our growing UK readership, British nationals account for 38% of our sample.

You are a very well educated bunch - 48% of you have a degree, while 41% hold a doctorate, higher degree or MBA - with an excellent command of languages. Three out of four respondents say they speak at least one language other than their mother tongue, and 43% claim to speak two. French is the most popular second language among readers, followed by English, German, Spanish and Italian.

Although past surveys have always shown that the Weekly is read more by men than women, this survey suggests that the balance is shifting towards equality between the sexes.

Teaching is the most common profession among the 69% of readers who are in the workforce, followed by professionals - doctors, scientists, public servants and charity/aid workers. Those involved in business are also well represented. Retirees as a group account for 24% of readers.

Teachers of English as a Foreign Language make up 15% of readers who work, thanks no doubt to our monthly Learning English supplement, and teachers in higher education comprise another 15%.

The survey also reveals how loyal you are: 43% of you have been reading the Weekly for more than 10 years, and a further 20% for longer than five years. And nearly nine out of 10 subscribers say they are "very likely" to renew their subscriptions. Only 2% of respondents think the Weekly is poor value for money.

All of this is enormously gratifying to the small team that produces the paper each week. But we are not complacent, and remain acutely aware that there are areas where we can improve.

According to the survey, you read the Weekly partly to catch up with what's been happening in the world and partly for our in-depth analysis of events. You enjoy the paper's informative nature, its unbiased view as well as the quality of its writing.

News - UK, but especially international - and comment and analysis are the pages you usually turn to when you get your Weekly. Book reviews are also important, and you appreciate the pages we bring you each week from Le Monde and the Washington Post.

Indeed, such is your hunger for high-quality information about the world that the only serious criticism (19% of) you make is that we should improve our international news coverage. Your view has been noted.

One area where readers can expect improvements in the next year is in our expanding use of the internet and email to deliver you news about the world and put you in touch with the jobs and courses we advertise.

The internet is clearly an important tool in most readers' lives: 84% of respondents have access to the internet, of whom 64% use it on a daily basis, mainly for email or research, and 36% of readers have used the internet to buy goods or services.

Although we always look for ways to improve the speed of delivery of the paper each week, the erratic nature of postal services is beyond our control. Any delay irks me as an editor and a journalist, and we are currently exploring electronic means of sending the paper to those able to download files from the internet. This method of delivery, though it may never replace the "feel" of a printed newspaper, is likely to become more and more acceptable as file compression improves and bandwidth expands.

Next year we also aim to improve our email service, available free to subscribers, which 10,000 of you currently receive, so that articles can be accessed online. This in turn will generate an online archive for those keen to carry out research.

What emerges most strongly from this survey, as those of the past, is how much you trust us to keep you informed about world events in unbiased way. Thank you for your continuing support.

fields.headline: First princess
fields.standfirst: American Queen: The Life of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis by Sarah Bradford, Viking 600pp
fields.trailText: Long before Diana Spencer, Jacqueline Kennedy was the world's ultimate fantasy princess. Her endlessly photographed and pored-over face was a screen onto which her emotionally hungry admirers projected their dreams of flawless refinement. Until she broke her own extraordinary spell by leaving the United States and marrying Aristotle Onassis in 1968 she possessed, in the minds of most of the American people, a kind of stylistic perfect pitch.
fields.body:
Long before Diana Spencer, Jacqueline Kennedy was the world's ultimate fantasy princess. Her endlessly photographed and pored-over face was a screen onto which her emotionally hungry admirers projected their dreams of flawless refinement. Until she broke her own extraordinary spell by leaving the United States and marrying Aristotle Onassis in 1968 she possessed, in the minds of most of the American people, a kind of stylistic perfect pitch.

A cool-headed socialite with aristocratic pretension, she began as an ornament to her millionaire husband's presidency, and ended by redefining it. Her elegantly petite figure and startled gazelle eyes, her familiarity with France, the 18th century and the finer points of dressage, lent a keynote of civility to the image of the Kennedy White House that the young president's freewheeling, technocratic glamour could not have provided alone. Then, in the traumatic days after his assassination, by brilliantly echoing what had been said and done after Lincoln was killed 100 years earlier, she raised him in death to a pinnacle of nobility that he could almost certainly never have attained in life.

The elaborate state funeral that she helped to plan, the solemn obsequies at Arlington, the eternal flame poignantly flickering in the freezing November twilight: these were her final, canonising gift to the husband who, though he had often betrayed and humiliated her sexually, had always hypnotised her imagination. Through a flawless sense of the dramatic fitness of things, and by the moving, healing stoicism of her publicly borne grief, she subtly magnified the nation's sense of the scale of the loss, and therefore of Kennedy's political achievement.

Sarah Bradford is right to spend two-thirds of her quiet, lucid biography on the years before the assassination. Between them the Kennedys altered the tone of the presidency. Temperamentally they had much in common, and a shared "snobbery of style" united them, more enduringly than sex. Both had wanted to be writ ers, and both possessed qualities of coolness and detachment, of intellectual reserve and ironic cruelty rare in the folksy, glad-handing, philistine arena of American political life.

For well over a century the White House had been looking west. Increasingly it thought fit to identify itself with the down-home Mark Twain, L Frank Baum aspect of the national character. The Kennedy innovation was to restore to the presidency some of its old east-coast elegance, to evoke, in modern guises, the spirit of Jefferson, Alexander Hamilton and the Founding Fathers.

It's easy now to be satirical about the Kennedy White House - those tales of naked girls scattering into the undergrowth like cats whenever Jackie came home unexpectedly still amuse - but one of the strengths of Bradford's book is that she does not underestimate its genuine, if mild enlightenment. In a dangerous age it lacked cheap fanaticism.

The tone JFK created set the moral agenda for the rest of the 60s. His idea of the presidency was aspirational and literary, drawn from the 18th-century English Whigs. His tightly honed but grandiloquent rhetoric rang like gold on marble, even when it was covering gross political ineptitude. At his side in public Jackie's air of sophistication and chic cultural warmth complemented it perfectly. In private she could be softly malicious, sceptical of those who jostled for influence, scurrilously funny, and full of the entertaining intolerance of those who are young, rich, beautiful and (as they think) impregnable.

Widowhood and the relationship with Onassis were to prove her mistaken. She lived on, famous but not especially admired, sad but no longer tragic, an icon of stylish jet-set reticence, a living image of tasteful conspicuous consumption, regretted most because she had proved in the end to be more psychologically ordinary than history had hoped.

Outwardly, she dwindled the moment she left America, dwarfed by the shadow of a legend that she had outgrown, fulfilling Charles de Gaulle's cynical prediction that she would "end up on some millionaire's yacht". Sadly, the second half of her life - much of it spent on beaches or in villas or palatial apartments, after the manner of the idle European super-rich - is little more than a transmutation of the theatrical pure gold of her historically approved widowhood into the base metal of mildly despised celebrity. Ultimately, like most iconic figures, she remains eerily featherweight, more potent as an image than as a rounded or recognisable personality, the reality of her life rendered insubstantial by the public self that replaced it.

It seems fruitless now to survey the casual detritus of her life and pronounce her vain, vapid or self-seeking; to call into question her ersatz-aristocratic good taste; or to accuse her of being, at heart, small-minded and avaricious. There's a morally tough common sense in such criticisms that the immaculate self-absorption of her public persona was always designed to elude or frustrate. Her virtues and their mirroring vices belong less to history than to the world of Scott Fitzgerald, and, like so many of Fitzgerald's haunting and ambivalent characters, she was deliberately arrested and incomplete. She lived within the poetic fiction of her own impossible sensitivity, and was eventually doomed by it.

In any case, after the husky-sweet ingénue of the Kennedy years the Mediterranean-island Jackie - dark, lustful, greedy, perverse - should come as a relief. It's good to see her turning from Audrey Hepburn into Sophia Loren, becoming candidly flesh-driven and obsessively materialistic, as if her hormones were in revolt against the glacial, photogenic dignity in which she had been imprisoned for so long. She was surely never meant to be either a chaste or a particularly serious person. The small liaison with Bobby Kennedy (if it happened, which Bradford more or less accepts it did) makes fine dramatic sense.

Nevertheless once the layers of scandal and speculation are stripped away, we are left with certain observable, significant actions, and these mostly do her credit. She gave much more to JFK than he gave to her, and in public she neither betrayed him nor criticised him. When the nation needed her to act like an old Roman, and ceremonialise her private grief, she did so sparely and magnificently. She cared for and protected her children, surrounding them with a cocoon of privacy from which they clearly benefited. The rest is of little consequence.

webTitle: Clinton leaves his mark on Vietnam

fields.headline: Clinton leaves his mark on Vietnam
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton ended his three days in Vietnam with the tide of popular support for his visit still apparently surging. But the enthusiasm masked dangerous undercurrents, which suggested that his historic trip had been less than a total triumph.
fields.byline: By Matthew Engel in Ho Chi Minh City
fields.body:
Bill Clinton ended his three days in Vietnam with the tide of popular support for his visit still apparently surging. But the enthusiasm masked dangerous undercurrents, which suggested that his historic trip had been less than a total triumph.

President Clinton spent last Sunday in Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, once the capital of South Vietnam and now the country's business hub. Had the security men allowed it, he would have been mobbed once more by delighted crowds.

But, as Air Force One took off for Washington, the response of his official hosts was somewhat colder.

Local television did not show the delighted crowds in the streets. And Mr Clinton's earlier calls for greater democracy have left some bruises on Vietnam's Communist leaders. Le Kha Phieu, the party secretary general, who is regarded as the most powerful figure in the country, resurrected the word "imperialists" to describe the Americans.

He is reported to have told the United States president: "We respect other nations' way of life and political systems. We also demand that other nations respect our country's political system and choices." Mr Clinton called their discussion "a nice little debate".

He left Vietnam heading joltingly towards economic, if not political, liberalisation. But the tone adopted by his hosts suggests that the process is not much helped by US hectoring.

"There is no question there is still a different vision of economics at the highest level of government," Mr Clinton's chief economic adviser, Gene Sperling, said.

Several smaller incidents suggest that the Americans are as indelicate about Vietnamese sensibilities as they were in the old days.

Mr Clinton was horribly late for a night at the Hanoi opera house, keeping everyone waiting. The tableau last Saturday night when he solemnly presided over the return of some bone shards wrapped in the Stars and Stripes seemed merely to emphasise the difference in weight accorded to the 58,000 American war dead compared with the millions of dead Vietnamese.

And there was a little argument between two security men about some detail of crowd positioning that seemed to sum up everything. It ended with an American shrug. "It's your country," the American said to the Vietnamese official, before adding: "But you're wrong." That is the US view of Vietnam in a nutshell.

There was no denying the welcome the US president received. Thousands gathered just to catch a glimpse of his limo as he drove round at the start of his official visit to Vietnam. He shook hands with all-comers while visiting the Temple of Literature (930 years old) and a Hanoi cappuccino cafe called Know One Teach One.

Old Hanoi hands said nothing had been seen on this scale since Fidel Castro hit town in the 1970s. But the Clinton fans belonged almost wholly to the generation born after what the Vietnamese call "the American war" ended in 1975. That's the majority of the population.

Many of the older generation in the south died; many have emigrated; the rest keep their heads below the parapet. But the entrepreneurial spirit remains strong here, and the president devoted most of his last day to economic themes.

He made his setpiece appearance far from the city centre, at the new freight terminal as the guest of the US shipping company APL: American President Lines. This was the new Vietnam that the White House wants to foster.

On a stifling day, almost all of them sat in the open air wearing uniform white shirts and APL baseball caps. It could have been a Japanese sales conference, the sort of gig Mr Clinton might have to play if nothing better comes up after he loses his current job.

It was certainly an occasion that made Le Kha Phieu's earlier protestations of continuing socialist purity hard to believe. The president noted that Vietnam's exports had increased sixfold in a decade. "You will grow even more as your economy becomes more open and the rule of law develops."

He also praised the high literacy rate. "Imagine how much more you will achieve," he went on, "as even more young people gain more freedom to shape the decisions that affect their lives."

Mr Clinton insisted: "The years of animosity are past. We have a stake in your future and we wish to be your partners."

But that partnership may be a bad-tempered one as long as the two political cultures remain so distinct. In a country of delicate sensibilities, the Americans still insist on marching in with heavy tread.

webTitle: Mounting pressure on Scots to provide free personal care

fields.headline: Mounting pressure on Scots to provide free personal care
fields.trailText: 4.45pm: Scotland's first minister Henry McLeish is facing mounting pressure to implement in full the royal commission report on long-term care which called for personal care to be provided free. David Mitchell reports.
fields.body:
Scotland's first minister Henry McLeish is facing mounting pressure to go it alone and implement in full the royal commission's report on long-term care after a leaked Holyrood committee report called for all personal care to be provided free.

A lengthy inquiry by the Scottish parliament's health and community care committee, leaked to the BBC's Holyrood programme, has concluded that personal care should be provided on the basis of assessed need and there should be an "unambiguous commitment" to increased funding, estimated at around £110m a year.

The UK government has decided to implement the report in part in England. It will introduce free nursing but not free personal care.

With Scottish opposition parties united in calling for the report to be implemented in full, the committee's findings due next week are bound to add to the pressure on McLeish as he completes his wide-ranging review of Scottish executive policy at the end of the year.

The report of the commission, which was chaired by Sir Stewart Sutherland, was singled out by McLeish when he announced the review shortly after his election. In a debate earlier this month, he said: "I was listening to what people in Scotland were saying about the Sutherland report and about care for our older people. I have gone a significant way along the road in saying that this is an issue of major importance to Scotland."

Last month, Scottish health minister Susan Deacon unveiled a £100m care package in response to the report, including free nursing care for all, extended home care for an extra 1,000 elderly people and free home care for up to four weeks after leaving hospital. But she stopped short of introducing free personal care, claiming it would only benefit the 7,000 or so Scots in residential care who are self-funding.

This was widely interpreted as the result of interference by Downing Street, which feared the introduction of a two-tier system of charging in Britain would put intolerable pressure on Westminster to follow suit.

According to Help the Aged, McLeish's review could provide a fresh opportunity to implement the Sutherland report in full. "Charges are seen by most of the population as a tax on thrift - if you are careful and put a bit by it doesn't do you any good. The notion of wealth tumbling down the generations comes to an abrupt halt when you need residential care," said Scottish officer Liz Duncan.

Help the Aged claims more money needs to be put into the system, ring-fenced and paid for by higher national insurance, and is distinctly unmoved about the fallout for the rest of the UK. "We are well aware of the implications, not least of which is a two-tier system, but it may put pressure on Westminster to review it again," said Duncan.

Directors of social work say the Scottish executive's response was a balanced one and are concerned that the debate is being dominated by free personal care. "Attention is being paid to free personal care to the exclusion of other areas which are even more important, including levels of service and the support available to carers," said Andrew Reid, secretary of the Association of Directors of Social Work (ADSW).

ADSW would also like to see a substantial increase in funding, but it wants the cash spent on providing more services for all older people. "If you spend money on free, rather than extra services, you are benefiting a few better-off people and choosing not to develop services for everyone. It is about inheritance and let's not pretend it is something different," said Reid.

The Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (Cosla), which backed the royal commission's findings, says full implementation is fine in principle but questions where the money will come from.

"The government spending review gives local authorities more money next year but it is still not enough. In community care particularly, the more you give the more demand it creates," said Cosla's head of policy development, David Henderson. "We are concerned that calling for this might mean a cut in education funding but if new money is going into community care we would welcome that."

Mary Marshall, director of the dementia services development centre at Stirling University and a member of the royal commission, is optimistic about the outcome of the McLeish review.

"Whether Henry McLeish is able to deliver it, I don't know," she said. "Politically, there might be constraints but practically it is not such a big deal as there are such disparate policies on charging anyway. It will have to happen some time - the present situation cannot be sustained. It is just a question of when and how."

webTitle: Hands up anyone who fancies playing a game of beach volleyball on Tiananmen Square

fields.headline: Hands up anyone who fancies playing a game of beach volleyball on Tiananmen Square
fields.standfirst:
Chinese hope to bury past in Olympic sand

Chinese hope to bury past in Olympic sand
Special report: Sydney 2000
fields.trailText: It is a question that even Judith Keppel, the Who Wants to be a Millionaire jackpot winner, would have trouble with.   What do Bondi Beach, Australia's surf capital, and Tiananmen Square, the scene in Beijing of the 1989 massacre of pro-democracy demonstrators, have in common?
fields.body:
It is a question that even Judith Keppel, the Who Wants to be a Millionaire jackpot winner, would have trouble with. What do Bondi Beach, Australia's surf capital, and Tiananmen Square, the scene in Beijing of the 1989 massacre of pro-democracy demonstrators, have in common?

The rather unlikely sounding answer, if China gets its way and Beijing is awarded the 2008 Olympic Games, is beach volleyball.

Despite being more than 100 miles from the coast, Olympic officials - a group never too concerned about placing ethics above financial opportunity - are said to believe the vast square would make a grand backdrop for television coverage of scantily clad beach volleyball players.

The idea of the using the square as a beach volleyball venue was born during an inspection tour by officials, according to the China Daily. Tiananmen Square was suggested after Beijing's rival Olympic aspirant, Paris, promised to stage the competition in front of the Eiffel Tower.

"It will be good for the sport if the competitions are held in the square," said Gao Shenyang, a Chinese Volleyball Association official.

How the image of the sport, already under fire for a dress code which insists female competitors must reveal as much flesh as possible, will be enhanced by being played in a venue synonymous with brutal repression is unclear.

But no doubt the embalmed body of Mao Zedong will be spinning in its mausoleum - alongside the square - at the thought of the tight fitting outfits on display. Beach volleyball and the triathlon, pencilled in to finish under Mao's portrait at the north end of the square, are probably not what he had in mind when he devised the cultural revolution.

Human rights groups estimate that hundreds of unarmed civilians were killed when when the army opened fire on pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing. Most were killed by random gunfire. Some were shot in the back.

If the Olympics are awarded to Beijing, one thing is for sure. Kate Adie, whose harrowing reports from Tiananmen Square gripped the nation, will not be doing the BBC commentary.

What do Bondi Beach, Australia's surf capital, and Tiananmen Square, the scene in Beijing of the 1989 massacre of pro-democracy demonstrators, have in common? The rather unlikely sounding answer, if China gets its way and Beijing is awarded the 2008 Olympic Games, is beach volleyball. Despite being more than 100 miles from the coast, Olympic officials - a group never too concerned about placing ethics above financial opportunity - are said to believe the vast square would make a grand backdrop for television coverage of scantily clad beach volleyball players. The idea of the using the square as a beach volleyball venue was born during an inspection tour by officials, according to the China Daily. Tiananmen Square was suggested after Beijing's rival Olympic aspirant, Paris, promised to stage the competition in front of the Eiffel Tower. "It will be good for the sport if the competitions are held in the square," said Gao Shenyang, a Chinese Volleyball Association official. How the image of the sport, already under fire for a dress code which insists female competitors must reveal as much flesh as possible, will be enhanced by being played in a venue synonymous with brutal repression is unclear. But no doubt the embalmed body of Mao Zedong will be spinning in its mausoleum - alongside the square - at the thought of the tight fitting outfits on display. Beach volleyball and the triathlon, pencilled in to finish under Mao's portrait at the north end of the square, are probably not what he had in mind when he devised the cultural revolution. Human rights groups estimate that hundreds of unarmed civilians were killed when when the army opened fire on pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing. Most were killed by random gunfire. Some were shot in the back. If the Olympics are awarded to Beijing, one thing is for sure. Kate Adie, whose harrowing reports from Tiananmen Square gripped the nation, will not be doing the BBC commentary.

webTitle: Gore goes to court to force recount

fields.headline: Gore goes to court to force recount
fields.standfirst: Special report: US election race
fields.trailText: Election 2000 stretched into the Thanksgiving holiday today without a president-elect as the battle between George W Bush and Al Gore over Florida's crucial electoral votes finally reached the US supreme court.
fields.body:
Election 2000 stretched into the Thanksgiving holiday today without a president-elect as the battle between George W Bush and Al Gore over Florida's crucial electoral votes finally reached the US supreme court.

The laborious hand recount resumed in Broward County, as the Gore campaign asked the Florida Supreme Court to order Miami-Dade officials to resume and complete a full handcount or at least the 10,000 'undervotes' - those with possible indented chads that machines didn't read the first time.

"We believe the Supreme Court didn't want its deadline used as an excuse not to count the vote," Gore spokesman Doug Hattaway said.

And ,citing the risk of a constitutional crisis, Mr Bush's lawyers had last night asked the high court justices to block a decision by the Florida supreme court to allow hand counts in three Democratic-leaning Florida counties.

The appeal said that, without a decision by the supreme court before 18 December when each state's electors cast the final vote on who next will occupy the White House, "the consequences may well include the ascension of a president of questionable legitimacy, or a constitutional crisis."

The seemingly never-ending presidential race remains unpredictable. Mr Bush's spokeswoman, Karen Hughes, said: "I heard someone compare it to a marathon. You think there's a finish line and as you cross it someone says, 'Oh, by the way, it's not over."'

While most Americans were feasting on turkey - the Thanksgiving holidayÕs traditional meal - Broward County election officials were instead tackling the contentious paper ballot election chads.

The officials gave up their holiday to continue counting ballots before the Sunday deadline set by the Florida supreme court.

Mr Gore and Mr Bush each planned a Thanksgiving dinner with their families, in Washington and Texas, respectively.

Mr Bush holds a 930-vote lead in Florida, not counting the results of manual recounts initiated at Gore's behest in the three counties, where 1.7m of the state's 6m ballots were cast.

Election workers in Palm Beach County took the holiday off and were to resume their count Friday. A Palm Beach County judge said officials must consider "dimpled chad" punch card ballots - those that show an indentation but no perforation.

However, Judge Jorge Labarga said elections officials can reject the questionable ballots if the voters' intent can't be determined.

The elections board chief, Charles Burton, said both sides would be able to make their cases tomorrow but on first glance he didn't think the ruling would change the way his board has judged ballots. Mr Gore wants the county to loosen its standards.

Democrats planned an appeal to the Florida supreme court to force Miami-Dade County to resume counting after a three-judge lower court panel turned them down.

The county's election board abruptly halted the count yesterday, saying there was no way it could be completed by Sunday at 5pm (2200 GMT), the deadline set by the state supreme court.

Away from the courts and counting rooms, the Republican vice presidential candidate, Dick Cheney, was in a Washington hospital recovering from a "a very slight heart attack" - his fourth. He underwent surgery yesterday to implant an artery-clearing device.

Mr Cheney, 59, said on CNN's "Larry King Live" program that he hoped to be discharged from the hospital in "a day or two". He joked: "I can tell you they didn't find any pregnant chads."

Mr Bush also filed suit in a Florida court asking 13 counties with heavy military populations to count overseas ballots. Hundreds of ballots, many from military outposts, were rejected last week when Democratic lawyers urged country boards to scrutinise them.

Both sides believe Mr Bush lost more votes than Mr Gore in the rejected ballots.

The Florida supreme court's decision on Tuesday night directing the Florida secretary of state, Katherine Harris, to include the results of the hand recounts in the state's certified vote totals has triggered Republican lawmakers in both Tallahassee and Washington threatening challenges to Mr Gore electors.

Mr Gore now has 267 electors pledged to him, Bush 246. Florida's 25 electors would give either the 270 majority needed to be declared the winner.

The US presidency is determined not by the nationwide popular vote, which Mr Gore won, but by the vote of the electoral college, a panel which is to meet December 18.

Each state - along with the district of Washington DC - sends three delegates plus an additional number based on its population.

In Florida and in all but two of the remaining US states, all of the delegates are generally committed to choosing the candidate who won the winner-take-all statewide vote.

Republicans, who hold majorities in both houses of Florida's legislature as well as in Congress, talked of convening to overturn the effect of a Florida court decision they noted was made by seven judges appointed by Democratic governors.

Tom Feeney, Florida's new House speaker, was ready to "ensure an electoral college representation for Florida" - though he also suggested last night that everyone "relax, take a deep breath for at least 24 hours." In Washington, House majority leader Dick Armey, of Texas, said Republicans in Congress were prepared to disqualify Florida's electors if the outcome of Florida's recount does not appear to be legitimate.

webTitle: Global warming: could there be a deal?

fields.headline: Global warming: could there be a deal?
fields.standfirst:
Special report: global warming
Envoy gets cake in face
fields.trailText: There are signs that ministers are inching towards agreement at the United Nations climate change conference in the Hague where delegates from more than 180 countries are meeting to decide the rules for achieving a reduction of world wide emissions of heat trapping gases blamed for global warming.
fields.body:
There are signs that ministers are inching towards agreement at the United Nations climate change conference in the Hague where delegates from more than 180 countries are meeting to decide the rules for achieving a reduction of world wide emissions of heat trapping gases blamed for global warming.

It has been reported that the deadlock after a week-and-a-half of talks is set to be broken as the first signs of compromise emerged. The key breakthrough is that more money may be on the table from industrialised countries to help the developing world cope with climate change and use cleaner technology.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, said the next 48 hours were "critical" to sorting out the issue of greenhouse gas emissions.

Mr Prescott called for "one last push". He said: "There are signs of agreement. I want that to turn in to an avalanche of support."

The conference hopes to reach consensus by the weekend on the degree to which countries should be able to use so called "flexible mechanisms" to meet emissions reduction targets they committed to three years ago in Kyoto, Japan, without actually scaling back the burning of fossil-fuels in power plants, factories and cars.

The conference's president, Dutch environment minister, Jan Pronk, said last night: "There is movement. It is not big, but moves are being made. We are not just seeing sheer repetitions of earlier positions."

But he added that he might submit his own proposal for discussion today "if no agreement is reached, or if only a partial agreement is reached".

Sticking points include the US-sponsored plan, backed also by Canada, Japan and Australia, that would allow countries to satisfy part of their emissions targets by gaining credits for the amount of carbon dioxide that trees and farmland take out of the air. Such lands are being referred to as "carbon sinks."

Some delegations do not think countries should be allowed to count forests and farmland that already exists, because such an inclusion would not constitute an active effort. They want credits only for new changes.

Others believe the US plan, which proposes credits for more than a third of the carbon dioxide absorbed by vegetation, is too generous. The intention is to use such alternatives as a supplement to actual reductions from switching to cleaner and more efficient fuels, they argue.

Mr Prescott acknowledged that the US, which is resisting calls from European states to cut its production of greenhouse gases, held the key to reaching agreement.

However, speaking on BBC Radio 4's Today programme, he said: "It is not only America. I do not think (the French) president Chirac did us any favours trying to identify villains." He added that America and other countries could not be allowed to argue for higher emissions quotas on the grounds that they had more forests - which "soak up" the pollutants blamed for climate change.

The idea of developed countries being able to gain credit for creating "sinks" in the developing world is also contentious.

Carbon dioxide is one of the major greenhouse gases, which scientists say are gradually accumulating in excessive amounts in the atmosphere, forcing the planet to heat up. The warming is already starting to affect the climate, melting glaciers, pushing up sea levels and causing recent flooding and severe storms, scientists say.

Elsewhere, the conference has been marked by apparently spontaneous actions by demonstrators. The talks were disrupted yesterday by protesters who burst into a negotiating room and staged a sit-in and, in a separate incident, a chocolate cream cake was pressed in the face of the head of the US delegation, Undersecretary of State Frank E Loy, as he gave his daily press briefing.

Security was being stepped up today at the talks following the incident and guards also had to deal with a string of protests from activists which resulted in 30 arrests.

The attack last night on Mr Loy, a veteran of the Earth Summit process, was by one of scores of protesters, some thought to be British, who appear to have infiltrated the centre, despite strict accreditation rules for delegates and journalists.

fields.headline: Diodes, Devils, and Despair
fields.trailText: JUST FOR THE RECORD
fields.body:
JUST FOR THE RECORD

As footballers go, Norwegians have looser tongues than most. It's the law. Whether it's Vegard Heggem revealing how his pre-season training was disturbed by young boys shouting: "You're shit," at him, or Steffen Iversen moaning about being woken up at 3am by the filming of Bridget Jones' diary, it seems they can't stop sounding off. So imagine our anticipation, no really, when we attended a press conference announcing Rangers' Scottish record signing of Tore Andre Flo from Chelsea for £12m.

What an anti-climax. Because on the flight to Scotland something seems to have happened to poor Tore ("nothing to do with me!" - Squadron Leader Fiver). He looks the same. Heck he even sounds the same. But his personality has been stripped, leaving only a walking footie-speak computer programme in its place. "I like Chelsea very much. It is a great club. But unfortunately for me I was not playing enough, so I had to do something. I am very happy to get this opportunity," Flo revealed robotically, adding the old favourite: "I wanted to go to a club that can win something and I believe we can do it here."

Realising that Tore was doing little to get our mind off Brian Woolnough's Bouffant (parked right in front of us, and held up by John Frieda lacquer), the Fiver fed Tore a sitter and asked if he was excited at the prospect of making his debut against Celtic. But even that failed! "I've watched derby games on TV and I understand it is very important for the people here," he explained, before dashing off to buy a light emitting diode.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ALL MOUTH AND NO £18M TRANSFER

The good angels and the bad devils are still out on Rio Ferdinand's shoulder, debating the pros and cons of a move to Leeds. "We hear the nightlife's great", says the devil, while the angel, in a high voice, suggests "You wouldn't want to make poor Harry cry, would you?" It is true that the rolling Yorkshire countryside is no Peckham High Street, but then Lucas Radebe is no Stevie Potts either. Yes, there's a lot for young Rio to weigh up (including a big pile of cash marked: "Your first week's wages") so it's not entirely surprising that there is no decision expected from Rio before tomorrow.

But that hasn't stopped the rumour mill from breaking free of its moorings and running amok through East London. First of all, quite a few of tomorrow's fish papers had 'Appy 'Arry down as a dead cert to sign Rigobert Song from Liverpool for £2.5m. Some even said it would happen today. But it didn't and one of the increasing number of West Ham officials (Terry Brown, Peter Barnes and now) Paul Aldridge said: "I can assure you that nothing like that is going to happen here today, and maybe never."

Big boo. Other bits of goss persist: the Hammers are in for Perugia's Mauro Milanese, 'Arry wants PSG's Sylvain Distin, but nothing looks like happening today, and maybe never. Maybe Frederic Kanoute will never leave Upton Park either. The French forward, who impresses everyone with his skills, and not many with his goals, has been the subject of an £8m approach from Chelsea. The Hammers turned the bid down, but in this day and age that doesn't mean an awful lot. Far more valuable is the fact that Freddie has told his own website: "Let me tell you something: the day I leave West Ham I will choose a side where I'll be a regular in the team." A ringing endorsement if ever we heard one.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"All I can say is that I am very flattered by the suggestions. It is obvious I am out of work at the moment and I am looking at a way back into football."

Steve Bruce tries the "Give me the job because I'm unemployed" approach to landing the manager's job at Hearts.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

FORSS MAJEUR

Who would have thought it? The same day that fashionable boutique Chelsea's of Chelsea flog their remaindered Norwegian to some Glaswegian bowler hat distributors, little Crystal Palace get a phone call. The phone call, which the Fiver was not privilege to, probably went a little something like this: "Hi, this is Claudio Ranieri's translator here. See we lent you prodigal Finnish striker Mikael Forssell for the whole season? Well we kind of want him back." "Well you can't have him." "Why?" "Cos rule is rules." "Mr Ranieri would like to say something." "Yeah, what's that?" "*@&#!!!!"

Yes, it's funny how the iniquities of Football League law only seem to bite when you're a striker light. Forssell, who was out of first team contention at Stamford Bridge, hasn't exactly impressed at Selhurst Park either, scoring two goals in 12 starts and losing his starting place to transfer-listed Clinton Morrison. But Forssell has been loaned to the Eagles for the entire season and, according to the Football League, that means the player stays with the club for the entire season. What planet are they living on?

"It is made clear to the clubs involved that this is a commitment for a whole season, and the effect is the same as a player signing a one-year contract with a club", a League spokesman said today. "We cannot change the rules halfway through a season." Which didn't impress Colin Hutchinson, Chelsea's Captain Peacock, one bit. "It is very unfortunate that Mikael Forssell is stranded at Crystal Palace", he said, to the accompaniment of a string quartet. "We have appealed to the Football League, with the support of Crystal Palace, but the League are just quoting the rule book at us." But don't worry Colin, we sense the people are right behind you.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Alen Boksic is being linked with a move to Panathinaikos after visiting the team at their hotel in Manchester earlier this week, reports Teamtalk.

Newcastle are lining up a move for Bayer Leverkusen's Croatian international Robert Kovac, reports Teamtalk.

Dean Windass is a target for Celtic and Charlton Athletic, claims Planet Football.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

South Africa striker Benni McCarthy could be coming to England after all, despite his club Celta Vigo rejecting a £9m bid from Aston Villa. McCarthy's agent Rob Moore told Planet Football: "I really believe he will end up in England. He is itching to get to the Premier League."

Former Bradford City manager Chris Hutchings could team up with Paul Jewell again after applying to run the Sheffield Wednesday Youth Academy.

Steve Bruce had admitted he is interested in the vacant manager's job at Hearts - but he refused to confirm whether he was on the shortlist being considered by chief executive Chris Robinson. "It is obvious I am out of work at the moment and I am looking at a way back into football," he admitted. "Hearts are a big club but we will wait and see."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO (JON "FOWL UP" FOWLER SPECIAL)

BBC 2: Match of the Day Live: Olympiakos v Liverpool (6.50pm)

Look Jon, it's not that difficult: The first half is on BBC 2.

BBC 1: Match of the Day Live: Olympiakos v Liverpool (8pm)

And the second half is BBC 1. So you've got to turn over, otherwise you'll end up watching Fred Dibnah's Magnificent Moments. OK?

British Eurosport: Uefa Cup Football: Olympiakos v Liverpool (9.45pm)

Oh we give up. And we're not the only ones.

Sky Sports 1: Football League Review (6.30pm)

"Jon Fowler is a muppet," reckons Justin Toland.

Fifa TV (7pm)

"Sack the cretin," cries Richard Buchanan.

Spanish Football (7.30pm)

"Having just returned from a few days in Calgary, I think young Jon's punishment should be to spend a weekend in Owen Hargreave's hometown. After 48 hours of non-stop country music (and alas not a snap of Shania Twain in sight) on every radio channel and arctic temperatures would soon set him straight," says Simon Vaughan.

Sky Sports 3: Classic World Cup Football (10.30pm)

"Skin the bastard's balls, fry them in butter and serve them in microscopic portions to all your subscribers," reckons Clive Milone.

World ITV: Football (3.10pm)

"Public hanging isn't good enough - but it's a start. Shall we say 8pm, Parliament Square, next Friday?" says Ed Barker.

Channel 4: Football Italia (3.55am)

Unfortunately Jon's got his supporters, though

Channel 5: Jonathon Pearce's Football Night (12.05am)

"Please thank Jon for his mistake," beams Clint Barnes. "Although one hour late for a 45 minute meeting this morning, I was later able to gather the attendees together, wave Jon's email in their faces and proudly proclaim: "SEE, SEE! I told you I wasn't the biggest screw-up on the planet!" There's a very real possibility his goof saved my job, so Jon Fowler - I SALUTE YOU!"

Dutch Football (12.35am)

"On behalf of the recently formed Save Jon Fowler Campaign I demand that he be granted clemency, a full pardon, and a knighthood (unless he is a Man Utd fan)," says Brendan Richardson. "Long live Jon Fowler!"

Argentine Football (2.15am)

"Noooooooo please don't hurt him," says 'Lonely of Leamington Spa. "Thank you Jon. You brought a glad smile to a sad, neglected woman's face for a few brief seconds. How many men could say that on a Tuesday morning?"

International Football (3.55pm)

Not us, that's for sure. We're too busy doing manly things. Like not sending out rogue emails.

"I've watched derby games on TV and I understand it is very important for the people here," he explained, before dashing off to buy a light emitting diode. * * * * * * * * * * * * * ALL MOUTH AND NO £18M TRANSFER The good angels and the bad devils are still out on Rio Ferdinand's shoulder, debating the pros and cons of a move to Leeds. "We hear the nightlife's great", says the devil, while the angel, in a high voice, suggests "You wouldn't want to make poor Harry cry, would you?" It is true that the rolling Yorkshire countryside is no Peckham High Street, but then Lucas Radebe is no Stevie Potts either. Yes, there's a lot for young Rio to weigh up (including a big pile of cash marked: "Your first week's wages") so it's not entirely surprising that there is no decision expected from Rio before tomorrow. But that hasn't stopped the rumour mill from breaking free of its moorings and running amok through East London. First of all, quite a few of tomorrow's fish papers had 'Appy 'Arry down as a dead cert to sign Rigobert Song from Liverpool for £2.5m. Some even said it would happen today. But it didn't and one of the increasing number of West Ham officials (Terry Brown, Peter Barnes and now) Paul Aldridge said: "I can assure you that nothing like that is going to happen here today, and maybe never." Big boo. Other bits of goss persist: the Hammers are in for Perugia's Mauro Milanese, 'Arry wants PSG's Sylvain Distin, but nothing looks like happening today, and maybe never. Maybe Frederic Kanoute will never leave Upton Park either. The French forward, who impresses everyone with his skills, and not many with his goals, has been the subject of an £8m approach from Chelsea. The Hammers turned the bid down, but in this day and age that doesn't mean an awful lot. Far more valuable is the fact that Freddie has told his own website: "Let me tell you something: the day I leave West Ham I will choose a side where I'll be a regular in the team." A ringing endorsement if ever we heard one. * * * * * * * * * * * * * QUOTE OF THE DAY "All I can say is that I am very flattered by the suggestions. It is obvious I am out of work at the moment and I am looking at a way back into football." Steve Bruce tries the "Give me the job because I'm unemployed" approach to landing the manager's job at Hearts. * * * * * * * * * * * * * FORSS MAJEUR Who would have thought it? The same day that fashionable boutique Chelsea's of Chelsea flog their remaindered Norwegian to some Glaswegian bowler hat distributors, little Crystal Palace get a phone call. The phone call, which the Fiver was not privilege to, probably went a little something like this: "Hi, this is Claudio Ranieri's translator here. See we lent you prodigal Finnish striker Mikael Forssell for the whole season? Well we kind of want him back." "Well you can't have him." "Why?" "Cos rule is rules." "Mr Ranieri would like to say something." "Yeah, what's that?" "*@&#!!!!" Yes, it's funny how the iniquities of Football League law only seem to bite when you're a striker light. Forssell, who was out of first team contention at Stamford Bridge, hasn't exactly impressed at Selhurst Park either, scoring two goals in 12 starts and losing his starting place to transfer-listed Clinton Morrison. But Forssell has been loaned to the Eagles for the entire season and, according to the Football League, that means the player stays with the club for the entire season. What planet are they living on? "It is made clear to the clubs involved that this is a commitment for a whole season, and the effect is the same as a player signing a one-year contract with a club", a League spokesman said today. "We cannot change the rules halfway through a season." Which didn't impress Colin Hutchinson, Chelsea's Captain Peacock, one bit. "It is very unfortunate that Mikael Forssell is stranded at Crystal Palace", he said, to the accompaniment of a string quartet. "We have appealed to the Football League, with the support of Crystal Palace, but the League are just quoting the rule book at us." But don't worry Colin, we sense the people are right behind you. * * * * * * * * * * * * * THE RUMOUR MILL Alen Boksic is being linked with a move to Panathinaikos after visiting the team at their hotel in Manchester earlier this week, reports Teamtalk. Newcastle are lining up a move for Bayer Leverkusen's Croatian international Robert Kovac, reports Teamtalk. Dean Windass is a target for Celtic and Charlton Athletic, claims Planet Football. * * * * * * * * * * * * * NEWS IN BRIEF South Africa striker Benni McCarthy could be coming to England after all, despite his club Celta Vigo rejecting a £9m bid from Aston Villa. McCarthy's agent Rob Moore told Planet Football: "I really believe he will end up in England. He is itching to get to the Premier League." Former Bradford City manager Chris Hutchings could team up with Paul Jewell again after applying to run the Sheffield Wednesday Youth Academy. Steve Bruce had admitted he is interested in the vacant manager's job at Hearts - but he refused to confirm whether he was on the shortlist being considered by chief executive Chris Robinson. "It is obvious I am out of work at the moment and I am looking at a way back into football," he admitted. "Hearts are a big club but we will wait and see." * * * * * * * * * * * * * TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO (JON "FOWL UP" FOWLER SPECIAL) BBC 2: Match of the Day Live: Olympiakos v Liverpool (6.50pm) Look Jon, it's not that difficult: The first half is on BBC 2. BBC 1: Match of the Day Live: Olympiakos v Liverpool (8pm) And the second half is BBC 1. So you've got to turn over, otherwise you'll end up watching Fred Dibnah's Magnificent Moments. OK? British Eurosport: Uefa Cup Football: Olympiakos v Liverpool (9.45pm) Oh we give up. And we're not the only ones. Sky Sports 1: Football League Review (6.30pm) "Jon Fowler is a muppet," reckons Justin Toland. Fifa TV (7pm) "Sack the cretin," cries Richard Buchanan. Spanish Football (7.30pm) "Having just returned from a few days in Calgary, I think young Jon's punishment should be to spend a weekend in Owen Hargreave's hometown. After 48 hours of non-stop country music (and alas not a snap of Shania Twain in sight) on every radio channel and arctic temperatures would soon set him straight," says Simon Vaughan. Sky Sports 3: Classic World Cup Football (10.30pm) "Skin the bastard's balls, fry them in butter and serve them in microscopic portions to all your subscribers," reckons Clive Milone. World ITV: Football (3.10pm) "Public hanging isn't good enough - but it's a start. Shall we say 8pm, Parliament Square, next Friday?" says Ed Barker. Channel 4: Football Italia (3.55am) Unfortunately Jon's got his supporters, though Channel 5: Jonathon Pearce's Football Night (12.05am) "Please thank Jon for his mistake," beams Clint Barnes. "Although one hour late for a 45 minute meeting this morning, I was later able to gather the attendees together, wave Jon's email in their faces and proudly proclaim: "SEE, SEE! I told you I wasn't the biggest screw-up on the planet!" There's a very real possibility his goof saved my job, so Jon Fowler - I SALUTE YOU!" Dutch Football (12.35am) "On behalf of the recently formed Save Jon Fowler Campaign I demand that he be granted clemency, a full pardon, and a knighthood (unless he is a Man Utd fan)," says Brendan Richardson. "Long live Jon Fowler!" Argentine Football (2.15am) "Noooooooo please don't hurt him," says 'Lonely of Leamington Spa. "Thank you Jon. You brought a glad smile to a sad, neglected woman's face for a few brief seconds. How many men could say that on a Tuesday morning?" International Football (3.55pm) Not us, that's for sure. We're too busy doing manly things. Like not sending out rogue emails.

webTitle: The Hague 2000: US envoy gets caked

fields.headline: Envoy eats cake as US quibbles
fields.standfirst:
Environmental activists give the US envoy at The Hague food for thought
Video of the cake throwing from Channel 4
Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: The climate change talks at The Hague were disrupted yesterday by protesters who burst into a negotiating room and staged a sit-in, and by a separate incident in which a woman pressed a chocolate cream cake in the face of the head of the US delegation, Undersecretary of State Frank E Loy, as he gave his daily press briefing.
fields.body:
The climate change talks at The Hague were disrupted yesterday by protesters who burst into a negotiating room and staged a sit-in, and by a separate incident in which a woman pressed a chocolate cream cake in the face of the head of the US delegation, Undersecretary of State Frank E Loy, as he gave his daily press briefing.

The assailant was identified as a smartly-dressed woman, later named an 'environmental activist'. She shouted something, unrecorded by the world's media, and took her exit at a leisurely pace. She has since gone to ground.

Loy, not to be put off from his usual glossing of the US refusal to curb their economy as concern about global warming rises, plucked out a neat little tribute to President John Kennedy: "He warned against being swayed by those who confuse the rhetoric with the reality and the plausible with the possible and I just want to assure you as we go cleanly up here what we are very anxious to do here is to do the possible, is to recognise reality, is to make a deal and we are looking for our colleagues to do the same. And the prospect is quite serious at the moment and we have every hope that it will be successful."

Then he retired, with injured dignity oozing from every chocolate-coated pore.

Loy is unlikely to be chastened by a chocolate cake. The US, though a little less intractable than they were at the start of the talks, are continuing to quibble about real cuts to carbon emissions.

Their strategy has been to argue that carbon sinks - forests and plants - can be used to prevent actual curbs on industry and individual lifestyles. This sort of refusal to adapt to global crisis, when they are responsible for 50% of emissions from industrialised countries, well merits a caking.

Today demonstrators from Greenpeace set off a siren outside the conference to mark the looming deadline and unfurled a banner from a Dutch water authority building saying: "Don't Let Us D(r)own"

• Damage to property due to global warming could bankrupt the world by 2065, an international World Climate Change Conference was told today. Leading Scottish insurance expert, Dr Andrew Dlugolecki, warned that the rate of damage to homes, buildings, and facilities was rising at an alarming speed due to changing weather and would eventually exceed all the world's wealth.

webTitle: US cliffhanger pushes tech stocks over edge

fields.headline: US cliffhanger pushes tech stocks over edge
fields.trailText: Global equity markets suffered another bout of jitters yesterday as concern about earnings growth of high-value technology stocks added to deepening unease about the outcome of the US presidential election.
fields.body:
Global equity markets suffered another bout of jitters yesterday as concern about earnings growth of high-value technology stocks added to deepening unease about the outcome of the US presidential election.

On Wall Street the technology-packed Nasdaq Composite plunged 113 points in early trading to a level not seen since October last year. By lunchtime the main US indices had made a slight recovery, with the Nasdaq down around 84 points.

In London, the blue chip FTSE 100 index slipped 160.7 points to 6,221.4, a five-week closing low, with technology and telecoms issues bearing the brunt of losses. The Techmark index ended 175 points weaker at 2,865.60, its lowest closing level since May.

The immediate cause of the nervousness was a Florida supreme court ruling allowing the hand recount of votes in the state, a verdict which threatens to prolong the battle for the White House by at least another five days.

Investors in the US are also worried about the slowdown in the economy. Some analysts have noted that fourth-quarter earnings growth could be half of that anticipated.

Fears about earnings growth of technology stocks were back on the agenda after a surprise profit warning from the Netherlands-based Getronics. The world's fifth-biggest computer services provider stunned investors when it warned it would make a loss in the first half of 2001 due to investment costs and sluggish sales.

European technology stocks were sold off on the news with rivals such as Cap Gemini Ernst & Young, Sema and CMG among the worst hit. The German Nemax 50 index comprising the top 50 growth stocks in the Neuer Markt - Europe's largest growth market - fell nearly 10% to 3,105.64 points, its largest one-day fall to the lowest level since it was launched in April 1998.

In Paris the CAC 40 index ended more than 100 points lower. Asian markets were also hit by the uncertainty with the Nikkei in Tokyo falling to a 20-month closing low.

fields.headline: Flo completes £12m Rangers move
fields.trailText: Tore Andre Flo today completed his protracted £12m transfer from Chelsea to Rangers in a move which establishes a new Scottish transfer record.
fields.body:
Tore Andre Flo today completed his protracted £12m transfer from Chelsea to Rangers in a move which establishes a new Scottish transfer record.

The 27-year-old Norwegian, who has failed to establish himself as a Stamford Bridge regular under new manager Claudio Ranieri, agreed a four-year deal this morning and was unveiled at a press conference at Ibrox later in the day.

Flo cited his failure to play regualr first-team football as the main reason for his move: "I've not been playing enough, so I had to do something," he said. "I'm very happy to get this opportunity. I wanted to go to a club that can win something and believe we can do it here."

He is likely to make his debut against Celtic on Sunday at Ibrox, a game Rangers must win to retain any realistic chance of catching their old rivals at the top of the table. "I've watched derby games on TV and I understand it is very important for the people here," he admitted.

Rangers manager Dick Advocaat said he was very "pleased" to finally secure the services of a player he has been chasing since June. Earlier this week it looked as if he might be further frustrated, but a wrangle over terms was finally resolved.

"I've tried many times to get him," admitted Advocaat. "The last time was in June when I phoned him, but he was still involved with Chelsea. I have been watching the Chelsea side since, and he has not been a regular. But I think he will gel very quickly here."

Chelsea managing director Colin Hutchinson blamed Norway coach Nils Johan Semb for affecting Flo's attitude in insisting he should be playing regular first-team football to be picked for his country. But it is not as if compatriot Ole Gunnar Solskjaer has similarly been persuaded to leave Manchester United.

Flo, a firm favourite with the Chelsea fans, is certain to leave a vacuum at Stamford Bridge. Ranieri's predecessor, Gianluca Vialli warned that Flo would cost at least £17m to replace, and Chelsea will look to make a quick signing to augment their main two strikers, Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink and Gianfranco Zola.

Yesterday they had a £8m bid for West Ham's Frederic Kanoute turned down and they may now return with an improved offer.

webTitle: Consumer: How to pick a great gift

fields.headline: How to pick a great gift
fields.standfirst: Only five weeks to Christmas - and you absolutely hate shopping. Well, don't panic. Tim Dowling can help
fields.trailText: Only five weeks to Christmas - and you absolutely hate shopping. Well, don't panic. Tim Dowling can help.
fields.body:
It's that time of year again when those of us who cannot shop are forced to compete with the people who do it all year round. Ideally there should be a few shopping days set aside for people who don't know what they're doing; who cannot choose colours or remember sizes, or, when it comes to making purchases for others, haven't an original thought in their head or an aesthetic bone in their body. But there are no such days. Christmas is a free-for-all, and amateurs suffer.

The main difficulty lies in the presents themselves. We try to tailor the presents we buy to the people we buy them for, but this is not always possible. Christmas presents are not like other presents. They are not birthday presents or anniversary presents. They are not meant to reflect complex sentiments, or private emotions.

Christmas is not the time to select gifts that show a deep understanding of the recipient's inner life, unless a travel iron does that. Christmas shopping is first and foremost a race against the clock. There may well be a perfect Christmas present out there to suit each and every individual, but if it's not at eye-level in John Lewis at 5.30pm on a Wednesday, then it's not going to be under the tree either.

Christmas shopping means buying presents in bulk - at the same speed favoured by Supermarket Sweep contestants - and in many cases for people whose likes and dislikes are largely unknown to us.

This is where those so-called popular presents come in, the stuff that everybody seems to be buying; the toys, games, books, clothes and kitchen implements which over the course of the Christmas period become absolute must-have items for people who don't know they're getting them.

The new Beatles CD is a perfect example. A collection of old Beatles No1 hits is about the most anodyne, impersonal present imaginable, which is why every man, woman and child in Britain will find themselves in possession of a copy come Boxing Day.

As a present it is safe, reasonably priced and easy to track down. In many outlets it will probably be available in a ready-wrapped condition. It is that most horrible and, sadly, necessary of things: the great gift idea.

Great gift ideas are not, generally speaking, actually great, or even really ideas. They are simply a guide to getting through your Christmas shopping while expending the least amount of imagination possible, and so they are invaluable.

Great gift ideas are items that the shops have guessed people will buy, hoping their friends and relatives will want them. There is a whole new crop each year, but there are always seven basic categories: bestselling hardback, hilarious novelty, crowd-pleasing CD (see Beatles, Sade, etc), electronic gizmo, gay apparel and alcohol.

As far as the hardback is concerned, there is only one real contender this year: Nigella Lawson's new cookbook, How To Be A Domestic Goddess. Perfect: grab one. Don't start worrying about where you stand on the whole "Nigella" thing. This is not about you. Just buy it. You can figure out who it's for when you get it home. If you've got time, root through the pile for a signed copy, which always gives a book that extra personal touch. If there aren't any signed copies, sign it yourself; nobody knows what Nigella's handwriting looks like.

The Booker Prize winner is also a fairly safe bet (Margaret Atwood's The Blind Assassin, in case you've forgotten), and it says "BOOKER PRIZE WINNER" right on the cover, which shows that you care enough to give only the very best. If both books are for the same person, remember to use different pens for the signatures.

Novelty gifts, such as the now-famous Billy the Singing Bass, pose a special problem. The publicity surrounding their brisk sales figures ensures that the joke wears ever thinner as Christmas Eve approaches. Everyone who has ventured out shopping has already seen all the novelty gifts on offer, and they've probably done all the laughing they're going to do right there in the shop.

Under the circumstances you may feel that the "novelty" of a rubber fish singing old rhythm and blues standards is no novelty at all, no matter what the Queen thinks, but you would be missing the point.

The general standard of humour plummets at Christmas. Think of those Christmas cracker jokes, and the stuff they put on telly. In comparison, Billy the Bass seems positively highbrow. If you still don't like the idea, try to think of it this way: chances are someone has already got you a Billy the Bass, so prepare a retaliatory strike.

Of all Christmas presents, clothes are notoriously the most difficult to get right so the possibility for error is enormous. Luckily, you don't really have to get it right any more. These days clothes are a kind of currency, representing a fixed amount of store credit. All you have to do is pick the right shop, and spend vaguely the right amount of money. The rest is up to the recipient.

In theory it doesn't really matter what you buy, but it's best to stick with scarves, shawls, gloves, bags and other items where you can't insult someone by getting the wrong size. Of course, it would be simpler to purchase a gift certificate, but it's nicer to be seen to have made an effort, even when you haven't.

Electrical goods seem like complex purchases to negotiate, but this is often because inexperienced shoppers attempt to listen to the technical chatter of sales assistants as if they had all the time in the world. Who cares which video camera is the best? This is Christmas. Get the shiniest one.

The same goes for personal organisers and mobile phones. Don't bother with larger gift items such as televisions and personal computers. These are now purchased in January, in the company of the intended recipient, at a fraction of the pre-Christmas price.

Perhaps the easiest and most dependable great gift idea is alcohol. It's not really a proper present, which is why people are so pleased to receive it. Giving booze is the closest you can come to giving money without seeming like you're missing the true meaning of Christmas, and your recipients will be almost as grateful.

You can even send it directly to their homes after purchasing it online with just a few clicks of the mouse. It may not sound particularly festive, but it does mean that you can continue with your Christmas shopping long after you've lost the will to live.

These days clothes are a kind of currency, representing a fixed amount of store credit. All you have to do is pick the right shop, and spend vaguely the right amount of money. The rest is up to the recipient. In theory it doesn't really matter what you buy, but it's best to stick with scarves, shawls, gloves, bags and other items where you can't insult someone by getting the wrong size. Of course, it would be simpler to purchase a gift certificate, but it's nicer to be seen to have made an effort, even when you haven't. Electrical goods seem like complex purchases to negotiate, but this is often because inexperienced shoppers attempt to listen to the technical chatter of sales assistants as if they had all the time in the world. Who cares which video camera is the best? This is Christmas. Get the shiniest one. The same goes for personal organisers and mobile phones. Don't bother with larger gift items such as televisions and personal computers. These are now purchased in January, in the company of the intended recipient, at a fraction of the pre-Christmas price. Perhaps the easiest and most dependable great gift idea is alcohol. It's not really a proper present, which is why people are so pleased to receive it. Giving booze is the closest you can come to giving money without seeming like you're missing the true meaning of Christmas, and your recipients will be almost as grateful. You can even send it directly to their homes after purchasing it online with just a few clicks of the mouse. It may not sound particularly festive, but it does mean that you can continue with your Christmas shopping long after you've lost the will to live.

fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.standfirst: Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: Fancy a flutter?
fields.body:
Fancy a flutter?

BlueSq.com is the place to go. However, although it is the country's leading online betting site, it doesn't take itself too seriously. So, if you couldn't care less whether Manchester Utd win the Premiership - again - you can still bet on the important things in life such as Denise Van Outen tying the knot with Jay Kay before the end of 2000 (6-4) or, for that matter, Robbie Williams marrying anyone (16-1).

Play the stock market at considerably lower odds than Nick Leeson by predicting the opening or closing prices. You can even have a wager on your favourite soap - the odds for Eastenders' Ian Beale floating an internet company are currently 16-1. And then, of course, there's the old chestnut of a London white Christmas at 6-1. Minimum deposit is an Ayrton Senna and with a minimum stake of 50p you won't break the iron tank.

For the old school, Bet.co.uk is Ladbrokes' online counterpart. The yob pictured on its home page might even make you yearn for the terraces - or it might not. You've got a limited choice of events - football, racing and, erm, golf, but you also get to avoid your local bookie experience of stale cigarette smoke and unpleasant bodily odours - which is well worth its weight in gold. Minimum deposit is a Lady Godiva and minimum stake £1.

The site for serious sports fanatics is Sportingbet.com, the most comprehensive in terms of global coverage. It offers an impressive range of opportunities to lose money, from the nags to baseball and hockey. The real bonus is that it's tax free - although the minimum stake is a fiver. As they say, "you pays your money". Mine's on Bushill Bandit in the 14.15.
