webTitle: US redoubles effort to halt Middle East war

fields.headline: US redoubles effort to halt Middle East war
fields.standfirst:
Neither side seems keen to negotiate, and events are being dictated by maverick armed groups rather than the increasingly desperate peace makers, reports Derek Brown.
Special report: Israel & Middle East
fields.trailText: Neither side seems keen to negotiate, and events are being dictated by maverick armed groups rather than the increasingly desperate peace makers, reports Derek Brown
fields.body:
US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright is intensifying her efforts to halt the escalating violence in Israel and the Palestinian territories.

As well as ritual appeals for calm, she is acting as a go-between for the Israelis and the embattled Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat.

Neither side seems in any mood to negotiate, though Albright has told the Israeli foreign minister Shlomo Ben-Ami that Arafat is ready to resume contacts. Ben-Ami was dismissive: "It could certainly be that this is a signal of distress and of a desire to get out of this cycle," he told Israeli radio.

Israel has consistently laid all the blame for the violence on the Palestinian National Authority (PNA) headed by Arafat. Officials are now bridling at US suggestions that both sides should exercise restraint.

The fact is that of the 259 lives lost so far, the overwhelming majority have been Palestinian. Israelis, however, passionately believe that they, not the Palestinians, are the victims - a mood violently reinforced by Wednesday's callous car bomb explosion in Hadera, north of Tel Aviv, which killed two Israelis and wounded more than 60.

Israeli media, doubtless tipped off by intelligence sources, identified the bomber as Iyad Hardan, an activist of the ultra-militant Islamic Jihad group, who was released from a Palestinian prison a month ago. PNA officials have said that he was rearrested and is now back in jail, but the theory that he could still be masterminding a guerrilla campaign is likely to be taken as gospel in Israel.

What is plain is that Arafat has lost most of his ability to control events on his own streets, let alone within Israel. In the present inflamed mood, his ragtag police and intelligence forces are unlikely to interfere with the militants of Islamic Jihad and Hamas.

Such groups are the wild cards of the Middle East, liable at any moment to throw a smoking bomb - literally - into the fragile relationships of Jew and Arab, moderate and militant.

The proliferation of small, determined armed groups is endemic in the region. There is new disturbing evidence that the contagion has spread to Saudi Arabia, where three British expatriate workers have been wounded in a car explosion. The three - two men and a woman - all worked for the same company in the capital, Riyadh.

Last week another British expat, Christopher Rodway, was killed when a booby trap explosion ripped through his car.

Throughout the Middle East, Islamists and other militants hold Britain guilty, mostly by association with America, of supporting authoritarian Arab regimes and the country they call the Zionist entity.

Now daily reports and images of bloodshed in the Palestinian territories are inflaming popular as well as militant opinion. Secretary of State Albright has taken on a daunting diplomatic task, as she tries to wrestle the evil genies of conflict back into their fragile bottle.

webTitle: Hospital infections kill 5,000 patients a year

fields.headline: Hospital infections kill 5,000 patients a year
fields.trailText: Infections acquired in hospitals lead to the deaths of up to 5,000 patients in England each year and cost the National Health Service £1bn, a new report warned today.
fields.body:
Infections acquired in hospitals lead to the deaths of up to 5,000 patients in England each year and cost the National Health Service £1bn, a new report warned today.

The House of Commons public accounts committee called for the health service to "get a grip" on the problem, demanding more resources be channelled into tackling it and a "root and branch shift" towards prevention.

Committee chairman David Davis, the Conservative MP for Haltemprice and Howden, said: "Hospital acquired infection (HAI) endangers patients' lives and is a major drain on NHS resources. Every year thousands die and £1bn leaks from NHS coffers.

"While it will never be entirely preventable there is more the NHS could do to combat this problem. It must be addressed as a matter of urgency and should be allocated adequate resources."

The report found:

 the best estimates suggest that each year there are at least 100,000 cases of HAI in England causing around 5,000 deaths, and the cost to the NHS may be as much as £1bn a year;

 it is estimated that across all NHS Trusts infection rates could be reduced by 15% by better application of existing knowledge and realistic infection control practices, with a potential saving of around £150m a year;

 the NHS does not have a grip on the extent of HAI and the costs involved and is unlikely to have the information it needs for a further three to four years. "Without robust, up to date data it is difficult to see how the Department of Health, the NHS executive, health authorities and NHS trusts can target activity and resources to best effect," said the committee;

 in particular, the committee noted that between 50-70% of surgical wound infections occur after discharge from hospital, but these infections are not monitored. MPs recommended the establishment of a national surveillance scheme;

 a root and branch shift towards prevention will be needed at all levels of the NHS if HAI is to be kept under control. "That will require commitment from everyone involved, and a philosophy that prevention is everybody's business, not just the specialists," the report said;

 the committee noted that hospital hygiene was crucial to preventing HAI, but added: "We find it inexcusable that compliance with guidance on hand washing is so poor".

The committee concluded that increased attention was now being given to HAI, but that has not been matched by resources.

It noted that some £5m had been allocated to combating the problem over two years and some additional infection control nurses have been appointed. But the MPs insisted: "The scale of HAI calls for sufficient funding to ensure that hospitals can tackle the problem effectively, and so reduce the impact on patients and NHS costs."

A Department of Health spokesman said: "We are determined to tackle the problem of hospital infections. That's why action is being taken now, across the NHS, to fight them."

Those measures included:

 from April next year every NHS trust will gather information about infection in the NHS so that there is a proper national monitoring system;

 from April 2002 the NHS will publish that information so that the public can see how well local hospitals are doing;

 the audit commission and the commission for health improvement will be able to independently check that information and monitor how effectively the NHS is fighting infection;

 under a system introduced last November, the NHS has established infection control teams, set up indicators to demonstrate improvement in infection control, and provided training for all health care staff in the area;

 next year health authorities in England will get extra resources of £2.9bn, and managers have been told to spend some of that money on investing to meet high standards of cleanliness.

fields.headline: Nazi movie exhibition enrages actor
fields.trailText: A Warsaw exhibition featuring photographs of movie stars in Nazi uniform was shut down by the Polish government yesterday following one actor's decision remove his image himself
fields.body:
A Warsaw exhibition featuring photographs of movie stars in Nazi uniform was shut down by the Polish government yesterday. The exhibition caused a storm of controversy with both the press and the public: one actor who found hiimself showcased was so incensed that he absconded with his own portrait, pausing only to slash at the other pictures with a ceremonial sword.

Entitled simply The Nazis, the exhibition, staged at Warsaw's Zacheta Gallery by New York-based artist Piotr Uklanski, featured stills of various actors taken from movies in which they have played Nazis. More famous faces included Ralph Fiennes, Frank Sinatra, Richard Burton, Roger Moore, Clint Eastwood and Omar Sharif. But it was one of the lesser known stars of the exhibition who finally decided to take matters into his own hands.

A supporting player in Volker Schlondorff's The Tin Drum and Krzysztof Kieslowski's Dekalog, Daniel Olbrychski is a stalwart of Polish cinema, best known for his roles in such homegrown swashbucklers as Dangerous Moves and With Fire and Sword.

According to Olbrychski's version of events, he became so enraged when a little girl who had visited the exhibition asked the actor if he was really a Nazi that he stormed to the Zacheta Gallery, removed his picture from the wall and attacked the other portraits with a sword that he had smuggled in.

The 55-year-old actor claimed that the show was "an abuse of the actors who played in anti-Nazi films." Prosecuting lawyers allege that the actor caused an estimated $80,000 (£57,000) worth of damage during his zealous act of vandalism.

In ordering the exhibition to be closed down, Poland's cultural minister Kazimierz Ujazdowski conceded that it could re-open when an "appropriate commentary" was added about the evils of Nazism.

fields.headline: Attenborough's Planet takes off
fields.trailText: 1pm TV overnights: Sir David Attenborough's epic TV special recovered from last week's Morse effect to soar in the ratings, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Sir David Attenborough was back on top of the world last night after his epic millennium TV special soared in the ratings.

The first episode of State of the Planet was hammered in the ratings by the final Inspector Morse last week.

But last night Sir David's environmental audit averaged 5.9m - nearly 2m up on the previous Wednesday - and a 25% share.

The landmark natural history documentary was up against live Champions League soccer on ITV.

An average of 7.1m viewers tuned in from 7.30-9.45pm to watch Leeds lose to Real Madrid on The Big Match.

The BBC1 Ten O'Clock News suffered against Coronation Street, which followed the football at 9.45pm-10.15pm, and Tonight with Trevor McDonald.

BBC1's news averaged just 4m viewers and an 18% share; while the flagship ITV soap took 10.5m.

Tonight, which included a report on the legal row between OK! and Hello! over photos of the Catherine Zeta Jones/Michael Douglas marriage, had 6.4m.

webTitle: Universal pulls horror trailer from family film

fields.headline: Universal pulls horror trailer from family film
fields.standfirst: Following government pressure over film marketing, Universal Studios has ordered a trailer for the upcoming horror movie The Mummy Returns to be removed from prints of the family film How the Grinch Stole Christmas
fields.trailText: Following government pressure over film marketing, Universal Studios has ordered a trailer for the upcoming horror movie The Mummy Returns to be removed from prints of the family film How the Grinch Stole Christmas
fields.body:
Prompted by concerns from nervous cinema owners, Universal Studios this week ordered a trailer for their upcoming horror flick The Mummy Returns to be removed from prints of the family film How the Grinch Stole Christmas (pictured).

Admittedly The Mummy Returns is hardly a full-on gorefest and The Grinch is not an out-and-out kiddie pic, but in today's jittery moral climate their close proximity was enough to cause a minor crisis.

Over the past few months, Hollywood has come under increasing pressure from certain sources in Washington over ruthless marketing tactics. First a damning Federal Trade Commission report charged that the film industry deliberately targeted R-rated material at underage audiences, then last month Motion Picture Association of America chairman, Jack Valenti, appeared before a congress hearing which demanded that Hollywood should clean up its act.

The trailer for The Mummy Returns had been added to 4,200 prints of the Jim Carrey picture How the Grinch Stole Christmas before studio bosses realised that they had a problem on their hands.

Yesterday Terry Curtin, head of publicity at the studio, confessed that increasing government scrutiny had led them to reconsider their decision. "Clearly the FTC attention is an issue," said Curtin. "[But] whenever you're dealing with young children you have to err on the side of caution."

fields.headline: Express titles 'not for sale'
fields.standfirst: 12pm: Hindujas renew Express bid
fields.trailText:
12.45pm update: OK! magazine publisher Richard Desmond says he won't be tempted by a cash offer for the Express newspapers, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
12pm: Hindujas renew Express bid
fields.body:
OK! magazine publisher Richard Desmond says he won't be tempted by any cash offer for the Express newspapers.

It emerged today that the publishing tycoon has already rebuffed a tentative £100m-plus deal for the Daily Express and the Sunday Express.

And a spokesman for Mr Desmond said that he would be equally dismissive of the expected cash offer from the Hinduja brothers.

He said: "He has been negotiating [to buy the Express titles] for five weeks. It is true to say that his first interest was in the Daily Star but after due consideration he decided to go for all three as a package.

"The Express and Sunday Express are simply not for sale."

He added: "If someone came in and offered £200m or something that would make him £75m in 24 hours, he might consider it. But it is simply not going to happen. Richard is in this for the long run."

Mr Desmond met United News & Media chief Lord Hollick for the first time last night in Room 12 on the ninth floor of the Express headquarters in Ludgate House in London.

He also met Express editor Rosie Boycott for the first time. Both sides are publicly insisting she will remain at the helm - Ms Boycott yesterday said she saw "no reason" why she should move.

However it is understood that lists of potential successors are being drawn up.

One source on the papers said: "It will be a matter of principle for Rosie. How can she possibly feel comfortable with a man who has made money out of exploiting women?"

fields.headline: Britons attacked in Saudi Arabia
fields.standfirst: The Foreign Office is considering stepping up its security advice to Britons visiting Saudi Arabia. We explain why
fields.trailText: The Foreign Office is considering stepping up its security advice to Britons visiting Saudi Arabia. We explain why.
fields.body:
What has happened in Saudi Arabia?
A car explosion today injured three Britons, less than a week after a British man was killed when the car in which he was travelling exploded in the Saudi capital, Riyadh.

In the latest blast, almost certainly another car bomb, two people suffered minor injuries and a third was reported to have sustained a leg wound as their car exploded in Riyadh.

The Foreign Office confirmed that the Britons injured today were two men and a woman who were living in Riyadh.

Are Britons been targeted - and who is behind the attacks?
The blast suggests that Islamic fundamentalists who have declared war on the United States and urged fellow Muslims to kill Americans at every opportunity now consider Britons to be equal targets, terrorism experts have argued.

Professor Paul Wilkinson, director of the centre for the study of terrorism and political violence at St Andrew's University, said today: "There is now every reason to enhance the vigilance of our security, and British security measures must be based on the assumption that British targets are also at risk."

He said many Saudi Arabians were angry over the violence in Israel and Palestine and what is seen as the west's support for the Jewish state.

But writer and commentator on Middle East issues Hazhir Teimourian said he thought it was unlikely that the attacks were in sympathy for the Palestinians. "These terrorists have been in place for a long time," he said. "They may be happy to attribute their anger to the Palestinian cause, but I think they have their own long-term plans - which are to fight according to the wishes of their leaders such as Osama bin Laden."

Is the US after Osma bin Laden?
Yes. Bin Laden, a Saudi millionaire, who is in hiding in Afghanistan, was this month named as one of the US's 10 "most wanted" terrorists.

The US state department has offered a $5m (£3.5m) reward for bin Laden and one of his military aides, blaming them for killing 224 people in attacks on US embassies in Nairobi, Kenya, and Dar Es Salaam, Tanzania, in August 1998.

In 1996, bin Laden declared war on the US and issued a fatwa. A bomb was thrown at the British embassy in the Yemeni capital of San'a last month. No one was hurt in the attack, which came shortly after an apparent suicide bombing which killed 17 sailors on the USS Cole as it refuelled in the port of Aden, in southern Yemen.

In total, 19 US Air Force personnel were killed and more than 500 Americans and Saudis injured when a truck bomb exploded outside the Khobar Towers housing complex near Dhahran in June 1996.

What is being done?
The Foreign Office said it would consider stepping up security advice to Britons in the area if, as expected, the incidents are found to be car bombings. Official advice to British nationals in Saudi Arabia warns there is "an increased threat to British interests from global terrorism".

What are the details of the earlier, fatal, attack?Christopher Rodway, a hospital worker living in Riyadh, died after an explosion ripped through his car last Friday.

His wife Jane, who was also travelling in the car, suffered minor injuries Mr Rodway, an expatriate in his 40s who worked in a Riyadh hospital, had lived in the country for eight years.

fields.headline: Express joins the OK! stable
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The porn and celebrity magazine publisher Richard Desmond took charge of the Express newspaper group last night and pledged to inject "panache" into its ailing titles with more show business features and exclusive interviews.
fields.body:
The porn and celebrity magazine publisher Richard Desmond took charge of the Express newspaper group last night and pledged to inject "panache" into its ailing titles with more show business features and exclusive interviews.

In a clear indication that he intends to transform the titles into celebrity-led popular tabloids, Mr Desmond said he would bring the success of his magazine group to the newspapers. "Everything's okay at the Express," he declared on the steps of the newspaper's London headquarters, referring to the title of his successful celebrity weekly OK!.

Mr Desmond is chairman of Northern and Shell, which beat off a rival bid from the billionaire Hinduja brothers to conclude a £125m deal with United News and Media yesterday. Lord Hollick, United's chief executive, wished the new proprietors well.

The new owners promised to maintain the editorial independence of the Labour-supporting Express. "The editors will edit it and we will build it," said Paul Ashford, the new editorial director.

But the future of the Daily Express editor, Rosie Boycott, was in the balance last night - Boycott had aligned herself in the past few weeks with the Hindujas' bid. Mr Ashford revealed that she had not been consulted before the deal was concluded. "We haven't spoken to her, but we like continuity," he said, before entering a meeting with Boycott. A member of staff described her as a "woman under siege".

Mr Desmond, whose titles include Asian Babes magazine as well as OK!, promised investment in the Express, once one of Britain's most successful campaigning newspapers with daily sales that topped 4m. Now, it struggles to sell 1m. "We hope to build it back to what it was," he said.

"We will continue its legacy," Mr Ashford added. "It will continue its tradition. It will still be a passionate advocate of causes. It will look like it does now, but with more panache."

The new owners pledged they would bring no "political agenda" to the newspapers, although Mr Desmond described himself as a socialist. A panel of "experts" will be established to maintain the titles' editorial integrity.

"We expect the political stance of the newspapers to be issue-led rather than party-led," Mr Ashford said.

In an earlier statement, Northern and Shell said it would boost the celebrity coverage of the Express group. The Express would combine the "national and international news with unbeatable celebrity news, emotive features and crusading columns". The new proprietors would target "18- to 34-year-old intelligent, independent-minded females".

The Express's new owners appear to be targeting a similar readership to its arch rival, the Daily Mail, whose parent company had previously indicated an interest in buying the group.

Northern and Shell appears to be committed to the Star, which it said was already successfully targeting "young, high-spending, fast-living males and their female counterparts". There had been speculation that a new owner would seek to sell off the title.

The deal ends months of speculation about the future of the Express papers. The Hinduja group had tabled an initial offer which is understood to have been worth between £100m and £120m.

The Barclay brothers, owners of the Scotsman and Sunday Business, offered £75m-£100m, but withdrew in October.

There was also interest from Daily Mail and General Trust; Conrad Black's Hollinger International, owner of The Telegraph; and David Montgomery, the former Mirror executive.

Mr Desmond approached Lord Hollick four weeks ago, after the Barclays pulled out. He promised a quick deal - unlike the other bidders, his deal did not require regulatory approval. A quick, cash sale was concluded yesterday afternoon.

United said that all proposals had been carefully considered in the light of the "price indicated, the speed and certainty of completion and the threat to the value of Express Newspapers during a prolonged period of uncertainty".

OK! magazine will move into the Express headquarters at Blackfriars in London, where Mr Desmond will take up an office. The newspaper group's share of the printing presses at Westferry is also included in the deal.

webTitle: Desmond in bid to reassure Express staff

fields.headline: Desmond in bid to reassure Express staff
fields.standfirst:
12.45pm: Express titles 'not for sale'
12pm: Hindujas renew Express bid
fields.trailText:
1.45pm update: New Express owner Richard Desmond has assured staff he will "spend whatever it takes" to restore the titles to their former glories, writes Dan Milmo.
12.45pm: Express titles 'not for sale'
12pm: Hindujas renew Express bid
fields.body:
The Express newspapers' new owner, Richard Desmond, has assured worried staff that he will "spend whatever it takes" to restore the titles to their former glories.

The publishing tycoon sent an email to anxious journalists at the Daily Express, Sunday Express and Daily Star, who are disgruntled at the lack of communication from the corridors of power on the ninth floor of Ludgate House.

They received no updates from the newpapers' former owner, Lord Hollick of United News & Media, and had to log on to newswires to get the latest on the situation.

Mr Desmond, who is known to have a very direct management style, told staff that his "door is always open".

The email in full:

"Dear colleague

I am enormously pleased and proud to be the new owner of three great British newspapers. The Express titles, along with the Daily Star, are household names which run through the fabric of our nation.

I am greatly looking forward to working with you all and to meeting you over the coming weeks. I do realise that you have all been living through a period of great uncertainty, but now we can all look forward to building the business together with the uncertainty finally over.

We must now all totally commit ourselves to restoring the papers to their rightful position - that is number one in their respective markets. As I have already said, I will spend whatever it takes. I guarantee we will win. My door is always open. OK!

Richard Desmond"

fields.headline: Games watch
fields.trailText: Chaos reigns | Hard driving | Bets are on
fields.body:
Chaos reigns
Tomorrow sees the launch of PlayStation 2 in the UK with many stores opening their doors at midnight tonight. However, the lack of non-allocated stock means it is unlikely that the chaotic US launch queues will be experienced here. Despite the pre-order scheme not going entirely smoothly, with customer confusion and some cutbacks in stock, anyone who has ordered a machine and has been contacted by Sony will be able to collect it tomorrow. The company intends to fulfil the other pre-ordered systems by Christmas but it could still be touch and go. Customers are advised to speak to their retailer.

Hard driving
Getting bored with synchronising your agenda and fiddling with your address book? Then how about a bit of hard driving? Infogrames are releasing V-Rally for Palm OS, which means it will run on Palms, Handsprings and other compatible devices. The game includes 40 tracks set in locations stretching from Indonesia to the UK and lets you choose from four rally cars to race. There is a small, but growing, market for PDA games and a free demo of V-Rally can be downloaded from www.palmtop.nl/palm/vrally.html

Bets are on
Despite its geeky reputation, online gaming seems to be growing in popularity. Apparently the number of female participants is rising, and with such consoles as the Dreamcast negating the need for expensive PCs, it is likely that playing games over LANs and the internet will become increasingly prevalent.

Last week's i-6 event, held at Newbury Racecourse, was the biggest so far in the online gaming series, with competitors bringing their PCs from all over the UK for three days of Quake and Counterstrike.

With most attendees so enthusiastic that they slept under their desks, it seems that Berkshire's pizza establishments are not the only ones keen for another event.

Crowd control
To soothe strained nerves this Christmas, the games website Flipside is opening a "male creche" at Lakeside Shopping Centre in Essex. Husbands and boyfriends will be able to play more than 40 games on the site while partners brave the retail hordes. The selection includes a mix of card and puzzle games, with prizes for winners. The creche runs from December 4-23.

Empire's herding game Sheep (see review below) was also released last week with John Noakes reliving his favourite "Shep" anecdotes at the launch.

fields.headline: One nation under the fairylights
fields.standfirst: Frank Tope has kept his ears sharp all year to find the best dance music to carry you through   the holiday season. Below, he picks out the highlights of clubland's Christmas parties
fields.trailText: Frank Tope has kept his ears sharp all year to find the best dance music to carry you through the holiday season. Below, he picks out the highlights of clubland's Christmas parties
fields.body:
If you read most music magazines you'll find their end-of-year round-ups trying oh-so-hard to convince you this has been a good year. But their hearts aren't in it. Where were the seismic cultural shifts? Where were the new Oasis/Fatboy Slim/ Spice Girls? Yes, the big picture has remained pretty stagnant in Y2K, but that's no reason not to wander into your local megastore. This year has seen the release of all manner of inspiring, exciting music, from obscure old funk tunes to jaw-breakingly hard house. If you holidayed in Ibiza or spent any Saturday (or Friday, or Thursday) night spinning around under the mirror ball, you could be forgiven for thinking this has been one of the best times dance music has had for years.

So what to buy your more fashionable music-loving friends for Christmas? And what to console yourself with in the sales after receiving that novelty tie? And what about Christmas dinner? Round my mum's every Christmas is "enlivened" by a seasonal impulse purchase of Frank/Bing/Cliff/Kurt's favourite Christmas songs. We wouldn't suggest that mum would thank you for a DJ Hell mix tape, but perhaps it's time you sought an alternative soundtrack to the annual nut roast carve-up.

Sasha/John Digweed
Communicate
INCredible, £15.99

They do have their critics, but it remains true that Sasha and John Digweed have been probably the most talented house DJs of the year. Fitting wispy, floaty moments next to head-down club shakers, this will restart any flagging Christmas party.

Various
New Orleans Funk
Soul Jazz, £11.99

After exhaustively researching the roots of reggae with their 100% Dynamite albums, Soul Jazz dig into the vaults of Southern funk for this spectacularly entertaining mix of old-fashioned party gumbo from Aaron Neville, the Meters, Allen Toussaint et al.

Ministry of Sound
Annual 2000
Ministry, £16.99

It wouldn't be Christmas without a Ministry of Sound Annual. Mixed by Judge Jules and Tall Paul, this has Spiller, Zombie Nation, Bob Sinclar and frankly every record you danced to in Ibiza. But probably not in Tuscany, eh Ewan?

Cream
Anthems 2001
Virgin, £15.99

The Mizzy's perennially big Northern rival in the your-memories-are-our-demographic stakes. With Moloko/Spiller/Darude and so forth on the firm they're playing on much the same pitch as their Southern rivals.

Various
Disco Not Disco
Strut, £12.99

Yes of course you were at The Loft in New York back in 1982. We all were, in our dreams. A mix of early 1980s rock-disco crossover oddities (Ian Dury, Yoko Ono) that have lasted well, due to the influence of oddballs like London's eccentric DJ genius Harvey.

Jazzanova
The Remixes
Compost

If all that thump-thump is giving you a migraine, this Berlin-based collective have the remedy. Moulding everything to their own wonky Latin-jazz tendency, this is eminently soothing, but can cause sudden games of "sardines" on discerning dancefloors.

Gabrielle
Rise Underground
Go Beat, £12.99

Rather than splashing out on any one of the UK garage round-ups, go for Gab's fine batch of remixes from all the biggest names on the garridge block: Stanton Warriors, Wookie, Zed Bias and all of 2001's biggest names poke an oar in.

Various
Back to Love 2
Hed Kandi, £15.99

If your idea of clubbing involves a purple hooded top and a lot of Soul II Soul records, relive your pre-mortgage years roaming the M25 with this bit of thirtysomething rave nostalgia. Unlike most other "classic" comps, the on-it selection indicates these fellows were really "there", matey.

Various
Old School Hip Hop from the Block Party Era
BGP

More nostalgia, this time with no pretences to actually being there - they can't even spell "skool" right! Still, first class hip hop edutainment (see, someone can spell) including rare joints from Spoonie G, Tanya Winley and - you have no idea what I'm going on about do you? Buy it on tape for your ghettoblaster.

Svek
After the Rain
Virgin, £14.99

Sweden isn't just a mythical land of liberal sexual morals, Abba and high suicide rates. In reality it's also the home of some wonderful dance music. Perfectly tuneful techno from Sunday Brunch, DJ INC and a whole lot of people I've never heard of but am hugely enjoying.

webTitle: 10 pop albums to buy for Christmas

fields.headline: Times of feast
fields.standfirst: John Aizlewood struggles to pick only 10 great pop albums to buy for Christmas
fields.trailText: John Aizlewood struggles to pick only 10 great pop albums to buy for Christmas
fields.body:
Musically, Britain has never had it so bad - or so they, whoever "they" may be, keep telling us. Yet such a despairing notion is flawed and not beyond refutation. Today, everything is roughly as it ever was; even the golden times were never truly golden. 1969 was the year of Abbey Road, but it was also the year of Jim Reeves. Punk was not in control in 1977, but Johnny Mathis and Slim Whitman were. And, in 1992, when the Orb topping the album charts appeared to mark a sea-change, its replacement by Neil Diamond suggested otherwise. All eras have had their Steps, their Robbie Williams and a fad such as boy bands. True, today's singles chart is chiefly pap, but this was the year that Eminem had a string of classic singles and U2 and David Gray flew traditional songwriting flags with gusto.

From opposite, but similarly committed, corners of the spectrum, Coldplay, Craig David and Iron Maiden were hugely successful with albums and tours; Radiohead made an average album but it went to number one in the US; and something as cutting edge as Badly Drawn Boy won the Mercury (it used to be M People, remember). Rightly, the US is Britain's musical overlord, but even there, what used to be the dark, dank, rebellious underground is now overground: Marilyn Manson and Korn are worldwide sellers, while a slew of bands, from Offspring to Limp Bizkit, are influenced by 2-Tone and third generation British punk. Nelly, Wyclef Jean and the indestructible LL Cool J showed US hip hop still thrills Britons. If this is famine, then the times of feast must have been truly special, had they existed in the first place. These 10 albums will make fine gifts, but the inclusion of a further 30 would not have sacrificed quality.

Attica Blues
Test, Don't Test
Higher Ground, £14.99

For kudos. Absurdly trendy to be sure, but that need not mean bad. In this case of sensuous hip hop, subtle beats and insistent melody, it means very good indeed.

Enya
A Day Without Rain
WEA, £14.99

For beauty. Samey on a solitary listen, but it soon blooms. Both tranquil and startling, often within the same song. In Flora's Secret it has the most achingly lovely song about open-air sex.

Wyclef Jean
The Ecleftic: 2 Sides II A Book
Columbia, £15.99

For catholicism. "All I hear is Fugee this, Fugee that," he trills, "where Fugees at?". By the end of this inspired behemoth, you really don't care. Features Kenny Rogers.

JJ72
JJ72
Lakota, £9.99

For guitars. When every other phase has passed, there will always be guitars. JJ72 use their guitars properly.

LL Cool J
GOAT: The Greatest of All Time
Def Jam, £12.99
For hubris. Still livelier, funnier and better than the young bucks. "Fuck all those niggas with their 9 or 10 hits," he sneers. Good man.

Magazine
Where the Power Is
Virgin, £9.99

For nostalgia. Virtually ignored during their 1978-81 pomp, in the way that inspiring, part-punk, part-electro, balding Mancunians were back then. Still wonderful, especially the line "I am angry, I am ill and I am as ugly as sin".

U2
All That You Can't Leave Behind
Island, £14.99

For dignity. Now U2 have dumped their unbecoming irony and settled into being a great rock band again, everything seems right with their world. Now, if only Bono would lose the silly sunglasses...

Sparks
Balls
Recognition, £13.99
For perseverance. Childishly titled, hopelessly packaged, but what wonders lie within. Thirty years on and the Maels have yet to stumble. The Calm Before the Storm is as good as anything bearing Sparks' name.

Sade
Lovers Rock
Epic, £14.99

For heartbreak. Rarely has pain sounded quite so exquisite and when Sade Adu sings "I'm crying everyone's tears" on King Of Sorrow, you actually believe her.

Vast
Music for People
Mushroom, £13.99

For grandeur. A Gothic symphony, its mighty songs, howled from the rooftops. Clever but never indulgent.

webTitle: UTV moves into radio by acquiring County Media

fields.headline: UTV moves into radio by acquiring County Media
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: ITV company Ulster Television has moved into radio by taking over Cork-based County Media, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
ITV company Ulster Television has made its first move into radio with the acquisition of Republic of Ireland outfit County Media.

The ITV company is paying IR£28.5m (£21.7m) for County Media, which operates three FM radio licences in and around Cork. In addition, UTV will take over County Media's £2.3m net debt.

John McCann, UTV managing director, said: "The acquisition of County Media is an important strategic development for UTV, which will further strengthen our multi-media offering throughout Ireland."

As well as the three radio stations, County Media owns a Dublin-based advertising sales house, Broadcast Media Sales, and weekly freesheet Inside Cork, which has a circulation of 20,000.

County Media managing director Colm O'Conaill and commercial director Ronan McManamy will remain at the company and continue to manage the radio broadcasting business.

UTV is financing the County Media deal with a combination of its own money and bank borrowing.

webTitle: Rush hour car bombing signals new cycle of violence in Israel

fields.headline: Rush hour car bombing signals new cycle of violence in Israel
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText:
A car bomb exploded with lethal force in the Jewish
heartland yesterday, leaving two dead, in an attack
that could drive the unending spiral of violence between
Israel and the Palestinians out of control.
fields.body:
A car bomb exploded with lethal force in the Jewish heartland yesterday, leaving two dead, in an attack that could drive the unending spiral of violence between Israel and the Palestinians out of control.

Minutes after the evening rush-hour attack on Hadera, a working class town 30 miles north of Tel Aviv, Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, was threatening reprisals against the West Bank and Gaza. "The state of Israel will get even with those who carried out the attack, and their messengers," he said in a statement.

A bus with about 20 passengers aboard took the brunt of the blast, which spewed burning chunks of metal and glass across Hadera's main shopping artery at about 5.20pm.

Police say the device, which was packed with nails, was detonated by remote control.

Witnesses said the bomb went off as the bus was pulling out of a stop, hurling it four metres in the air. More than 50 people were wounded.

The bus rolled down the road, and then lurched into a shopfront. At least eight other shop fronts were reduced to charred shells. Shock waves shattered the windows of shops across the wide road.

"There was a flash of light, smoke, and then an ear-shattering explosion," said Leor Janach, who had parked his car in front of the explosive- laden white Mitsubishi only minutes before.

Doctors at Hadera's Hille Yefe hospital said that at least 50 people were wounded, including an 18-month-old baby.

One of the dead was charred beyond recognition, said Mor Yashar, who was minding the till in his uncle's clothing shop when the blast shredded its frontage into splinters.

"A lady was lying [in the middle of the road] - I think she was without legs," he said. He stripped a shirt off a mannequin to make a tourniquet, and then threw clothes over the burnt corpse.

Such scenes, captured in gruesome detail by Israeli television, are bound to raise the pressure on Mr Barak - even while it remains uncertain which militant group is responsible for the bombing.

Even before the blast, the tension had escalated. In the morning, Israeli troops machinegunned two Palestinian cars near the Jewish settlement of Morag in the Gaza Strip, killing four men. There was no indication the victims were armed. The Palestinians threatened retaliation.

Within hours, Mr Arafat's Fatah militiamen were on the streets of Gaza City. "Fatah will not let this crime pass," loudspeakers blared. "We will direct our rifles against the Israeli soldiers."

There was no claim of responsibility for the blast, more powerful than the car bomb at an open-air market in West Jerusalem three weeks ago. But despite the furious denials from the Palestinian Authority, Mr Barak said Yasser Arafat's administration was responsible because it had freed Hamas and Islamic Jihad militants.

Last night, he summoned his security cabinet to discuss his next move, but previous Israeli reprisals - including the unleashing of 30 missiles on Gaza City on Monday - have only stoked the violence.

By nightfall, reports came in of Israeli tanks in the Jewish settlement of Psagot firing on the West Bank city of Ramallah, and of roadside bombs in the Gaza Strip.

"Only war, that is all we can do," said Pnina Lev, a neighbour of a restaurant worker killed in the blast. "We do not have to think about what America will say, or what the Arabs will say. We have the power, and we must do it."

As she stood at the gates of the hospital, propping up his wailing relatives, she said: "A man goes to work and doesn't come back home. We can't stand it any more. In the middle of Israel, we can't stand it."

webTitle: Big Brother Craig to help launch drink drive campaign

fields.headline: Big Brother Craig to help launch drink drive campaign
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Big Brother star Craig Phillips will help launch the Christmas drink drive campaign, reports Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Big Brother star Craig Phillips is backing the government's tough new Christmas drink drive campaign.

The star's own father died when he was hit by a drunk driver's car in 1984, when Craig was just 13.

He will help launch the £1.9m series of commercials from the Department of Transport & the Regions, which hit TV screens next week.

The ads will feature classic Christmas hits including Mistletoe and Wine and I Wish It Could Be Christmas Every Day juxtaposed with horrific scenes of drink drive accidents taken from real police footage.

The endline will read, "Drinking and driving is one Christmas tradition we can all do without. Think".

Pauline Clare, vice-chairman of the Association of Chief Police Officers, said: "You have the responsibility to think before you drink and drive and not combine the two.

"This responsibility doesn't just rest with the driver - society needs to reject drink driving as an option."

fields.headline: Searching questions
fields.standfirst: Sergey Brin is the president and co-founder of the search engine Google, which was set up in 1998
fields.trailText: Sergey Brin is the president and co-founder of the search engine Google, which was set up in 1998
fields.body:
You were late into the search engine game. Does that mean first mover advantage doesn't exist? We started research that led to Google back in 1995. At the time, search engines were primitive - reusing basic technologies that were used to search newspaper articles in order to search the web. Our work focused on building search technologies for hypertext, so in some sense we were the first mover.

Today, our index includes more than 1 billion web pages. We support 25 languages and Google can be used on a variety of wireless devices, handheld computers, and internet appliances. We handle more than 50 million searches per day. I think there is now a significant barrier to entry. I believe we are at a point analogous to the semiconductor industry 12 years ago.

How will search engines look different in five years' time? In five years I hope they will be able to return answers, not just documents. Some companies have tried to do that today but they do not work very well, which is why Google still returns documents. In the future, Google will be your interface to all the world's knowledge - not just web pages.

Is it possible for a search engine to make a profit and will there be a massive shake-out if they don't? The main obstacle to profitability is when the search engine does not have the best user experience and so it has to pay for users. Google does not pay for users and yet we grow very rapidly through word-of-mouth. Google's advertising and licensing businesses are showing strong growth and we expect to be profitable within one year. I believe there is an ongoing shakeout and many former search engines have now been bought or have diversified into other areas.

What do you use Google for? Any tips? I use Google for all of my information needs. As far as tips, when trying to phrase a query think about how documents with the answer are likely to discuss the topic.

What worries you about the direction the web is taking? Not enough attention is paid to the user experience, an area we pay close attention to. Many sites are more focused on glitz than on functionality.

Has the fall in dot.com shares still got a way to go? Over the past several years there have been many short-term corrections such as the recent one and the one around March and April of this year. Nevertheless, the overall value of the internet sector has continued to grow on a long-term scale. I think that value will continue to move around within the sector but I do not think the pie as a whole will shrink.

What are your favourite web sites (except Google) - for business and pleasure. I like Yahoo, Slashdot, shopper.com.

What are your must-have gadgets? Honestly, my must-have gadgets are a paper notepad and a pen!

fields.headline: Playing for very high stakes
fields.standfirst: Now that PlayStation 2 is finally hitting the shops, Neil McIntosh assesses its effect on the world of gaming and home entertainment
fields.trailText: Now that PlayStation 2 is finally hitting the shops, Neil McIntosh assesses its effect on the world of gaming and home entertainment
fields.body:
With the amount of attention the new Sony Playstation 2 has been receiving for most of this year, you could be forgiven for thinking it has been on sale for months. In fact, the successor to the best-selling games console ever goes on sale in Britain tomorrow, more than nine months after its launch in Japan.

But unless you got your reservation in early, don't expect to lay your hands on one this side of Christmas. Because of massive demand in Japan and the US, and component droughts, Sony has rationed the number on sale. Only around 165,000 machines will be available initially, down from an original estimate of 200,000. Some people who pre-booked their machines will not get them before Christmas, says Sony.

Its PR machine is deftly spinning, pointing out that the number of consoles going into homes is higher than for the original PlayStation. But the circumstances are different: there has never been a games machine so eagerly awaited. One million were sold in its first weekend in Japan.

Why? It helps being the successor to the PlayStation 1, which has snatched 60% of the world's games console market. It also helps that its technical specification eclipses anything else on the market. Sega's Dreamcast - which has seen a rise in sales because of Sony's supply problems - runs on a chip with a speed of 200MHz. It can draw 3 million polygons per second, this being a key indicator of a console's power, and consequently the quality of its graphics.

The PlayStation 2 has a 300Mhz chip. But the biggest difference is in the number of polygons drawn in a second: a cool 75 million. So it can display a richer variety of colours, and smoother graphics. It can also play DVDs, and is expected to lie at the centre of any Sony attempts to create home networks of electronic equipment.

But some gamers have criticised the quality of the first selection of PS2 games. Programmers are struggling with the complexities of producing good-looking graphics for it. At the heart of the problems is its "anti-aliasing" capabilities which are supposed to smooth out graphics before they are displayed. On some titles, like Ridge Racer V from Namco, this feature has not worked well - particularly embarrassing for a console being sold on the power of its graphics.

Sony is keen to play down these problems as early glitches, and promises supplies will flow more freely in the New Year. They may need to: Sony's launch is only the opening salvo in a fierce four-way battle for console supremacy.

Already established is Sega's Dreamcast. There is also a new machine from gaming veteran Nintendo, the GameCube - due next year. And Microsoft is getting ready to enter the fray.

Its Xbox, due to appear in the US towards the end of next year, will have a 733 MHz chip able to draw a staggering 150 million polygons a second. And it should launch with a healthy software library; Microsoft is making great efforts to make it simpler to write for.

This will be the last Christmas where Sony has all the hype to itself.

fields.headline: Dame for a laugh
fields.standfirst: She is impish, eccentric, mischievous and talented - and even the Queen has noticed. Alex Clark pays tribute to Beryl Bainbridge
fields.trailText: She is impish, eccentric, mischievous and talented - and even the Queen has noticed. Alex Clark pays tribute to Beryl Bainbridge
fields.body:
When Beryl Bainbridge was created a Dame in the Queen's birthday honours list this year, she was quick to press the self-deprecation button that has endeared her to so many. "I don't even know how to spell DAME," she told one interviewer, "I didn't even get my school certificate."

She flashed her lack of educational credentials again when she was invested at Buckingham Palace this week, but the truth is Bainbridge is fooling nobody. Missing school cert notwithstanding, she is more than equipped to withstand elevation to the ranks of literary grande dame.

Quite apart from her prodigious talents as a novelist, Bainbridge is blessed with an impeccable sense of theatricality, an impish temperament that has got her into more than one scrape.

Last year, as she collected the WH Smith Literary Award for her Booker-shortlisted novel Master Georgie, she brought down the wrath of the tabloids when, in a moment of possibly aperitif-related candour, she appeared to call for compulsory elocution lessons and the eradication of regional accents.

"After much soul-searching as to how and why I came up with such a sensible proposition," she later wrote, "I can only suppose that, it being Tuesday, I was looking forward to the midweek episode of Brookside."

At the time, one suspected her remarks were in part serious comment on the advantages of literacy and articulacy, in part a piece of tongue-in-cheek mischief-making. Having been present at the moment of the gaffe, I recall that Bainbridge also naughtily tweaked arts minister Alan Howarth's tie as he attempted to present her with a cheque and pose for a photograph at the same time. He remained poker-faced, but the assembled company giggled appreciatively.

Bainbridge's willingness to assume the mantle of Lady of Misrule does not diminish her literary achievements. Five times shortlisted for the Booker Prize, she has always managed to avoid looking remotely sour in defeat; when the camera fell on her at this year's ceremony, she was grinning cheerfully as Margaret Atwood's acceptance speech touched on the perils of bridesmaid-dom.

One cannot imagine Bainbridge's much-documented eccentricity - encapsulated by frequent references to the stuffed bison in her hallway - will pose a great threat to her career as a Dame. After all, she's in good company. Neither of two recently deceased recipients of the honour, Iris Murdoch and Barbara Cartland, was particularly renowned for her straightforward behaviour.

Even before the onset of Alzheimer's, Murdoch spent most of her days squirrelled away in companionable seclusion with husband John Bayley, emerging only to deliver messy, Byzantine manuscripts to her publishers in a tatty carrier bag. Dame Barbara added to her seemingly endless oeuvre in a haze of pink, pekes and royal jelly before finally being laid to rest in a cardboard coffin.

Nor does an aura of strait-laced conformity surround extant Dames. From her Tuscan diaspora, Muriel Spark, now 82, continues to produce slender works of wickedness, the latest being a fictionalisation of Lord Lucan's later life.

Over the past few years, she has waged a public feud with her son, attacked English hyprocrisy, dismissed a return to Edinburgh on the grounds that it is too provincial and suffered the macabre death of her five dogs through strychnine poisoning. Her latest visit to these shores was delayed by blockading French fishermen; unsurprisingly, she got through.

Perhaps the Dame most closely associated with the literary establishment is Antonia Byatt, whose combination of high-minded erudition and occasional, darting forays into populism led not only to the Booker-winning, bestselling Possession but also to her attendance at the England v Germany match in Euro 96. Only Dame Antonia could describe the progress of Gascoigne, Pearce, Seaman et al with reference to Wagner, Peter Pan and Monet.

Bainbridge's own passions range from Dr Johnson, the subject of her forthcoming novel, to painting, her children and grandchildren and, unrepentantly, smoking. She was apparently much impressed by the provision of ashtrays at the Palace. Quite probably, she didn't have cause to correct their accents, either.

webTitle: Labour fears low turnout in byelections

fields.headline: Labour fears low turnout in byelections
fields.standfirst: Special report: elections 2000
fields.trailText:
Voters are going to the polls in three parliamentary byelections today, in what could prove to be the last big test of the government's popularity before the next general election.
Special report: elections 2000
fields.body:
Voters are going to the polls in three parliamentary byelections today, in what could prove to be the last big test of the government's popularity before the next general election.

Polling takes place for Commons seats at Glasgow Anniesland, Preston and West Bromwich West - all three safe Labour seats which should be held by the party despite fears of low turnouts.

But any sharp slumps in Labour support or signs of a Tory revival could delay a widely expected plan for the prime minister, Tony Blair, to go to the country next May.

There is also a byelection for the Scottish parliament seat at Glasgow Anniesland where Labour is expected to face a strong challenge from the Scottish Nationalists.

The byelections are caused by the deaths of two MPs and the decision of Betty Boothroyd to step down from parliament when she resigned as speaker.

In Glasgow Anniesland it was Donald Dewar's death from a brain haemorrhage which forced the first ever byelection for both the Westminster seat and the Scottish parliament. The so-called "double header" will mean voters will be faced with two ballot papers when they enter the polling booths to choose their new MP and MSP.

In the traditional Labour stronghold of Preston the death of leftwing MP Audrey Wise caused the vote. There has been controversy surrounding the selection last month of 41-year-old Blairite Mark Hendrick, a former MEP and college lecturer, to fight the Lancashire seat after he defeated Wise's daughter Valerie for the nomination.

In West Bromwich West, Ms Boothroyd stood unopposed by the major parties in the last election and was returned with a 15,000 majority. In 1992, when she fought the seat as the Labour candidate against the Liberal Democrats and Conservatives, she commanded a safe 6,000 majority in the traditional Labour area.

The results are expected to be announced early tomorrow.

fields.headline: Out of the shadows
fields.standfirst: Jamie O'Neill has just won a £1m book deal. He is being compared to James Joyce. So why has he spent 10 years as a night porter? And what about his love affair with Russell Harty? Stephen Moss reports
fields.trailText: Jamie O'Neill has just won a £1m book deal. He is being compared to James Joyce. So why has he spent 10 years as a night porter? And what about his love affair with Russell Harty? Stephen Moss reports.
fields.body:
'Impecunious night porter gets £1m for novel" is one of those rags-to-riches publishing stories the press loves. Bus drivers, teenage students, teachers who hit the jackpot: it could be you. But Jamie O'Neill, this week's literary lottery winner, is even more interesting than that. Who knows, his book might even live up to the hype.

Not, though, his normally sensible agent Giles Gordon's hype. The book - called, significantly, At Swim, Two Boys - is, Gordon says modestly, "a natural successor to James Joyce, Flann O'Brien and Samuel Beckett". Simon & Schuster clearly agrees and has paid £250,000-plus for the right to publish the book next September. Worldwide rights and film options are expected to boost O'Neill's earnings to the magical seven figures.

How does he feel about being branded the new Joyce? "Very nice, isn't it," he says, before giving his true opinion. "It's very unfortunate really. It's just asking for somebody to shoot you." "Giles is a good man, he'll protect you," I blather. "But they won't shoot him ," O'Neill counters.

O'Neill is a laconic, softly spoken 39-year-old. He lives in a rented flat near the Hogarth roundabout in west London, and for the past 10 years has earned £200 a week as a night porter at the Cassel hospital in west London, a residential hospital for mentally ill patients.

He chose the job specifically to be able to write at night - his role was to man reception and keep an eye on the hospital - and when we met he was wondering why members of the hospital trust had been trying to call him. "I don't think they're too pleased to know that somebody's been writing on their time," he says. "It was a bit like getting a bursary from the NHS."

For someone who has just hit the jackpot, he is pleasingly phlegmatic. He will be giving up his job and going back to live in his native Ireland - he was born in Dun Laoghaire, near Dublin - but had been planning to do that anyway. In any case, it isn't the usual unknown-writer-gets-fortune-for-first-book tale.

In his late 20s he had two novels, titled Disturbance and Kilbrack, published by Weidenfeld. "If you ask me how did they do, they didn't," he volunteers. "The woman who bought the novels left, so they were orphaned." He more or less disowns them now, and says he can't even bear to open Kilbrack.

However, I did open the book and was struck by the handsome, dark-haired youth on the back cover, and by the jaunty blurb describing a life spent going to festivals and eating out in restaurants. It didn't sound much like the quiet, reclusive, almost nocturnal figure in front of me. I soon discovered why.

O'Neill, who had come across from Ireland for a fortnight in 1982 but never gone back, was chat show host Russell Harty's partner for six years before his sudden death in 1988. They lived together in Harty's cottage in Giggleswick, Yorkshire, and the shock of his death overwhelmed O'Neill.

The experience was made worse by press intrusion - his parents back in Ireland only discovered their son was gay when they saw his photograph on the front of the Sunday Mirror - and by the determination of the Harty family to get O'Neill out of the cottage as quickly as possible. It was a disturbing experience for the 27-year-old, and one he says he is only now coming to terms with.

"I was in therapy for a while. I still have vivid dreams about Russell. One of the problems was that I didn't just lose a share of my heart; I lost my whole way of life." Harty had encouraged O'Neill's writing and read his manuscripts; by 1988 he had secured a two-book deal with Weidenfeld and the novels were published in the following two years. But then, grieving for Harty and alone in London, he found he could no longer write, parted company with both agent and publisher, and took the job at the Cassel.

The important thing about this book, he says, is that there was no pressure to impress anyone. Clearly, living in the home of the older Harty, he had wanted to prove himself a writer: not to Harty himself, but to his friends, some of whom saw O'Neill as a hanger-on. "I had been published and I didn't feel the push to finish this book, so I took time over it. I didn't have to prove anything."

In fact, he took 10 years. The book tells of the love of two 16-year-old boys caught up in the Easter Rising in Dublin in 1916, and O'Neill makes an explicit connection between nationalism and sexual awakening.

"I feel that in the process of writing the book, I learned how to write and how to research. When I had finished it, I felt that I would like to start all over again and do it properly." Not an opinion shared by his publisher, Ian Chapman, who has pronounced it "a painfully beautiful book" and "the most exciting typescript I have read in the past 10 years".

O'Neill's efforts to get the period detail right in the book were unstinting, and his flat is filled with books about the rebellion. "I possibly got bogged down in the research," he says. "I read a book by Arthur Koestler, and talking about writing Spartacus he said that he knew he was getting bogged down in research because he had two thick files on Roman underwear. I was getting a bit like that. But it's one of those things where you don't have to convince the reader so much as yourself. You have to know what was going on, and when you have that confidence you can leave it out."

He finished the book in September and passed it to David Marcus, a literary scout in Ireland, who in turn sent it to Giles Gordon at Curtis Brown. Gordon, highly regarded and not usually given to hyperbole, called it "the first major novel I've encountered in typescript since Vikram Seth's A Suitable Boy in 1992," and sold the book almost immediately to Simon & Schuster. Ironically, while he was still writing it, O'Neill had pre-sold the novel to Duckworth for £400, but bought it back for the same sum when his editor left.

O'Neill's is a remarkable story of perseverance. He gives the impression that while being published matters, writing matters more. "I'm only really happy when I'm writing," he says. "I've always been writing something." He was not close to his parents, nor to his siblings (none of whom knew he was gay), and perhaps needed the security of imagined worlds. Harty, in life and in death, had a profound influence on him. His death interrupted his writing, but the trauma also changed O'Neill as a person and deepened the work. He says one of the characters in the book embodies aspects of Harty.

Referring to Flann O'Brien in the title of your book, and having a publisher determined to proclaim your literary pedigree, is courting danger, but O'Neill is alert to it. "You don't consciously follow anyone. But it is quite difficult for an Irish writer to have Joyce standing there. He is leaning over you the whole time, and it is daunting. You get around it by being truthful to yourself."

Ironically, while he was still writing it, O'Neill had pre-sold the novel to Duckworth for £400, but bought it back for the same sum when his editor left. O'Neill's is a remarkable story of perseverance. He gives the impression that while being published matters, writing matters more. "I'm only really happy when I'm writing," he says. "I've always been writing something." He was not close to his parents, nor to his siblings (none of whom knew he was gay), and perhaps needed the security of imagined worlds. Harty, in life and in death, had a profound influence on him. His death interrupted his writing, but the trauma also changed O'Neill as a person and deepened the work. He says one of the characters in the book embodies aspects of Harty. Referring to Flann O'Brien in the title of your book, and having a publisher determined to proclaim your literary pedigree, is courting danger, but O'Neill is alert to it. "You don't consciously follow anyone. But it is quite difficult for an Irish writer to have Joyce standing there. He is leaning over you the whole time, and it is daunting. You get around it by being truthful to yourself."

webTitle: Counting the carbon cost of the Hague

fields.headline: Counting the carbon cost of the Hague
fields.standfirst: Director of Best Foot Forward, Craig Simmons, works out the carbon emissions of the Hague delegates during the last two weeks
fields.trailText: In December 1997 a group of 36 dedicated environmentalists from 14 countries decided to shun the use of aircraft and make their way to the COP3 Climate Change Convention in Kyoto using train, boat and bike. Their detailed calculations showed that by doing so they saved around 110 tonnes of greenhouse gas emissions.
fields.body:
In December 1997 a group of 36 dedicated environmentalists from 14 countries decided to shun the use of aircraft and make their way to the COP3 Climate Change Convention in Kyoto using train, boat and bike. Their detailed calculations showed that by doing so they saved around 110 tonnes of greenhouse gas emissions.

COP6 in the Hague this week has enticed, according to news reports, some 5,500 delegates and observers to Holland. If it is generously assumed that one-third of these made the journey by train or coach, a further third flew short-haul, and the remainder long-haul, then the carbon dioxide emissions attributable to transport can be estimated as around 5,000 tonnes.

Carbon dioxide is not the only greenhouse gas. High altitude air travel, in particular, leads to other damaging emissions. These are often accounted in terms of the equivalent amount of CO2 that would be needed to generate the same global warming potential. Adding in this additional impact raises the carbon dioxide 'cost' of travelling to the Convention to around 15,000 tonnes. To put this figure in perspective, this is equivalent to the emissions arising from the production of 22 million copies of The Guardian.

Apart from travel, the accommodation choices of conference-goers can also affect their carbon budget. Luxury hotels, with their daily clean laundry, gourmet cuisine, over-heated suites and seemingly endless supplies of small packaged toiletries, can consume vast amounts of energy. A typical night at a top hotel will check in at around 90kWh of electricity and 300kWh of gas. This is somewhere around eight times more than one would typically consume at home. Assuming, rather conservatively, that only one-third of delegates opt for luxury accommodation, one-third for more modest lodgings and the remainder for a friend's sofa (or in the case of the Mozambique delegates a shared room at the youth hostel), then the resulting CO2 emissions are close to 2,000 tonnes.

Taking all greenhouse gases into account the average Convention attendee has an expenditure of over 3 tonnes for the fortnight. This is 50% above what the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) recommends as sustainable annual CO2 emissions.

COP6 is only part of the picture - past Climate Conferences have also added to the environmental costs of negotiation. But isn't it necessary to break a few eggs to make some omelettes, you might ask? What other alternative is there for international delegates?

Well, the scale of impacts can at least be put into perspective by looking at other ways in which the Conference funds might have been invested to reduce emissions.

A rough calculation puts the cost of the just the accommodation and travel elements of the Hague Convention at £10m. For this cost it would be possible to install 8 giant wind generators, such as that at Swaffham in Norfolk, providinq sufficient electricity for 24,000 households displacing 35,000 tonnes of CO2 or 5 Hagues each, and every, year.

Of course, it would be wisest to invest in 'negawatts' - energy saving measures. According to the DETR, to save a tonne of domestic CO2 emissions costs around £100 to £150. Our £10m pounds would therefore have the potential to save up to 100,000 tonnes of CO2 or 14 Hagues each year.

What such back-of-the-envelope calculations start to reveal is the true cost, in environmental terms, of massive international gatherings such as COP6. It must be said, however, that such emissions will pale into insignificance if countries really do meet the targets set out in the Kyoto Protocol.

Craig Simmons is co-founder and Director of sustainability consultancy Best Foot Forward. His new book, Sharing Nature's Interest (with Nicky Chambers and Mathis Wackernagel) is published 29th November by Earthscan.

fields.headline: Campaign round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: November 24.
fields.trailText: November 24: Publicis has been picked by Coca-Cola to handle its pan-European branding assignments.
fields.body:
Publicis has been picked by Coca-Cola to handle its pan-European branding assignments.

Jerry Hill, the former chief executive of United News & Media sales company TSMS, has been appointed as new group chief executive of Initiative Media UK.

Kingston Interactive Television is looking for an agency to create a £25m advertising blitz as it moves to take on more established players like Open.

Christmas songs combined with scenes of road crash carnage will be used in TV ads to reinforce the government's message not to drink and drive over the festive period.

Ford of Europe has returned lead agency status to Ogilvy & Mather just two years after it handed the bulk of its business to Young & Rubicam. Meanwhile, Y&R is denying it has won the Land Rover account.

Publicis Dialog has hired Mike Cavers as its creative director.

J Walter Thompson has plans to acquire Manchester-based agency Cheetham Bell, with a view to merging it with its own Manchester agency.

M&C Saatchi will handle the UK launch of Time Inc's In Style magazine.

The US soft drinks manufacturer, T&T, has negotiated a £1.5m deal to sponsor ITV's new real-life soap opera, Popstars, to launch the T&T brand in the UK.

Broadcasters including BSkyB and NTL are launching an initiative under the working title AdCo that is aimed at tackling the issue of interactive TV advertising.

fields.headline: Capital gains
fields.standfirst: James Richardson on Roma, the pacesetters who have set Serie A alight
fields.trailText: James Richardson on Roma, the pacesetters who have set Serie A alight
fields.body:
Veni, vidi, vici. Barely seven weeks into the season, AS Roma are making a run for the title, and popular opinion says it's alea jacta est for their rivals. Here in the capital, fevers run high while bunting stocks dwindle.

Now, if it sounds a little early for the scudetto boat to have sailed, consider this: Roma are already six points up on Lazio and Juventus, seven ahead of Parma, eight of Inter and a whopping nine clear of Milan. Roma have scored 12 times in their last three away games and won all three, which from a side that only claimed four away victories in the whole of last season speaks volumes.

The best-looking figures this side of Baywatch don't end there: the club haven't started this well since 1983, and haven't scored this many goals - 19 in seven games - for 40 years.

Impressive, no? Roma's long-suffering fans certainly think so. And since they've been starved of these kind of earth-shattering numbers for decades, naturally they're making the most of things. Hundreds of fans flocked to the city's airport to welcome the homecoming team last Sunday night, and this was just from a league trip to Verona. Tune to the capital's radio stations meanwhile and there's a treat in store: We Are The Champions, with goals from Totti and Batistuta sampled over the top. Let's hope 5ive never read this.

Speaking of over the top, here's one of the week's most fascinating statistics: since Serie A introduced three points for a win, the eventual Scudetto winner has never been more than that sum behind at this stage of the season. Looking at the table Roma's competition thus is Udinese, Atalanta and Bologna. No wonder they're celebrating.

With the 27 games still to go clearly now irrelevant, the question is: is there any room left on the bandwagon for the papers? Certainly. "Roma," they gratefully assure us, "are the heirs to the mid-90's Milan - the side that put the wind up footballers the length and breadth of Europe". Roma certainly have the same coach - Fabio Capello - and there's a possible Van Basten / Batistuta parallel too (although Bati actually scores more regularly) but that's as far as it holds.

That Milan team had Baresi, Tassotti, Costacurta and Maldini at the back - the Giallorossi don't. And like the aforementioned Baywatch types, they may be loaded up front but they're dangerously exposed behind - as we'll see when their calendar starts getting a little tougher. Until now the only big team they've faced has been Inter, and they lost to them 2-0.

But I come to praise Roma, not to bury them. Beyond the hype, in the weakest Serie A line-up for many a year, they look by far the most convincing candidates. And thanks to another summer spending spree, they've got Gabriel Batistuta.

Back in the summer, £23m for the 31-year-old raised plenty of eyebrows, but club president Sensi's gift of the Gab now looks an inspired choice. After eight fruitless years in Florence, Gabriel's caught the scudetto scent at last and is playing like a man possessed: eight goals in just five league matches, and that's while playing with a crook knee. Even if the rest of the side had spent the last decade collecting trophies (and they haven't ), the ageing Argentine's pride alone would be enough to ensure they stay hungry right till week 34.

Roma fans can expect their team to get taken down a notch or two in the coming months, but they should keep that bunting handy. For the team, it's above all Carpe Diem. After all, in the words of ex-Roma manager Carlo Mazzone, now at Brescia; "If Roma don't win it this season, they never will."

fields.headline: Press Gazette round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: November 24.
fields.trailText: November 24: The new owner of Express Newspapers, Richard Desmond, has pledged support for the Star.
fields.body:
The new owner of Express Newspapers, Richard Desmond, has pledged support for the Star, which he says will be groomed to take on the Sun.

Hello! publisher Sally Cartwright has said that any relationship between the Express and Hello! is over, following the purchase of the newspaper by OK! proprietor Northern & Shell.

Journalists' lives are being put at risk by mercenaries who go to war zones disguised as journalists, it was claimed at last week's Newsworld conference. Meanwhile, ITN editor-in-chief Richard Tait has called on the government to do more to protect journalists' safety after a series of high-profile killings.

John McVicar, the celebrity Punch columnist, is predicting a "staff meltdown" following the departure of editor James Steen. Mr McVicar and a number of other staff are reported to be on the point of leaving the magazine.

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner.
fields.body:
Costly death

Forget the high cost of living: Jonathan Lawson, an Anglican priest in Sunderland, is dismayed by the high cost of dying in his city. "A single grave is £493.50; in neighbouring Gateshead it's £175," he says. "A double grave is £641.20 in Sunderland; in Gateshead it's £175. And if you live outside Sunderland, burial costs are £987 for a single grave and £1,282 for a double, whereas in Gateshead both cost £350. My parish is in an area of significant social deprivation and this sum is a huge burden."

 Sunderland claims that its fees are lower than the national average and cites league tables compiled by the chartered institute of public finance and accountancy as proof. However, its fees have more than doubled since the institute's last report, whereas Gateshead's have remained much the same.

'Luxury' wheelchair

Most of us understand that if you fly with low-cost airlines you dispense with the "luxuries" of mainstream rivals. But when does a luxury become a necessity? Patience Owen of London suffers from multiple sclerosis and, although she does not use a wheelchair, she finds it difficult to walk.

So when she flew with Ryanair she asked to be conveyed to and from the plane in an airport wheelchair. To her horror she discovered that she would be charged £48 for the privilege. "No other airline charges for this," she says. "Ryanair told me it's because it's a no-frills operation. Since when has a wheelchair been a frill?"

 A spokeswoman from Ryanair explained that the company wouldn't dream of charging for wheelchair users but that "if a passenger is not a wheelchair user and is therefore capable of walking to the airplane, we would expect that passenger to walk". Wheelchairs are hired from an airport contractor and the fee goes to them, not Ryanair.

Other low-cost airlines say they absorb the charges themselves, however, and the air transport users council says that Ryanair is the only company it has had complaints about on this issue.

Corked off

When Sally James of London hired a party venue at the Barbican she was astonished to be told she would be charged corkage plus VAT if she brought her own alcohol. "How can they charge us that for something they haven't paid VAT on themselves?" she asks.

 All too easily, says customs and excise. "If the caterers are employing somebody to take the corks out that is a service, and services are subject to VAT," says a spokeswoman.

TV lifespans

As technology becomes more sophisticated, the life expectancy of household gadgets seems to diminish. Louise Story of London was told by a Comet salesman that new TVs are no longer built to last more than five years, and she'd be wise to buy a five-year warranty. A salesman in Currys, however, said that new TVs should last 20 years and quality was better than ever.

 Salesmen will try anything to get you to buy an expensive insurance policy because retailers can earn more from them than the electrical goods. But do new TVs really have such a miserable life-span? Of the three manufacturers Consumer contacted, only Panasonic replied to say there's no specific lifespan for a TV. "It depends on how often it is switched on and off, how often the channels are changed, the temperature of the room and whether it's coal or gas heating," said a spokeswoman.
