fields.headline: Frederick Wiseman: Welfare
fields.trailText: Wiseman's camera simply looks and records... We may see everything through his eyes, but we are at liberty to form our own opinions... We should be grateful for his essential lack of bias. It's one way to get at some sort of truth.
fields.body:
For over 30 years Frederick Wiseman has trained his camera on American life and institutions, having no obvious polemical stance but merely observing, sometimes in minute detail, what he finds. He shoots for many hours, so that his subjects begin to ignore the camera, and edits the collected material for much longer. The surprise is that what he finds is often nothing like what we, or even he, might expect.

Some have criticised his even-handedness, remembering Titicut Follies, his first effort, about life in a prison for the criminally insane. That became mired in litigation with the state authorities and gave Wiseman the reputation of a controversial attacker of the system.

Thereafter, his films went less obvious ways, neither courting notoriety nor seeking to confirm or even deny expectations. Partly because of this, his work is of great value, almost as slices of the times we live in or, as he has called it, "a form of natural history".

His masterpiece, perhaps, is Welfare, which looks at the New York benefits system from the point of view of the officials administering it and the claimants crowding their offices. The result is both mind-boggling and eye-opening. Mind-boggling because this is clearly a bureaucracy pitted against people least fit to deal with it; eye-opening because those running it are not inhuman and frequently do everything they can to help.

Any half-hour of this long film provides revelations, like the girl claimant who is told by her interviewer that he's looking after two and a half million people and that if a couple of thousand don't get what's due them, he's doing a good job. Or the German immigrant who says that God only helps you if he wants to and that, under the circumstances, "I'd better look for a nice place to hang myself."

"Are you attending a clinic?" an officer asks a woman who says she's been ill.
"No."
"Why not?"
"Because I have no money," comes the utterly logical riposte. And without a note from a doctor, she can't get a dollar.

An ex-druggie who got himself work, an apartment and a dog, then lost everything but the dog, is told he can have a room in a hostel. He objects that he can't take his dog there. But the official says: "We're giving assistance to you, not your dog."
"I don't say it's right," says a man who admits stealing food. "I say it's necessary. . . I'm waiting for something that will never come: justice."

Every small tragedy is a large one for some people. Even the police who patrol the offices get involved. They are mostly black and there are racists about, but they keep their cool, even when told they breed like rabbits and will cause blood on the streets one day if they're not wiped out first.

Throughout all this, Wiseman's camera simply looks and records. It doesn't have to do anything else. It's the editing that's important. fields.bodyText: For over 30 years Frederick Wiseman has trained his camera on American life and institutions, having no obvious polemical stance but merely observing, sometimes in minute detail, what he finds. He shoots for many hours, so that his subjects begin to ignore the camera, and edits the collected material for much longer. The surprise is that what he finds is often nothing like what we, or even he, might expect. Some have criticised his even-handedness, remembering Titicut Follies, his first effort, about life in a prison for the criminally insane. That became mired in litigation with the state authorities and gave Wiseman the reputation of a controversial attacker of the system. Thereafter, his films went less obvious ways, neither courting notoriety nor seeking to confirm or even deny expectations. Partly because of this, his work is of great value, almost as slices of the times we live in or, as he has called it, "a form of natural history". His masterpiece, perhaps, is Welfare, which looks at the New York benefits system from the point of view of the officials administering it and the claimants crowding their offices. The result is both mind-boggling and eye-opening. Mind-boggling because this is clearly a bureaucracy pitted against people least fit to deal with it; eye-opening because those running it are not inhuman and frequently do everything they can to help. Any half-hour of this long film provides revelations, like the girl claimant who is told by her interviewer that he's looking after two and a half million people and that if a couple of thousand don't get what's due them, he's doing a good job. Or the German immigrant who says that God only helps you if he wants to and that, under the circumstances, "I'd better look for a nice place to hang myself." webTitle: Safeway gains customers after dropping TV ads

fields.headline: Safeway gains customers after dropping TV ads
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Dropping its TV ad campaign has helped attract new customers to Safeway stores. Claire Cozens reports.
fields.body:
Safeway's decision not to spend millions on high-profile television advertising has helped attract more than 1m new customers to its stores since March, the company said today.

The supermarket giant decided last year to axe its long-running £12m TV campaign starring toddler Harry and spend the money instead on price promotions and local advertising.

Stores now send out leaflets carrying details of that week's deals to around 9m homes a week.

Carlos Criado-Perez, Safeway's chief executive, today announced a 10% rise in pre-tax profits to £166m, saying the results proved the viability of the controversial plan.

Safeway, the UK's fourth biggest supermarket chain, was once viewed as a lost cause by rivals Tesco and Sainsbury. But the decision to focus on price appears to have turned the supermarket's fortunes around.

webTitle: Losses at sports news service Teamtalk

fields.headline: Losses reported at sports news service Teamtalk
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Leeds-based sports service Teamtalk.com reports losses despite increased user uptake, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Teamtalk.com, the Leeds-based sports news internet service, has reported widening losses despite a massive increase in its user base.

The site, which attracts a fanatically loyal fanbase, said its number of users had more than doubled to 2m between June and September.

Teamtalk, which launched in 1988, is best known for its coverage of international and domestic football news. It also tracks horseracing, tennis and golf and has a dedicated ladies football service, womensoccer.com.

Over 60 in-house journalists and 225 freelancers around the world provide content.

Teamtalk has been an acquisitive six months for the group, which has added 12 new sites to its portfolio and spent £10.7m on US football site internetsoccer.com.

However, Teamtalks's growth, which includes ambitions for the untapped US market, led to first-half losses of £1.8m, against a deficit of £0.3m for the same period last year. The group, which floated in April, has healthy cash reserves of £41m.

Turnover doubled from £2.55m to £5.1m on the back of a boost on syndication sales. The group has links with a broad range of companies, including BT's mobile phone arm and internet giant AOL, Cellnet and bookies Ladbrokes.

Bill Wilson, Teamtalk chairman, said: "These interim results clearly demonstrate the significant progress that the group has made since its IPO in becoming the leading sports content provider.

"The quality of our proprietary sports content is driving revenue and network statistics, both of which have shown good growth over the period."

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours are refusing to make Eye Contact with 'curvy' Kelly Brook's red-hot stage play
fields.trailText: Leeds are planning to top their £18m signing of Rio Ferdinand by splashing out £20m-rated Sunderland striker Kevin Phillips, reports the Daily Mirror.
fields.body:
Leeds are planning to top their £18m signing of Rio Ferdinand by splashing out £20m-rated Sunderland striker Kevin Phillips, reports the Daily Mirror.

Meanwhile West Ham are about to splash some of their cash. The Sun reports that Harry Redknapp has already agreed a £2.5m fee for Liverpool's Rigobert Song - and predict the Cameroon skipper will be unveiled at Upton Park today. And the Hammers' spending might not end there either. According to Planet Football, Perugia's Mauro Milanese and Paris Saint Germain's Sylvain Distin are being watched by club scouts.

Brazilian midfielder Edu could finally complete a £6m move to Arsenal in January. Yesterday he told the Corinthians website that he is confident a deal will go ahead, insisting: "My future is with Arsenal."

Middlesbrough have lined up Hibs manager Alex McLeish to replace Bryan Robson, Teamtalk reports. They quote local newspaper reports, which say that Boro chairman Steve Gibson has finally run out of patience with Robson after their dismal run of defeats.

Planet Football claims that Manchester United, Chelsea and Fulham are all interested in 22-year-old AZ Alkmaar striker Robin Nelisse, who has scored 10 goals so far this season.

Blackburn have made a £2m offer for Sheffield United striker Marcus Bent, reports the Star. However they say that Blades manager Neil Warnock is holding for £3m.

Aston Villa manager John Gregory is ready to sell Israeli international defender Najwan Ghrayib. "He has not lived up to expectations," admitted the Villa manager. "If someone comes along, we can't stand in his way, we'll try and make it happen."

Bradford striker Dean Saunders has been offered a three month loan deal with Dundee United.

Out of favour Manchester City striker Gareth Taylor is considering a move to Stockport.

fields.headline: New count setback for Gore
fields.trailText: Florida's largest county last night abandoned a recount of votes, claiming it could not meet a new timetable set by the state supreme court. The move dramatically reversed the chances of Al Gore gathering enough votes to defeat George W Bush.
fields.body:
Florida's largest county last night abandoned a recount of votes, claiming it could not meet a new timetable set by the state supreme court. The move dramatically reversed the chances of Al Gore gathering enough votes to defeat George W Bush.

Mr Gore immediately signalled an appeal against the decision by members of the supervisory canvassing board in Miami-Dade county, where officials had recounted about a fifth of their 654,000 votes before throwing in their hand amid noisy scenes in Miami.

But it was a day of unpleasant surprises for both men. Mr Bush's vice-presidential running mate, Dick Cheney, was admitted to a Washington hospital with chest pains and last night underwent a minor operation. Doctors said they had inserted a stent - tiny tube - into one of Mr Cheney's arteries to prevent it from closing.

The former defence secretary, 59, has a history of heart disease and bypass surgery.

Mr Gore's chances of capturing the White House were also hanging on yet another key legal ruling, this time in Palm Beach county, where a judge was to decide whether to allow "dimpled chad" voting papers to be included in the recount.

Meanwhile, the Bush camp was weighing the chances of taking the Florida supreme court ruling to the US supreme court in Washington, confirming how much was at stake. But the chances of success were viewed sceptically by independent legal experts. The federal supreme court was thought unlikely to want to intervene in a matter of state law.

The new mood of litigiousness on the Bush side was underscored by fresh court filings on the Texas governor's behalf in Tallahassee, where a court was asked to order all postal votes cast before November 7 by members of the armed services to be included in the count.

Meanwhile, Mr Gore's lieutenant William Daley tried to steady his side's nerves by stressing that the recounts were "mandatory" and called for "the rule of law" to be upheld.

But yesterday was not a day for the Queensberry rules, as the gloves came off in the fist fight for the presidency and Mr Bush led an angry Republican reaction to the possibility that Tuesday night's supreme court ruling might hand the White House to Al Gore.

In their judgment, the seven judges voted unanimously to instruct Florida's secretary of state, Katherine Harris, to accept the results of manual recounts in Broward, Palm Beach and Miami-Dade counties before a 5pm Sunday deadline.

The ruling kept the doors open for Mr Gore to claw back Mr Bush's existing 930-vote lead in Florida, but the decision in Miami-Dade threw all calculations up in the air once again.

Mr Bush accused the Florida court of "usurping" the authority of election officials and of "overreaching" its powers in keeping the recount process open until Sunday night's deadline. "No fair or accurate result" was now possible in Florida, he warned in a statement delivered in Austin.

"I believe secretary Cheney and I won the vote in Florida. And I believe some are determined to keep counting in an effort to change the legitimate result," Mr Bush said.

The man who campaigned before November 7 as a candidate who would "change the tone in Washington DC" signalled a sharply partisan turn which was taken up throughout the party.

In Tallahassee, Mr Bush's lieutenant James Baker invited the Republican-controlled Florida legislature to step in and declare Mr Bush the winner. "One should not now be surprised if the Florida legislature seeks to affirm the original rules," Mr Baker said in a statement condemning the court's "unjust result".

Other top Republicans echoed the defiant mood. Governor Mark Racicot of Montana, who has emerged as an important mouthpiece for Mr Bush in the past week, threatened "some extraordinary" measures to overcome the effects of the court's ruling.

As the political temperature rose in Washington, so did tempers in Florida, where there were angry scenes in Miami as Republicans accused a Democratic lawyer of stealing a ballot paper and as Republican observers shouted and demonstrated outside the meeting of the county election canvassing board.

After Tuesday's ruling, Mr Gore announced "democracy is the winner" and welcomed the court's reassertion of the principle that "the will of the people should prevail".

webTitle: Judges' ruling makes will of the people top priority

fields.headline: Judges' ruling makes will of the people top priority
fields.standfirst:
Late-night decision gave Gore ray of hope

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Florida's supreme court appeared to give Al Gore a lifeline when it ruled that the local secretary of state, Katherine Harris, must accept the   results of all county recounts submitted before a 5pm Sunday deadline.
fields.body:
Florida's supreme court appeared to give Al Gore a lifeline when it ruled that the local secretary of state, Katherine Harris, must accept the results of all county recounts submitted before a 5pm Sunday deadline.

The ruling late on Tuesday night upheld almost everything Mr Gore's lawyers wanted, and meant that the doors were left open to allow the continuation of recounts that could take Mr Gore's total past Mr Bush's.

Stating that "an accurate vote count is one of the essential foundations of our democracy", the court said the rights of the voters took precedence.

"We consistently have adhered to the principle that the will of the people is the paramount consideration," the court ruled in its unanimous 42-page decision.

"Our goal remains ... to reach the result that reflects the will of the voters, whatever that may be," the ruling added.

The judges, largely Democrat-appointed, placed themselves in the political crossfire with their ruling, which angered Republicans.

The court swept away Ms Harris's imposition of a November 14 deadline for the receipt of county returns, replacing it with November 26.

The court tried to strike a balance between those who argued that the state should do everything permissible to ensure that as many votes as possible were recounted in a lawful way, and those who argued that Florida could not run the risk of its electoral college votes being excluded.

The judgment means that lawyers for both sides will have time after the deadline to challenge the results which Ms Harris will certify and still meet the crucial December 12 deadline by which the membership of Florida's electoral college must be appointed.

The court's ruling gave support to the principle that ballots initially counted by machine can properly be checked by human hand, as the Gore campaign wants.

"Although error cannot be completely eliminated in any tabulation of the ballots, our society has not yet gone so far as to place blind faith in machines."

And there were strong words for Ms Harris, who has been thrust into the international spotlight. "To allow the secretary to summarily disenfranchise innocent electors in an effort to punish dilatory [canvassing] board members, as she proposes in the present case, misses the constitutional mark," the court said.

It was less clear-cut in its ruling on the question of disputed ballot papers, the source of much of the post-election controversy in Florida. At several points in the ruling, however, the judges said that county election officials must do everything they can to ascertain the will of the individual voter.

The court endorsed as "particularly apt" an Illinois judgment that said a voter should not have his or her vote excluded "simply because the chad [hole] they punched did not completely dislodge from the ballot."

webTitle: Dimpled chads dispute backfires on Gore

fields.headline: Dimpled chads dispute backfires on Gore
fields.standfirst:
Tempers fray in scramble to meet court's deadline

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The race for the presidency yesterday boiled down to a scramble in three Democratic counties to sort through about 28,000 disputed ballots in the teeth of determined Republican opposition before a Sunday evening deadline laid down by the Florida supreme court.
fields.body:
The race for the presidency yesterday boiled down to a scramble in three Democratic counties to sort through about 28,000 disputed ballots in the teeth of determined Republican opposition before a Sunday evening deadline laid down by the Florida supreme court.

As tempers frayed in Miami-Dade, Palm Beach and Broward counties - a strip of south Florida coastline which has become ground zero in a bizarre electoral endgame - Republican and Democratic representatives engaged in ballot-by-ballot combat as the counting accelerated.

In Miami-Dade county, scuffles broke out between Republican count observers and police after election officials took the controversial decision to scrap a general recount of its 588,000 votes, in order to concentrate on 10,750 contested ballots which are thought most likely to yield extra votes for Al Gore.

Two hours later, the county canvassing board took an even more explosive decision when it bowed to a combination of Republican anger, tight timetables and sheer exhaustion, and called off even that count. If the board's decision stood, it would be a potentially disabling blow to Al Gore's hopes that the recounts would give him the votes he needs to capture Florida and the White House.

In their earlier meeting, the three members of the board argued that it would not be able to perform a complete recount by 5pm on Sunday, the deadline set by the state's supreme court.

The Republican observers chanted "cheats" and "the world is watching" and accused a Democratic official of stealing a ballot from the Miami-Dade counting room. Kendall Coffey, a Democratic lawyer, said the official had only taken a sample ballot for use in court, but the incident reflected an increasingly volatile mood surrounding the recount.

In Palm Beach county, Democratic lawyers took election officials to court in an attempt to force them to count all "dimpled" or "pregnant" ballots, on which the voter had dented the punchcard ballot but had failed to punch a complete hole alongside the name of a presidential candidate. Such ballots would not be registered as votes by vote-counting machines, but could conceivably be interpreted as votes by the human eye.

Dimpled ballots are at the centre of the rancorous post-election struggle. In the counties where the Democrats had demanded a hand recount, the new tallies did not appear to be producing enough extra votes for Mr Gore to overturn George W Bush's 930-vote lead in Florida.

By yesterday, the recounts had boosted Mr Gore's total by 106 in Broward (with all precincts counted), 157 in Miami-Dade (with about a fifth of its precincts counted), and three in Palm Beach (with a fifth of the precincts counted). Analysts said that many of the precincts yet to be counted were mostly Republican.

However, a total of 27,761 ballots were rejected as "undervotes" by counting machines in the three counties, and have to be reviewed by three-member canvassing boards in each county.

Undervotes are ballots which register no presidential vote on the machines, but the Democrats argue that many of them are "dimpled" ballots which ought to be counted. They believe that an analysis of these "dimples" would swing the Florida result to Mr Gore.

Republicans have been outraged by the attempts to include "dimpled" ballots as votes and point to the changing criteria used by the three canvassing boards to interpret them as proof that the process is subjective and haphazard. The Florida supreme court ruling delivered on Tuesday night gave no firm guidelines.

The Miami-Dade board has used a liberal interpretation of the dimpled ballot, counting as votes any ballot where the chad (the small perforated cardboard rectangle the voter is supposed to punch out to indicate his or her preference) had been pushed in enough to allow a chink of light through the punchcard.

Broward county has yet to make up its mind over "dimpled" ballots. Palm Beach initially used this "sunshine rule" but switched after a few thousand votes had been counted, to accept only "dimpled" chads as votes for the presidency if the voter had consistently marked other parts of the ballot (for congressional and local positions) with the same sort of marks.

"We are trying to find out why the voter had a problem," Charles Burton, the head of the Palm Beach canvassing board said yesterday. "If they consistenly had the problem, we are determining that shows intent [to vote]."

Mr Burton was speaking in a Palm Beach courtroom, where Democratic lawyers were attempting to force the canvassing board to accept all "dimpled" ballots.

Republicans vehemently opposed the move.

fields.bodyText: The race for the presidency yesterday boiled down to a scramble in three Democratic counties to sort through about 28,000 disputed ballots in the teeth of determined Republican opposition before a Sunday evening deadline laid down by the Florida supreme court. As tempers frayed in Miami-Dade, Palm Beach and Broward counties - a strip of south Florida coastline which has become ground zero in a bizarre electoral endgame - Republican and Democratic representatives engaged in ballot-by-ballot combat as the counting accelerated. In Miami-Dade county, scuffles broke out between Republican count observers and police after election officials took the controversial decision to scrap a general recount of its 588,000 votes, in order to concentrate on 10,750 contested ballots which are thought most likely to yield extra votes for Al Gore. Two hours later, the county canvassing board took an even more explosive decision when it bowed to a combination of Republican anger, tight timetables and sheer exhaustion, and called off even that count. If the board's decision stood, it would be a potentially disabling blow to Al Gore's hopes that the recounts would give him the votes he needs to capture Florida and the White House. In their earlier meeting, the three members of the board argued that it would not be able to perform a complete recount by 5pm on Sunday, the deadline set by the state's supreme court. The Republican observers chanted "cheats" and "the world is watching" and accused a Democratic official of stealing a ballot from the Miami-Dade counting room. Kendall Coffey, a Democratic lawyer, said the official had only taken a sample ballot for use in court, but the incident reflected an increasingly volatile mood surrounding the recount. In Palm Beach county, Democratic lawyers took election officials to court in an attempt to force them to count all "dimpled" or "pregnant" ballots, on which the voter had dented the punchcard ballot but had failed to punch a complete hole alongside the name of a presidential candidate. Such ballots would not be registered as votes by vote-counting machines, but could conceivably be interpreted as votes by the human eye. Dimpled ballots are at the centre of the rancorous post-election struggle. In the counties where the Democrats had demanded a hand recount, the new tallies did not appear to be producing enough extra votes for Mr Gore to overturn George W Bush's 930-vote lead in Florida. By yesterday, the recounts had boosted Mr Gore's total by 106 in Broward (with all precincts counted), 157 in Miami-Dade (with about a fifth of its precincts counted), and three in Palm Beach (with a fifth of the precincts counted). Analysts said that many of the precincts yet to be counted were mostly Republican. However, a total of 27,761 ballots were rejected as "undervotes" by counting machines in the three counties, and have to be reviewed by three-member canvassing boards in each county. Undervotes are ballots which register no presidential vote on the machines, but the Democrats argue that many of them are "dimpled" ballots which ought to be counted. They believe that an analysis of these "dimples" would swing the Florida result to Mr Gore. Republicans have been outraged by the attempts to include "dimpled" ballots as votes and point to the changing criteria used by the three canvassing boards to interpret them as proof that the process is subjective and haphazard. The Florida supreme court ruling delivered on Tuesday night gave no firm guidelines. The Miami-Dade board has used a liberal interpretation of the dimpled ballot, counting as votes any ballot where the chad (the small perforated cardboard rectangle the voter is supposed to punch out to indicate his or her preference) had been pushed in enough to allow a chink of light through the punchcard. Broward county has yet to make up its mind over "dimpled" ballots. Palm Beach initially used this "sunshine rule" but switched after a few thousand votes had been counted, to accept only "dimpled" chads as votes for the presidency if the voter had consistently marked other parts of the ballot (for congressional and local positions) with the same sort of marks. "We are trying to find out why the voter had a problem," Charles Burton, the head of the Palm Beach canvassing board said yesterday. "If they consistenly had the problem, we are determining that shows intent [to vote]." Mr Burton was speaking in a Palm Beach courtroom, where Democratic lawyers were attempting to force the canvassing board to accept all "dimpled" ballots. Republicans vehemently opposed the move. webTitle: Hasbro shifts ad account to DDB Worldwide

fields.headline: Hasbro shifts advertising account to DDB Worldwide
fields.trailText: 10.45am: Games company Hasbro has restructured its advertising business. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Hasbro, the company that brought Monopoly, Pokemon and Play-Doh to the gaming masses, has restructured its advertising business.

The toy giant has shifted its estimated £70m advertising account into DDB Worldwide.

The appointment follows a competition between its three roster agencies - Grey Worldwide, Rotter Kantor and Griffin Bacal.

Sister companies Griffin Bacal and DDB may well share some of the workload from now on. Griffin Bacal has held a place on the Hasbro roster for more than two decades and will be keen to continue the relationship.

OMD, DDB's media unit, is likely get the whole planning and buying assignment for Hasbro toys while Grey will hang on to some of its Hasbro's game business, including Risk and Monopoly.

webTitle: Bush takes fight to highest court

fields.headline: Bush takes fight to highest court
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The chances of Al Gore gathering enough votes to defeat George W Bush in the US presidential election suffered a blow yesterday when Florida's largest county abandoned its recount.
fields.body:
The chances of Al Gore gathering enough votes to defeat George W Bush in the US presidential election suffered a blow yesterday when Florida's largest county abandoned its recount.

And in a separate move, Mr Bush asked the US supreme court to bar the use of recounted ballots in the state.

Mr Gore immediately moved to appeal against the decision by members of the supervisory canvassing board in Miami-Dade county, where officials had recounted about a fifth of their 654,000 votes before throwing in their hand amid noisy scenes in Miami.

The board claimed it could not meet a new timetable set by the state supreme court in a ruling late on Tuesday night that said the counting in three Florida counties should continue.

Meanwhile, Mr Bush's lawyers filed two appeals with the highest US court. "This is a case of the utmost national importance, involving the constitution's most fundamental rights as exercised in the nation's most important election," the lawyers said in court papers.

The chances of success were viewed sceptically by independent legal experts. The federal supreme court was thought unlikely to want to intervene in a matter of state law.

In a day of unpleasant surprises for both men, Mr Bush's vice-presidential running mate, Dick Cheney, was admitted to a Washington hospital where doctors last night said he had suffered a "very slight heart attack". Mr Bush had earlier insisted: "Dick Cheney is healthy. He did not have a heart attack."

A stent - tiny tube - was inserted into one of Mr Cheney's arteries to stop it closing. The former defence secretary, 59, has a history of heart disease and bypass surgery.

Mr Gore's one boost last night was when a Florida judge ruled that "dimpled chad" voting papers could be accepted in the Palm Beach recount as long as the intention of the voter was clearly discernible.

The new mood of litigiousness on the Bush side was underscored in Tallahassee, where a court was asked to order all postal votes cast before November 7 by members of the armed services to be included in the count.

Mr Gore's lieutenant, William Daley, tried to steady his side's nerves by stressing the recounts were "mandatory" and calling for "the rule of law" to be upheld.

Yesterday was not a day for the Queensberry rules, as the gloves came off in the fist fight for the presidency and Mr Bush led an angry Republican reaction to the possibility that Tuesday night's state supreme court ruling might hand the White House to Al Gore.

In their judgment, the seven judges voted unanimously to instruct Florida's secretary of state, Katherine Harris, to accept the results of manual recounts in Broward, Palm Beach and Miami-Dade counties before a 5pm Sunday deadline.

The ruling kept the doors open for Mr Gore to claw back Mr Bush's existing 930-vote lead in Florida, but the decision in Miami-Dade threw all calculations up in the air again.

Mr Bush accused the Florida court of "usurping" the authority of election officials and of "overreaching" its powers in keeping the recount process open until Sunday night's deadline. "No fair or accurate result" was now possible in Florida, he warned in a statement delivered in Austin.

"I believe secretary Cheney and I won the vote in Florida. And I believe some are determined to keep counting in an effort to change the legitimate result," Mr Bush said.

In Tallahassee, Mr Bush's lieutenant, James Baker, invited the Republican-controlled Florida legislature to step in and declare Mr Bush the winner. "One should not now be surprised if the Florida legislature seeks to affirm the original rules," Mr Baker said in a statement condemning the court's "unjust result".

Other top Republicans echoed the defiant mood. Governor Mark Racicot, of Montana, who has emerged as an important mouthpiece for Mr Bush in the past week, threatened "some extraordinary" measures to overcome the effects of the court's ruling.

There were angry scenes in Miami as Republicans accused a Democratic lawyer of stealing a ballot paper and Republican observers protested outside the meeting of the county election canvassing board.

After Tuesday's ruling, Mr Gore declared "democracy is the winner" and welcomed the court's assertion that "the will of the people should prevail".

webTitle: Three Britons injured in Riyadh explosion

fields.headline: Three Britons injured in Riyadh explosion
fields.trailText: A small explosion in the Saudi capital has injured three British citizens, the second such explosion in a week.
fields.body:
A small explosion in the Saudi capital has injured three British citizens, the second such explosion in a week.

The explosion late last night hit a car carrying two men and a woman - all British workers at an unidentified company in Riyadh - the director of Riyadh police department told the Saudi Riyadh Daily.

The three were taken to a hospital, where one was in stable condition with an injured right leg. The other two were slightly injured, the newspaper reported.

The Foreign Office confirmed Wednesday's explosion. A spokesman said it was too early to speculate on the cause.

By this morning, the start of the weekend in Saudi Arabia, the street and surrounding mixed residential and business neighbourhood were quiet. Workers in the area said they had heard the explosion and seen police arrive to briefly cordon off the area last night.

Last Friday, Christopher Rodway, 48, a British citizen working in a Saudi hospital, died after a small explosion tore through his car, which was believed to have been booby-trapped. Rodway's wife, Jane, 50, was slightly injured.

Another Saudi paper, Okaz, quoted Deputy Interior Minister Prince Ahmed as saying the two explosions could be related, but that the three injured last night did not work with the Rodways. "What happened... has no political undertones, it is a personal matter," Ahmed was quoted as saying.

US forces in Saudi Arabia and other parts of the Gulf have been on highest alert since an October 12 attack on the USS Cole killed 17 American sailors in the port of Aden, Yemen. Such an alert level is only issued when an attack occurs in the region or when there is specific information indicating that one may occur.

American residents in Saudi Arabia had been reminded of the alert, with the US Embassy describing it as a "precautionary measure."

webTitle: Prescott looks to Europe for flood solutions

fields.headline: Prescott looks to Europe for flood solutions
fields.standfirst:
Experts from Holland and Germany show variety of approaches to rising water levels
Special report: the weather
Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: The sandbag has had its day. In future British cities vulnerable to flooding, such as Shrewsbury and York, may be protected by collapsible rings of steel if John Prescott, the environment secretary, has his way.
fields.byline: Paul Brown, environment correspondent in the Hague
fields.body:
The sandbag has had its day. In future British cities vulnerable to flooding, such as Shrewsbury and York, may be protected by collapsible rings of steel if John Prescott, the environment secretary, has his way.

Mr Prescott took time off from the Hague climate talks yesterday to see newly developed flood defences which allow towns on rivers to enjoy their waterways as amenities in good times, but when floods threaten allow them quickly to seal endangered areas off from rising waters.

Parts of the Rhine and the Mosel rivers in Germany have already been protected by the barriers which can be up to 4.5 metres high.

When Mr Prescott recently visited areas flooded by the Severn he conceded he was at a loss to know how to stop the devastation.

"This could be the answer for historic places like Shrewsbury where they do not want to lose the view of the river and refuse to build the barrier that would save them. This kind of temporary structure, that can be put up and taken down quickly, is a solution that would appeal to them," he said.

Conceding that it might cost 20% more than concrete flood defences he said: "We are looking at a new situation in Britain where these kind of events are more common, and we are going to have to give this idea a lot of attention. When I get back I shall have to speak to Gordon [Brown, the chancellor] and see what we can do."

The German firm IBS buries steel plates in concrete along the edge of the river. When floods threaten, steel posts are bolted into the plates. High strength aluminium girders with rubber seals are slotted sideways between the posts to build up the defences. Unlike sandbags they do notallow water to seep through. As the flood rises, the girders can be piled higher and higher.

IBS's managing director, Volker Weingartner, said the fences came in different heights and strengths so, if necessary, a city on a flood plain could be entirely surrounded by a ring of steel until the water subsided. This had already been done with a fence over a mile long circling a chemical factory on the Rhine.

Mr Prescott then went on a tour of Delfland, the county in which the Dutch capital, the Hague, stands and is an average of two metres below sea level. The area was once the delta of the Rhine and is very similar to areas of Lincolnshire and Norfolk.

It has suffered a series of disastrous floods, the worst in 1953 when 1,800 people died, but floods have become more and more frequent.

Jan Dounes, secretary of the Delfland water board said: "In 1998 we had what we were told was a once-in-150-years flood. We had another one in 1999 and one again this year, the same time as you had one in England. We have to accept this is now normal."

The water board has earmarked large areas of low lying land to be deliberately flooded during heavy rains to buy time for the pumps to drain the water from the dykes.

One of Mr Dounes's problems is the 3,000 greenhouses in the area, each a hectare in size, which cause flash floods because the water drains straight into the dykes and is not absorbed in the fields.

The water board has the power to ban building on flood plains, and in some places is only allowing new houses to be built on stilts. Some homeowners keep boats to escape if the water level gets too high.

Mr Prescott, who has post poned new planning guidance on flood plains until after Christmas when the recent floods have been evaluated, said similar powers were being considered.

Mr Prescott, clearly impressed by what he saw, said: "In England when we see flooded fields we see it as a sign of failure. In Holland it is a feature of a working water management system.

"This is the best place in the world to come because they have a complete flood plain management system. We have to learn because flooding is going to be a regular feature of the weather in Britain."

Mr Dounes said: "We are holding the water back at the moment but if the sea rises a metre by the end of the century, as the scientists tell us it will, we will have to abandon this land and move to higher ground. We will have no alternative."

At the conference, demonstrators disrupted the proceedings. Frank Loy, the chief US negotiator, and undersecretary of state for global affairs, had a custard pie thrown in his face during a press conference. He continued to speak through the mess and said that the US was still hoping to find a deal.

Earlier, politicians and officials split into a series of meetings to try to thrash out some of the contentious issues that have been dividing the power blocks of the US, EU and developing countries. Although there was no visible progress, officials were more positive and there was a proposal that some meetings should continue through the night.

There was a series of demonstrations outside the main entrance from people from small islands that will disappear because of rising sea levels and another group which believed that the talks should be abandoned altogether.

Corporate Watch said: "What we see is a huddle of gangsters, plotting the most profitable scams to dodge even the woefully inadequate Kyoto targets."

Mr Prescott was more positive. "There are still a lot of difficult issues still unresolved, but things are moving forward, we hope we will get there and have an agreement that everyone can sign up to by Friday night."

webTitle: MacKenzie to buy stake in Delta Radio

fields.headline: MacKenzie to buy stake in Delta Radio
fields.trailText: 10.30am: The Wireless Group is in talks to buy a 33% stake in Delta Radio, which is launching a rival to BBC Radio 2, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Kelvin MacKenzie's Wireless Group is negotiating to buy a 33% stake in Delta Radio, which is launching an offshore rival to BBC Radio 2.

The Wireless Group will manage the station's programming and airtime sales in return for the 33% stake. The deal with Delta Radio, a Dutch company, does not involve any cash payment.

The offshore service, which will have the same branding and music policy as TWG's easy listening digital format, The Lounge, is due to launch on a long wave frequency licensed by the Dutch government in 2002.

The service will be available to more than 40m UK listeners.

Mr MacKenzie, TWG chairman and chief executive, said the deal "will give our national sales team a complementary sell, offering advertisers access to an older audience as well as to women."

TWG's advertising sales house, Impact, will represent the new station, which will be branded 171 The Lounge.

171 The Lounge will be broadcast from a transmission facility that is to be built off the Dutch coast.

The service will not be regulated by UK law, but TWG is planning to ensure it complies with domestic copyright and broadcast content codes and Advertising Standards Authority guidelines.

The Wireless Group will manage the station's programming and airtime sales in return for the 33% stake. The deal with Delta Radio, a Dutch company, does not involve any cash payment. The offshore service, which will have the same branding and music policy as TWG's easy listening digital format, The Lounge, is due to launch on a long wave frequency licensed by the Dutch government in 2002. The service will be available to more than 40m UK listeners. Mr MacKenzie, TWG chairman and chief executive, said the deal "will give our national sales team a complementary sell, offering advertisers access to an older audience as well as to women." TWG's advertising sales house, Impact, will represent the new station, which will be branded 171 The Lounge. 171 The Lounge will be broadcast from a transmission facility that is to be built off the Dutch coast. The service will not be regulated by UK law, but TWG is planning to ensure it complies with domestic copyright and broadcast content codes and Advertising Standards Authority guidelines.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Vintage wine at a vintage price
fields.body:
Vintage wine at a vintage price

Three bottles of Chateau Lafite claret, dated 1784, 1787 and 1789, should fetch up to £25,000 each, or £750 a gulp, at a Christie's wine sale in London today.

The world record is £105,000 for one bottle, coincidentally a 1787 vintage though it also bore the signature of president-to-be Thomas Jefferson.

Teacher returns to classroom

Teacher Anthony Taylor is due to return to work today at Hesketh Fletcher Church of England high school in Wigan, Greater Manchester.

He was suspended on November 15 for reportedly tapping a 13-year-old boy with a piece of wire he used as a blackboard pointer. Governors lifted the suspension after deciding on "appropriate action".

Dublin flight for £1 return

Ryanair is offering 12,000 Manchester to Dublin seats at £1 return, if passengers book on the internet and pay airport tax of £19, to celebrate the passage of 2m people on the route.

Flights must be booked by November 29 but can be taken until December 14.

No damages for foolhardiness

The appeal court yesterday refused damages to two young men from Hull who were injured while "surfing" on trains while truanting as schoolboys.

Andrew Scott lost a leg in 1988 when he was 15, and Michael Swainger lost a leg and an arm in 1992 when he was 13. The appeal judges concurred with a previous judgment that the pair had been foolhardy.

Prison governor found dead

A 54-year-old governor of Cardiff prison was found dead at his home in St Briavels, Gloucestershire. Police confirmed he had been arrested on November 17, and bailed pending further inquiries, after child pornography was found on a computer.

Free mobiles for battered women

Mobiles programmed to make 999 calls only are being given to victims of domestic violence in a scheme by Liverpool city council, which is appealing for old mobiles to be given in at local police stations.

Bottled waters recalled

All bottles of Chiltern Hills Natural Mineral Water and Ashridge Spring Water are being recalled immediately. The decision, which the maker stressed was precautionary, follows an analysis of water suggesting contamination with faeces.

Cannabis find at nursery school

A teacher found a three-year-old boy with a small amount of cannabis at an unnamed nursery school in Glasgow, police confirmed last night. "How it came to be in the child's possession is unknown," the police spokesman said. "No charges are being proferred and social services has been advised."

Hotel takes cash not excuses

A court in Bridgetown, Barbados, has given a British tourist until Tuesday to pay $525 she owes her hotel plus a $750 fine, or go to jail for nine months. As Susan Stacey, 39, from Birmingham, was leaving on Monday, she told hotel desk staff she could not pay her phone and restaurant bill, so they had her arrested.

Queen Mother's files returned

The Queen Mother's medical records have been returned by police to Clarence house, having been found in a London street the day after being stolen from a car belonging to the royal family's orthopaedic surgeon, Roger Vickers, last week.

Three share £3.3m jackpot

Three tickets shared last night's lottery jackpot of £3.3m with the winning numbers 4, 12, 20, 23, 31 and 34; the bonus was 16. The lottery extra jackpot was £2.3m and the numbers were 18, 20, 24, 34, 43, and 49.

webTitle: Historian unearths origin of 'King Arthur's table'

fields.headline: Historian unearths origin of 'King Arthur's table'
fields.trailText: One of the great medieval mysteries - the origin and purpose of what is commonly referred to as King Arthur's Round Table - could have been solved.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
One of the great medieval mysteries - the origin and purpose of what is commonly referred to as King Arthur's Round Table - could have been solved.

Historians over the centuries have tried to discover when the table, at the Great Hall in Winchester, was built and why.

Now a 20-year investigation by historians has found it could have been the central part of an elaborate medieval Arthurian fancy dress ball in the reign of Edward I, the notorious Hammer of the Scots.

Martin Biddle believes timber dating of the 51 superb oak planks, completed in the last few months, proves it was made for the event in 1290 to celebrate the betrothal of two children - Edward, the son of Edward I, and Margaret, the child Queen of Scotland.

"This table is a hugely important object, the greatest piece of English medieval furniture to survive, and perhaps the greatest monument to the tradition of English chivalry," said Professor Biddle, head of medieval archaeology at Oxford University.

The table is world famous - tiny images of it are worn as the symbol of the international Round Table organisation - but has often been dismissed as a Tudor fake. In fact when it was restored in the 18th century, and when Henry VIII first ordered it to be painted in 1519, it was already ancient, the oldest surviving round table in Europe.

If Arthur ever existed, archaeologists believe he was probably a dark ages Romano-British warlord.

However, the romance of Arthur, and his fellowship of knights seated at a round table, had a powerful grip on the medieval imagina tion, and on no one more strongly than the king, Edward I.

In household accounts and contemporary records, previously missed by historians, Prof Biddle pieced together the tournament and feast the king organised at Winchester. His best knights fought in Arthurian costume, as the legendary heroes Lancelot, Galahad and companions, and feasted afterwards at the round table.

webTitle: Unison escalates Scottish local government strikes

fields.headline: Unison escalates Scottish local government strikes
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Trade union Unison has escalated its four-month-old pay dispute with Scottish local authorities by calling a further 700 council staff out on indefinite strike. Simon Parker reports.
fields.body:
Trade union Unison has escalated its four-month-old pay dispute with Scottish local authorities by calling a further 700 council staff out on indefinite strike.

The decision will double the number of employees involved in Unison's campaign of industrial action, and bring the number of councils affected to 26.

The union is pressing ahead despite its decision to enter conciliation talks with authorities and Acas aimed at ending the strikes.

Unison has blamed councils for the escalation, accusing them of imposing a pay increase already rejected by the union's members.

This follows a statement from the Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (Cosla) last week, which said that councils would implement a 6.1% increase for all employees paid over two years. This is likely to cost well over £200m, with the first increase to be awarded in April.

Unison has accused councils of complicating discussions by employing contract workers to fill the roles of striking staff.

Scottish local government organiser Joe Di Paola said: "After the inflammatory actions by some local authorities in bringing in private firms and agency staff to do our members' work, the unilateral breach of the agreed negotiations by Cosla in imposing a pay rise rejected by the majority of their staff is very unhelpful, and may increase the difficulty of finding a settlement."

The pay offer has already been accepted by the GMB and Transport and General Workers' unions, and the convention says it felt a "moral duty" to implement the increase.

A Cosla spokeswoman said: "Unison's decision is extremely disappointing, particularly as they've gone ahead with this as conciliation talks have started. It makes things difficult for councils and it's causing problems for the general public, which is regrettable."

webTitle: Bill threatens £5,000 fines to fox hunters who defy ban

fields.headline: Bill threatens £5,000 fines to fox hunters who defy ban
fields.standfirst: Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: Fox hunters who defy a ban on their sport will face fines of up to £5,000 if a hunting bill is passed in parliament.
fields.body:
Fox hunters who defy a ban on their sport will face fines of up to £5,000 if a hunting bill is passed in parliament.

All members of a hunt, including masters of hounds, landowners and officials, will also be subject to searches if police suspect they are breaking the law to continue hunting.

The measures are outlined in the government's hunting bill which will be introduced in next month's Queen's speech. Under pressure from backbenchers, ministers have agreed to introduce a "multiple choice" bill which will give MPs the chance to vote on options ranging from an outright ban to maintaining the status quo.

The details of the bill were seized on last night by the pro-hunting Daily Telegraph, which warned that huntsmen "are to be treated as members of criminal organisations under the government's hunting bill".

The government believes it has protected itself against such charges by offering MPs a free vote on the various options on offer in the bill.

The more stringent elements of the bill would give the police the right to detain vehicles used in hunting and to confiscate and destroy dogs. Anyone who breaks the ban would not be jailed, "to avoid creating martyrs", the Telegraph said.

However, anyone who refused to pay a fine could face jail for contempt of court.

The bill will sail through the Commons, after heated debates, because Labour MPs are overwhelmingly opposed to fox hunting. It could come unstuck in the House of Lords, however, where peers have pledged to vote down the measure.

Ministers are likely to have ambivalent feelings about the row over hunting in the run-up to the general election.

Some, such as John Prescott, will be delighted that the government is moving to abolish a sport associated with the landed classes. Others are likely to dread angry confrontations with rural voters who complain that a ban on fox hunting would affect all classes.

The Countryside Alliance has threatened to bring London to a standstill with a demonstration of up to half-a-million people if the government refuses to give into its demands.

It was infuriated by Mr Prescott, who declared at the Labour conference: "Every time I see the Countryside Alliance and their contorted red faces I redouble my determination to abolish fox hunting."

His remarks were condemned by John Jackson, the alliance chairman. He said: "The deputy prime minister has pushed us further down the road." He described Mr Prescott's remarks as "no more than the exacting of retribution to pay off old political scores".

webTitle: Bush running mate in hospital after heart attack

fields.headline: Bush running mate in hospital after heart attack
fields.standfirst:
Cheney has operation after chest pains
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Dick Cheney, the Republican vice-presidential candidate, suffered a "slight" heart attack, surgeons said yesterday after they had performed a two hour operation on him in a Washington hospital.
fields.body:
Dick Cheney, the Republican vice-presidential candidate, suffered a "slight" heart attack, surgeons said yesterday after they had performed a two hour operation on him in a Washington hospital.

Mr Cheney was admitted to Washington University hospital before dawn with chest and shoulder pains.

Doctors inserted a stent, a small mesh tube, into a narrowed artery to restore blood flow but it was only at the second of two press conferences that they disclosed Mr Cheney's real condition.

George W Bush had initially insisted that his 59-year-old running mate had not had a heart attack. "Dick Cheney is healthy. He did not have a heart attack."

But later Dr Alan Wasserman, a professor of medicine and cardiology, said: "There was a very slight heart attack."

An initial blood test and electrocardiogram did not show signs of an attack, but a second blood test showed elevated cardiac enzymes that indicated a small heart attack had occurred, Dr Wasserman confirmed.

Mr Cheney, the former defence secretary to George Bush Sr, has a history of heart trouble but had been given a clean bill of health by doctors when George W Bush picked him as running mate.

Mr Cheney had his first heart attack in 1978 when he was 37. A second followed in 1984 and a third four years later. All were described as mild. Following the third attack he underwent quadruple heart bypass surgery.

Doctors said that Mr Cheney would remain in hospital for up to three days and played down the possibility that he would need more extensive treatment.

"It would be exceedingly unlikely for him to undergo a repeat bypass operation," Dr Jonathan Reiner, Mr Cheney's personal doctor, said.

Stents work well for many patients but in between 20% and 30% of cases the artery can become clogged again, particularly in patients such as Mr Cheney with a long history of heart disease.

fields.headline: Labour boasts of spending upsurge
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday adopted an emollient tone towards public sector workers by conceding lack of government investment was the root cause of Britain's inadequate public services
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday adopted an emollient tone towards public sector workers by conceding lack of government investment was the root cause of Britain's inadequate public services.

A year ago he blamed forces of conservatism amongst public sector workers and bemoaned the "scars on his back" caused by their resistance to change.

Mr Blair was speaking yesterday at a Downing Street press conference designed to highlight plans to double net capital investment to £18bn a year by 2003-4.

This will double the proportion of GDP committed to public investment, but still leave it well below the figure of the mid-80s. In addition, ministers hope to sign private finance initiative projects over the next three years worth a further £12bn.

In pre-election mood, Mr Blair used the press conference to contrast his willingness to spend alongside the Tories' commitment to spend below the rate of economic growth.

He said: "Who can seriously doubt that Britain has been chronically under-invested in for over 20 years? We have the fourth biggest economy in the world. Yet we do not have the fourth best public services. I lay the blame for that firmly at the door of under-inevestment."

He admitted that the government had not put enough investment into public services in its first two years, but said the tight controls had been necessary to lay the foundations for growth.

But he claimed the government has now made its choice between spending and tax cuts. "We could have taken all this money and blown it on Treasury tax cuts, but look back at the late 80s and 90s, people had their tax cuts then and they were followed by tax rises."

The emphasis on the extra capital spending has been given added urgency by news that the public sector surplus was £11bn in the seven months to October, £1bn more than the Treasury forecast for the whole year.

Even the IMF in its review of the British economy called for extra spending, writing: "Certainly, we recognize that, after several years of fiscal tightening, increases in public spending are needed in some areas, particularly infrastructure and health care".

However, the commitment to extra spending has been hit by signs that Whitehall is not spending as fast as the Treasury wants.

Andrew Smith, the Treasury chief secretary, admitted a Whitehall culture created by Thatcherite hostility to the public spending may be leading government departments to under-spend on both capital and current account. Capital spend was £1bn under plans last year and current spend £2bn under target.

Treasury officials claim some of the lower than expected spending can be attributed national statisticians increasing the level of depreciated assets, so reducing the net value of capital investment. However, the officials admit they are puzzled as to why capital spending tends to be undertaken so late in each financial year.

Mr Smith said: "You don't turn round capital expenditure overnight and we were starting from a low base."

He said this year there are £800m more net public sector net investment this year and we are on course and we are on course to see an extra £4bn gross investment this year." The figures do not yet bear out this claim.

The shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, said:"Labour have been promising to improve public services from day one.

"But three and a half years later, taxes are up and Labour's spending is failing to deliver."

Priority areas

 Health £1.4bn extra spending in NHS capital spending over three years. This will lead to 100 major new hospital projects by 2010, 250 new scanners, modernisation of over 3,000 GP premises and 500 one stop primary care centres.

 Education Extra £1.6bn in capital spending for most urgent repairs in 7,000 schools and complete refurbishment in 650 schools.

 Transport 150% increase in transport public investment designed to produce 50% rise in rail passenger use, and 10% rise in bus use.

 Home Office Extra 20% for police capital spending, mainly on CCTV and information technology.

 Environment An extra £1.6bn a year by 2003-4 compared with 2000-1 to cut by a third the number of houses not of a decent standard.

fields.headline: Strike could spread across NHS
fields.trailText: Industrial action could spread across the national health service, the public service union Unison warned yesterday, unless plans to privatise the jobs of hundreds of health workers in Dudley as part of the government's private finance initiative are abandoned, writes Seumas Milne
fields.body:
Industrial action could spread across the national health service, the public service union Unison warned yesterday, unless plans to privatise the jobs of hundreds of health workers in Dudley as part of the government's private finance initiative are abandoned.

Around 600 hospital workers in the West Midlands town have begun their seventh strike against transfer to the private sector, in a dispute which has become the front line in the growing resistance to the public finance initiative in the health service.

Yesterday was the second full day of a two week stoppage by non-clinical staff at four Dudley hospitals, whose jobs have been earmarked for transfer to Summit Healthcare, a private consortium, in an industrial stand-off that is being claimed as the longest series of strikes in the NHS.

Rodney Bickerstaffe, Unison's general secretary, said the "very principled stand" of the low paid Dudley workers had the full backing of the national union, while the West Midlands Unison official Fiona Westwood warned: "If they don't back off in Dudley, industrial unrest over PFI is likely to spread."

The campaign of walkouts by Unison members, who have now clocked up 44 days on strike, has escalated from an initial two day stoppage in August. A mass meeting of Dudley strikers yesterday voted to back a three week strike over Christmas.

At issue are the health trust's plans to hand hospital buildings and non-clinical services and employees - including porters, cleaners and IT staff - over to the private sector on a 40-year £80m contract.

In return, the private consortium, which includes Siemens, Building & Property and Sir Robert McAlpine, will rebuild one of Dudley's four hospitals as a "super hospital", turn two others into outpatient centres and close the fourth, with a loss of 70 beds.

Despite advice from the health secretary, Alan Milburn, last year that PFI contracts need not include the transfer of non-clinical staff to the private sector, Dudley trust management says it is too late to revise the contract, which is due to be signed within weeks.

The strikers have been promised there will be no change to their terms and conditions, but strike leaders say they do not trust the undertakings, which anyway would not cover new recruits.

webTitle: Tookey to head content at Taste

fields.headline: Taste for Tookey
fields.standfirst: Nov 22: Ellis hired for Taste
fields.trailText:
8.15am Charlotte Tookey has been appointed content director for Taste Network, the TV and online food and drink venture between Carlton and Sainsbury. By Jason Deans.
Nov 22: Ellis hired for Taste
fields.body:
Charlotte Tookey has been confirmed as the content director for Taste Network, the TV and online food and drink joint venture between Carlton and Sainsbury.

Ms Tookey will oversee content for the Carlton Food Network, which is to become part of new joint venture and relaunched as tasteTV next spring.

She was formerly director of lifestyle for Carlton's SimplyFood website. SimplyFood is to be merged with Sainsbury's tasteforlife website and rebranded taste.co.uk as part of the Taste Network initiative.

Ms Tookey will report to Taste Network chief executive Antony Ellis.

Jeremy Hallsworth, who formerly oversaw CFN as managing director of Carlton Digital, is leaving Carlton after turning down other roles within the company.

webTitle: Channel 4 in car website broadband trial

fields.headline: Channel 4 trials broadband strategy with car website
fields.trailText: 8.15am Car website 4car.co.uk is to run a broadband trial for Channel 4 in what could prove a test-bed for the channel's broadband strategy. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Car website 4car.co.uk is to run a broadband trial for Channel 4, which is being used as a test-bed for the channel's long-term broadband strategy.

A three-month trial will be launched next spring to 300 households with ADSL connections, some in the London area.

The site is a joint venture between Channel 4 and eworld interactive, which is part-run by Ideal World's managing director Zad Rogers. It already offers video clips over ADSL.

The trial is likely to determine whether additional funding will be made available for 4car.co.uk and other broadband services.

Channel 4 is working closely with media group Emap on developing some of its teen brands into broadband offerings.

fields.headline: Barclays cashes in on free Millionaire publicity
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Barclays bank got hundreds of thousands of pounds-worth of free publicity from Monday's night edition of Who Wants to be a Millionaire?, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Barclays bank got hundreds of thousands of pounds-worth of free publicity from Monday's night edition of Who Wants to be a Millionaire?.

Fulham gardener Judith Keppel may be Britain's first million-pound quiz winner, but the high street bank was another surprise beneficiary of the hit ITV quiz show.

Experts believe Barclays may have got up to £400,000-worth of free publicity during Monday night's show because the bank has its name emblazoned on the cheques handed over by presenter Chris Tarrant.

Nearly 15m viewers tuned in to watch Mrs Keppel pick up her cheque for £1m and advertisers would have had to pay about £150,000 for a 30-second commercial during the show.

But Barclays would have got at least as much airtime without paying a penny as the cameras repeatedly panned in on the £1m cheque.

Advertising experts believe that this, coupled with the press coverage of Britain's first million-pound winner, is worth hundreds of thousands of pounds to the bank.

Andy Smith, TV director at Zenith Media, said: "This is basically free sponsorship for Barclays and that is usually worked out by looking at how much airtime the brand got and how much of the screen it covered.

"Say the cheque was on screen for 10 seconds and took up about 20% of the screen, that would be worth about £10,000."

But the bank's exposure extended far beyond that 10 seconds on the nation's screens. As the tension mounted during the quiz, Mr Tarrant held up the each of the cheques for longer than usual before delivering his trademark line, "But we don't want to give you that".

And further exposure came in the following day's newspapers. The Daily Mail and Daily Express both carried photographs of Mrs Keppel brandishing the cheque on their front pages, and many other newspapers featured the images on their inside pages.

Experts expressed disbelief that the bank had not had to pay for its association with one of Britain's most popular shows. "I'd be amazed if there wasn't some kind of deal there," said one media buyer.

But Barclays, which does the corporate banking for Who Wants to be a Millionaire?, said no money had changed hands.

Barclays needs as much good publicity as it can get at the moment. The bank suffered a PR disaster earlier this year when it closed several local branches.

A spokeswoman for the show said: "Barclays have always been Celador's bank. We had to use somebody to issue cheques. It was just one of those things."

fields.headline: Channel 5 inks airtime-for-equity deal with charity site
fields.trailText: 8am: Channel 5 has signed its fourth airtime-for-equity deal, with charity shopping website Free2give, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 5 has signed its fourth airtime-for-equity deal, with charity shopping website Free2give.

Online shoppers can access leading internet retailers including WH Smith, Amazon, Carphone Warehouse and Vauxhall via the Free2give portal.

Each purchase made through Free2give earns a free donation to a charity of the customer's choice.

Retailers featured on the site in effect pay a percentage of their earnings to one of 45 charities, which include the NSPCC and the World Wildlife Fund.

James Burgon, Channel 5 head of new business, said: "Channel 5 liked the business model behind Free2give because it benefits the chosen charity with no additional cost to the consumer."

The broadcaster already has airtime-for-equity deals with websites RapidInsure, Cheekymonkey and TheFirstResort.

webTitle: Online TV programme trading service bags £1/4m

fields.headline: Online TV programme trading service bags £1/4m
fields.trailText: A forthcoming online trading service for TV programme ideas has just picked up £250,000 pounds in start-up funding.
fields.body:
A forthcoming online trading service for TV programme ideas has just picked up £250,000 pounds in start-up funding.

Kiaron Finnegan, a TV producer and former editor of Kilroy, has sold a 45% stake in his soon-to-launch business, TVToBe.com, to StartIT, a seed venture capital firm.

Mr Finnegan set up the business after he saw a gap in the market for sifting through ideas for new TV programmes.

Mr Finnegan, CEO of TVToBe.com, said: "Broadcasters are always looking for fresh new ideas but have only limited time to search. The traditional method is a very inefficient use of their time.

"Producers are very keen to get their proposals in front of the right people but some, especially the smaller independents, often struggle to do this. TVToBe.com provides the right channel for both parties."

Proposal summaries will appear anonymously on the site's database for broadcasters to search or choose to browse at random.

If they like the synopsis, TVToBe.com arranges a meeting between the two parties. If the programme gets commissioned, TVToBe.com will take a 2%-3% commission.

In the UK it is estimated that there are around 450 commissioning editors and 2,500 independent producers.

The £250,000 investment is StartIT's eight investment to date.

fields.headline: The best bribery scene
fields.standfirst: The Yards
fields.trailText: The Yards
fields.body:
New York. In voiceover, Willie Gutierrez (Joaquin Phoenix) explains to his friend Leo Handler (Mark Wahlberg) how the city's subway operation runs on his and boss Frank Olchin's behalf.

"In the business," he says, "favours are more important than friends."

We see Willie ending a dinner with a smartly-suited associate; the two shake hands warmly.

"It's about making people feel wanted in life. Making them feel appreciated."

Cut to Willie shaking another man's hand, while Leo keeps watch outside.

"You find out what they like, and you make it happen for them. They want to go to a ball game, or a show, you get 'em tickets."

Cut to Willie with the second man, pulling an envelope from his inside jacket pocket.

"A little something for the wife or girlfriend? You get 'em a fur."

Cut to Willie outside his car, beaming and handing a third man a fur coat.

"Sometimes all they want is an expensive bottle of wine."

Cut to Willie slapping a man's back.

"If all they want is cash, there's always plenty of that."

Cut to Willie, sidling up to Leo, and handing him a bundle of notes.

"If you take care of them, the business is going to take care of you."

He whispers in Leo's ear.

"Just don't spend it all in one place."

fields.bodyText: New York. In voiceover, Willie Gutierrez (Joaquin Phoenix) explains to his friend Leo Handler (Mark Wahlberg) how the city's subway operation runs on his and boss Frank Olchin's behalf. "In the business," he says, "favours are more important than friends." We see Willie ending a dinner with a smartly-suited associate; the two shake hands warmly. "It's about making people feel wanted in life. Making them feel appreciated." Cut to Willie shaking another man's hand, while Leo keeps watch outside. "You find out what they like, and you make it happen for them. They want to go to a ball game, or a show, you get 'em tickets." Cut to Willie with the second man, pulling an envelope from his inside jacket pocket. "A little something for the wife or girlfriend? You get 'em a fur." Cut to Willie outside his car, beaming and handing a third man a fur coat. "Sometimes all they want is an expensive bottle of wine." Cut to Willie slapping a man's back. "If all they want is cash, there's always plenty of that." Cut to Willie, sidling up to Leo, and handing him a bundle of notes. "If you take care of them, the business is going to take care of you." He whispers in Leo's ear. "Just don't spend it all in one place." fields.headline: 10 best videos for Christmas
fields.standfirst: Rob Mackie selects the 10 best videos for Christmas
fields.trailText: Rob Mackie selects the 10 best videos for Christmas
fields.body:
Fight Club
Rental, retail (£14.99) and DVD (£24.99)
Fox Path&eacute
Cert 18

An anti-consumerists' dream. A handbook in applied anarchy. A knuckle sandwich in the face of Hollywood's incessant pandering to the lowest common denominator. Fight Club is sly as a fox, busting with ideas, wildly unpredictable, brilliantly directed by David Fincher, and with career-best performances all-round. And its best gags are way beyond what the Farrellys think is bad taste.

American Beauty
Rental, retail (£16.99) and DVD (£24.99)
Universal
Cert 18

Confirmed Kevin Spacey as the Sultan of Sly in his comical but tender lead role as henpecked worm on the turn. Debutant Sam Mendes took on US suburbia, keeping up appearances and bottled- up lives unravelling and - with the help of a witty script and an apposite score - emerged with a bunch of Oscars: a rare example of the Academy recognising one of its year's best.

The Insider
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Buena Vista
Cert 15

The more remarkable half of Russell Crowe's double whammy. He was fine as the straightforward action man hero of Gladiator but he was a revelation as the hesitant, middle-aged, overweight whistleblower hero of Michael Mann's audacious film, matched against Al Pacino's gruff intensity. This was a long, dark and above all thoughtful film about business and morals. Demands concentration but repays it.

Bringing Out the Dead
Rental, retail (£12.99) and DVD (£15.99)
Buena Vista/Warner
Cert 18

You may have read reviews saying, "Scorsese's done it all before and better, blah blah..." What piffle. This was New York's finest back with Paul Schrader (Taxi Driver's writer) and in exhilarating form dragging us through a long, dark night of the soul for Nicolas Cage's tortured paramedic. Guilt, redemption, demons from the past, gallows humour and Van Morrison's TB Sheets as a kind of Greek chorus.

Bowfinger
Rental, retail (£16.99) and DVD (£19.99)
Universal
Cert 12

Irresistibly daft Steve Martin comedy that reminded you of 1980s triumphs (and helped you forget his vapid 1990s stuff). Martin is the director making a film for $2,184, Eddie Murphy is unexpectedly hilarious as the unknowing star (and his dimwitted brother). Stuffed with memorable lines, wacky ideas and actors having a ball. I just wish we could see Chubby Rain, the film-within-a-film, too.

The Cup
Retail (£15.99)
Alliance
Atlantis
Cert PG

A hilarious and utterly charming film directed by a lama and starring Tibetan monks. One of them, a tough new recruit with a Ronaldo T-shirt under his robes, is determined to see as much of the '98 World Cup as possible, mainly through extortion and bribery. This is far nearer to an Ealing comedy than anything we've produced in years and just as cynical about outsiders and authority.

Go
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Columbia Tristar
Cert 18

The follow-up to Doug Liman's memorable Swingers is even better. It's dynamically paced, stylistically adventurous and full of unusual characters who take the plot in unpredictable directions. Liman returns to a key scene and follows different characters each time. It's like American Graffiti re-shot in the style of Mystery Train. You need to stay more alert than some of the participants to follow it all.

Magnolia
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
EV
Cert 18

Deep, dark and dangerous multi-character film by Paul Thomas Anderson of Boogie Nights fame. Anderson visits a plague of frogs and many crises on his characters in a strange, bleak, ambitious tale full of regret, guilt and doppelgangers. The director brought something entirely new out of Tom Cruise in a sinister turn and was well served by William H Macy, Philip Baker Hall and Julianne Moore.

The Iron Giant
Retail (£14.99) and DVD (£15.99)
Warner
Cert U

Witty and delightful cartoon which brought Ted Hughes's story to life with humour, suspense and some terrific set pieces. It takes a child's viewpoint without ever being childish and combines elements of King Kong, Frankenstein and The Snowman to create another story of depth and resonance. And, as it's set in the 1950s, you get the Coasters' wonderful Searchin' and no saccharine songs at all.

The Matrix
Rental, retail (£16.99) and DVD (£19.99)
Warner
Cert 15

OK, yes, you could have bought this last Christmas and maybe you did. But it was just too late for last year's list so I'm picking it this year. Visually, its mindbending, gravity-defying tricks haven't been matched since and it was made for the DVD format. If Kafka had re-written Alice in Wonderland, it would have been a lot like this. Matrix 2 and 3 are being shot back to back.
