The most interesting aspect of France's BSE scandal is that it makes no sense at all. Britain stopped exporting contaminated cattle feed to Europe in 1991 (though we continued sending it to the third world until 1996). In most other EU countries cases have already peaked and declined, as expected.

But in France, the number of infected animals has doubled in the last year. It is impossible to see how this pattern could result from the export of British bone meal.

The simple fact is that the transmission of BSE has never been satisfactorily explained by the prevailing theory. The consumption of meat and bone meal from infected cows has doubtless had an important role to play. Yet this explanation alone fails to account for the huge numbers of cattle in Britain which continued to become infected after most contaminated feed had been removed from the food chain. The latest research on the human form of the disease, nvCJD, published three weeks ago, failed to find any link with the consumption of infected beef.

You might have imagined that when its theory isn't working, a government would wish to test the alternatives. But the British administration has, so far, sought only to attack a hypothesis which does appear to fit the facts. Since 1988, a Somerset farmer called Mark Purdey has been arguing that scientists have overlooked the root causes of BSE. Self-taught and self- financed, he has mastered the brain's complex biochemical pathways and this year published a groundbreaking paper in a respected medical journal. His reward is to have been reviled, misrepresented and physically attacked.

Prions, the brain proteins whose alteration seems to be responsible for BSE, are designed to protect the brain from the oxidising properties of chemicals activated by dangerous agents such as ultra- violet light, Purdey argues. When, he suggests, the prion proteins are exposed to too little copper and too much manganese, the manganese takes the place of the copper the prion normally binds to. This means that the protein becomes distorted and loses its function.

BSE arose in British herds during the 1980s, Mark Purdey asserts, because the Ministry of Agriculture started forcing all cattle farmers to treat their animals with an organophosphate pesticide called phosmet, at far higher doses than are used elsewhere in the world. The pesticide had to be poured along the line of the spinal cord. Phosmet, Purdey has shown, captures copper. At the same time, cattle feed was being supplemented with chicken manure, from birds dosed with manganese to increase their egg yield. The prion proteins in the cows' brains were both deprived of copper and dosed with manganese. In France, the use of phosmet first became mandatory in Brittany. Twenty of the country's initial 28 cases of BSE emerged there. BSE's subsequent spread, Purdey maintains, mirrors the use of the pesticide.

Poisoning by similar means may explain the distribution of the human form of the disease. Of the two main clusters in Britain one, in Kent, is in the middle of a fruit and hop growing area where huge quantities of both organophosphates and manganese-based fungicides are used. The other is in Queniborough in Leicestershire, whose dyeworks (until they caught fire a few years ago, spraying chemicals over the village) used to dump some of their residues into the sewage system, Purdey alleges. The sewage was spread over the fields. Dyeworks use shedloads of manganese.

Purdey has tested his theory on BSE and CJD clusters in Iceland, Colorado, Slovakia and Sardinia. He found that people and animals had been exposed to deficiencies of copper and surfeits of manganese. Most of the clusters, intriguingly, are in mountainous areas, where levels of ultraviolet light are high. But the most compelling evidence in support of his hypothesis comes from a paper published by a team of biochemists at Cambridge this year. They found that when copper was substituted by manganese in prion proteins, the prions adopted precisely the distinguishing features which identify the infective agent in BSE.

If Purdey is right, he deserves a Nobel Prize for medicine. Instead he has been shot at, his phone lines have been cut and his house has been burnt down. The Ministry of Agriculture, which for 50 years has enjoyed a dangerously close relationship with the agrochemical industry, has repeatedly sought to discredit him. Suddenly, however, its tone has changed, and it has now promised to start funding his research. The families of the French victims of CJD are threatening to sue the British government, and it desperately needs an alternative transmission theory. With funding on its way, and new evidence accumulating every month, a self-educated Somerset dairy farmer could be about to overturn the entire body of scientific research on the biggest public health scandal of modern times.

webTitle: Illegal migrants sneaking out of Britain

fields.headline: Illegal migrants sneaking out of Britain
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Police at Liverpool docks revealed yesterday that they have caught more than 100 illegal migrants in the past year, trying to get out of the country rather than into it.
fields.body:
Police at Liverpool docks revealed yesterday that they have caught more than 100 illegal migrants in the past year, trying to get out of the country rather than into it.

Most were originally from eastern Europe and the Balkans and wanted to stow away on container ships to join relatives in what they saw as the promised lands in the US or Canada.

"Few speak English," said Superintendent Mike Hindley. "They have little with them, just the clothes they stand in and a rucksack with water and chocolate bars."

Having smuggled themselves on to a boat, the migrants would surrender to the crew two or three days into the voyage and then claim asylum when the vessel docked.

Immigration services in Canada and the US complained, as did ship owners faced with fines running into thousands of pounds.

In response, dock police stepped up security by adding fence alarms and security cameras at the docks, a huge complex visited by 5,000 vehicles a day. Extra night patrols were carried out by officers in camouflage suits, with close checks made on a nature reserve bordering the complex.

"We seemed to be in the only force in the country dealing with people leaving the country rather than coming in," said Supt Hindley. "Before we introduced the new measures, about a dozen people had made it on to a boat. But there has been only one in the past nine months."

Most of those arrested were known to the immigration authorities and were waiting decisions on their applications to stay. "One or two who had not registered had come in through Dover and been in hiding in the UK before trying to cross the Atlantic," added Supt Hindley.

"We are really trying to catch the people who are making money out of this. We knew it was organised, that someone was taking cash, bringing the migrants to Liverpool and showing them the way into the docks.

"We caught one of them and he was deported back to Romania. After that, the numbers dried up for a bit. But there are other groups involved. Half the time they just drop these people at the fence and leave them to it."

Not all migrants who have made it on to a ship have reached their chosen destinations: by choosing the wrong cargo some found themselves in Scotland or Ireland.

fields.headline: Strike could spread across NHS
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Industrial action could spread across the national health service, the public service union Unison warned yesterday, unless plans to privatise the jobs of hundreds of health workers in Dudley as part of the government's private finance initiative are abandoned.
fields.body:
Industrial action could spread across the national health service, the public service union Unison warned yesterday, unless plans to privatise the jobs of hundreds of health workers in Dudley as part of the government's private finance initiative are abandoned.

Around 600 hospital workers in the West Midlands town have begun their seventh strike against transfer to the private sector, in a dispute which has become the front line in the growing resistance to the public finance initiative in the health service.

Yesterday was the second full day of a two week stoppage by non-clinical staff at four Dudley hospitals, whose jobs have been earmarked for transfer to Summit Healthcare, a private consortium, in an industrial stand-off that is being claimed as the longest series of strikes in the NHS.

Rodney Bickerstaffe, Unison's general secretary, said the "very principled stand" of the low paid Dudley workers had the full backing of the national union, while the West Midlands Unison official Fiona Westwood warned: "If they don't back off in Dudley, industrial unrest over PFI is likely to spread."

The campaign of walkouts by Unison members, who have now clocked up 44 days on strike, has escalated from an initial two day stoppage in August. A mass meeting of Dudley strikers yesterday voted to back a three week strike over Christmas.

At issue are the health trust's plans to hand hospital buildings and non-clinical services and employees - including porters, cleaners and IT staff - over to the private sector on a 40-year £80m contract.

In return, the private consortium, which includes Siemens, Building & Property and Sir Robert McAlpine, will rebuild one of Dudley's four hospitals as a "super hospital", turn two others into outpatient centres and close the fourth, with a loss of 70 beds.

Despite advice from the health secretary, Alan Milburn, last year that PFI contracts need not include the transfer of non-clinical staff to the private sector, Dudley trust management says it is too late to revise the contract, which is due to be signed within weeks.

The strikers have been promised there will be no change to their terms and conditions, but strike leaders say they do not trust the undertakings, which anyway would not cover new recruits.

webTitle: Call for more money to lure passengers back to trains

fields.headline: Call for more money to lure passengers back to trains
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The 25 rail companies should produce a big national offer in 2001 to encourage people to use the railway again, Stewart Francis, chairman of the rail passengers' council, said yesterday. He said the council was pressing for the introduction of a two for one ticket, which would allow passengers to make the same journey twice with one ticket.
fields.body:
The 25 rail companies should produce a big national offer in 2001 to encourage people to use the railway again, Stewart Francis, chairman of the rail passengers' council, said yesterday. He said the council was pressing for the introduction of a two for one ticket, which would allow passengers to make the same journey twice with one ticket.

Mr Francis was responding to a £50m compensation package for passengers announced by the Association of Train Operating Companies. It has been jointly funded by Railtrack, the shadow strategic rail authority and the train companies.

The package offers up to four weeks' free travel for those suffering the greatest disruption. About 500,000 passengers will receive three weeks' free travel, including most London commuters.

Mr Francis said the deal for daily and weekly passengers should reflect the level of disruption. "I am concerned they will only be dealt with in line with passenger charters. Passengers should only need to provide proof of travel, which will help many claim if they have not kept tickets."

Mr Francis said the passengers had called for a "simple, clear compensation package from each company, bound by a national statement".

One suggestion was that the companies should have announced at least one week's free travel for everybody but this was rejected.

Mr Francis said: "Once again we have seen an industry that is seemingly incapable of speaking with a single voice."

George Muir, the association's director general, said: "No amount of compensation can make up for the delays and inconvenience passengers have experienced since the Hatfield accident. But we hope this package goes some way to letting them know we recognise the frustration."

He said that although some people were already getting their compensation, others might have to wait several weeks. "We aim to pay as quickly as possible, but would ask everybody to be patient. This will be the largest compensation package the rail industry has ever arranged and delivered."

Passengers with weekly or daily tickets will have to enclose proof of travel and details of the journey and delays experienced to qualify for normal refunds, usually 20% of the cost of the ticket.

Mr Muir said in exceptional circumstances passengers could produce a letter from their employers showing that they normally travelled to work by train. This is because thousands of passengers have probably thrown away tickets.

The association said the level of disruption had been evaluated for each route and local arrangements would generally allow compensation by cheque or credit card refund. Passengers will be told through local announcements whether, instead of a monetary refund, they can choose additional days' extensions to season tickets, but this will not always be possible.

It accepted that some companies might have done more to warn passengers to keep tickets during the crisis.

fields.headline: Stranded in the north
fields.standfirst:
Peter Hetherington is based in northern Britain, where business and family travel is turning into a nightmare

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Britain is in crisis, paralysed. Local businesses are at breaking point, sometimes unable to send valuable goods to export markets and managers to meetings. Dispersed families cannot link up for important occasions. Holiday plans have been scrapped. People feel trapped, helpless and increasingly desperate as the clock turns back to the 19th century.
fields.body:
Britain is in crisis, paralysed. Local businesses are at breaking point, sometimes unable to send valuable goods to export markets and managers to meetings. Dispersed families cannot link up for important occasions. Holiday plans have been scrapped. People feel trapped, helpless and increasingly desperate as the clock turns back to the 19th century.

It is difficult to overstate the deep sense of foreboding in the outlying regions of a country whose transport system has collapsed and shows little sign of immediate improvement - even to reach the level of some third world countries, let alone emerging first world economies in eastern Europe. Railways, where they run at all, often operate at half speed and half capacity. Domestic airlines, cashing in on the crisis, cannot take the strain. Once quiet roads in the north are jammed.

John Prescott's transport and environment policy is in tatters with more cars pumping more hydrocarbons into the atmosphere as people abandon rail for the roads.

This week, we are meant to be grateful. A service, of sorts, is resuming on Britain's supposedly most modern east coast line. This comes a month after the fatal Hatfield train crash finally exposed our rail system as an antiquated network, shamefully - criminally? - neglected by people more interested in transforming stations into shopping malls and exploiting property assets than in providing a safe railway.

Courtesy of public money and EU aid, the east coast mainline connecting Edinburgh to King's Cross, was electrified (on the cheap) 10 years ago. But at least in those days British Rail's Intercity subsidiary could provide a decent service. Latterly, its private Great North Eastern Railway successor on the east coast has been struggling. Those of us in the north-east using the service have been forced to endure long-delayed trains so overcrowded that they verge on the dangerous.

While a succession of problems are blamed, it is clear that the overhead power supply is giving particular cause for concern. This is in addition to the bottlenecks on the track itself, such as the notoriously narrow Welwyn Viaduct, and the inability of the network around King's Cross to cope with modern electric trains.

For the past few weeks, the combination of the Hatfield derailment and a railway embankment landslip near Doncaster has more than doubled travel times to London from Edinburgh and the north-east. Unable to run trains between Newcastle and Doncaster, GNER has been offering a bus service instead. Normally the company runs 27 trains a day, transporting 13,500 people between Newcastle and London and almost as many to and from Scotland.

Some north-east businessmen have taken to flying to Heathrow - at £271 return almost double the standard rail fare. Others have simply abandoned Britain and begun looking abroad for work. One businessman says he finds it easier to fly to Brussels and Amsterdam than to get to London. With markets shrinking small and medium-sized firms are feeling the pinch from a doubling of transport costs (if they are lucky enough to find a flight). Jobs are at risk. Some businesses are considering moving closer to markets in the south, further widening a north-south divide which is already causing ministers concern as the election approaches.

Not for nothing did Tony Blair rail against Railtrack last week. The collapse of Britain's transport system is hitting the economy of regions like his adopted north-east, where unemployment (at 9%) had been falling.

On the reopened east coast line the journey time from Edinburgh to King's Cross - once four hours and 20 minutes on some trains - will almost double. It could take six hours to get from Newcastle to London. The result? Thousands will forgo rail. After Christmas, the service might get back to something like normal - although with 100 speed restrictions still in force due to track repairs (some slowing 125mph trains down to 20mph) GNER oozes pessimism.

The company recently leased two redundant 14-coach Eurostar trains to take the strain off its eight-coach trains between London and York. But they can't be used during rush-hour because of "insufficient" generating capacity around King's Cross. Many also suspect that the Eurostar, a variant of the French TGV, cannot be used from York to Edinburgh because overhead power lines, track, stations and signalling are unable to cope with heavier and more powerful trains.

With little sign of track improvements on the east coast line - never mind the more dilapidated west coast route - some ministers clearly fear that Britain's collapsing transport infrastructure will become a key election issue. Promises of improvements from a battered John Prescott will not be enough. In 2000, people just want to travel with the ease of their parents and grandparents, when journey times seemed shorter. But in third world Britain, that's clearly asking for the earth.

webTitle: Perils of cheap flights may force up prices

fields.headline: Perils of cheap flights may force up prices
fields.standfirst:
Threat of blood clots could make flyers accept need for more leg room
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Opting for cheap flights may prove so dangerous that passengers will have to accept higher prices, a Labour peer said yesterday, as the House of Lords called for more research into links between potentially fatal blood clots and flying.
fields.body:
Opting for cheap flights may prove so dangerous that passengers will have to accept higher prices, a Labour peer said yesterday, as the House of Lords called for more research into links between potentially fatal blood clots and flying.

At a press conference to publicise the report by the science and technology committee into in-flight conditions, Lord Winston, a leading consultant, said: "We understand very well that mass air travel has had a liberating influence on our society... but there may need to be some cost involved with the implementation of the report.

"It may well be that flying too cheaply is potentially too risky and there may well have to be a trade-off."

His warning was backed by Michael Davies, a former director of health at British Airways and specialist adviser to the committee, who suggested that people should accept that long haul flights could become the preserve of the rich.

He said: "Ideally, everyone should have a first class seat at an economy price." But he added that it was more realistic that passengers would have to pay for more leg room and wider seats.

Last night, the airline industry criticised the comments by pointing out that the report itself found that deep vein thrombosis (DVT) - dubbed "economy class syndrome" - was just as likely to strike first and business class passengers.

"The report clearly says that "economy class syndrome" is a total misnomer: the risks apply to everyone and it is sitting around for a long time which causes the risk," said Roger Wiltshire, secretary general of the British Air Transport Association, which represents several of Britain's airlines.

A spokeswoman for Britannia Airways, which offers charter flights to the United States and Caribbean, added that many customers preferred not to fork out an extra £120-£195 for up to 6in more legroom. "Some of our extra leg room seats remain empty: for whatever reason, some of our passengers aren't prepared to pay the extra," she said.

Under current regulations, economy class seats in British planes can offer as little as 26in for every passenger, with many long haul flights offering just 31in.

The Lords' report comes a month after the death of Emma Christofferson, a 28-year-old sales assistant, who developed a blood clot after sitting in an economy seat for the 20-hour return journey from Australia.

The report accepts that there is, as yet, no proven link between an increased risk of DVT and flying, but says the wealth of anecdotal evidence - a few case collection reports and a case control study - justifies further research. The Departments of Health and Transport have since started to carry out studies.

Claiming that the airline industry has "woefully neglected" the health of its passengers, the report calls for health warnings to be issued with long haul tickets which would outline ways of preventing potentially fatal blood clots.

One in 1,000 people will develop the condition each year, with 30,000 dying, and pregnant women, smokers, those suffering from heart disease and women on HRT or the pill being most in danger.

Yesterday, the committee said taking low doses of aspirin, drinking water, avoiding alcohol and exercising during flights could reduce the risk of developing the condition.

The report also controversially suggested that long coach and rail journeys held similar risks.

 move around in seat and cabin as much as practicable

 flex calf muscles half-hourly and rotate ankles for a few minutes

 avoid alcohol and drinks containing caffeine

 drink only water or caffeine-free soft drinks

Those at minor risk - the over 40, very tall, short or obese, who have had recent minor surgery or extensive varicose veins

 take only short sleeps

 do not take sleeping pills

 consider wearing support stockings

Those at moderate risk - pregnant, on the pill or HRT, with a family history of deep vein thrombosis, recent leg surgery or recent heart disease

 ask doctor about the risks involved

 take aspirin before the flight

 take advice about compression stockings

Those at substantial risk - with DVT, known clotting tendency, recent surgery or stroke, paralysed lower limb(s)

 get prescription of low molecular weight heparin

 avoid flying

Hidden danger of the cramped long haul flight

 Jill Dawson was just five hours into her 14-hour return flight from Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, when she stood up and felt "a massive pain" in the back of her thigh.

"It was like a knife cutting in," she recalled. "Then, after half an hour, my lower calf started swelling and I knew at once it was a thrombosis."

Terrified of what could happen next, Mrs Dawson, 54, a businesswoman from Aldridge in the West Midlands, called over a British Airways steward who, she claims, showed little sympathy for her.

"I told her it was a thrombosis but she told me it was just a swelling, that they saw a lot of this and that I should see my GP 24 hours after getting back. If I had done what she suggested, I would have been dead," she said.

With the staff allegedly refusing to call for a doctor, she was forced to lie across three seats in the aircraft while the top of her thigh swelled by a third. "The staff just came back to say they'd arranged for a wheelchair at Heathrow - and when I got there I had to hop from the plane."

Mrs Dawson was driven straight to Ealing hospital, west London, where her life-threatening deep vein thrombosis was diagnosed and treated. "It was a very extreme case. If I hadn't had the revolutionary new treatment, I would have had my leg amputated. As it was, I was in intensive care for 36 hours."

British Airways rejected her allegation that cabin staff were negligent or inept, but Mrs Dawson, who is in none of the high risk groups, feels more could have been done to have prevented her blood clot. "DVT is an easily preventable problem if only the airlines would give some verbal advice - it's no use having it buried in an inflight magazine people don't read. Doing this could save so many lives."

 Emma Christoffersen, the Marks & Spencer sales assistant whose death last month sparked the recent awareness of "economy class syndrome", collapsed shortly after completing a 20-hour flight from Australia.

The 28-year-old, from Newport, south Wales, who was about to marry, complained of feeling unwell within minutes of the Quantas jet touching down at Heathrow. She lost consciousness in the arrivals hall and died before she reached a hospital.

Ruth Christoffersen, her mother, recalled: "We were told she died from sitting in the cramped seat of a jumbo jet for such a long time."

Her fiance, Tim Stuart, added: "Emma was fit and active and a non-smoker - all of the things not usually associated with sufferers of DVT. It's not as if she had never been on a plane before, as we had been on holiday to the States twice and Barbados, all on long-haul flights... [the condition] seems to strike at random, and in a way it's just like Russian roulette. And it could happen to anyone."

webTitle: Ministers offer pension deal to avert new Lords defeat on air traffic sale

fields.headline: Ministers offer pension deal to avert new Lords defeat on air traffic sale
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The government is preparing to make concessions over the planned part privatisation of national air traffic services in a bid to rescue the measure from a second defeat in the Lords and a possible loss of the £1bn sale.
fields.body:
The government is preparing to make concessions over the planned part privatisation of national air traffic services in a bid to rescue the measure from a second defeat in the Lords and a possible loss of the £1bn sale.

Peers voted by 112 votes to 90 voting to delay the sale of Nats until after the next election, a decision reversed in the Commons last week despite a sizeable backbench Labour revolt. Conservative and Liberal Democrat peers are now preparing to challenge the government again when the transport bill containing the measure returns to the Lords on Monday. The shadow cabinet met to discuss tactics yesterday.

But the Treasury is now preparing to make concessions to buy off what they regard as the key group of Labour rebels in the Lords, including Lord Brett, the former general secretary of the IPMS, the union of air traffic controllers. Lord Brett was a leader of one of the large group of Labour abstainers on October 26.

Ministers have been told that Lord Brett and a group of Labour peers are "willing to sell their soul" and accept the part privatisation, so long as they are given concessions designed to reassure the existing workforce that their pensions will be safeguarded. Treasury and Department of Environment ministers are preparing to offer Lord Brett new reassurances that any firm taking over Nats cannot raid its pension fund surplus.

The Treasury has until now opposed the demand saying it would place an unnecessary burden on the proposed public private partnership. But Treasury ministers are now planning to table concessions in the form of an amendment. They are also going to table separate amendments stating the civil aviation authority pension scheme trustees will not be legally liable in any dispute over the pension fund. The trustees had been preparing to spend £1m to take the government to court over their liability.

Lord Brett is awaiting details of the amendments, but warns the government could just still face defeat on Monday if the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats marshall their forces. If the government is defeated, its business managers will rush the bill back to the Commons to reverse the defeat a second time, provoking a constitutional clash. The issue would then be returned for a third Lords vote later in the week.

Ministers have to settle the issue quickly with time running out for the current parliarmentary session before the Queen's speech opening a new one on December 6. A poll showed yesterday that the majority of voters want Nats to remain in public hands. The NOP survey showed that 62% of the public disagree with the selling off of part of the Nats, according to the poll of 1,000 people.

Just 21% favour partnership proposals and only 11% believe it should be fully privatised, the study for ITN's Powerhouse programme, screened on Channel 4, revealed.

webTitle: Faraway Tonga cashes in on its gene pool secrets

fields.headline: Faraway Tonga cashes in on its gene pool secrets
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: The isolated Pacific archipelago of Tonga is to add DNA to its more usual trade in fish, coconuts and coffee, after striking a deal to help an Australian biotechnology firm find the genetic cause of common diseases.
fields.body:
The isolated Pacific archipelago of Tonga is to add DNA to its more usual trade in fish, coconuts and coffee, after striking a deal to help an Australian biotechnology firm find the genetic cause of common diseases.

Autogen Ltd hopes to isolate rogue genes linked to inherited illnesses by assembling a DNA database of people in the tropical kingdom, located 1,245 miles north-east of New Zealand.

Tonga's isolation and the ethnic homogeneity of its Polynesian population removes "genetic distractions" for scientists, the chairman of Autogen, Joseph Gutnick, said yesterday.

"The less mixture of interracial marriage, the more likely you are able to determine a particular gene that may be responsible for a particular disease, whether it's breast cancer or whether it's kidney disease," Mr Gutnick said. "There may be a gene that's common to a particular family and you need to isolate it. That's easier if the population has been isolated."

Tonga, which has 170 islands, was colonised by Polynesian people almost 3,500 years ago. Dubbed the "friendly islands" by Captain Cook in the 18th century, Tonga was a British protectorate between 1900 and 1970. But its population remained untouched by immigration and just 300 of its 108,000 people today are of European origin.

The islands' unique family structure will also aid the five-year research programme. Traditionally the inhabitants of small Tongan villages have been blood relations, living in extended family groups, although recent urbanisation has complicated the gene pool.

Similar experiments are being conducted among isolated people who share similar DNA maps in southern Italy and on Pingelap island and Norfolk island in the Pacific, as biotechnology companies race to find lucrative cures for common diseases.

A research lab will be established by Autogen at a hospital in Nuku'Alofa, the capital of Tonga, to collect DNA samples and map the genetic mix of the population and its diseases. The Melbourne-based company specialises in identifying genes found in people with diabetes and obesity.

Tonga will receive royalties from any successful commercial ventures, such as new drug treatments, that emerge from the study. The country will also own all DNA samples collected by Autogen's scientists.

Millions could be spent in Tonga as the research develops, a welcome boost to an economy based around fishing and tourism, which is also dependent on foreign aid to offset its trade deficit.

But selling its DNA secrets to scientists is not the only way Tonga's constitutional monarchy is obtaining hard currency in the modern global economy. The kingdom is also offering ".to" web addresses for £35 a year, ploughing the proceeds into funding further education programmes for its population.

webTitle: Gene therapy experiment offers hope to diabetics

fields.headline: Gene therapy experiment offers hope to diabetics
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Scientists have used gene therapy to treat diabetic mice and rats, they report today. It could be many years before humans benefit, but the research raises hopes for people with type 1 or insulin-dependent diabetes.
fields.body:
Scientists have used gene therapy to treat diabetic mice and rats, they report today. It could be many years before humans benefit, but the research raises hopes for people with type 1 or insulin-dependent diabetes.

This auto-immune disease begins in early life and ends in the destruction of the insulin-producing cells in the pancreas. The only treatment is to inject insulin to adjust blood sugar levels.

Ji-Won Yoon and others from the University of Seoul report in Nature today that they made an artificial gene which coded for an insulin substitute, and transferred it to a harmless virus. They injected the virus into diabetic rats and mice.

Both species were able to secrete the synthetic insulin into their bloodstreams for up to eight months. During that time, they had normal blood glucose levels without side effects.

fields.headline: Heath 'approved Londonderry massacre'
fields.standfirst:
QC tells hearing that orders for a 'turkey shoot' of nationalists came from highest army command and from Downing Street
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The killing of 13 unarmed Catholic demonstrators on Bloody Sunday in Londonderry in 1972 was a deliberate plan approved by the then prime minister of the United Kingdom, Edward Heath, and his Northern Ireland counterpart, Brian Falkner, as well as their most senior military advisers, the new inquiry into the events was told yesterday.
fields.byline: Maggie O'Kane in Londonderry and David Pallister
fields.body:
The killing of 13 unarmed Catholic demonstrators on Bloody Sunday in Londonderry in 1972 was a deliberate plan approved by the then prime minister of the United Kingdom, Edward Heath, and his Northern Ireland counterpart, Brian Falkner, as well as their most senior military advisers, the new inquiry into the events was told yesterday.

The secret plan, drawn up by the army, led, according to Lord Gifford QC, to a "turkey shoot" in some parts of Derry. Bloody Sunday, on January 20th 1972, was the most controversial day in Northern Ireland's troubled history. It led to hundreds of young Catholics joining the IRA.

Lord Gifford is representing the family of one of the dead - 22-year-old Jim Wray, who, according to eye witnesses, was shot once in Glenfada Park then finished off at close range with a bullet in the back.

Lord Gifford told the inquiry that while there was no written evidence to support his claim, he would prove in the coming weeks that the killing of unarmed civilians was approved at the highest political and military level as a last resort following demands by local and powerful Protestant businessmen to get the "hooligans" under control. And that the "turkey shoot" was not the actions of indisciplined troops, but rather a group of soldiers who had been authorised by their superiors to shoot.

Attempting to explain why no such orders were written, Lord Gifford quoted from a letter from another former prime minister, Jim Callaghan: "Very heavy pressure was brought to bear on the army commanders to step up their attitude. I don't suppose any of us will ever know whether they were acting on their own judgment or whether they yielded to the judgment of others... I am sure such information would never have been committed to paper but would have been passed on by word of mouth."

At yesterday's hearing Lord Gifford quoted from the testimony of a former private in the parachute regiment accused of carrying out the killings who said: "One night in January 1972, I was sitting with the rest of my muckers of the anti-tank platoon in the barracks when our lieutenant informed us that we were due for an operation in Londonderry the following day. He said that the heart of Derry had been bombed out. Several hundred soldiers had been hospitalised... the people of the Creggan had not paid rent and had been hijacking their food for several years. We were all in high spirits and our lieutenant said let us teach those guys a lesson and get some "kills" tomorrow. To the mentality of the blokes he was speaking to that was tantamount to an order."

Lord Gifford will insist that orders to kill demonstrators were so politically explosive that it would not have been left to local commanders. He claimed that the parachute regiment, brutalised by previous campaigns in Aden, were sent to Derry because of their aggressive approach and that they used racist and abusive language against local people.

Quoting a local woman who was present when two members of the parachute regiment entered the house where another woman was wounded, Lord Gifford said she had recalled one soldier screaming at the wounded woman: "Let the whore bleed to death." When the woman told the soldiers that another man was wounded in the yard the second soldier replied: "Let them all die."

Lord Gifford also said he would rely on a memo from General Robert Ford - then the army's second-in-command in Northern Ireland - to Sir Harry Tuzo, general officer commanding in the province, in which he said that the time had come to shoot dead rioters in the city, known among troops as the "Derry Young Hooligans".

General Ford wrote: "Against the DYH - the army in Londonderry is... virtually incapable. This incapacity undermines our ability to deal with the bombers and gunmen and threatens what is left of law and order on the west bank of the River Foyle.

"Attempts to close with the DYH bring the troops into the killing zone of the snipers. As I understand it, the commander of a body of troops called out to restore law and order has a duty to use minimum force but he also has a duty to restore law and order.

"We have fulfilled the first duty but are failing in the second.

"I am coming to the conclusion that the minimum force necessary to achieve a restoration of law and order is to shoot selected ringleaders amongst the DYH, after clear warnings have been issued. I believe we would be justified in using 7.62mm but in view of the devastating effects of this weapon and the dangers of rounds killing more than one person, I believe we must consider issuing rifles adapted to fire .22 inch ammunition to sufficient members of the unit dealing with this problem to enable ringleaders to be engaged with this less lethal ammunition.

"If this course is implemented, as I believe it may have to be, we would have to accept the possibility that .22 rounds may be lethal. In other words, we would be reverting to the methods of internal security found successful on many occasions overseas, but would merely be trying to minimise the lethal effects by using the .22 round. "I am convinced that our duty to restore law and order requires us to consider this step"

In his statement General Ford said: "The suggestion to shoot a few leaders was not an instruction to kill. Shoot and kill are obviously different words."

The Ministry of Defence was criticised for not sending a representative to the £130m inquiry, which will run for at least another two years. Ms Eilish MacDermott QC, for the relatives of Patrick Doherty, said: "Could anyone imagine the recent Stephen Lawrence inquiry in England being conducted without the Metropolitan police being present.

"We say the truth... was and still is known to senior army officers and senior politicians of the day.

"It could be written on a sheet of paper if the political will to do so existed."

Asked about its failure to have a permanent legal representative at the inquiry, a Ministry of Defence spokesman told the Guardian: "There is a long-standing convention that ministers and civil servants should not comment on the proceedings of a public inquiry."

Lord Gifford will insist that orders to kill demonstrators were so politically explosive that it would not have been left to local commanders. He claimed that the parachute regiment, brutalised by previous campaigns in Aden, were sent to Derry because of their aggressive approach and that they used racist and abusive language against local people. Quoting a local woman who was present when two members of the parachute regiment entered the house where another woman was wounded, Lord Gifford said she had recalled one soldier screaming at the wounded woman: "Let the whore bleed to death." When the woman told the soldiers that another man was wounded in the yard the second soldier replied: "Let them all die." Lord Gifford also said he would rely on a memo from General Robert Ford - then the army's second-in-command in Northern Ireland - to Sir Harry Tuzo, general officer commanding in the province, in which he said that the time had come to shoot dead rioters in the city, known among troops as the "Derry Young Hooligans". General Ford wrote: "Against the DYH - the army in Londonderry is... virtually incapable. This incapacity undermines our ability to deal with the bombers and gunmen and threatens what is left of law and order on the west bank of the River Foyle. "Attempts to close with the DYH bring the troops into the killing zone of the snipers. As I understand it, the commander of a body of troops called out to restore law and order has a duty to use minimum force but he also has a duty to restore law and order. "We have fulfilled the first duty but are failing in the second. "I am coming to the conclusion that the minimum force necessary to achieve a restoration of law and order is to shoot selected ringleaders amongst the DYH, after clear warnings have been issued. I believe we would be justified in using 7.62mm but in view of the devastating effects of this weapon and the dangers of rounds killing more than one person, I believe we must consider issuing rifles adapted to fire .22 inch ammunition to sufficient members of the unit dealing with this problem to enable ringleaders to be engaged with this less lethal ammunition. "If this course is implemented, as I believe it may have to be, we would have to accept the possibility that .22 rounds may be lethal. In other words, we would be reverting to the methods of internal security found successful on many occasions overseas, but would merely be trying to minimise the lethal effects by using the .22 round. "I am convinced that our duty to restore law and order requires us to consider this step" In his statement General Ford said: "The suggestion to shoot a few leaders was not an instruction to kill. Shoot and kill are obviously different words." The Ministry of Defence was criticised for not sending a representative to the £130m inquiry, which will run for at least another two years. Ms Eilish MacDermott QC, for the relatives of Patrick Doherty, said: "Could anyone imagine the recent Stephen Lawrence inquiry in England being conducted without the Metropolitan police being present. "We say the truth... was and still is known to senior army officers and senior politicians of the day. "It could be written on a sheet of paper if the political will to do so existed." Asked about its failure to have a permanent legal representative at the inquiry, a Ministry of Defence spokesman told the Guardian: "There is a long-standing convention that ministers and civil servants should not comment on the proceedings of a public inquiry."

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • There is no word as to when Gordon Brown plans to concede that he is dyeing his hair, partly perhaps because the Treasury is busy with a nascent public relations disaster concerning the extra winter fuel allowance for pensioners. In his pre-Budget report, the weirdo chancellor made much of this welcome electoral bribe (the allowance rises by £50 to £200), telling the Commons: "I can confirm that the cheques are being sent out from Monday."
fields.body:
 There is no word as to when Gordon Brown plans to concede that he is dyeing his hair, partly perhaps because the Treasury is busy with a nascent public relations disaster concerning the extra winter fuel allowance for pensioners. In his pre-Budget report, the weirdo chancellor made much of this welcome electoral bribe (the allowance rises by £50 to £200), telling the Commons: "I can confirm that the cheques are being sent out from Monday."

Well, he can bleedin' well unconfirm it because that Monday was November 13 and the cheques have not turned up yet. Pensioners swamping a special phone line in Cardiff are eventually told by recorded message: "If you are waiting for your cheque, you will get it by Christmas Day." This is a very poor show, especially with a freezing snap predicted soon. We can all comb black shoe polish into our temples, but what doth that profiteth our fellow man if we come over all Arthur Daley - "It's in the post, love, honest, I posted it meself" - with pensioners' extra fuel money?

 The conspiracy theory of the week comes courtesy of Who Wants To Be A Millionaire, which is suspected by the BBC of rigging its jackpot win for ratings reasons. Winner Judith Keppel was once married to Neil Shand, the comedy writer, it goes, who used to write for Jasper Carrott, a part-owner of Celador, the TV production company that makes Who Wants To Be A Millionaire. It's absolute rubbish, of course. But it's our rubbish.

 It's always a pleasure to resurrect an old favourite, and today we take Another Trip Down Memory Lane with Gus. He may swoon now at the idea of renationalising the railways, but Transport Minister Lord Macdonald once thought differently. Collecting a Political Studies Association award for World In Action on Tuesday in front of Edward Heath, Margaret Beckett and others, Granada's Ian McBride recalled how, when Gus was running the station, he used to tell his programme makers to "make the viewers sit up at the back"; and to "comfort the afflicted and afflict the comfortable". Isn't that very Mr Tony? I bet Gus trots that out every week at cabinet.

 Speaking of Gus, I am hoping to launch my new board game, Turncoat Olympics, in time for Christmas 2001. Using dice, cards with printed quotes stacked in two piles called Now and Then and coins (pieces of silver), players can gauge how well ministers are doing at abandoning once-cherished principles in return for gaining high office. Anyone experienced in board game design, preferably for Waddingtons, should get in touch.

 In the Mirror, gout-ridden working-class warrior Paul Routledge recalls the end of Thatcher. "I was glad that she was out, for one plain and simple reason," he writes. "She destroyed Arthur Scargill and the NUM." How odd this seems from someone who once compared Arthur Scargill to Nicolae Ceausescu, and wrote so scathing an unauthorised biography in 1993. As for Lady Thatcher, you'd have thought Gouters would thank her for changing the home rental laws in favour of the landlord; or landlady in this case, what with all those Yorkshire properties being in the name of Mrs Routledge. Ungrateful beast.

 There is no room today for step two of my mother's recipe for chicken soup. This will appear tomorrow. In the meantime, please follow step one and buy a large kosher boiling chicken in readiness. Those of you living in particularly goyishe areas can make do with an organic boiler.

 In Lausanne, Switzerland, German tourist Hermann Roeg miraculously survived a fall from the window of his 8th floor hotel room with no more than a broken ankle but died after he fell out of the ambulance taking him to hospital and under the wheels of a bus.

webTitle: Livingstone says tube bids aimed at property profit

fields.headline: Livingstone says tube bids aimed at property profit
fields.standfirst: Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone yesterday revealed that most of the bidders to run the London Underground in John Prescott's controversial public-private partnership, or PPP scheme, were more interested in using stations for property development than in "improving the track".
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone yesterday revealed that most of the bidders to run the London Underground in John Prescott's controversial public-private partnership, or PPP scheme, were more interested in using stations for property development than in "improving the track".

The mayor of London used an awards lunch at the Savoy hotel to warn ministers he had cleared his diary for the coming month to fight the scheme and warned the lord chancellor, Lord Irvine - who had just given him a prize - that he might go to court to overturn the government's policy.

"The good news is that the contracts are in. The bad news is all the bidders want to spend most of their time developing the stations, not improving the track," said Mr Livingstone, who has hired Bob Kiley, a top New York transport manager, to revitalise the system.

As the man who beat the Labour establishment to be elected mayor last May, and was expelled as a result, he had just won the "survivor of the year" award in the annual ceremony organised by the Spectator magazine and the Highland Park whisky distillers.

Mr Livingstone's speech followed one by Lady Young, co-winner as campaigner of the year for her fight against equalisation of the age of consent. He quipped he was planning to officiate over "my first gay registration ceremony" and divulged that he would not use the mayor's job "as a platform to cause the government more trouble. That's their job."

But his latest attack was a further sign he would continue pressing to retain public ownership and use bond issues to raise cash for modernisation. After studying the books Mr Kiley is to see Mr Prescott. Last night the mayor's office could offer no elaboration on his remarks.

fields.headline: Kosovo killing
fields.standfirst:
Explosion adds to fears of renewed violence

Special report: Serbia
Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: A senior member of Yugoslavia's government warned yesterday that war could start once again in the Balkans, after renewed fighting on the boundary between Kosovo and Serbia.
fields.body:
A senior member of Yugoslavia's government warned yesterday that war could start once again in the Balkans, after renewed fighting on the boundary between Kosovo and Serbia.

The warning coincided with a bomb attack on the home of the Yugoslav representative in Kosovo which killed one person.

Zoran Djindjic, one of President Vojislav Kostunica's most powerful allies, claimed that four policemen were killed during fighting with Albanian guerrillas in the Presevo valley, southern Serbia.

Speaking in Belgrade, Mr Djindjic warned that the fighting might spread. "Those are big clashes. This could lead to large-scale war.

"Dozens of local Serb policeman are now surrounded by hundreds of Albanian rebels armed with mortars, and other heavy weapons launched the attack from Kosovo.

"We are warning the international community that if it tolerates this, there could be another flashpoint in the Balkans."

Mr Djindjic's claims were rejected by General Carlo Cabigiosu, the commander of K-For, the peacekeeping force in Kosovo. He said there was no evidence of an exchange of fire over the boundary with Kosovo.

But the head of the UN's mission in Kosovo, Bernard Kouchner, referred to the clashes when he condemned yesterday's bomb attack on the Yugoslav official residence in Pristina.

He said both the explosion and the border fighting were part of a "trend of premeditated violence" sweeping the province.

"The wave of violence is a warning...the extremists are now ready to step up their targeting of the Serb community."

The blast early yesterday tore through the ground floor of the official residence, where Stanimir Vukicevic and his staff were living. An RUC sergeant and an American police officer, on secondment to the UN, were searching the area when the bomb went off. Both were thrown back by the explosion.

The residence's driver, Goran Jaftic, a Kosovo Serb, suffered arm and leg injuries in the blast. He was driven to the British military field hospital in Pristina, where he died. A second person was injured in the attack, which was described by Dr Kouchner as "well prepared and carefully executed".

"This was not a random act of violence. This was a professional job and the perpetrators were willing to take enormous risks to achieve their ends."

The commander of British forces in Pristina, Brigadier General Robert Fry, whose troops are responsible for security in the city, called the bombing a "ruthless and determined act of terrorism".

He rejected criticism that K-For had failed to provide adequate security. Most UN buildings are sealed off from the public, and K-For troops guard several Serbian orthodox churches in Pristina, yet no such measures were put in place to protect the Yugoslav representative's residence.

"If I was to try and do that I would very soon run out of troops," said Brig Fry.

"Much more important than that I am sure Mr Vukicevic or any other Kosovar Serb living in Kosovo today does not want to live in a prison. What they want to do is to live in a society which allows them to go about their business in a free and safe manner."

webTitle: Milosevic keeps grip on party and its cash

fields.headline: Milosevic keeps grip on party and its cash
fields.standfirst:
From his Belgrade villa, ex-president vanquishes rebels

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Yugoslavia's former president, Slobodan Milosevic, has shown he remains a powerful political force by putting down a revolt against his leadership of Serbia's largest party.
fields.body:
Yugoslavia's former president, Slobodan Milosevic, has shown he remains a powerful political force by putting down a revolt against his leadership of Serbia's largest party.

Efforts by rebels to use an emergency party congress on Saturday to oust him now look set to collapse, so that it will be Mr Milosevic who leads the party into crucial elections for the Serbian parliament next month.

Though he lost the Yugoslav presidency after his election defeat and a popular uprising this autumn, the main power in the country rests with the Serbian authorities rather than those of the Yugoslav Federation which Serbia dominates. Whichever party wins the December election will have ultimate control.

When plans were laid, in the aftermath of last month's uprising in Belgrade, for an emergency congress of the Socialist party of Serbia (SPS), Mr Milosevic's critics hoped to use the momentum that forced his shock departure from the Yugoslav presidency to dump him as party chief.

But from his private villa in the elite Belgrade suburb of Dedinje, Mr Milosevic has been rallying his supporters over the telephone or by summoning them to meetings. He is thought to make occasional forays into town in small cars with tinted windows.

The party congress this weekend is to take place in the Sava Centre, a large conference hall in the suburb of New Belgrade, but Serb journalists said yesterday that no details have been given as to whether the press will be allowed in or if Mr Milosevic will attend.

In a rare appearance this week on Yu Info, a state TV channel he created, Mr Milosevic was seen urging party associates to maintain unity.

"There are scenarios to destroy the state, to destroy the economy, to destroy the party because it is the only guarantee for the defence of the national interests," he declared. If the congress sent a message of unity, "the consequences in the elections on December 23 will be positive".

It was unclear where the televised meeting with party colleagues was held but viewers noted that the Serbian president, Milan Milutinovic, - once thought ready to break from Mr Milosevic - was sitting meekly in the audience.

"Milosevic is seeing many people," said the party's general-secretary, Zoran Andjelkovic, a loyalist who was Belgrade's last governor in Kosovo before the Nato intervention in the Serbian province last year. "Many people communicate with Milosevic personally or over the phone. Milosevic is communicating with the outside world directly. I can assure you of that."

Former colleagues now concede that they have failed to generate enough strength to remove Mr Milosevic.

Zoran Lilic, a past president of Yugoslavia, who left the Socialist party a few weeks ago, has set up his own party. "Milosevic is not giving up politics. He is considering his best possible survival options, and counting on things going downhill for the movement that ousted him," he said.

The SPS's former vice-president Milorad Vucelic, who split with Mr Milosevic at the end of 1998, had been considered the most likely replacement as party president. Now he too is planning to form his own party and says he may not even attend the congress.

"If I thought I could serve any purpose, I would come," he said. "But, as matters stand, my presence would not facilitate a democratic dialogue."

Mr Vucelic belongs to a group calling itself the "SPS founders", which has been calling for Mr Milosevic to resign in favour of a temporary secretariat to run the party.

The group includes another former Yugoslav president, Borislav Jovic, and the former head of the Belgrade branch of the party, Slobodan Jovanovic.

None of these men is a liberal and most were involved in the virulent nationalism of the early 1990s during the wars with Croatia and Bosnia. At that time Mr Vucelic ran Radio Television Serbia, the main state channel, which protesters burned down last month.

The latest defector from the SPS is Ratko Markovic, a former deputy prime minister, who led the negotiations for autonomy in Kosovo in 1998 and 1999. He denounced Mr Milosevic for taking control of drafting all documents for the congress without consultation.

The platform says that the Socialists have a "big chance of a comeback because of the deteriorating economic and social situation in the country", according to the party sources.

Mr Milosevic is also counting on clear strains among Yugoslavia's new leaders. President Vojislav Kostunica is at odds with Zoran Djindjic, his campaign manager, who has made no secret of wanting to be Serbia's next prime minister.

But independent Serbian journalists say public support for the new leadership is still high. Foreign aid is providing fuel and this has meant fewer power cuts than a year ago.

Mr Milosevic's party is expected to get a maximum of 20% in the December elections, and possibly much less. Some observers believe the SPS will do worse with him at its head, so they see his defeat of party rebels before Saturday's congress as a plus.

"Staying in charge of his party does not mean he can make a comeback. But Milosevic wants to send a message to the country and the world that he's still very much politically alive and a political fact," an experienced Belgrade analyst said yesterday.

As SPS head, Mr Milosevic will also continue to control large party funds. This helps him command the obedience of potential rebels. Because most were involved in making money under his mafia-style rule as well as in war crimes, he can also use blackmail.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In our report of the avalanche near Obergurgl, (our G2 lead, When the snow falls, page 2, November 21), the excision of a word made it appear that the snow had come "crashing down about 10,000ft". In fact it came down  from a height of 2,849m (converted to "about 10,000ft" in the piece, but actually just under).
fields.body:
In our report of the avalanche near Obergurgl, (our G2 lead, When the snow falls, page 2, November 21), the excision of a word made it appear that the snow had come "crashing down about 10,000ft". In fact it came down from a height of 2,849m (converted to "about 10,000ft" in the piece, but actually just under).

Lady Ottoline Morrell, The Lonely Princess of Bohemia, Weekend, page 36 onwards, November 18, did not return home from George V's Jubilee celebrations in 1930 (page 43). The silver jubilee did not take place until May 1935.

Jesse Fuller, the byline on our G2 lead, November 20, was a pseudonym concealing the identity of the London Underground employee who wrote the piece. We should have said so at the time.

In the article Welcome here, page 2, Education, November 21, we consistently spelt Dukinfield incorrectly as Duckinfield, although it appeared clearly enough on the grey school sweatshirt worn by the boy in one of the accompanying photographs.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. webTitle: South Korea's match of the day: football fans and love hotels

fields.headline: South Korea's match of the day: football fans and love hotels
fields.standfirst: Special report: Korea
fields.trailText: If any British teams qualify for the 2002 World Cup finals in South Korea and Japan, their fans visiting Seoul may find themselves lodged in unusually sensual surroundings.
fields.body:
If any British teams qualify for the 2002 World Cup finals in South Korea and Japan, their fans visiting Seoul may find themselves lodged in unusually sensual surroundings.

Hundreds of "love hotels", usually favoured by couples for romantic trysts, will be requisitioned for football fans because the city's tourist and business hotels do not have enough capacity for the surge in demand expected in 2002.

The controversial accommodation policy has been drawn up by Seoul municipal authorities who have been wondering what to do about the bed shortage in the city.

Official estimates suggest that Seoul faces a shortfall of 20,000 rooms during the tournament, when almost a million football supporters are expected.

With the economy still wobbling slowly out of the Asian financial crisis, South Korea cannot afford to construct new facilities for visitors as it did for the 1988 Seoul Olympics.

However, the love hotel industry is booming and has more than enough capacity to handle the overspill. Earlier this week, Seoul city hall said that it would nominate 370 of them as "world inns" with upgraded booking systems and translation services.

It is a move that ought to be welcomed by football fans. As well as being far cheaper than regular hotels, love hotels offer an intriguing insight into a different culture.

Although less gaudy than their more famous Japanese counterparts, South Korean love hotels feature the same combination of convenience and privacy for couples looking to do anything but sleep.

They offer discreet parking and short-term rates for a one- or two-hour stay in rooms, some of which are lined with mirrors or fitted with water- or vibrating beds. Many also supply condoms, pornography and sex toys.

In recent years, love hotels have proliferated in urban areas, where space and privacy are in short supply. Part of the reason for their growth is that so many young single people remain at home with their parents, but some people see the explosion as a sign of decadence.

In recent weeks there has been a growing backlash by Christian groups and residents' associations, who claim that such facilities are undermining the nation's morals by encouraging extra-marital affairs and sexual promiscuity among teenagers.

Some protesters have taken photographs of people and cars entering the love hotels and posting them on the internet.

By redesignating them as world inns and making them perform more of a social function in providing accommodation for visiting football fans, Seoul city officials hope to soothe this controversy.

"The latest measure is aimed at killing two birds with one stone," said a municipal official quoted in the Korean Herald. "We can help to resolve the dire shortage of lodging facilities during the World Cup as well as finding a good use for love hotels, which have become a source of headaches in the capital."

It remains to be seen, however, how enthusiastic love hotel owners will be about the plan, which will mean they only let their rooms once a night instead of four or five times.

webTitle: Comment: Thatcher's ghost haunts question of European army

fields.headline: Friendly fire hits Hague's army manoeuvres
fields.trailText: The Tory party now resembles one of those vast allegorical canvasses of the French revolution. Lady Thatcher, global life president of the World Institute of Thatcherology, appears here in the role of Marie-France - mob cap on head, banner in hand - though I think that rather than a bare breast we should hope for something sturdily wrapped in whalebone.
fields.body:
The Tory party now resembles one of those vast allegorical canvasses of the French revolution. Lady Thatcher, global life president of the World Institute of Thatcherology, appears here in the role of Marie-France - mob cap on head, banner in hand - though I think that rather than a bare breast we should hope for something sturdily wrapped in whalebone.

It was behind her that they were massed yesterday for the great debate on the European army. In the morning, the Jacobin organ the Sun had given over its front page to her battle cry: "Euro army sensation. Maggie rages at folly of vain Blair."

There was to be a statement, in which the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, chained on the back of a tumbril, would be brought out to face the fury of the mob. But before then we had prime minister's questions. Mr Hague hoped that by guillotining the king, he could destroy the crumbling will of the ancien régime.

It was not to be. As Mr Major discovered, it is impossible for its ostensible leader to run the Conservative party with her exhorting the troops behind him. I wondered idly whether she has prepared for her death, and the time when she can not ring the Sun to deliver her revelations of divine truth.

Possibly, like the prophet Joanna Southcott, she will leave behind a box containing her views on every topic that might ever crop up. That way, in 2019 the Tory leader, Michael Fabricant, can be told his views on the gay age of consent in the British colony on Mars, or whatever.

Mr Hague started fairly well. Britain's Gulf war commander, General Sir Peter de la Billière, opposed the proposed European defence cooperation. He asked: "Shouldn't we put our faith in someone who led from the front in the Gulf war rather than people who ran from the front in the cold war?"

Memo to Mr Hague: It is no good hammering on about Tony Blair's CND past and implying that he is some kind of white-feathered pacifist. It was just cynical opportunism at the time, and the public are quite happy with that.

Mr Blair pointed out that most senior American officials were all in favour of the new plan. Mr Hague quoted a weird remark by the president of the European commission, Romano Prodi, who is clearly a sort of Italian John Prescott.

Mr Prodi had said: "I am not joking when I call it a European army. You can call it Mary Ann, you can call it Margaret," he added, rather mysteriously. Mr Hague thought Margaret was an excellent name for an army.

Mr Blair quoted Mr Hague back at himself, which is usually pretty easy, since his views do seem to change from day to day. "You put your finger on it when you mentioned Margaret.

"I gather you now have to sum up your policy in six words. Here are six words for you: 'Lady Thatcher - you lead, I'll follow'."

But he saved the flashing blade for the very end, knowing Mr Hague could not answer. He quoted a pamphlet which argued that the Europeans had to take more responsibility for their own defence, rather than leaving it all to the Americans. "The answers make it evident that that such problems have to be tackled jointly," Mr Blair read out.

"Who was the author of this pamphlet?" he demanded with relish. "In 1984, it was the submission to the European Council by the leader of the delegation, one Margaret Thatcher! I rest my case."

Half an hour later, Mr Hoon faced a ferocious assault by the usually mild John Major, who provided much the most coherent attack on the plan. But it hardly mattered. By this time the house was almost empty, and only the faint, spectral rattling of chains could be heard in the distance. And perhaps the glug of another celebratory whisky pouring into the glass.

webTitle: Tan's biotech firm leads brave float-bound pack

fields.headline: Tan's biotech firm leads brave float-bound pack
fields.trailText: Three more companies yesterday announced they are to brave recent volatility in the world's major stock markets and opt for flotation.
fields.body:
Three more companies yesterday announced they are to brave recent volatility in the world's major stock markets and opt for flotation.

The largest is biotech firm GeneMedix, which will be valued at around £300m.

GeneMedix, which develops hepatitis and cancer treatments, is listing on the London and Singapore stock exchanges to raise £20m.

It is chaired by Kim Tan, who also heads the quoted company KS Biomedix and is among Britain's 10 most successful biotech entrepreneurs.

Also going to market is Datamonitor, the market research company which specialises in the technology and health care sectors.

The move will turn chairman Mike Danson's initial £5,000 investment into a stake worth approximately £46m, and value the London-based company at £116m.

Datamonitor, which was formed in 1989, is raising funds in order to expand in the Far East and Europe.

Mr Danson said: "Our strategy has been to develop high quality data and powerful expertise to help our global blue-chip client base take advan tage of market and technological developments." Trading is due to begin on November 29.

Finally there is Genetix, which makes robotic equipment for use in gene discovery.

The company is raising around £27m - of which £17m will be used for expansion and £10m will go to existing backers, who are selling some of their shareholdings.

The shares have been placed with institutions at 150p each, valuing Genetix at £112m.

The company is said to be looking for acquisitions and also wants to develop its sales and marketing in the US and to expand in Asia.

webTitle: NTT to take £6.4bn stake in AT&T

fields.headline: NTT to take £6.4bn stake in AT&T
fields.trailText: NTT DoCoMo, the world's biggest telecoms company by market value, is aiming to gain a crucial foothold in the US market by taking a stake in AT&T Wireless.
fields.body:
NTT DoCoMo, the world's biggest telecoms company by market value, is aiming to gain a crucial foothold in the US market by taking a stake in AT&T Wireless.

The 1 trillion yen (£6.4bn) deal would strengthen the Japanese firm's position in setting new global standards for mobile internet technology.

But it is unclear how the tie-up would affect BT, which already has an alliance with AT&T.

According to Japanese media reports, DoCoMo will take a 15-20% stake in AT&T, possibly as early as next week, with a view to introducing a joint service next May.

DoCoMo refused to comment on the reports yesterday, but a spokesman in Tokyo said the company's desire to find a partner in north America was well known. The two firms have reportedly been talking for several months.

If the deal goes ahead it would be the most ambitious move to date by DoCoMo, whose i-mode mobile internet service has attracted more than 14m subscribers.

DoCoMo also has a one-year lead in wireless internet technology. Next May the company expects to be the first in the world to market the next gener ation of mobile communication - W-CDMA - which it wants to export around the globe.

To achieve this aim, it has joined AOL, the world's leading web portal, and brought minority shares in Hutchinson 3G UK Holdings and KPM Mobile of the Netherlands. The Japanese firm also announced plans yesterday to spend ¥60bn on a 20% stake in KG Telecom, Taiwan's third-largest telecoms firm.

Uncertainties remain about the technical and financial aspects of a deal with AT&T Wireless. AT&T has been working on a different format to W-DCMA.

Investors are also unhappy that DoCoMo will probably have to issue ¥1 trillion worth of new shares in a sluggish market to fund the purchase. Yesterday the company's stock closed lower on the news of a deal.

webTitle: IQE buys rival as it cashes in on record profit rise

fields.headline: IQE buys rival as it cashes in on record profit rise
fields.trailText: The Welsh-based semiconductor firm IQE yesterday announced a big new contract and plans to buy up a rival on the back of a record leap in profits.
fields.body:
The Welsh-based semiconductor firm IQE yesterday announced a big new contract and plans to buy up a rival on the back of a record leap in profits.

The company, which makes compound semiconductor wafers, said that fibre optics firm Bookham was to make use of IQE's production site in order to cope with increasing demand for wafers.

IQE also revealed that it had paid £41.3m for Wafer Technology, based in Milton Keynes, in order to consolidate its position as the global leader in outsourcing production of epitaxial wafers, used in many electronic chips and optical fibres.

The epitaxial wafers are used in compound semiconductors which can work much faster than silicon-based technology, especially in transmitting or absorbing light - crucial to fibre optics.

Yesterday's third-quarter results for the three months to end-September showed underlying pre-tax profits up 190% to £875,000 on sales up 39% to £6.43m. The company said that new capacity would see revenues continue to grow into the fourth quarter.

The company, the world's biggest independent specialist maker of compound semiconductor wafers, said new capacity would contribute strongly to increased revenues in the fourth quarter. Shares in IQE were up 5p to 295p.

webTitle: Coca-Cola pulls out of Quaker deal

fields.headline: Coca-Cola pulls out of Quaker deal
fields.trailText: Coca-Cola yesterday pulled out of a $15bn (£10.6bn) deal to take over Quaker Oats - which would have given the the world's biggest soft drinks company control of the huge Gatorade sports drink brand.
fields.body:
Coca-Cola yesterday pulled out of a $15bn (£10.6bn) deal to take over Quaker Oats - which would have given the the world's biggest soft drinks company control of the huge Gatorade sports drink brand.

The decision to walk away from the deal came after a fraught five-hour board meeting in New York, and is understood to have been instigated by billionaire investor Warren Buffet, who owns 8% of Coca-Cola. A report in the Wall Street Journal suggested that the two firms had been so sure of announcing the merger that publicity photos of the two chairmen had already been taken.

The collapse of the deal was last night being viewed as a serious humiliation for Douglas Daft, who took over as chairman of Coca-Cola earlier this year after his predecessor was ousted by the board. But in a terse announcement, released late on Tuesday night, Coca-Cola sought to downplay suggestions of a boardroom rift.

"The board expressed its enthusiastic support for the current strategic course of the company under Doug Daft's leadership as the best means for enhancing shareowner value," it said.

Shares in Coca-Cola rose 7% as investors welcomed the company's decision to abandon the deal, which Wall Street traders believe could leave the way open for rival PepsiCo. Quaker is understood to have rejected a bid from Pepsi which valued its business at less than $15bn earlier this month.

But there are other possible contenders, including Groupe Danone, the French consumer company. Danone confirmed its interest yesterday in a con ference call with analysts. The news, however, was greeted with a sharp sell-off of its shares as investors reacted nervously to the company's suggestion that such a large acquisition would hit earnings for the next three years.

Other companies believed to be interested in acquiring Quaker Oats to get their hands on its top-selling Gatorade sports drink include Nestlé, the Swiss consumer group, and Kraft Foods, a unit of Philip Morris.

webTitle: Rentokil says it has stopped rot

fields.headline: Rentokil says it has stopped rot
fields.standfirst: City welcomes upbeat forecast
fields.trailText: Shares in Rentokil Initial, the home and office services group, rose almost 10% yesterday as chief executive Clive Thompson announced it was on target for a strong improvement in core profits.
fields.body:
Shares in Rentokil Initial, the home and office services group, rose almost 10% yesterday as chief executive Clive Thompson announced it was on target for a strong improvement in core profits.

The company, which provides pest control at Buckingham Palace, has seen its shares fall after confidence was knocked by its failure to deliver a 20% annual growth target for the first time in 17 years.

In a trading statement Mr Thompson said Rentokil had was 90% on the way to completing its £600m disposal programme.

"With this disruptive influence removed, the board expects that in 2001 core business will show accelerating turnover growth together with growth in profits."

Rentokil also pleased the City by reiterating its determination to keep on buying its own shares at up to 295p each without hitting its earnings per share.

The company has already bought 778m shares representing 27.2% of the share capital at a cost of £1.3bn and there was "outstanding capacity" to buy back a further 270m shares.

The shares ended the day with a 17p spurt to 192p.

Analysts said they were relieved that the company was going to deliver on promises of producing a better second half result. In the first half of the year pre-tax profits fell to £208m from £253m for the same period of 1999.

The consensus among analysts is for Rentokil to produce full-year profits of £411m, down from last year's £540m.

Rentokil has been disposing of businesses such as its UK scaffolding operations and French distribution activities to concentrate on specialised services and facilities management. The latter has notched up £117m worth of new contracts.
