webTitle: Brinkmanship ended two minutes before deadline

fields.headline: Brinkmanship ended two minutes before deadline
fields.trailText: On Sunday night, two old friends met for dinner at Signor Sassi, an exclusive Italian restaurant located a stone's throw from Harrods in Knightsbridge.
fields.body:
On Sunday night, two old friends met for dinner at Signor Sassi, an exclusive Italian restaurant located a stone's throw from Harrods in Knightsbridge.

On one side of the table was John Duffield, multi-millionaire founder of the Jupiter fund management empire. Opposite him was Edward Bonham Carter, brother of the actress Helena, who was recently appointed joint chief executive of the company.

The topic of conversation was Mr Duffield's £15m unfair dismissal claim from Jupiter and, more importantly, his desire to lure top staff to his new venture, New Star.

Discussions were earnest and businesslike, because the pair were due to face each other in the high court the following morning. Both were anxious to avoid a public showdown which could reveal too much financial trivia.

With the bare bones of an agreement, they parted at 2.30am and a few hours later sought an adjournment of the case from Mr Justice Buckley. Given 24 hours' grace, the pair reconvened on Monday evening and this time talked until 3am.

The seeming intractable points related to staff. For Mr Duffield, who recently made £175m from selling his Jupiter shares to Commerzbank, the £15m cash at issue was peanuts.

With three senior Jupiter managers -including financial services expert Richard Gibbs - prepared to give evidence for their former boss, Mr Bonham Carter feared defections of leading staff to New Star. Such departures could totally destabilise Jupiter.

The judge's patience was sorely tried on Tuesday but he granted a second adjournment . Advisers to the two sides were closeted at law firm Clifford Chance until the early hours again - when talks briefly broke down entirely.

Brinksmanship continued yesterday until 11.58am - with an "absolute" deadline of midday. Finally, Jupiter traded £300m of its funds under management (including a substantial chunk of Mr Duffield's own money) for a "hands off" promise on its top staff.

webTitle: Gone are the days of west knows best

fields.headline: Gone are the days of west knows best
fields.standfirst: Former Warsaw Pact countries are ready to take a prominent place in global financial markets
fields.trailText: Former Warsaw Pact countries are ready to take a prominent place in global financial markets.
fields.body:
This week dealers on the Warsaw stock exchange have been getting used to their swanky new electronic trading system. Life is very different to the market's first day of trading back in April 1991. Then only a handful of stocks were listed but dealings took place in a room that had been former communist party headquarters - called the United Workers Party headquarters but everyone knew who they were. Embryonic capitalism had taken over at the heart of the old regime.

These days symbolism has been replaced by a more sober reality. The exchange is in the process of moving to new headquarters and now trades more than 220 stocks. There is talk that it might yet take a place in the game of musical chairs otherwise known as the restructuring of the western European stock markets.

Such a coming of age is not confined to the Warsaw exchange. Bankers from central and eastern Europe are winning top jobs in international financial institutions. Josef Tosovsky, head of the Czech central bank, was recently appointed to take charge of the Financial Stability Institute at the Bank for International Settlements - the central bankers' club.

Hanna Gronkiewicz-Waltz, his highly respected opposite number at the Polish central bank, is moving to a senior role at the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, though she is replacing another east European, Miklos Nemeth, the former prime minister of Hungary.

"Central bankers in countries like Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic always had talent. What they have now got is the experience of how to operate and control areas like monetary policy and financial markets; how to set them up and how they work," according to one observer.

Slovenia and Estonia - where Swedish influence has made itself felt - are also attracting attention. Central banks in places such as Bulgaria are said to have their rising stars.

Gone are the days when an east European central banker would have to acknowledge with a wry expression that his bank had terrific systems for shuffling credits around the economy but none for assessing risk "because risk evaluations had no place in a five-year plan". New recruits to the central banks in central and eastern Europe now come armed with PhDs and masters degrees in macroeconomics, accountancy and finance.

Perhaps the clearest signal of the effectiveness of the changes which have taken place since the beginning of the decade was the ability of central and eastern European economies to ride out - not without difficulty, perhaps -the shock waves from the Russian debt crisis of 1998.

The change is important, not just for the conduct of domestic monetary and markets' policies.

Many of the central banks in central and eastern Europe are now pursuing similar policies to those of central banks in the west; targeting inflation and allowing exchange rates (broadly) to float, rather than aggressively pursuing exchange rate or monetary targets.

Their policy choices and, arguably initially more important, the skills with which they are carried out will be crucial for those countries wishing to sign up for the European Union and, beyond that, for the single currency. Confidence in the conduct of policy will be a significant factor both in persuading doubters to open the door and to ensuring successful entry once that happens.

The development of commercial banking in central and eastern Europe has pursued a somewhat different path. Banking sectors in most if not all of the former Soviet bloc countries lacked not just the technical expertise to operate in a market environment - they lacked the capital to do so as well.

Nor did a tendency for banks to raise money from depositors, only to lend it on to shareholders or corporate allies, help to engender confidence. Most countries have suffered some sort of banking crisis over the past 10 years and one consequence has been that the sector is now largely dominated by western-owned banks.

Even so the era of western banks buying financial institutions in central and eastern Europe and then poring over their own staff lists in search of executives who spoke the appropriate language and who could be parachuted into the new acquisition is largely over.

Expatriate executives are now more likely to be the link with head office than the fount of all banking knowledge.

Remnants of the old guard still cling on to a few of the commanding heights of the region's commercial banking sector. But there is, according to Nicholas Adamovich, a Commerzbank executive with responsibilities in a number of countries in the region, a rising generation of "very young, very professional people, many of whom have trained in western countries and working according to the same principles".

Education remains a drawback in ensuring the average level is brought up to western standards, according to Mr Adamovich. "Some of the professors are still from the old school. They have re-educated themselves but it is not quite the same thing as having market-orientated people." Nevertheless, he reckons that there are plenty of young bankers in central and eastern Europe with the skills to pursue their profession outside the region.

Progress indeed from the time when one west European banker (albeit in St Petersburg) pointed out to me the highest-paid Russian member of his staff - a well-groomed, athletic young man with just the hint of a bulge beneath the left armpit of his otherwise well-cut suit.

fields.headline: Brown heeds IMF warning
fields.standfirst: There will be no pre-election giveaway Budget, chancellor assures MPs
fields.trailText: The chancellor last night pledged that the government would heed a warning from the International Monetary Fund and resist the temptations of a pre-election giveaway Budget in the spring.
fields.byline: Larry Elliott, Charlotte Denny  and Andrew Osborn  in Brussels
fields.body:
The chancellor last night pledged that the government would heed a warning from the International Monetary Fund and resist the temptations of a pre-election giveaway Budget in the spring.

As the IMF urged the government to save rather than spend his burgeoning surplus, Gordon Brown said: "We have no intention of doing anything other than being prudent and cautious with the public finances in the coming months."

The chancellor told MPs on the treasury select committee: "There will be no spending spree... We have no intention of doing anything other than meeting our fiscal rules."

Mr Brown's tough response coincided with forecasts from the European commission suggesting that he hugely underestimated the likely size of this year's fiscal surplus when he made his pre-Budget statement earlier this month.

The EC predicted that the goverment's surplus in 2000-01, swollen by £22.5bn from the sale of mobile phone licences, would be 4.5% of gross domestic product, amounting to more than £40bn. Stripping out the one-off windfall, the EC said the budget surplus would be 2.1% of GDP - in line with City estimates - and almost double Mr Brown's forecast surplus of 1.1% of GDP.

However, Mr Brown made it clear that he intended to follow the advice contained in the IMF's health check of the UK economy, which said it would be "prudent" for the government to refrain from announcing any additional expenditure in what will probably by the last Budget before the next election.

The IMF said that extra public spending not matched by a slowdown in private spending could lead to higher inflation and tilt the balance towards higher interest rates. Minutes of this month's Bank of England monetary policy committee meeting, released yesterday, showed a unanimous decision to keep rates on hold at 6%, encouraging the City to believe that the next move will be a cut in borrowing costs.

But the IMF said the Bank had to "stand ready" to move in either direction, adding that the better than expected performance of the public finances should be used to cover extra investment in public infrastructure without the need for borrowing and to prepare the ground for tax cuts.

"We recognise that, after several years of fiscal tightening, increases in public spending are needed in some areas, particularly infrastructure and health care. Nevertheless, there may be more scope for moderating the increase in current expenditure in other, less critical areas," the IMF said.

In its report, the IMF said that Britain's overall performance was "impressive", singling out reforms to the labour market, which it said were an exmple to the rest of Europe.

Mr Brown said that the IMF explicitly supported the government's framework for economic policy, and agreed with the IMF's description of Britain's productivity record as a potentail "Achilles' heel" for the economy.

In a series of ill-tempered exchanges with the opposition members of the treasury committee, Mr Brown said monetary and fiscal policy were now more in harmony than they had been under previous governments when the Treasury presided over both interest rates and the Budget.

The chancellor blamed 20 years of Whitehall belt-tightening for the failure by many departments to spend all new money allocated to them, which is adding to the public sector surplus.

"For the last 20 years the Treasury has been the department which says no," he said. "Now we are trying to push departments to invest faster."

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Managers have become "sharply anti-euro" over the past 18 months because of the currency's poor performance and a lack of proper debate on whether Britain should join, according to a survey published yesterday.
fields.body:
Euro animosity increases

Managers have become "sharply anti-euro" over the past 18 months because of the currency's poor performance and a lack of proper debate on whether Britain should join, according to a survey published yesterday.

An Institute of Management poll of 228 managers ranging from sole traders to heads of firms employing 1,000 workers found increasing levels of hostility to the single currency. The survey showed that 61% would vote not to join the euro if there were a referendum now, compared with 43% 18 months ago.

Only 29% said they would vote in favour, compared to 47% in a previous survey.

Merger talk helps Glynwed

Shares in engineering group Glynwed International dropped 6% yesterday after the company issued what amounted to a profits warning - but the price was underpinned by merger speculation.

Glynwed said second-half profits nearly matched the first half's £50m amid tough trade in its industrial pipes division, which makes up 80% of its business.

But chief executive Tony Wilson said the market had expected a second-half figure some £10m higher and blamed trading conditions in the United States and Britain.

He did not rule out a deal with rival Georg Fischer of Switzerland, a rumoured bidder for Glynwed earlier this year.

Strike threat looms at airline

Irish budget airline Ryanair held talks with pilots yesterday in a bid to head off a threatened 24-hour strike in a dispute over working hours.

Ryanair has said disruption to its Irish schedules is likely if an agreement is not found to prevent the strike going ahead tomorrow. It has advised some passengers to reschedule flights from Dublin.

The strike has been called by the Irish Airline Pilots Association which accuses Ryanair of trying to increase their working hours.

Executive shift at Britannia

Britannia Building Society announced yesterday that it had appointed non-executive director Rhidian Jones as its deputy chairman, adding that he takes over from Calum MacLeod, who will be retiring on December 20.

Something afoot at Boots

Boots is to invest £6m to open 45 chiropody and foot care practices in its stores. The initiative follows a pilot project in seven stores. The additional 38 will be opened by March next year.

Chiropody and foot care are among a range of services on trial by Boots. Others include physiotherapy, reflexology and beauty salons. Space for the new venture is being created as the group pulls out of areas such as books, records and kitchen goods.

fields.headline: Citigroup executive 'quit over cocaine addiction'
fields.trailText: Cocaine addiction, long regarded as a hidden menace on Wall Street, prompted the departure of one of the financial world's most high-profile executives, according to reports yesterday.
fields.body:
Cocaine addiction, long regarded as a hidden menace on Wall Street, prompted the departure of one of the financial world's most high-profile executives, according to reports yesterday.

Marc Weill, a senior manager with Citigroup and the son of its chairman, Sandy, stepped down from his $2m-a-year job as head of the group's investment business earlier this year because of his drug dependency, according to the Wall Street Journal.

The newspaper quoted E D Donahey, Mr Weill's former wife, saying that the 44-year-old father of two was "in treatment for drug addiction".

"The only thing that's important is that Marc is getting help for his drug addiction," said Ms Donahey, who is understood to have remained close to the Weill family after her divorce in 1995.

Neither Marc nor Sandy Weill has commented on the reports or speculation about the alleged addiction. Citigroup refused to return calls yesterday.

The younger Mr Weill blamed exhaustion for his decision to leave his job managing the firm's $113bn (£80bn) investment portfolio in July. His departure, following an extended leave of absence, raised eyebrows as the division had been performing well.

Colleagues had already started to notice signs of erratic behaviour from a man known for working 12-hour days in the shadow of his father. According to the Wall Street Journal, Mr Weill dozed off during important meetings, some of which were led by his father. He also took days off and was hospitalised twice within four months, suffering with pneumonia. On his return to the company, colleagues noticed that his fingertips were stained brown. Their concerns prompted an investigation, according to the newspaper.

The personal revelations come as a blow to Sandy Weill, whose company is expected to make more money than any other business this year.

Citigroup was formed from the merger of Travelers and Citibank almost three years ago. It owns the Salomon Smith Barney and Schroders investment banks as well as several retail businesses.

Mr Weill's promotion of his children is understood to have caused some resentment in the company.

His daughter, Jessica Bibliowicz, quit in 1996 after falling out with Jamie Dimon, a rising star in the business. Mr Weill was reportedly furious that his second-in-command had blocked his daughter's path to a senior job.

webTitle: Pharmacy group backers catch a cold

fields.headline: Pharmacy group backers catch a cold
fields.standfirst: Damien Hirst and Matthew Freud lose heavily as trendy chain tries £4m rescue
fields.trailText: Damien Hirst and Matthew Freud lose heavily as trendy chain tries £4m rescue.
fields.body:
The entrepreneurs behind Hartford Group, which owns upmarket restaurants including the trendy Notting Hill eaterie Pharmacy, yesterday resigned en masse admitting that their strategy for the business had "not been successful".

Property tycoons Nigel Wray and Nick Leslau, public relations supremo Matthew Freud and chief executive Kevin Finch, stepped down from the board as the struggling company launched a £4m refinancing. They quit nursing heavy losses - Hartford's market value has collapsed from £20m to just £2.5m since March. Between them, four men own just over 20%.

In an attempt to revive the company's fortunes, they were replaced by a team chaired by Stephen Thomas, who runs the nightclubs company Luminar. Sheila McKenzie, best known for founding the Pitcher & Piano bar chain, joins as chief executive.

Mr Thomas signalled that big changes were likely for the company, which has been trying to roll out a chain of "fine dining" restaurants in London's suburbs: "The business was being run like an upside-down pyramid. There was more cost going out than there were customers coming through the door."

Hartford has been opening up-market restaurants named after American states, includ ing Utah in Wimbledon, Canyon in Richmond and Dakota in Notting Hill. Mr Thomas said this had not worked: "If you want to create a localised dining format, it has to reflect the neighbourhood - it can't just be a template."

Insiders say these are likely to be put up for sale, leaving the company focused on finding new opportunities - "investing in the next Pret A Manger", as one source put it.

Originally centred around Pharmacy, the Damien Hirst-designed restaurant notorious for its window displays of medicines, Hartford had planned to open a chain of high-class kebab shops. This plan was dropped, as was a suggestion of opening further branches of Pharmacy. The company branched out through a merger with rival Montana this year but its suburban restaurants have failed to attract customers during the week.

Ms McKenzie suggested that achieving consistent standards in food and service had been a problem: "My experience is that sometimes the restaurants are absolutely fabulous but sometimes they miss it a little. We'll try to get these businesses stabilised, then look at other opportunities."

Hartford made a £2.5m loss in 1999, followed by a £1.67m deficit in the first-half of this year. The business was sustained by directors, who guaranteed loans of £500,000.

Analyst Greg Feheely of Old Mutual Securities said: "The concept wasn't right. New openings have been very disappointing." The company is raising money through an open offering of 70.9m shares at 5p each. Mr Freud, whose public relations clients include Chris Evans and Geri Halliwell, is paying £220,000 to increase his stake to 5.3%. Mr Thomas is investing £500,000 in a 14% stake and Ms McKenzie is buying £10,000 of shares.

Among the big losers at Hartford is Damien Hirst, the artist best known for submerging farm animals in chemicals, whose 5.71% stake is now worth just £140,000.

Mr Thomas signalled that big changes were likely for the company, which has been trying to roll out a chain of "fine dining" restaurants in London's suburbs: "The business was being run like an upside-down pyramid. There was more cost going out than there were customers coming through the door." Hartford has been opening up-market restaurants named after American states, includ ing Utah in Wimbledon, Canyon in Richmond and Dakota in Notting Hill. Mr Thomas said this had not worked: "If you want to create a localised dining format, it has to reflect the neighbourhood - it can't just be a template." Insiders say these are likely to be put up for sale, leaving the company focused on finding new opportunities - "investing in the next Pret A Manger", as one source put it. Originally centred around Pharmacy, the Damien Hirst-designed restaurant notorious for its window displays of medicines, Hartford had planned to open a chain of high-class kebab shops. This plan was dropped, as was a suggestion of opening further branches of Pharmacy. The company branched out through a merger with rival Montana this year but its suburban restaurants have failed to attract customers during the week. Ms McKenzie suggested that achieving consistent standards in food and service had been a problem: "My experience is that sometimes the restaurants are absolutely fabulous but sometimes they miss it a little. We'll try to get these businesses stabilised, then look at other opportunities." Hartford made a £2.5m loss in 1999, followed by a £1.67m deficit in the first-half of this year. The business was sustained by directors, who guaranteed loans of £500,000. Analyst Greg Feheely of Old Mutual Securities said: "The concept wasn't right. New openings have been very disappointing." The company is raising money through an open offering of 70.9m shares at 5p each. Mr Freud, whose public relations clients include Chris Evans and Geri Halliwell, is paying £220,000 to increase his stake to 5.3%. Mr Thomas is investing £500,000 in a 14% stake and Ms McKenzie is buying £10,000 of shares. Among the big losers at Hartford is Damien Hirst, the artist best known for submerging farm animals in chemicals, whose 5.71% stake is now worth just £140,000.

fields.headline: Duffield agrees to settle for £5m
fields.trailText: John Duffield, the founder of fund management group Jupiter, yesterday accepted £5m compensation for unfair dismissal from his former employer, in a settlement signed just two minutes before a High Court deadline.
fields.body:
John Duffield, the founder of fund management group Jupiter, yesterday accepted £5m compensation for unfair dismissal from his former employer, in a settlement signed just two minutes before a High Court deadline.

Both Mr Duffield and Commerzbank, the German owner of Jupiter, claimed victory over the agreement, which avoided a potentially embarrassing showdown for each side.

Mr Duffield, who made £175m from selling his stake in Jupiter to Commerzbank, had initially demanded £15m, one of the biggest unfair dismissal claims in British legal history. His barrister, Andrew Hockhauser QC, told the court: "Agreement has been reached between the two parties on terms most acceptable to Mr Duffield and which dispense with the need to continue."

Under the terms of the settlement, Commerzbank will pay £2.5m to Mr Duffield and £2.5m to a charitable trust set up by the multi-millionaire.

More significantly, Jupiter director Alan Miller will be allowed to join Mr Duffield's new venture, New Star, taking with him several of Jupiter's offshore funds, with £300m under management.

Mr Duffield has agreed not to poach any more Jupiter staff until May - at which point, his spokesman said: "It is entirely possible that other senior Jupiter directors may join New Star."

The court battle was expected to lift the lid on the secretive world of lucrative City pay deals. It threatened to trigger an exodus of staff from Jupiter, which manages £15bn of funds and is one of the biggest sellers of Isas to small investors.

A showdown would also have created unwelcome publicity for Mr Duffield - recently named one of the country's top five earners.

Talks have been going on all week. One source described the saga as "an incredible game of brinkmanship".

Mr Justice Buckley finally lost patience yesterday morning, declaring that he would not adjourn the case any further than midday. Agreement was reached at 11.58am. The roots of the dispute lie in Commerzbank's takeover of Jupiter. The German bank bought 75% of Jupiter five years ago, agreeing to buy the remaining 25% from directors this year. Commerzbank disagreed with Mr Duffield over the amount payable for this final quarter, which was on a sliding scale according to the business's earnings.

Commerzbank eventually paid the £505m Mr Duffield wanted but acrimony between the two sides persisted and he left shortly afterwards.

A colourful character, Mr Duffield, 61, used to be married to Vivien Duffield, former head of the Royal Opera House. She once described him as "a brilliant fund manager but a lousy husband".

He set up Jupiter as a one-man operation in 1985 but while growing the business, he has run into controversy.

He handed over £10,000 to settle a sexual harassment case brought by a junior colleague, Fiona Mills, who complained that "blue language" used by staff at the company had caused her stress and unhappiness.

Both sides will pay their own costs - amounting to more than £1m each. Commerzbank is planning to tie in staff with a new share options package, to prevent key employees defecting to New Star next year.

Jupiter's joint managing director, Edward Bonham Carter, said: "We're celebrating - new Jupiter will be even better than old Jupiter."

fields.headline: At this price?  Anglian Water
fields.trailText: AWG, the Anglian Water business in the process of transforming itself into an asset management firm, has ambitions to undertake the maintenance of parts of the rundown UK rail network.
fields.body:
AWG, the Anglian Water business in the process of transforming itself into an asset management firm, has ambitions to undertake the maintenance of parts of the rundown UK rail network.

Chief executive Chris Mellor yesterday said he saw "huge opportunities in the whole transport area".

The group's Linc consortium is already shortlisted for the contract to upgrade the infrastructure for London Underground's Bakerloo, Central and Victoria lines. The contract would include the replacement of all signalling equipment and rolling stock.

Mr Mellor said rail could be "a very interesting opportunity" for the group as it expands its asset management operation to offset a decline in the profitability of its regulated water business.

His ambitions go beyond the £12m repair contract it has for part of Railtrack's property portfolio. "My perception of Railtrack is that it does not have the capability in-house to maintain and monitor contracts," he said.

The group's first-half results, announced yesterday, were hit by the price cuts imposed by the water regulator. Pre-tax profits fell from £93.3m to £60.1m, largely as a result of the new price regime, which is expected to cost AWG £70m over the full year.

The interim dividend has been raised 3.3% in line with the board's policy of maintaining the payout to shareholders at least in line with inflation.

Mr Mellor said the group expected to make an announcement about separating its regulated water business assets and operations by the end of June.

He said Anglian Water was looking at a model different to those of Welsh Water and Yorkshire Water. The idea has been discussed with the water industry regulator who had given it "an amber light".

Even if its plan to get shot of its regulated water assets come to nothing, it still has plenty of growth prospects. Its shares, up 8p to 615p yesterday, are worth holding.

fields.headline: McAlpine gets a build-up
fields.trailText: The performance of construction stocks has been good of late. With investors seeking a haven from the volatility of technology shares, the likes of Redrow, up 13p to 199.5p, and Barratt Developments, up 14p to 315.5p, have been making regular appearances at the top of the FTSE Mid 250 leaderboard.
fields.body:
The performance of construction stocks has been good of late. With investors seeking a haven from the volatility of technology shares, the likes of Redrow, up 13p to 199.5p, and Barratt Developments, up 14p to 315.5p, have been making regular appearances at the top of the FTSE Mid 250 leaderboard.

Nonetheless, market professionals insist there is more to the recent performance of Alfred McAlpine, the small cap construction and housbuilding group, than simply defensive buying. Yesterday its shares moved up 6p to 209.5p on speculation that corporate developments are afoot.

McAlpine held fruitless merger talks with fellow housebuilder Bryant, up 3.5p to 146.5p, last year and since has made no secret of its search for a partner to achieve critical mass. The gossips believe McAlpine might have reopened talks with Bryant.

fields.headline: Invensys strives to cut debt
fields.standfirst: Power systems unit to be spun off
fields.trailText: Invensys, the troubled controls and engineering group created by the merger of Siebe and BTR, yesterday announced plans to spin off its power systems division in a move which could raise up to £3.5bn.
fields.body:
Invensys, the troubled controls and engineering group created by the merger of Siebe and BTR, yesterday announced plans to spin off its power systems division in a move which could raise up to £3.5bn.

Shares in Invensys, which have halved this year, rallied strongly to end the day up 10.25p at 160.25p despite a collapse in interim pre-tax profits on ordinary activities from £419m to £111m.

Exchange rate difficulties caused by the weak euro also had an impact on the business and operating profits for the ongoing group - excluding subsidiaries sold during the year - fell 5% to £470m.

The company is to sell up to 25% of its power systems unit through a separate listing in both London and New York. Invensys' own planned introduction to the New York market is to be postponed until after the power system launch.

The City welcomed the flotation, saying it should raise substantial amounts of money that could help pay off its £2.89bn of debt and unleash the inherent value contained in the remaining business.

Since a profit warning in September and a further slump in the share price, the names of a host of potential predators such as GE and KKR have been linked with a takeover. Invensys has denied that any talks are under way.

Chief executive Allen Yurko said last night he was "extremely disappointed" that the operating profits were down for the first time in 10 years and promised that "the second-half operating profit will be better than the first half".

He admitted that some of the cost overruns in the global group had been self-inflicted and promised to restore Invensys's growth pattern partly through a further round of cuts.

More than 3,000 employees will join the 15,500 who have already been shed by Invensys during a swath of plant and office closures. A further 1,300 staff - nearly one third of the total - have also been cut at the Dutch software company Baan which it bought in the summer.

"We are continuing to streamline our organisation to reduce management layers, lower our administrative costs and speed up decision making," Mr Yurko said.

Prices would be increased where costs could not be reduced. Higher energy costs and electronic component prices took their toll on the group.

Baan is a loss-making operation but Mr Yurko believes it will return to profitability in the first quarter of the next financial year.

Sales at Invensys rose 8% to £3.6bn over the first half of the year with a strong performance in the higher growth areas of software and power systems.

But the core area of automation and controls continued to fell the effects of lower demand.

fields.headline: Only losers need apply
fields.trailText: There is a new club in London and membership is proving very popular. Conditions of admittance are simple: your company must have lost 60% of its value since Nasdaq reached its peak in March.
fields.body:
There is a new club in London and membership is proving very popular. Conditions of admittance are simple: your company must have lost 60% of its value since Nasdaq reached its peak in March.

At the end of last week there were around 60 members in the FTSE All Share universe and more are joining all the time. In fact, some are even threatening to form a breakaway club where 80% of your company's value must have disappeared.

One company banging on the door of the breakaway club is Bookham Technology and its credentials are excellent. Although Bookham did not come to market until April its descent has been breath-taking. From a £54.73 peak in July the stock was sitting at £11.59 last night after falling 124p, or 9.66%, yesterday.

Another would-be member is Filtronic, which makes mobile phone components. Yesterday its shares dropped 95p to 600p, taking its decline since March to more than £17. The fall came after HSBC Securities lowered its recommendation - from "buy" to "hold" - and its profit forecasts following a chat with the company on Tuesday night.

Apparently HSBC was telling clients yesterday that Filtronic will miss its first-half profits target by about £1m. Although HSBC is sticking with its full-year profits figure of £18m, the broker was said to be warning investors that Filtronic has a lot to do to make up the shortfall in the second half of the year.

However, Filtronic is confident. A statement released late in the session said its two major businesses continue to trade well.

One company which already qualifies for inclusion in the 80% club is niche investment bank Durlacher. It shares - changing hands for 388p in March - were under fire again yesterday on reports that senior members of its private placement team has been poached by WestLB Panmure. Durlacher shares ended 5.5p weaker at 33.5p.

In fact at just about every turn yesterday blood was being shed. The initial spark was events on the other side of the Atlantic where a Florida court ruling put the outcome of the US presidential election back in the balance.

Faced with more uncertainty and talk - later denied - of a profits warning from General Electric, investors decided to sell first and ask questions later, a wise move as things quickly got worse. The software and computerservices sector was shaken by news of a shock profit warning from Dutch group Getronics.

Blaming a lack of demand for its services was not what the market wanted to hear, especially as British counterparts such as Sema, off 61p to 624p, CMG, down 131p to 970p, and Misys, off 26.5p at 608.5p, trade on valuations that assume a heroic level of future of growth.

But it was not only technology stocks that were suffering. Banks were under the cosh after Merrill Lynch turned cautious on the sector.

Following the lead of its US colleagues, Merrill moved from a selectively "overweight" position to "neutral" and at a stock-specific level lowered its rating on Lloyds TSB, 40p weaker at 682p

Unsettled by the downgrade, HSBC fell 52p to 966p, while Barclays shed 85p to £18.60 and fund manager Amvescap slipped 140p to £13.10. All of which left the leading shares nursing some nasty losses. The FTSE 100 ended the day down 160.7 points at 6,221.4 and the FTSE Techmark 100 fell 175 points to 2,865.6.

Lower down the ladder the FTSE Mid 250 closed off 89.5 points at 6,551.7, with the telecoms group Fibernet slipping 117.5p to £13.37 ahead of today's full-year figures. Word has it the group will be asking shareholders for some more cash, probably via a placing of shares.

Tour operator Airtours remained out of favour, falling 8p to 215p despite executive chairman David Crossland dipping into the market to buy 1.4m shares at 220p each.

fields.headline: Sainsbury's recovery 'on track'
fields.trailText: Sir Peter Davis, the chief executive shipped in from the Pru to rebuild the battered Sainsbury's supermarket chain, yesterday declared his recovery plan "very much on track".
fields.body:
Sir Peter Davis, the chief executive shipped in from the Pru to rebuild the battered Sainsbury's supermarket chain, yesterday declared his recovery plan "very much on track".

He was announcing a 17% dip in first half profits to £300m but reiterated a pledge made in May to stabilise profits this year and then move back into growth.

Sainsbury's shares have rebounded since Sir Peter took the top job. From a low of 247p when he moved in they climbed 75% to 431p and outperformed the market by 35% during the past three months.

But yesterday, despite re sults exactly in line with City expectations, they lost 33.5p to close at 397.75p as profit takers moved in.

"There's a bit of disappointment that Homebase hasn't been sold yet, and the share price is up with events," said Venessa James, head of UK equities at Legal & General.

Sainsbury put the Homebase chain up for sale in the summer, hoping to raise £1.2bn to fund investment in the core supermarkets business. The original four bidders have now been whittled down to just one - believed to be a financial buyer - and yesterday Sir Peter said he hoped to finalise the deal by Christmas.

But analysts now believe the disposal is likely to raise only around £1bn.

Nevertheless the DIY chain is performing well. Like-for-like sales - which exclude the impact of new floorspace - were up 5.6% and operating profits ahead 5%.

At the core supermarket chain like-for-like sales were down 0.7%, excluding petrol revenues, and operating profits were down 23%.

Sir Peter has given himself three years to restore Sainsbury's reputation as a top retailer, focusing on quality ahead of price, although he has promised to keep prices in line with the competition across 1,000 items.

He is updating the group's systems, distribution and stores, and has got off to a flying start with a programme to deliver cost cuts of £600m a year. "We have never worked so hard in all our lives", he said yesterday. "It is all moving at a faster pace here than it has for some time."

The group's new Taste the Difference range of 350 high- quality products - mimicking Tesco's Finest range - went from conception to consumption within four months, and Sainsbury's e-commerce operation has been shaken up.

Sir Peter's predecessors believed Tesco-style store-based operations woud be inefficient and set about building huge e-commerce warehouses. But under the new regime store-based operations are under way, and 65% of the country will be covered by next spring, so that Sainsbury does not lose too many customers before the special depots have begun operating.

Yesterday Sainsbury revealed it had bought 18 Grand Union stores in Connecticut and Vermont to expand its Shaw's operation in the US. Grand Union recently filed for bankruptcy. But Sir Peter insisted that while Sainsbury would continue to look for expansion in the US his priority was the UK business.

He made it clear he would also be keen to buy "any individual or parcels of stores" that came on to the UK market, using the cash he hopes to rake in from Homebase.

He made it clear he would also be keen to buy "any individual or parcels of stores" that came on to the UK market, using the cash he hopes to rake in from Homebase.

webTitle: In case you hadn't noticed, it's crunch time

fields.headline: In case you hadn't noticed, it's crunch time
fields.standfirst: 70s numbness returns to City
fields.trailText: In the 12 months from January 1973 to January 1974, the London stock market fell by a third. From there over the next year it fell by a further 60%. Britain was in crisis, and share prices said as much.
fields.body:
In the 12 months from January 1973 to January 1974, the London stock market fell by a third. From there over the next year it fell by a further 60%. Britain was in crisis, and share prices said as much.

Older City hands recall the numbing effect of turning up at the office each day only to watch the market ratchet lower once again and another client go bust. Twenty-six years on, the younger breed of London stockbrokers must be experiencing strange tinglings in their fingers and toes. Numbness could be setting in.

The headline eco-stats do not point to crisis. But with the nation's transport infrastructure disintegrating and this season's fashion pages full of mauves and unlikely greens, the 70s revival now includes a 70s-style market crunch.

It is not a crash in the sense predicted by those alarmed at the collapse of the US savings rate and its runaway trade deficit. But wealth is disappearing fast and confidence at some stage will follow.

Bar a couple of hundred points, the Nasdaq composite index has halved in value this year. The same is true of Britain's frothy Techmark 100. In broad terms, the more established equity indices - the Dow Jones and the FTSE 100 - have been travelling sideways for 20 months.

US investors have lost $4,000 billion since the spring peak and, most worryingly, a third of that has been blown away in the past two weeks. So much for western stock markets celebrating the most sustained period of economic expansion on record.

EU's poison pill

Meanwhile, over in the foreign exchange markets, the euro has been wobbling along as usual. The currency's supporters seem quite sanguine about its lack of short-term progress, alive to the fact that its level against the dollar is being dictated by the legal quagmire into which the US presidency has sunk.

But there remain plenty of longer-term reasons to question the euro's chances of a swift recovery. Take the debate being held in the European parliament's legal affairs committee yesterday, where an amendment has been tabled to Article 9 of the EU's directive on takeover rules. It seeks to allow firms "poison pill" defences against takeovers without asking their shareholders. At the extreme, the move could make hostile bids all but impossible across the continent; at best it could tie up takeovers in years of litigation.

The move has appalled the UK's Takeover Panel, whose code is generally held up as a model for EU legislation. Instead, after 10 years of wrangling, a crucial practical measure embodying investor protection - giving shareholders the right to override management on the question of whether their business should be sold - is in danger of being thrown out. When commentators refer to the need to restructure European industry the presumption is that it will get rid of such reactionary corporate measures, not introduce new ones.

Here's the beef

The hospitality industry is really much tougher than it looks - as both Basil Fawlty and Nigel Wray have discovered to their cost.

It must have seemed a delicious idea two years ago for Mr Wray and his Notting Hill friends to go into the restaurant business, capitalising on the success of Damien Hirst's Pharmacy.

After all, the place is constantly packed with wealthy diners clad in polo necks, grazing on focaccia while discussing the virtues of nouvelle vague cinema. However, as City analysts were quick to point out yesterday, the service industry is no place for amateurs. Particularly at upmarket establishments, one minor lapse can deter a customer for life.

The approach of the Hartford management team was questionable from the start - for a time, PR guru Matthew Freud served as the unlikely chief executive, finding time to run the business between publicity stunts for Chris Evans.

The company then opted for a merger with Montana, which has come up with the peculiarly contradictory concept of an upmarket American restaurant. Expanding these through London's suburbs seems an idea doomed to failure - there is simply insufficient demand for foie gras on a Monday lunchtime in Richmond.

Furthermore, industry experts question whether a chain of posh restaurants is possible - at the top end of the market, diners want exclusivity, rather than a Pizza Express-style template.

All these things are easy to say with the benefit of hindsight. To be fair, Mr Wray and his colleagues have been unlucky with timing - the restaurant bubble has burst this year throughout the country, with the likes of Belgo and City Centre Restaurants faring worst.

But the sad saga of Hartford does bring home one point - in business, style needs to be backed with substance.

fields.headline: Banks attacked on mortgage selling
fields.standfirst: Ombudsman accuses industry of trying to avoid code of practice
fields.trailText: Banks came under renewed fire yesterday - this time from the industry's ombudsman, who accused some of trying to "worm their way around" the code of practice designed to protect customers.
fields.body:
Banks came under renewed fire yesterday - this time from the industry's ombudsman, who accused some of trying to "worm their way around" the code of practice designed to protect customers.

Ombudsman David Thomas also waded into the controversy over mortgage endowment policies, saying he had seen cases where customers were clearly given misleading advice by their bank.

His comments came as it was revealed that complaints to the ombudsman scheme had risen by 14.7% to a new record. In the year to September 30, it received 14,583 written complaints compared with 12,713 during the same period last year.

The scheme, which covers all the big UK banks and resolves individual complaints about banking issues, awarded compensation in 305 of the 604 cases that went to a formal decision. The largest amount of compensation paid was £100,000 - the maximum that can be awarded.

The report comes in the run-up to the introduction of a revamped code of practice which is designed to ensure customers are treated fairly and features new requirements relating to branch closures, cash machine charges and other controversial issues. It comes into force on January 1.

Commenting on the changes, Mr Thomas said he was disappointed the declaration that the rules must be "observed in the spirit as well as the letter" was not contained in the code itself.

"It is hard to reconcile some bank promotional material with the code requirement that marketing material should be 'reasonable and not misleading'," he said.

Mortgages were the biggest source of complaints, and endowment policies featured strongly. There has been growing concern that millions of endowment holders may not be on course to pay off their mortgage loan.

Mr Thomas said he had seen evidence of misleading advice given to borrowers, highlighting a letter from an unnamed bank to a customer stating that for them, an endowment would offer "far better value for money than your existing method of repayment".

The letter contains "no suggestion of any risk that the policy would not produce enough to pay off the loan," said the industry ombudsman.

webTitle: We will fight them in the galleries...

fields.headline: We will fight them in the galleries...
fields.standfirst: As the Nazis threatened, Churchill's government knew what to do: mobilise the brush and easel brigade. By Jonathan Jones
fields.trailText: As the Nazis threatened, Churchill's government knew what to do: mobilise the brush and easel brigade. By Jonathan Jones.
fields.body:
The roof of the House of Commons has gone. Fallen timbers glow red on the floor and priceless wooden panelling stands exposed to the weather. Colours illuminate the night: crimson, sapphire and gold.

This is how John Piper marked the bombing of the Commons on May 10 1941. The German air raid started fires across London and killed 1,436 people. Piper's paintings of the Blitz stay in your mind. He was a self-consciously minor artist, with a depressive nostalgic love for old England.

But when he was sent as an official war artist to paint historic buildings destroyed by German bombing, Piper found his perfect subject. As a show of his work at the Imperial War Museum demonstrates, he became the Canaletto of the Blitz, recording the ruins of London and Coventry with the same precision that the 18th-century painter brought to the canals of Venice.

This is not so much a tribute to Piper as to the war art scheme he worked for. John Piper: The Forties serves as an introduction to the vast archive of official painting created by state-employed artists who recorded, in a traditionalist, romantic style, the gothic horrors of the Blitz. Piper was directed to paint bombed architecture by the War Artists' Advisory Committee, set up in 1939.

Everything during the war was centrally organised. Even creativity was directed from above. Thirty artists were put on salary; others received specific commissions. By the end of the war 5,570 works of official art had been produced. Art historians have tended to be sceptical about their quality.

Yet John Piper: The Forties reveals that some artists did their best work for the WAAC. Far from producing undifferentiated propaganda pulp, it knew just who to send where. While Piper painted architecture, Laura Knight recorded the lives of women workers.

Today artists strain to imagine apocalyptic horrors; these artists didn't have to. The Britain of 1940-41 faced a real apocalypse. How did artists respond? With images of green fields and ancient churches.

This is the art of a fortress island, looking into its past and its countryside as a symbol, in the context of a threatened invasion. This is where war paintings tell us more than photographs, because art is a document of the collective imagination. A painting of a V1 over a field quotes Constable, it quotes the history of Romantic landscape art.

The story of British art in wartime is part of a wider convulsion that defined the nature of art in the second half of the 20th century. Art all over the world became more nationalist in the 40s. The International Style of pre-war modernism gave way to art that was aggressively local. Piper, Graham Sutherland, Henry Moore and their followers broke drastically with continental modernism, but went in the other direction.

The imagination of Britain became inward-looking as people dug down to survive the Blitz. This is rawly visible in Piper's paintings with their anguished love of nature and of architecture so old and solid it has become part of the landscape.

Piper became famous after the war as the champion of the old against the ugly new. Although in the 30s he was an abstract painter, Piper was already turning towards the British rural past as shadows spread across Europe; in 1940 and 1941, painting the bombed hulks of Coventry Cathedral and London churches, he became a devout worshipper of what remained of the old Britain. In 1942 he published his manifesto, British Romantic Painters. His art and that of Sutherland, Ivon Hitchens and John Minton came to be called Neo-Romantic.

At the Imperial War Museum this movement's relics are part of a vast archive of war art, some on display and the rest available online or on request. About 2,000 works of official second world war art ended up here, as well as the far better-known avant-garde art of the first world war.

All kinds of artists painted the war - realists as well as romantics, Royal Academicians as well as intellectuals. Artists went abroad with British forces; three official war artists were killed. Yet it was the imagery of the British landscape under attack in the Battle of Britain and then later from V1 and V2 attacks in 1944-45 that created the most haunting art.

Women were prominent on this other home front. In Eve Kirk's Remains of St Nicholas Cole Abbey, London EC4, the twisted ruins of blitzed London are populated by tiny figures crawling over a damaged world. The sky is clear but specked with silver barrage balloons. In this painting, formal traditionalism and belief in the British tradition of landscape and topographic art collides with undreamt of destruction.

CJ Pearce's painting, Crashed Aeroplane in Devon, is a similarly nostalgic image of the British landscape. Green grass rolls up into a smoky sky, the horizon marked by a row of grey trees. The only thing wrong is that the smoke comes from a burning plane, as firemen rush uphill to try to save the pilot.

War appears in these paintings as a surreal disturbance of the British landscape. Leslie Cole's painting of gunners bringing down a doodlebug in the marshes outside London has the V1 in flames over a brown English marsh.

In AM Weston's A Wrecked Barrage Balloon at Dulwich Station the deflating form of the balloon descends on railway lines like a Salvador Dalí dream as the night sky burns orange, while in Knight's A Balloon Site, Coventry, blue-uniformed ATS women haul on ropes to get one of these soft monsters into position. Before the war, Dalí came to lecture in London. In wartime paintings, the more scrupulous the realism with which life is depicted, the more it turns into dream images.

War's surrealism fed the imagination of the painter who was to create the most significant art of the period. Francis Bacon's Three Studies for Figures at the Base of a Crucifixion (c. 1944) in Tate Modern depicts blind, malformed beasts perched in an airless interior.

The only thing they have in common with Knight's balloon is their physical perversity. The gothic regression of the Neo-Romantics is taken up and transformed into something terrible; where Piper painted Coventry Cathedral as a still-noble ruin, Bacon's medieval triptych is populated by gargoyles. It shocked viewers when shown in an exhibition with Sutherland and Moore in 1945. This was the underside of Romanticism, a return to the middle ages.

More in tune with how the nation saw itself at war were Moore's drawings of sleepers in London's underground stations. Moore's figures have the resilience of tomb sculptures. He made them for the WAAC after observing the way people behaved in makeshift tube shelters. These bodies are de-individualised. They lie together, allowing danger to pass overhead. It's a vision of a community of survival.

The art of the second world war explains so much about what came after. Modern art was shut out of the national imagination not just because of conservatism. The British turned to their past because, in 1940, that was all they had. What was modernity to people enduring the Blitz? A gas mask?

The Imperial War Museum's Artistic Records Committee, set up in 1972, continues to send artists to record conflicts and peacetime military operations all over the world. In 1990 John Keane went as an artist to the Gulf war; in 1993 Peter Howson was sent as an official war artist to Bosnia. But you get the feeling that fashion may push the Imperial War Museum to give up painting in favour of new media.

Yet painting has a special value as a record of great events. We think we know what the second world war looked like from photographs, from film footage, from posters warning Careless Talk Costs Lives, but there's something dark and frightened in these paintings, a confession that perhaps everything won't be all right. That makes them a unique confessional memory of their time.

 John Piper: The Forties is at the Imperial War Museum, London SE1 (020-7416 5320) until January 28. The museum's art collection can be viewed online at www.vads.ahds.ac.uk

webTitle: Arts: Adam Sweeting meets Clint Boon

fields.headline: Carpets, who needs 'em?
fields.standfirst: Clint Boon found fame with the Inspiral Carpets. So why did he turn down the chance to do it all again, asks Adam Sweeting
fields.trailText: Clint Boon found fame with the Inspiral Carpets. So why did he turn down the chance to do it all again, asks Adam Sweeting.
fields.body:
You probably haven't been counting, but it's five years since the Inspiral Carpets, midfield dynamos of Manchester's "baggydelic" era, bit the dust. This was bad news for the keyboard player Clint Boon, the one with the pudding-basin haircut and the Farfisa organ.

"We had a five-album deal with Mute, and on the eve of recording the fifth album Mute decided to sever the contract," Boon reports, slurping Coca-Cola in an Islington pool hall. "But I'm not griping about what Mute did. They gave me a lot of opportunities I would never have got on other labels."

Among other things, Mute gave him an opportunity to make money, though the band didn't make the most of it. Despite a 10-year career and a string of hits, the Inspirals emerged with no dosh whatsoever.

"For four years getting up there we earned nothing, for two years at the top we earned loads, and for four years on the way down we spent everything we'd earned. But I'm a passion-over-profit man, me. I'm always turning down big chunks of money, much to the disdain of me missus."

Today's Boon is barely recognisable. The shapeless clobber is gone. Instead, Boon is wearing a sharply-cut jacket with a horizontal pinstripe, a tightly buttoned black shirt and immaculate white jeans. His hair is mown close to the scalp. He looks as though he's about to sell me a timeshare.

As he sees it, the demise of the Inspirals set him free. "I feel I really started living after that. I thought, 'I never want to have all me eggs in one basket again', so the more things I can do the better."

Soon the post-Inspirals Boon was sticking his fingers in all sorts of pies. He dabbles in record production, he featured on a TV pop quiz called Elvis Has Just Left The Building, he concocts TV jingles, and he deejays regularly all over the country. Above all, Boon is commander-in-chief of the Clint Boon Experience, his zany retro-boogie unit specialising in primitive technology, irresistible tunes and a dash of "space-opera".

Their new album, Life In Transition, picks up where last year's The Compact Guide To Pop Music And Space Travel left off. This rol licking saga of psychedelic lounge music, cornball balladry and echoes of Puccini manages to look both forwards and backwards.

The album contains built-in self-promotion, topped and tailed with Clint's wife, Meg, intoning slogans in her cool Texan accent. On the tracks in between, which include Boon's duet with Travis's Fran Healy on Do What You Do, he pays homage to his musical heroes, including Brian Wilson, Joe Meek and Ennio Morricone.

"Why do I love stuff like that? It's like these guys created sounds which are as emotional as any words. Like The Tornados made Telstar with a machine called a Clavioline. It sounds like a duck if you play it on its own, but put it through an echo unit and it's the most amazing sound ever."

Boon thrives on the undemocratic nature of his new group. It's his name on the posters and the songwriting credits. "Sting didn't come out of The Police and set up another democratic band, did he? You find out what you're good at, then you go away and prosper, hopefully. It's brilliant just to be able to write a song and not have to apologise for it or explain it to anybody. I love the freedom."

Boon is enjoying himself so much that he wasn't interested when the former Inspirals received an offer to reform. "I found it sad that the industry would rather pay loads of money for a band that split up five years ago than something new and exciting like the Clint Boon Experience." But his ex-bandmates were eager to accept. Boon can't have been very popular with them. "I think they were a bit upset, but life goes on, dunnit?"

It does, but sometimes only just. Eighteen months ago, Boon and his new band were involved in a horrific road accident. Despite severe injuries, they were back on stage within two months. Boon reckons the experience has brought them all closer together.

"Things happen all through your life that change the way you live. Since the crash, I'm not scared of anything somehow. This was bad news for the keyboard player Clint Boon, the one with the pudding-basin haircut and the Farfisa organ. "We had a five-album deal with Mute, and on the eve of recording the fifth album Mute decided to sever the contract," Boon reports, slurping Coca-Cola in an Islington pool hall. "But I'm not griping about what Mute did. They gave me a lot of opportunities I would never have got on other labels." Among other things, Mute gave him an opportunity to make money, though the band didn't make the most of it. Despite a 10-year career and a string of hits, the Inspirals emerged with no dosh whatsoever. "For four years getting up there we earned nothing, for two years at the top we earned loads, and for four years on the way down we spent everything we'd earned. But I'm a passion-over-profit man, me. I'm always turning down big chunks of money, much to the disdain of me missus." Today's Boon is barely recognisable. The shapeless clobber is gone. Instead, Boon is wearing a sharply-cut jacket with a horizontal pinstripe, a tightly buttoned black shirt and immaculate white jeans. His hair is mown close to the scalp. He looks as though he's about to sell me a timeshare. As he sees it, the demise of the Inspirals set him free. "I feel I really started living after that. I thought, 'I never want to have all me eggs in one basket again', so the more things I can do the better." Soon the post-Inspirals Boon was sticking his fingers in all sorts of pies. Their new album, Life In Transition, picks up where last year's The Compact Guide To Pop Music And Space Travel left off. webTitle: Arts: Scott Capurro on gay comics

fields.headline: Straight jacket
fields.standfirst: Gay comics are supposed to tell cute jokes about homosexuals, avoid serious subjects, and above all mind their language. Aren't they? Scott Capurro refuses to be a good little queer
fields.trailText: Gay comics are supposed to tell cute jokes about homosexuals, avoid serious subjects, and above all mind their language. Aren't they? Scott Capurro refuses to be a good little queer.
fields.body:
Whenever I'm trying to fill an hour of stand-up, the last thing I'm wondering is, "Jeez, will this set land me a spot on television?" The reasons are twofold: first, I do what makes me laugh, otherwise I get bored; second, I've done stand-up on television and it ain't the apex of my career. Television producers and editors seem to have an uncanny knack for siphoning the humour out of just about anything, especially the royals, and particularly the pretty, dead ones.

Yet television comedy is seen as a move up for a comic. I guess that's because if you can't get a TV profile going, your live shows in the provinces don't sell very well. To be on any television programme, though, your set must be "clean".

Which means few or no dirty words. Misogyny within social norms, fine, but save the word cunt for the wife-beatings, mate. That's right. No cunts, although the halls of the BBC are teeming with them. Which is sad, since cunt is plainly the most versatile word in the English language. It's a verb, a noun, an adjective, and the one word that, no matter how it's used, makes my mother angry. One is also discouraged from using the word fuck, particularly as a verb. Particularly if you're gay.

See, as an out cocksucker, there are lots of things I can get away with on stage, but on television I'm perceived as dangerous. In rehearsals, TV companies treat me as though I'm retarded, or a child or, worse yet, American. "Please be nice, Mr Capurro. You want the people watching to like you, don't you?"

Then they go through the litany of words I'm not supposed to use. When the show is edited, other comics' "fucks" are left in. Mine are removed. After all, being gay is dirty enough. Do I have to be dirtier with my dirty mouth?

I'm not really complaining. I've learned to manoeuvre my way through television. I can play the take-the-cock-out-of-my-mouth-and-press-the-tongue-to-my-cheek game with the rest of them. Usually.

But in Australia, during the taping of a show in Melbourne, I described Jesus as a "queer-wannabe". I saw papers fly up over the heads of the audience. Later I found out it was the director's script. Apparently they found him, huddled in a corner, crying like a new prisoner who'd just taken his first "shower".

He was afraid I'd pollute minds. At least, that's what he told his assistant. So now TV is promoting itself as a moral barometer? A big-eyed nanny looking out for our sensitive sensibilities?

In the six years I've been performing in the UK, I've seen political correctness catch on like an insidious disease, like a penchant for black, like the need to oppress. Comics use the term to describe their own acts during TV meetings, and everyone nods in approval. Or are they choking? I can never tell with TV people.

Yet no one really understands the meaning behind political correctness, the arch, highbrow stance it panders to. The phrase was coined as a reaction to racism in the US, a belated substitute for the kindness that was stifled when hippies disappeared.

PC took the place of sympathy, which has, since Reaganomics, had a negative, "girly" tone to it. Being politically correct makes the user feel more in control, because they can manipulate a conversation by knowing the proper term to describe, say, an American Indian.

"They're indigenous peoples now," a talk show host in San Francisco told me on air recently. "The word Indian is too marginal."

"But where are they indigenous to?"

"Well, here, of course."

"They're from San Francisco?"

"No. I mean yes. My boss" - the producer, Sam - "was born and raised here, but his parents are Cherokee from Kansas. Or was it his grandparents?"

"My grandfather is Italian, from Italy. What does that make me?"

"Good in bed."

Indigenous, tribal, quasi or semi. All these words are used to describe, politely, "the truth". But, strangely enough, the truth is camouflaged. The white user pretends to understand the strife of the minorities, their need for acceptance, when all the minorities require is fair pay. I've never met a struggling Costa Rican labourer who was concerned that he be called a Latino as opposed to a Hispanic. He just wants to feed his family. Actually, I've never met a struggling Costa Rican. But that's because I'm one of the annoying middle class who keep a distance from anyone who's not like them, but have the time and just enough of an education to make up words and worry about who gets called what.

To the people we're trying to protect, we must appear naive and bored, like nuns. Ours is a tolerance that has become intolerant. As if to say: "If you don't think this way - if you don't think that a black person from Bristol is better off being called Anglo-African - you're not only wrong, you're evil!" It's fascism, plain and simple.

Suddenly it's naughty to make jokes about blacks unless you're black, and bad to make fun of fat people unless you're fat. Everyone is tiptoeing around everyone else, frightened they'll be labelled racist if they use the word Jew in a punchline. Somehow we've forgotten that it's all in how you say it. These words are not "racist" or "dangerous" by definition.

Speaking of definitions, let's talk about the word gay. Lots of people I meet are concerned about what I should be called. Is it gay, which pleases the press, or queer, which pleases the hetero hip, since they think gays are trying to reclaim that word?

The fact is that both words are straight-created identifiers. Gay is a heterosexual concept. It's a man who looks like a model, dresses like a model and has the brain of a model. He has disposable income, he loves to travel, and he adores - sometimes thinks he is - Madonna. He's a teenage girl, really, and straights love objectifying him the way they do teenage girls. Or infants. Try watching a diaper commercial with the sound off. It's like porn.

I'm about as comfortable with the word "gay" as I am with kiddie porn. I'd prefer to be called a comic. Not a gay comic. Not a queer comic. Not even a gay, queer comic, or a fierce comic, or an alternative comic. It's just the mainstream trying to pigeonhole me, trying to say, OK, he's gay, so it's OK to laugh at his stuff about gays. Which is why, partially, in my act, I make fun of the Holocaust: "Holocaust, schmolocaust, can't they whine about something else?"

The line is meant to be ambiguous, initially. It's meant to start big, and then the actual subject gets small, as I discuss ignorance about the pink triangle as a symbol of oppression, which has since been turned into a fashion accessory. Like the red ribbon, which makes the PC brigade feel they've done their part to ease hatred in the world by adorning their lapel with a pin. When asked, they're not even sure what oppression they're curing, or how they are oppressed.

But if you make fun of that triangle, or this Queen Mum, or that dead princess, suddenly you're - why mince? I'm the bad guy. I'm not acting like a good little queer should. I'm not being silent about issues that don't concern a modern gay man. I'm being aggressive. And those straights, those in charge, the folks looking after "my minority group", don't like rolling over.

Who decides what I can and cannot say? Isn't it the people that aren't listening? If I've got a good joke and a point to make, why is it bad? Why not just do my same old weenie jokes, keep playing the clubs and sleeping with closeted straight comics? Just doing those three things - particularly the last - would keep me busy and distracted, which is what "life" is all about.

But I imagine that when people go for a night out, they want to see something different. It's a big deal finding a babysitter, getting a cab, grabbing a bite and sitting your tired ass on a pricey seat to hear some faggot rattle on for an hour. So I try to offer them a unique perspective. One that might seem overwrought, desperate or strangely effortless, but also might make them look at, say, an Elton John photo just a bit differently next time.

It's not my job to find anyone's comfort zones. I don't give a shit what people like, or think they like, or want to like. I'm not a revolutionary. I'm just a joke writer with an hour to kill, who wants to elevate the level of intelligence in my act to at least that of the audience. If in doing that, I get a beer thrown at me or lose a "friend" (read: jealous comic), so be it. In the meantime I'll keep fending off my growing array of fans who are sick and tired of being lied to and patronised.

"Gosh, get her !" Get me, sounding all holier than, well, everybody. Strangely enough, the more I find my voice on stage, the more serious comedy becomes for me. Maybe I should go back to telling those "Americans are so silly" jokes before I lose my mind and throw all my papers in the air.

 This is an edited version of an article from Index on Censorship's next issue, The Last Laugh, published tomorrow, price £8.99.

fields.headline: Adidas attacked for Asian 'sweatshops'
fields.standfirst: MEPs told of Dickensian conditions in Indonesia
fields.trailText: Indonesian factory workers producing clothes for the German sportswear giant Adidas are subject to forced overtime, physical abuse and poverty-line wages, the European parliament heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Indonesian factory workers producing clothes for the German sportswear giant Adidas are subject to forced overtime, physical abuse and poverty-line wages, the European parliament heard yesterday.

In a controversial hearing organised by a British Labour MEP, Richard Howitt, an Indonesian non-governmental organisation described how workers toiled in Dickensian conditions which it said breached the company's own code of conduct.

"Wages are still below the legal minimum set by the government, the number of hours people work exceeds the legal maximum and people are paid less than a dollar a day," Rainy Hutabarat of Urban Community Mission (UCM) said after the hearing, which Adidas did not attend.

Underpayment and poor conditions for child workers in the developing world is not confined to Indonesia. The problem is severe in India where, according to aid organisations, children are making sports goods in appalling conditions.

The new allegations against Adidas centre on the Tuntex factory in Jakarta, where 1,700 workers, most of them women, produce jackets and socks.

A UCM investigation into conditions at Tuntex and two other factories - Tainan and Nikomas Gemilang - alleges that employees face "extraordinarily high financial sanctions" if they make mistakes or are late for work.

UCM also claims that sexual harassment and verbal and physical abuse are rife. Workers at the Tainan factory are, UCM says, threatened with the sack unless they work overtime, and are locked up if they refuse. It also alleges that children as young as 14 are working illegally.

Adidas yesterday denied the vast majority of the allegations. "These allegations are based on old facts. We don't use child labour and we pay above the minimum wage," Jan Runau, the company spokesman, said. "We have nothing to hide and we are confident that our suppliers are following our business practices."

He added that Adidas was maintaining a special team to check that suppliers adhere to the firm's code of conduct.

But later he appeared to admit that problems persisted. "We know that everything is not perfect with our business partners which is why we are continuing to carry out audits."

MEPs also heard allegations concerning Nestlé, the food multinational, which has has long been criticised for the way it markets baby milk products in Pakistan and elsewhere. No one from Nestlé was present at the hearing.

Mr Howitt, who is keen to bring in a binding code of conduct for European multinationals, said that the companies were guilty of "astonishing arrogance".

fields.headline: African editor killed
fields.trailText: One of Mozambique's most prominent journalists, Carlos Cardoso, has been shot dead in a central area of the capital, Maputo.
fields.body:
One of Mozambique's most prominent journalists, Carlos Cardoso, has been shot dead in a central area of the capital, Maputo.

Cardoso, editor of Metical, an independent daily news sheet, was ambushed in his car by gunmen near his office yesterday afternoon. There are no clues as to who the assassins were, but exposés in Metical may have earned him enemies in the illegal economy.

A television crew was soon on the scene, and last night's main news began with shocking pictures of Cardoso's body, riddled with bullets, being removed from the car by police

The prime minister, Pascoal Mocumbi, said he was "deeply shocked". He praised Cardoso as "a journalist who has fought tirelessly for freedom of the press".

Cardoso was the director of the Mozambican news agency, AIM, from 1980 to 1989. He later founded the first independent daily in the country, Mediafax, which was distributed by fax. He was known as courageous and outspoken.
Mozambique News Agency (AIM), Maputo

webTitle: Baghdad starts oil flowing in pipeline to Syria

fields.headline: Baghdad starts oil flowing in pipeline to Syria
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: In the biggest challenge to international sanctions so far, Iraq has begun pumping oil to Syria through a long-disused pipeline, Arab sources said yesterday.
fields.body:
In the biggest challenge to international sanctions so far, Iraq has begun pumping oil to Syria through a long-disused pipeline, Arab sources said yesterday.

Diplomats accused Iraq of illegally attempting to export 200,000 barrels of oil a day through the pipeline, which has been out of action since 1982.

This would more than double Iraq's illegal oil sales, currently thought to total around 150,000 barrels a day.

A Foreign Office spokesman in London said oil exports to Syria would deprive ordinary Iraqis of humanitarian support if they were conducted outside the UN's oil-for-food programme.

"Revenues would go to the pockets of the regime to purchase their luxuries, and not to the Iraqi people," he said.

Under UN resolutions, a new export route through Syria or anywhere else would have to be approved by the security council's sanctions committee.

Although the Foreign Office has asked Syria to confirm or deny claims that the pipeline has reopened, it was still awaiting a reply yesterday.

"It is not clear yet that Syria intends this to be outside the oil-for-food programme," the spokesman said.

According to yesterday's issue of the Saudi-owned newspaper, al-Hayat, Iraq and Syria have a written agreement "to participate in lifting the sanctions against the Iraqi people without infringing security council resolutions".

This is ambiguous because Iraq claims that, due to a loophole in the rules, the oil for Syria would not be an infringement.

The oil would not be sold directly on the open market. Instead, Syria would refine the Iraqi oil for its domestic use - which, in turn, would allow Syria to export an equivalent amount of its own oil to the Mediterranean market.

That device would allow Iraq to claim that its arrangements with Syria were no different from those with two other neighbours - Jordan and Turkey - which are already allowed to receive Iraqi oil outside the oil-for-food programme.

The attitude of western diplomats is that the oil supplies to Jordan and Turkey are technically illegal, though nothing has been done to stop them, and the quantities involved are small.

fields.headline: Ex-UN chief heads Peru government
fields.trailText: The leader of Peru's congress, Valentin Paniagua, was sworn in as the country's interim president yesterday, replacing Alberto Fujimori, who was sacked and declared "morally unfit" by the legislature.
fields.body:
The leader of Peru's congress, Valentin Paniagua, was sworn in as the country's interim president yesterday, replacing Alberto Fujimori, who was sacked and declared "morally unfit" by the legislature.

Mr Paniagua, seen as a moderate member of the opposition during Mr Fujimori's rule, took the oath of interim president before a packed chamber. He has a mandate to lead Peru into early elections in April, and will hand over the presidency to the victor on July 28.

Mr Paniagua, 64, who is expected to win consensus support ahead of the elections, named a former UN secretary general, Javier Perez de Cuellar, as the country's new prime minister.

Mr Fujimori, who stepped down on Monday, had been engulfed by a nine-week political crisis centred on his fugitive former spy chief, Vladimiro Montesinos. The former president is in Japan and has not said when he will return to Peru.
