fields.headline: Shop orgy shocks workers
fields.trailText: It must have been the mother and father of all launch parties. Earlier this month, the hitherto rather staid Paris department store Printemps held a gala evening to celebrate the grand reopening of its now thoroughly modern women's fashion floor.
fields.body:
It must have been the mother and father of all launch parties. Earlier this month, the hitherto rather staid Paris department store Printemps held a gala evening to celebrate the grand reopening of its now thoroughly modern women's fashion floor.

All the usual supermodels, actors, celebrities, designers and rock stars were there, plus a handful of engineers to ensure the lights did not go out. However, so shocked were the technicians by what they saw, that they might have wished the lights had gone out.

"The guests were a flock of drag queens and other nocturnal fauna, equipped with the entire panoply of drugs necessary for them to lose their inhibitions," the technicians' union, the CGT, wrote in a letter of complaint to the store's management.

"Under the influence, many of them exhibited themselves on the stage either semi- or utterly naked, and called on the remainder to take part in a gigantic group sex experience.

"There were sessions of sodomy, oral sex and collective masturbation in the toilets and in the changing rooms. (You will excuse us for not going into the details)."

The department store, needless to say, could not take such foul accusations lying down.

"Only five people were taken ill through alcohol," Printemps's management wrote indignantly yesterday, "and if any excesses did take place in ladieswear these were only marginal and not in the least representative of the evening as a whole."

webTitle: Violence and boycott mar Haitian election campaign

fields.headline: Violence and boycott mar Haitian election campaign
fields.standfirst: Former president Aristide likely to return to power after all main opposition parties withdraw their candidates
fields.trailText: Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the slum parish priest once hailed as the democratic saviour of impoverished Haiti, is expected to sweep back to power this weekend in a presidential election conducted amid random violence.
fields.body:
Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the slum parish priest once hailed as the democratic saviour of impoverished Haiti, is expected to sweep back to power this weekend in a presidential election conducted amid random violence.

All of the Caribbean nation's main opposition parties have withdrawn their candidates in protest at disputed counting of votes in May's parliamentary election, which handed overwhelming victory to the ruling Fanmi Lavalas party, led by Father Aristide.

The Organisation of American States, which monitored but refused to ratify those polls, has declined to oversee this presidential race.

Campaigning has been low key. Father Aristide, 47, who is now married with two daughters, has not spoken in public since October 9, when he registered his candidacy. He has become reclusive, receiving visitors in his walled 40-acre estate on the outskirts of the capital, Port-au-Prince. His Aristide Foundation for Democracy website was last updated in November 1999.

Since the United States sent in 20,000 troops in 1994 to remove the leaders of a military coup and restore the ousted President Aristide, Haiti, traditionally the poorest country in the Americas, has repeatedly disappointed the hopes of the international community.

Father Aristide stood down in 1996, in one of the country's rare instances of a peaceful transfer of power. Despite his popularity, Titid, as he is known, was barred from standing for immediate re-election under a strict constitutional provision - designed to prevent the re-establishment of dictatorships - which outlawed consecutive presidential terms.

The president argued he was entitled to serve three years lost in exile, but international pressure forced him to hand over power to his protege, René Préval.

The scramble for votes in the American presidential election, where naturalised Haitian refugees were among those criticising electoral irregularities in Florida, has overshadowed the Haitian poll and undermined US disapproval. President Clinton's call for Haiti to remedy the "serious irregularities and deficiencies evident in the May elections" has effectively been ignored.

In the runup to the presidential election, there have been numerous gun attacks but without any claims of responsibility. Earlier this month, 10 people were killed in the space of 24 hours in Port-au-Prince and incendiary devices were thrown into election council buildings.

In Gonaives, Haiti's second city, gunmen on a motorcycle riddled an empty UN vehicle with bullets last week.

To add to the atmosphere of insecurity, six senior policemen fled across the border to the Dominican Republic several weeks ago after being accused of plotting to assassinate Father Aristide, President Préval and the prime minister, Jacques-Edouard Alexis.

The officers, who included the police chief from the northern city of Cap-Haitien, were alleged to have been planning a coup.

The opposition parties hope that their decision to pull out of this weekend's race will raise questions about the legitimacy of the contest.

"This election is a masquerade," said Calixte Dorisca, an independent candidate who withdrew earlier this month. Another candidate, Evans Nicolas, said he would not run in an election marred by violence, allegations of unfairness and voter apathy. "We want a balanced elections council, not one loaded with Aristide partisans," Mr Nicolas said.

But the elections council has said it is too late for candidates to withdraw because their names are already on ballot papers for the more than 4m people registered to vote.

Fanmi Lavalas mayors in several towns have recently been accused of harassing anti-government protesters.

A British charity, Action Aid, has expressed concern about its work supporting coffee growing in the town of Thiotte, after its staff were told not to criticise the government.

"We aim to promote the democratic process but we were called in by the local mayor. If our right to express our views is now in jeopardy, then this is becoming like the early years of the Duvalier regime," said the charity's regional coordinator, Helen Collinson.

More than half of Haiti's population of 8m are illiterate, and 5% of the workforce are thought to be infected with the Aids virus. But despite the country's poverty, many foreign donors have withdrawn, or threatened to withdraw, funding from Haiti in protest at the political climate.

webTitle: French town bites back at big, bad wolf

fields.headline: French town bites back at big, bad wolf
fields.trailText: Back in the Middle Ages, peasants would dump dead wolves in the village square to help exorcise the nightmares of their families. Now, in the small Alpine town of Allevard, it seems someone is trying to send the same kind of message.
fields.body:
Back in the Middle Ages, peasants would dump dead wolves in the village square to help exorcise the nightmares of their families. Now, in the small Alpine town of Allevard, it seems someone is trying to send the same kind of message.

A delivery man discovered the fresh corpse two days ago, a single bullet hole in its chest. The adult male was hanging by its hind legs from a tree. A handwritten sign hung round its neck read: "This we can do, when we have had enough of wolves."

Hundreds of years ago, the grey wolves - which stand up to 3ft high and can weigh more than 100lb - caused terror as they roamed in packs across the southern massif.

Now, police say that if the killer is found he will be charged with "destruction of an endangered species", an offence which carries a maximum penalty of £6,000 and a six-month jail term.

The adult male wolf, thought to have been shot at the weekend, was the first to be slaughtered in France since January 1954. Scientists believe the grey wolf was extinct in France until a number of animals wandered over the border from Italy in 1992.

There are now between 20 and 30 wolves living in southern France: two small packs in the Mercantour national park, and individual animals which have spread north into the Isère and Savoie regions - traditional summer pastures of the region's shepherds.

"This killing is good news, excellent news," said Jean-Pierre Jouffrey, a shepherd from Arles who has lost 228 of his sheep to wolves on the Isère pastures in the past three years. "That's one beast that won't be ripping my ewes' throats out next summer."

But many in the region saw the return of the grey wolf as cause for celebration. "The wolf is an ancient part of France's fauna," said Marie-Paul de Thiersant of the local nature protection society. "It is a magnificent symbol of diversity. And it is part of a natural heritage that belongs to us all."

Ms de Thiersant condemned the wolf's death as "a completely indescribable act, unjustified even given the problems wolves can cause. Shooting a magnificent animal like this and then hanging it up by its paws - these are the methods of a brutal, bygone age."

The small community of Allevard is divided, according to its mayor, Philippe Langenieux-Villard.

"There is outrage at such a horrific sight but also relief at the idea that it's possible to get rid of this terror," he said. "I don't approve of stringing the thing up, but the killing's different - that reflects our exasperation. We've asked the government for help, and we never even got a reply."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: The United States yesterday issued an exceptional warning to it is citizens about Germany's growing problem of neo-Nazi and skinhead violence
fields.body:
US warns over German attacks

The United States yesterday issued an exceptional warning to it is citizens about Germany's growing problem of neo-Nazi and skinhead violence.

A state department notice cautioned that: "Hooligans, mostly young and drunken skinheads, have molested and attacked people who they take for foreigners or members of rival groups."
Tony Paterson, Berlin

France urged to admit torture

The general who led French paratroops in the notorious 1957 battle of Algiers, said in an interview published yesterday that France should admit and condemn its use of torture during the fighting.

"Morally, torture is something pretty dismal. I think [to recognise and condemn] what happened would be positive," retired general Jacques Massu, 92, told Le Monde.
Reuters, Paris

Gambia holds ex-junta chief

Gambia has detained the former head of a Sierra Leonean military junta, who may now be deported to his home country, officials said yesterday.

Valentine Strasser, who ruled the country from 1992 to 1996, arrived in Gambia in October from Britain, where he went to study after losing power. Gambia deported him back to Britain, but he was denied entry and returned to Gambia.
Reuters, Banjul

Hot record for candle dancer

A Indian junk collector has won a place in the Guinness World Records for dancing four lit candles on his luxuriant moustache.

Rajendra Kumar Tiwari balances the candles on the moustache, which he swirls to music without twitching a muscle elsewhere. He has had two teeth extracted to add flexibility.
Reuters, Allahabad

webTitle: G2: Juliet Nicolson meets Diana Mosley

fields.headline: 'Maybe the Jews could have gone somewhere like Uganda: empty and a lovely climate'
fields.standfirst: Juliet Nicolson meets Diana Mosley, unrepentant at 90
fields.trailText: Juliet Nicolson meets Diana Mosley, unrepentant at 90.
fields.body:
The Hon Lady Mosley greets me at the door of her Paris apartment. "How wunn-derful!" she exclaims in the exaggerated vowels of the prewar upper class. "Are you exhors-ted? I hope you didn't get LOORRST."

Now aged 90, she has lived in France for more than half a century. Yet after all that time, there are those in Britain who stiffen at the mention of her name. For she is the Mitford sister who married Oswald Mosley, leader of the British Union of Fascists (BUF) during the second world war, who counted Hitler among her close friends and was imprisoned for her husband's politics.

Although born into a privileged world before the great war, the Mitford sisters continue to captivate: Nancy's classic novel, Love in a Cold Climate, has been adapted for the BBC (to be shown this winter).

The letters of Jessica, who became a communist, are to be published next year. Deborah married the Duke of Devonshire and has made the estate at Chatsworth a commercial success (and even opened a shop in Belgravia, on Elizabeth Street). And the fascination with Unity's idolisation of Hitler, for whom she killed herself, continues.

But Diana was always the beautiful Mitford sister. Dressed in a tightly belted Balmain jacket and skirt, pearl earrings, her silver hat held in place by a velvet band, she is just as striking as she was when she was the focus of the world's media.

In her sunny Left Bank apartment, filled with the scent of lilies, books lie everywhere. "I stole a book once," she suddenly confides, "from Holloway Prison." She is barely able to contain her delight. "Would you like to see it?" From a drawer, she produces a small, red, cloth-bound copy of the complete works of Racine in French. The prison librarian had catalogued the book with two words in pencil: "Classic. Dull."

Diana Mosley was imprisoned for three and a half years in June 1940 for "spousal association". A year later, her husband was moved from Brixton to Holloway, to join her. Blithely she recalls their time there: "It was the sunshine and warmth I missed most." One hot day, they stripped off to sunbathe in the tiny concrete yard. The prison priest caught sight of them. "It's like the Garden of Eden out there - Lady Mosley in her little knickers," he told a warden.

Sir Oswald was Diana's second husband. At the age of 18, she married the Hon Bryan Guinness, of the brewing dynasty. The diarist James Lees-Milne wrote at the time of her engagement that she was "a goddess, more immaculate, more perfect, more celestial than Botticelli's sea-borne Venus", while an infatuated Evelyn Waugh thought her beauty "ran through the room like a peal of bells".

She would dine with Lady Colefax and weekend at Chartwell with her cousins Clemmie and Winston Churchill. Lytton Strachey was her neighbour (she described him as "cleverness incarnate"), and a present from Dora Carrington, a collage made of coloured silver-foil sweet wrappers, now hangs in her room in Paris.

Through friends who were to remain faithful throughout her life, such as Waugh, Sir Harold Acton, Lord Berners and Sir John Betjeman, she was to enjoy the intellectual company she craved. Amazingly, all these relationships survived her later marriage to Mosley and their joint imprisonment.

More than half a century on, she is still eager to hear the latest literary gossip from London. She is thrilled by the indiscretions in James Lees-Milne's recently published posthumous volume of diaries; avid for the latest on Martin Amis and curious to hear about David Hare's new play. She expresses horror at the inadequacy of the US presidential candidates and dismay at William Hague's Euroscepticism. She is au courant. Only deafness impedes her; she relies on the fax machine which whirs continually in the background.

Diana met "my fate" in 1931, at the age of 21. From the first encounter with Sir Oswald Mosley she "followed him politically, absolutely blindly". She also fell in love with him: "I knew it would never end, except with death. Never, never was I unfaithful." She didn't expect the same from him, a man who had slept with most of his first wife's best friends and even her sister. "I knew fidelity wasn't in his nature; if he had fallen for someone's mind I should have cared much more."

In 1933, Diana began to make regular visits to Germany where, with her younger sister Unity, she met Hitler. He was entranced by her and Unity, and described them as "angels", while she found him "extremely clever, incredibly frank and wonderful, charming. We were very great friends. But I didn't love Hitler any more than I did Winston." Does that mean, then, that she loved Hitler? "I was very fond of him. Very, very fond."

On October 6 1936 Diana and Mosley were secretly married in Joseph Goebbels's drawing room. Hitler came to the wedding and gave her a photograph of himself in an eagle-topped silver frame. I asked her where it is now. "I put it in a parcel in a bank when the war began because I thought it might hurt people's feelings.

I think I've got the little chit somewhere." While Hitler's present remains hidden in the safe of a Staffordshire bank, the 22 volumes of the works of Goethe, inscribed to "Liebe Diana", which the Goebbels gave her on her wedding day, sit in the small library of her Paris apartment.

Until August 1939, Diana spent long evenings alone with Hitler in his hotel in Berlin, trying to persuade him to let her set up a commercial English-speaking radio station, the advertising revenue from which would help fund the BUF.

She says that the subject of the Jews never came up. "I never heard him mention them; I know that he didn't like them, that he hated them, that he murdered them..." She hesitates; her hands flutter in front of her but her blue eyes hold my gaze unwaveringly. "Maybe instead they could have gone somewhere like Uganda: very empty and a lovely climate."

On the Mosleys release from prison in November 1943, on the grounds of Oswald's ill-health, Diana remembers queuing up in the local bank. When people reached the head of the queue, they would begin all over again, just to be able to continue staring at her. "I am a famous awful person," she laughs without a hint of apology. Even now, the British embassy in Paris is forbidden to invite her to any function there. She was never reconciled with her sister Jessica. The communist and fascist schism between them was too deep.

Since the death of her husband in 1980, she has relied on her family. Four children, 14 grandchildren, 20 great-grandchildren, their husbands and wives and her remaining sister Debo provide her with support. They all came to her 90th birthday party in June. She remains an icon to the handful who still hold her late husband's beliefs. A photograph taken on her birthday shows her sitting among 17 mild-looking, red-faced, grey-suited elderly members of BUF, not a boot or black shirt between them, who travelled to Paris on the Eurostar to raise a glass to her.

Diana Mosley feels in no way exiled. Nor is she lonely. Although most of her friends have died, her apartment has become a place of pilgrimage for historians and for those who are simply curious. The old woman who still exudes a powerfully seductive charm, who loved Hitler and Churchill equally and was in turn loved by them, continues to arouse a mixture of reverence and horrors.

And the fascination with Unity's idolisation of Hitler, for whom she killed herself, continues. But Diana was always the beautiful Mitford sister. Dressed in a tightly belted Balmain jacket and skirt, pearl earrings, her silver hat held in place by a velvet band, she is just as striking as she was when she was the focus of the world's media. In her sunny Left Bank apartment, filled with the scent of lilies, books lie everywhere. "I stole a book once," she suddenly confides, "from Holloway Prison." She is barely able to contain her delight. "Would you like to see it?" From a drawer, she produces a small, red, cloth-bound copy of the complete works of Racine in French. The prison librarian had catalogued the book with two words in pencil: "Classic. Dull." Diana Mosley was imprisoned for three and a half years in June 1940 for "spousal association". A year later, her husband was moved from Brixton to Holloway, to join her. Blithely she recalls their time there: "It was the sunshine and warmth I missed most." One hot day, they stripped off to sunbathe in the tiny concrete yard. The prison priest caught sight of them. "It's like the Garden of Eden out there - Lady Mosley in her little knickers," he told a warden. Sir Oswald was Diana's second husband. At the age of 18, she married the Hon Bryan Guinness, of the brewing dynasty. The diarist James Lees-Milne wrote at the time of her engagement that she was "a goddess, more immaculate, more perfect, more celestial than Botticelli's sea-borne Venus", while an infatuated Evelyn Waugh thought her beauty "ran through the room like a peal of bells". She would dine with Lady Colefax and weekend at Chartwell with her cousins Clemmie and Winston Churchill. Lytton Strachey was her neighbour (she described him as "cleverness incarnate"), and a present from Dora Carrington, a collage made of coloured silver-foil sweet wrappers, now hangs in her room in Paris. Through friends who were to remain faithful throughout her life, such as Waugh, Sir Harold Acton, Lord Berners and Sir John Betjeman, she was to enjoy the intellectual company she craved. Amazingly, all these relationships survived her later marriage to Mosley and their joint imprisonment. More than half a century on, she is still eager to hear the latest literary gossip from London. She is thrilled by the indiscretions in James Lees-Milne's recently published posthumous volume of diaries; avid for the latest on Martin Amis and curious to hear about David Hare's new play. She expresses horror at the inadequacy of the US presidential candidates and dismay at William Hague's Euroscepticism. She is au courant. Only deafness impedes her; she relies on the fax machine which whirs continually in the background. Diana met "my fate" in 1931, at the age of 21. From the first encounter with Sir Oswald Mosley she "followed him politically, absolutely blindly". She also fell in love with him: "I knew it would never end, except with death. Never, never was I unfaithful." She didn't expect the same from him, a man who had slept with most of his first wife's best friends and even her sister. "I knew fidelity wasn't in his nature; if he had fallen for someone's mind I should have cared much more." In 1933, Diana began to make regular visits to Germany where, with her younger sister Unity, she met Hitler. He was entranced by her and Unity, and described them as "angels", while she found him "extremely clever, incredibly frank and wonderful, charming. We were very great friends. But I didn't love Hitler any more than I did Winston." Does that mean, then, that she loved Hitler? "I was very fond of him. Very, very fond." On October 6 1936 Diana and Mosley were secretly married in Joseph Goebbels's drawing room. Hitler came to the wedding and gave her a photograph of himself in an eagle-topped silver frame. I asked her where it is now. "I put it in a parcel in a bank when the war began because I thought it might hurt people's feelings. I think I've got the little chit somewhere." While Hitler's present remains hidden in the safe of a Staffordshire bank, the 22 volumes of the works of Goethe, inscribed to "Liebe Diana", which the Goebbels gave her on her wedding day, sit in the small library of her Paris apartment. Until August 1939, Diana spent long evenings alone with Hitler in his hotel in Berlin, trying to persuade him to let her set up a commercial English-speaking radio station, the advertising revenue from which would help fund the BUF. She says that the subject of the Jews never came up. "I never heard him mention them; I know that he didn't like them, that he hated them, that he murdered them..." She hesitates; her hands flutter in front of her but her blue eyes hold my gaze unwaveringly. "Maybe instead they could have gone somewhere like Uganda: very empty and a lovely climate." On the Mosleys release from prison in November 1943, on the grounds of Oswald's ill-health, Diana remembers queuing up in the local bank. When people reached the head of the queue, they would begin all over again, just to be able to continue staring at her. "I am a famous awful person," she laughs without a hint of apology. Even now, the British embassy in Paris is forbidden to invite her to any function there. She was never reconciled with her sister Jessica. The communist and fascist schism between them was too deep. Since the death of her husband in 1980, she has relied on her family. Four children, 14 grandchildren, 20 great-grandchildren, their husbands and wives and her remaining sister Debo provide her with support. They all came to her 90th birthday party in June. She remains an icon to the handful who still hold her late husband's beliefs. A photograph taken on her birthday shows her sitting among 17 mild-looking, red-faced, grey-suited elderly members of BUF, not a boot or black shirt between them, who travelled to Paris on the Eurostar to raise a glass to her. Diana Mosley feels in no way exiled. Nor is she lonely. Although most of her friends have died, her apartment has become a place of pilgrimage for historians and for those who are simply curious. The old woman who still exudes a powerfully seductive charm, who loved Hitler and Churchill equally and was in turn loved by them, continues to arouse a mixture of reverence and horrors. © Juliet Nicolson/Tatler/The Condé Nast Publications Ltd. A full version of this article is published in the December issue of Tatler, on sale now.

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: The Burren, Ireland
fields.trailText: The Burren, Ireland
fields.body:
We were lucky the day Irish television came to film - brilliant sunshine with a blue sky and sea. The cotoneaster ground cover was vivid with scarlet berries, wet holly leaves glistened, and our stone walls gleamed white and soft grey. It has, of course, been the wettest autumn I remember in the Burren, but we escaped being flood victims.

On the whole, it hasn't been wonderful walking weather. On one walk I got caught in an electrical storm. Swiftly I made for open ground, away from the trees where I had sheltered from a cloudburst. Lightning fire swept and played over the fields and hills, illuminating stony hollows, ash, hazel and holly copses.

Thunder grumbled overhead. Minutes later it passed inland - the zigzag light becoming faint, then disappearing over the rim of the hills. The thunder ceased, leaving that dead calm of silence. It didn't last. The crackling of hail broke the quietness, "hail", as Elizabeth Bishop describes it, "the biggest size of artificial pearls/ Dead white, wax-white, cold".

There was an icy sting as I stretched out my bare hand to touch the stone wall. On my way home I noticed the hedges shining with a myriad variety of ferns; sheltered behind one cluster were a few blue harebells, while above them, suspended from yellow fuchsia leaves, were some ruby flowers.

Today, I walked the same stretch in soft falling rain - the harebells and fuchsia blooms are still there. Later I counted 56 whooper swans, including five signets, on Loch Murree. In the rain I stood and watched their "gondoliering legs" (Marianne Moore). Reluctantly I left them.

webTitle: G2: Pass notes on Helmut Kohl

fields.headline: No: 1767
fields.standfirst: Helmut Kohl
fields.trailText: Helmut Kohl
fields.body:
Appearance: Like Jacques Chirac, only much bigger. At least three Tony Blairs could fit into this fellow's trousers. You could hide a brace of Robin Cooks in his jacket. He's big, see? And German, extremely German.

Why are we writing about the biggest German chancellor in the history of German chancelling? Although he was one of the leading architects of German reunification back in 1990, his 16-year rule as chancellor came to a painful end in September 1998, when he lost the election to the social democratic challenger Gerhard Schroeder. Following that, of course, there was the humiliation of being ousted as the chairman of his Christian Democratic Union party during a scandal over illegal donations.

Why now? If you would shut up for five seconds I might tell you.

There's no need to be rude. Last Sunday the Welt am Sonntag newspaper published the first extract from Helmut Kohl, My Diaries, 1998-2000.

Sounds fantastic. I must put it on the little list I'm sending to Santa. Good idea. The book is published in Germany with an initial print run of 100,000. But there's a problem.

Ooh, I love this bit. This is what journalists call "the news angle". Yes. You see, Kohl's biographer, Klaus Dreher, says the chancellor didn't keep a diary. Unlike, say, Tony Benn, he didn't spend his midnight hours noting down the day's political meetings. He made it up retrospectively, claims Dreher.

I'm shocked. It recalls that scandal a few years ago over the Hitler diaries that were really written by Bernard Manning. It wasn't quite like that. But the Hitler diaries were fake, as the historian Lord Dacre found to his cost when he prematurely announced they were genuine.

What does Kohl write about in these fun - if questionable - diaries? How taking Germany into the Euro cost him the election. All the inside gen on the illicit party funding scandal.

Not to be confused with: Andy Cole, Old King Cole, coal, a fireman's helmet.

webTitle: Party leaders hope Clinton can break peace deadlock

fields.headline: Party leaders hope Clinton can break peace deadlock
fields.standfirst:
Prospect of visit to province 'concentrating minds'
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Political leaders on both sides of the Irish border are looking to President Clinton to "work his magic" again in Northern Ireland and break the deadlock in the peace process during a farewell visit to the province next month.
fields.body:
Political leaders on both sides of the Irish border are looking to President Clinton to "work his magic" again in Northern Ireland and break the deadlock in the peace process during a farewell visit to the province next month.

The prospect of a pre-Christmas visit, in which the outgoing president would pay a visit to the scene of the 1998 Omagh bombing, is said to be concentrating minds among republicans and unionists, who are still miles apart over disarmament.

Sinn Fein won a small victory yesterday when the high court in Belfast granted its two ministers the right to mount a legal challenge against first minister David Trimble's decision to block them from attending a special cross border ministerial body.

However, the judicial review hearing will be too late to save a meeting tomorrow in Dublin between Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness, the education minister, and his Irish counterpart, Michael Woods.

The sight of unionists and republicans fighting out their differences in court, with its echoes of the events in Florida, highlights the growing gulf between the two sides over the arms issue. Sinn Fein is still furious with Mr Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionist party, after he banned its ministers from attending the cross border body in retaliation for the IRA's "failure" to live up to its commitment to negotiate with the international arms body.

Tony Blair will intensify his efforts to revive the peace process today when he holds a "midair summit" with his Irish counterpart Bertie Ahern during a flight to a Balkans summit in Zagreb. One British official would only say last night that it was "not impossible" to hammer out a deal between Sinn Fein and the unionists.

Amid the gloom, all sides are turning once again to Mr Clinton, who has played a crucial role in nudging forward the peace process throughout its seven year history. The prospect of his first presidential visit to Northern Ireland almost exactly five years ago was a key factor in breaking an earlier deadlock between London and Dublin over disarmament.

John Major and the former Irish prime minister, John Bruton, managed to broker a last minute deal at a late night summit in Downing Street hours before the president set off from Washington. The president went on to receive a rapturous reception during his visit, which was carefully designed to reassure all sides. Mr Clinton broke the ice with Sinn Fein by shaking the hand of Gerry Adams in the heart of west Belfast. He shared a stage with the SDLP leader, John Hume, at an open air rally in Londonderry and delighted Mr Trimble by giving him a lift in the presidential limousine through Belfast.

Washington would like Mr Clinton to crown his presidency by flying into Belfast next month to congratulate Sinn Fein and the Ulster Unionists on a deal on IRA arms. That is highly unlikely and the best that can be hoped for by Washington, which will make a final decision on the visit next week, is that progress will have been made by next month.

One Irish official said: "A deal is unlikely in the next few weeks. But work is ongoing and the prospect of a presidential visit is a very helpful factor in the negotiations. There are strong parallels with Mr Clinton's visit in 1995."

The British and Irish governments both agree that the IRA must reopen its talks with the arms body headed by the Canadian General John de Chastelain. London and Dublin believe that republicans have failed to live up to their commitments which persuaded the Ulster Unionists to rejoin the power-sharing executive last May.

However, republicans believe it is unfair to blame them for the lack of progress. They say that the British government has failed to live up to its commitments in two crucial areas, policing and the scaling down of security measures. They say that the Northern Ireland police bill, which passed through parliament on Tuesday night, falls well short of the recommendations of the Patten report.

This point was underlined yesterday by the Sinn Fein chairman, Mitchel McLaughlin, who indicated that his party was unlikely to take up its places on the new police board. "The [nationalist] community will demonstrate very clearly that they recognise the betrayal of the British government and they will have no truck whatsoever with the RUC dressed up in a new uniform," he said.

Dublin is pressing London to reassure nationalists when it publishes a plan to implement the policing bill next month. "There is room for flexibility," one Irish official said.

A British source highlighted tensions between London and Dublin over policing when he said that it was "fantasy land" to think of changing elements of the bill. However, Peter Mandelson is willing to send conciliatory signals to nationalists. "We are reassuring nationalists as far as we can and Peter Mandelson made clear that he will not introduce a badge for the new force which discourages any community," one British source said.

However, the source made clear that nationalists should understand the pressures facing the unionists. "We do not support the ban imposed by the UUP," the source said. "But the ban was the least David Trimble could get away with. If he had not done that Jeffrey Donaldson [his hardline opponent] would have won."

webTitle: TV and Radio: The Onion internet newspaper

fields.headline: Read 'em and weep
fields.standfirst: For 12 years, internet newspaper The Onion has produced the sharpest, funniest and most offensive comedy in America. Now the men behind it are cutting deals with Steven Spielberg.  Danny Leigh talked to them
fields.trailText: For 12 years, internet newspaper The Onion has produced the sharpest, funniest and most offensive comedy in America. Now the men behind it are cutting deals with Steven Spielberg. Danny Leigh talked to them.
fields.body:
Los Angeles, spring 2000. A bright-eyed executive sits behind his/her desk in the glass-fronted offices of Dreamworks - the entertainment conglomerate founded by arch-moguls David Geffen, Jeffrey Katzenberg and Steven Spielberg - scouring for stories to turn into movie magic.

It's a bad week for ballsy single parents triumphing against the odds; a go-slow for cute puppies saving their owners from certain doom. Then he/she chances on the latest missive from satirical website The Onion.

Tenth Circle Added To Rapidly Growing Hell declares the headline, above an account of the underworld's upsizing to accommodate new legions of the damned: besides the flatterers and simonists, space has now been found for the publicists, award-show hosts and "media whores". The executive makes a call, then strikes a deal. And suddenly America's darkest, most biliously inspired comic talents are playing footsie with Hollywood.

On paper, it looks implausible. In reality, the story's transformation from sly gag to potential blockbuster still has its author, Onion head writer Todd Hanson, reeling. "I guess stranger things have happened", he ponders. "But not to us. When the call first came in we were laughing hysterically, just because the idea of Dreamworks wanting this sounded so much like one of our jokes."

He's dead right. With its overtones of blank surrealism, the entire concept could have come straight from the archives Hanson's helped build since the then-shoestring operation started rolling in Madison, Wisconsin 12 years ago.

Alongside "Christ Announces Hiring Of Associate Christ", "Man With Heart Disease Eagerly Awaits Young Boy's Death", and the definitive "Christopher Reeve Placed Atop Washington Monument", the notion of Spielberg's stormtroopers climbing into bed with The Onion's immaculate cynics would have slotted in nicely.

But the irony doesn't end there. With Hanson hired as scriptwriter ("Yup, they're sucking me into the whirling maelstrom with them"), Dreamworks' plans for the finished product involve animation and - a deep breath may be advisable here - musical singalongs.

Hanson knows how it sounds. "You'd like to hope it won't end up completely toothless," he says dolefully. "But I'm prepared for the possibility that by the time it comes out it'll be the story of a super-intelligent killer whale and a sickly child who learns to love again."

In a sense, Tinseltown's attentions were inevitable. To its million-plus readers, The Onion represents a much-needed scalpel jabbing at the flabby underbelly of America's self-image. To the comedy industry, however, it's buzzword heaven: hip, edgy, and - most importantly - young, an ascendant brand name to be bought and sold like Saturday Night Live and National Lampoon before it.

Diversification doesn't frighten the staff - their books, The Onion's Finest News Reporting and Our Dumb Century, have already hogged the bestseller list, while editor-in-chief Rob Siegel speaks enthusiastically of venturing into movies and TV under The Onion banner.

All the same, he's aware of the horrors lurking in the entertainment shark-tank. "We definitely want to move into other mediums, but we get prickly when we're told how to be funny. So the only way we could do it would be to have total control. We've had a lot of meetings with Hollywood people, and what usually happens is they tell us how much they love what we do right before they become the experts on how to do it."

In other words, the "edge" to which the business pays such ardent lip service is precisely what makes Siegel and company such a risky investment. Because, while they can do pathos, and even a strange, twisted variant on sweet, what The Onion does best is the kind of scabrous deadpan that, as Hanson points out, most execs are "paid to eliminate on sight".

Somehow - entertaining as the idea may be - you can't imagine studio chiefs salivating over "Teachers Are Appalled By Poorly-Written Teen Suicide Notes" or "Stephen Hawking Builds Robotic Exo-Skeleton".

Equally, although various alumni have graduated to the likes of Futurama and Buffy The Vampire Slayer, the fiercely independent staff of mid-Western college drop-outs hardly fit the profile of the career-minded Ivy Leaguers typically found on the networks' payroll.

The last writer Siegel took on was poached direct from a sandwich shop. "We try not to hire rich kids from Harvard," he explains, "which is the source of most TV comedy writers. There's a real anti-elitist chip on our shoulder, so how comfortably we'll ever fit in, I don't know."

And yet, with the offers getting bigger, Siegel knows The Onion's moment has arrived; and, with it, the risk of being seen to (whisper it) sell out. He may be sanguine about Tenth Circle ("They've paid their blood money, they can do what they want"), but he's also conscious of protecting the air of fearless spite that made the site's name in the first place. "I think people appreciate there's a purity to us. And yes, if we do move on, then we'll have to be incredibly careful about what we put our names to."

There's an odd mixture of excitement and apprehension in his voice, echoed by Hanson as he mulls over a shiny, gilt-edged future: "The question of how you preserve anything even remotely biting in the face of being mainstreamed is one I worry about constantly. So if any of your readers know the answer, please ask them to write to me." Then comes a low, throaty snigger. "But you know, I'm sure we'll cope. I like to think that, deep down, we're every bit as shallow, craven and corruptible as the next guy."

In other words, the "edge" to which the business pays such ardent lip service is precisely what makes Siegel and company such a risky investment. Because, while they can do pathos, and even a strange, twisted variant on sweet, what The Onion does best is the kind of scabrous deadpan that, as Hanson points out, most execs are "paid to eliminate on sight". Somehow - entertaining as the idea may be - you can't imagine studio chiefs salivating over "Teachers Are Appalled By Poorly-Written Teen Suicide Notes" or "Stephen Hawking Builds Robotic Exo-Skeleton". Equally, although various alumni have graduated to the likes of Futurama and Buffy The Vampire Slayer, the fiercely independent staff of mid-Western college drop-outs hardly fit the profile of the career-minded Ivy Leaguers typically found on the networks' payroll. The last writer Siegel took on was poached direct from a sandwich shop. "We try not to hire rich kids from Harvard," he explains, "which is the source of most TV comedy writers. There's a real anti-elitist chip on our shoulder, so how comfortably we'll ever fit in, I don't know." And yet, with the offers getting bigger, Siegel knows The Onion's moment has arrived; and, with it, the risk of being seen to (whisper it) sell out. He may be sanguine about Tenth Circle ("They've paid their blood money, they can do what they want"), but he's also conscious of protecting the air of fearless spite that made the site's name in the first place. "I think people appreciate there's a purity to us. And yes, if we do move on, then we'll have to be incredibly careful about what we put our names to." There's an odd mixture of excitement and apprehension in his voice, echoed by Hanson as he mulls over a shiny, gilt-edged future: "The question of how you preserve anything even remotely biting in the face of being mainstreamed is one I worry about constantly. So if any of your readers know the answer, please ask them to write to me." Then comes a low, throaty snigger. "But you know, I'm sure we'll cope. I like to think that, deep down, we're every bit as shallow, craven and corruptible as the next guy." Useful link The Onion

webTitle: TV and Radio: The price is right

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Who would be David Letterman's replacement on The Late Show if he retired before the end of 2001?
fields.trailText: Who would be David Letterman's replacement on The Late Show if he retired before the end of 2001?
fields.body:
Jerry Seinfeld ...........Evens

Ed Regis ........................2-1

Bill Cosby ......................4-1

Howard Stern .................8-1

Rosie O'Donnell ...........16-1

David Letterman is the Jerry Springer of the celebrity chat show, taking down his A-list guests with pointed mockery. But can a late-night comedian still be funny after open-heart surgery? The grind of hosting a nightly show requires keen concentration and physical and mental agility.

"This is a hard job, but it will look good on a CV", says Andy Clifton, Ladbrokes' entertainment odds compiler. "It's one of the most high-profile positions in American TV, provided you do well. But Letterman is a hard act to follow."

Bill Cosby and Ed Regis have both guest-hosted the show during Letterman's illness. We all know who Bill Cosby is, but Ed Regis? This 68-year-old senior with beige hair is now signing $20m TV deals thanks to the one line - "Is that your final answer?" Yes, he hosted the American version of Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? "But debate rages over whether they'd replace Dave with someone old enough to be his Dad", says Andy.

By comparison ,the other three contestants are spring chickens by comparison. Shock jock Howard Stern already has his eponymous late-night TV show, but could he perform five nights a week? "I think his brand of humour (if you want to call it that) would start to wear thin after a while and even alienate the guests. He's too big a risk."

Rosie O'Donnell, on the other hand, is very reliable and knows her way behind the scenes after producing and hosting VH-1's Stand-Up Spotlight. Yet Andy thinks it's unlikely a woman will get the gig. "American network TV is a male-dominated world", he says.

So, once again, the spotlight falls on Jerry Seinfeld, New York's favourite comedian, winning the SAG (Screen Actors Guild) awards almost yearly. "I think this would be a perfect new venture for him, and he could almost name his price", says Andy.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Work in progress

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: Michael Wood, historian
fields.trailText: Michael Wood, historian
fields.body:
My new series, Conquistadors, is inspired by the events of the Spanish conquest of the New World. We follow the journeys of Hernán Cortés in Mexico, Francisco Pizarro in Peru, the El Dorado expedition through Ecuador and Brazil, and Cabeza de Vaca, who lived with native Americans for eight years. All are based on first-hand Aztec and Inca accounts.

It's probably about the 70th documentary I've made. You go through two years of intense experiences and in the end you have to confine it all to just four shows. With a series like this you have life experiences: trekking up the Andes at three in the morning to see the ridge hills on the ice. We don't use actors, so I have to be the front person and dramatise scenes - Montezuma and Cortés in the pyramid, braziers of human hearts all around...

We were run out of town at gunpoint in the Yucatan - they're very touchy about outsiders. They tried to break up our cameras, so you leave, because it's only a film. People ask if you were shot at, and whether it was dangerous - it's all a load of bollocks really.

There are moments of mild danger, but in the main people are fantastically welcoming. I remember landing on the riverbank to camp for the night in the Ecuadorian rainforest; we asked for permission and it was fine. But if an Ecuadorian film crew arrived in Hampstead in a boat, you can imagine people's attitudes: "I'm terribly sorry, but..."

I'm a partner in a small independent film company, so I'm involved in talks for the next project with the BBC - a documentary life of William Shakespeare, still the world's number one writer. My series of medieval essays, In Search Of England, is just out in paperback, and I'm preparing a book of stories of 20 years of travelling. History is the thread - what comes down to us from the past, how the pace has changed, and how identities that built up over the millennia have been wiped out.

But my main priority now is the school panto in December - real life returns with a vengeance!

 Conquistadors, Fri 24 Nov, 9pm, BBC2.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The Routes Of English | Analysis
fields.body:
Melvyn Bragg launches his third series about the evolution of our language. This latest segment of The Routes Of English (9.0am, Radio 4) considers the astonishing number of local variations to have emerged in the past millennium, not all of them mutually comprehensible. As a Londoner, I had some trouble with the Northumberland accents demonstrated. The local miners' Pitmatic dialect, for example, can describe the act of putting one foot in front of the other as "wawking", "wahking" or "wairking".

Adam Smith thought that his famous "invisible hand" would never steer us toward altruism. He argued that people responded only to self-interest, a proposition challenged by Andrew Dilnot in Analysis (8.30pm, Radio 4). Among the experts Dilnot calls in aid is Professor Richard Dawkins, proponent of the selfish gene. Dawkins protests that his thesis has been widely misinterpreted, and does not support Smith's chilly view of mankind. Altruism is in our make-up, but needs to be encouraged.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Last night's TV

fields.headline: The odd couple
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: Friends for Dinner | State of the Planet | The X-Files | Coronation Street
fields.body:
In the tradition of that oven chips advert in which a chorus of workmen in the back of a Transit van wonder "Will it be chips or jacket spuds? Will it be mushrooms, fried onion rings? You'll have to wait and see", so the titles of Friends For Dinner (BBC2) muse "Is it Jamie? Could it be Gary? Ainsley? It might be Rick?"

It is none of the above, for that is the noise of the barrel bottom being scraped. Yes, it's Antony Worrall Thompson.

Now, if he turned up at my front door, I'd do what my granny used to do when the nuns came round collecting for charity - hide under the window. As it was, Stuart, who was indeed having friends for dinner, let AWT in and so began a strange affair between an odd couple.

"I like his cooking and he seems like a nice man", Stuart said, hardly bubbling with enthusiasm. Obviously, he was still miffed that he got AWT and not JO - that's Jamie Oliver to you - to help him dans la cuisine. Mind you, had he got his mitts on Jamie, Stuart and his chums probably would have attempted to spit roast the Naked Chef.

And that's not something you want to see on national television. Thus, it was leek and roquefort quiche, chocolate and prune terrine and chargrilled squid on AWT's menu. Or more accurately, straight out of a recipe book. Be still, my beating imagination.

Stuart and Antony went shopping. Back at Stuart's house things got really icky when it came to squid preparation. After removing the tentacles, the ink sac and the strange plasticky bits from inside the animal (how many hints do some people need before they twig that some things are so vile, they aren't supposed to be eaten?), Stuart and his friend Derek slid them, sheath-like, over a couple of courgettes. "Don't stretch it too much. Ease it in." It wasn't the most appetising spectacle.

Speaking of unappetising spectacles, both State Of The Planet (BBC1) and The X Files (BBC2) warned of the sixth extinction which threatens the world. Where the latter relied upon Dana Scully running down corridors looking exasperated and Fox Mulder lying around looking dead to make its point, the former had Sir David Attenborough scooting hither and thither, from Hawaii to Surrey via the African savannah.

After the distraction of calculating just how many air miles Sir David had earned (a lot), State Of The Planet was an engrossing, entertaining (and slightly frightening) look at the destructive power of humanity. And that of snails. Specifically, snails in Hawaii, where a species of killer snail was introduced to kill off another introduced species which had been killing native snails. Unfortunately, the killer snails much preferred the taste of the native snails, so ate them instead.

Almost every species of plant and animal that tourists see on the islands are introduced; the natives having died out long ago. Even Tom Selleck wasn't actually from Hawaii.

Attenborough's point was clear: like pulling a stray thread on a jumper, Hawaii's environmental impoverishment is what happens when humankind starts messing around with nature. A landmark series, State Of The Planet is Reithian television at its most impressive.

At last we know what's happened to Roly, formerly dog-in-residence at The Queen Vic (pre-Janine). In an attempt to revive his soap career, he's taken to perching on Liz McDonald's head in Coronation Street (ITV). As if poor Jim hasn't suffered enough. Actually, he hasn't.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Johnny Guitar | Flavour Of Green Tea Over Rice | Out Of Sight | On The Waterfront
fields.body:
Johnny Guitar

(Nicholas Ray, 1954)

8am, 2pm, Sky Cinema

Ray's weird first Western was panned on its release, but admired by Godard and Truffaut as "beautiful and profound". Sterling Hayden's Johnny Guitar wanders into town and, unlike most Western heroes, takes a back seat to the two women struggling for power - his former lover, Joan Crawford's black-clad saloon-bar owner, Vienna, and Mercedes McCambridge's extraordinary, butch, land-grabbing Emma Small. Here's the Western as surreal Freudian study of sex and power.

Flavour Of Green Tea Over Rice

(Yasujiro Ozu, 1952)

6pm, FilmFour

With its journeys by plane, train and car, baseball games and busy camerawork, this is something of a departure from Yasujiro Ozu's still, calm style, but the delicately probing treatment of a range of emotional ties is entirely his. A study of the strengths and weaknesses of the arranged marriage.

Out Of Sight

(Steven Soderbergh, 1998)

8pm, Sky Premier

This hip, witty thriller brought indie star Soderbergh storming into the mainstream. Scriptwriter Scott (Get Shorty) Frank plots an intricate path through Elmore Leonard's twisty novel, and hangs on to the master's snappy dialogue. Meanwhile George Clooney's bankrobber and Jennifer Lopez's federal marshal fizz with odd-couple chemistry, and Michael Keaton and Samuel L Jackson appear, unannounced.

On The Waterfront

(Elia Kazan, 1954)

10pm, FilmFour

Classic method mumbling from Marlon Brando as Terry Malloy, the pug turned stevedore struggling against a corrupt dockers union. A meaty cast includes Rod Steiger as his disloyal brother, Karl Malden's upright priest and Eva Marie Saint. Kazan wanted Arthur Miller to do the script, but he was put off by Kazan's testimony to the HUAC committee. Budd Schulberg's writing wasn't bad: "And what do I get?" Terry asks his brother. "A coupla bucks and a one-way ticket to Palooka-ville."

fields.headline: Will Pluto get the push?
fields.standfirst:
We could miss our chance to explore the most distant planet, writes Duncan Steel
Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: We could miss our chance to explore the most distant planet, writes Duncan Steel
fields.body:
A nother express has come off the rails, and may be years late in reaching its destination. It is not a train, but Nasa's long-planned Pluto-Kuiper Express probe.

The only planet yet to be visited by a spacecraft, and so the one we know least about, is Pluto. This is hardly surprising. We've known of it for but a fraction of a Pluto year. Since it was discovered in 1930 Pluto has traversed little more than a quarter of its loop around the Sun, a complete orbit taking 248 of our years.

Tiny Pluto - only two-thirds the size of our Moon - plods around the frigid depths of space, never coming within 2.7 billion miles of the Sun. But it's not alone. In 1978 a moon of Pluto was discovered, and named Charon. Unlike most moons it is large compared to its parent. Pluto is about 1,475 miles across, Charon a little more than half that, at 750 miles. Astronomers tend to think of the two as a binary planet, taking a little over six days to pirouette around each other.

More recently, a host of other cosmic lumps have been found in their vicinity. Since 1992 astronomers have spotted more than 300 minor planets, typically 100 miles or so in size, slowly circuiting the sun beyond Neptune. This is called the Kuiper belt, after the Dutch-American astronomer who suggested its existence in 1950. The plan was for the Pluto-Kuiper Express (PKE) space probe to fly past Pluto, then visit several Kuiper belt objects.

Express seems a misnomer when interplanetary journeys can take decades. Nasa's Voyager 2 probe, launched in 1977, arrived at Neptune in 1989. Even that required boosts from successive fly-bys of Jupiter, Saturn and Uranus. The plan is to launch PKE in 2004. An encounter with Jupiter in 2006 will use its gravitational slingshot action to throw the satellite on to a high-speed trajectory reaching Pluto in 2012.

That plan has its drawbacks. When it gets to Pluto, PKE will be travelling at 12 miles per second, and so will whiz by, providing only a series of snapshots rather than a prolonged period of data collection. It is not feasible to give PKE an adequate rocket booster to stop it at its destination.

The other problem is that Jupiter has to be in the right place if PKE is to use its gravity to accelerate. Jupiter will be positioned correctly until 2015 at the earliest. PKE would then reach Pluto in 2022. The researchers, who have invested a decade in planning PKE, would by then be superannuated.

PKE's timetable is set by celestial mechanics. If it does not fly in 2004, it may be left standing for a dozen years. Someone might invent a novel propulsion technique that will work far from the Sun, but nothing could be cheaper than a free gravity assist from Jupiter in 2006.

This seems a compelling case, if the last unexplored planet is to be reconnoitred in the near future. Enter the reality of limited budgets, and vested interests. The Nasa hierarchy says the agency cannot afford the $600m PKE would cost to build for a 2004 launch. Instead the order has been given to concentrate on a mission to Europa, one of the four large moons of Jupiter.

Here critics think that Nasa is bowing too low to public opinion, which is bedazzled by the prospect of life elsewhere. Detractors say astrobiology is the only science with nothing to study, although it hits the headlines frequently, such as in 1996 when Nasa announced the possible identification of microfossils in a meteorite from Mars.

Why Europa? It is largely made of ice. Many scientists think it likely that Europa has an ocean beneath the frozen crust now being inspected by the Galileo satellite, which has spent the past five years orbiting Jupiter, returning detailed images of the planet and its moons. The sine qua non of life on Earth is liquid water. If Europa has that, plus the plethora of organic chemicals we find everywhere, then some form of life is a possibility, even if it's only microbial.

The Europa Orbiter mission will carry a radar system capable of penetrating the ice, indicating the existence of that ocean, if it's there. But new engineering technologies are needed, and their development has already caused the launch date to slip from 2003 to 2006.

To keep even to that delayed timetable, Nasa chiefs decided that PKE must be dropped, deferring arrival at Pluto until 2020 or so. This provoked a storm of protest. The Planetary Society, the worldwide association of space exploration enthusiasts, collected 10,000 letters of support for PKE within a fortnight.

PKE advocates say that Nasa cannot be that hard up if it has just found $200m for an additional rover vehicle to be sent to Mars in 2003, for which there is limited scientific priority but huge public interest. They also argue that the Europa Orbiter could be launched any year, whereas PKE has to go in 2004.

Would it be that bad if PKE were delayed a decade or so? It was a surprise when, in the 1980s, Pluto was recognised to have a tenuous atmosphere, largely composed of methane. At that time Pluto was closest to the Sun (and hence the hottest) it ever gets, having dipped within Neptune's orbit from 1979 until 1999.

As Pluto recedes, the atmosphere is expected to freeze out. This also explains why the planet is relatively bright, for its tiny size: we think it is largely coated with methane snow, replenished each orbit, and that frosting reflects much of the sunlight reaching it.

This provides another timetable. Soon that gaseous shroud will be no more, and PKE was designed specifically for atmospheric investigations. As one PKE advocate put it: "The last time Pluto was where it is right now, George Washington was chopping down a cherry tree. It will be more than two hundred years before we can do what we can do today with Pluto."

The time to build a PKE to reach Pluto in 2012 is right now. A few years back, when astronomers discussed if Pluto should be regarded as a fully-fledged planet, there were howls of protest from the public, and the plan to demote it was abandoned. Perhaps the imperative to visit Pluto within our lifetimes, will also put enough pressure on Nasa to put the Express back on the rails.

Duncan Steel works at the University of Salford. His new book Target Earth (Time Life) will be published shortly.

Jupiter will be positioned correctly until 2015 at the earliest. PKE would then reach Pluto in 2022. The researchers, who have invested a decade in planning PKE, would by then be superannuated. PKE's timetable is set by celestial mechanics. If it does not fly in 2004, it may be left standing for a dozen years. Someone might invent a novel propulsion technique that will work far from the Sun, but nothing could be cheaper than a free gravity assist from Jupiter in 2006. This seems a compelling case, if the last unexplored planet is to be reconnoitred in the near future. Enter the reality of limited budgets, and vested interests. The Nasa hierarchy says the agency cannot afford the $600m PKE would cost to build for a 2004 launch. Instead the order has been given to concentrate on a mission to Europa, one of the four large moons of Jupiter. Here critics think that Nasa is bowing too low to public opinion, which is bedazzled by the prospect of life elsewhere. Detractors say astrobiology is the only science with nothing to study, although it hits the headlines frequently, such as in 1996 when Nasa announced the possible identification of microfossils in a meteorite from Mars. Why Europa? It is largely made of ice. Many scientists think it likely that Europa has an ocean beneath the frozen crust now being inspected by the Galileo satellite, which has spent the past five years orbiting Jupiter, returning detailed images of the planet and its moons. The sine qua non of life on Earth is liquid water. If Europa has that, plus the plethora of organic chemicals we find everywhere, then some form of life is a possibility, even if it's only microbial. The Europa Orbiter mission will carry a radar system capable of penetrating the ice, indicating the existence of that ocean, if it's there. But new engineering technologies are needed, and their development has already caused the launch date to slip from 2003 to 2006. To keep even to that delayed timetable, Nasa chiefs decided that PKE must be dropped, deferring arrival at Pluto until 2020 or so. This provoked a storm of protest. The Planetary Society, the worldwide association of space exploration enthusiasts, collected 10,000 letters of support for PKE within a fortnight. PKE advocates say that Nasa cannot be that hard up if it has just found $200m for an additional rover vehicle to be sent to Mars in 2003, for which there is limited scientific priority but huge public interest. They also argue that the Europa Orbiter could be launched any year, whereas PKE has to go in 2004. Would it be that bad if PKE were delayed a decade or so? It was a surprise when, in the 1980s, Pluto was recognised to have a tenuous atmosphere, largely composed of methane. At that time Pluto was closest to the Sun (and hence the hottest) it ever gets, having dipped within Neptune's orbit from 1979 until 1999. As Pluto recedes, the atmosphere is expected to freeze out. This also explains why the planet is relatively bright, for its tiny size: we think it is largely coated with methane snow, replenished each orbit, and that frosting reflects much of the sunlight reaching it. This provides another timetable. Soon that gaseous shroud will be no more, and PKE was designed specifically for atmospheric investigations. As one PKE advocate put it: "The last time Pluto was where it is right now, George Washington was chopping down a cherry tree. It will be more than two hundred years before we can do what we can do today with Pluto." The time to build a PKE to reach Pluto in 2012 is right now. A few years back, when astronomers discussed if Pluto should be regarded as a fully-fledged planet, there were howls of protest from the public, and the plan to demote it was abandoned. Perhaps the imperative to visit Pluto within our lifetimes, will also put enough pressure on Nasa to put the Express back on the rails. Duncan Steel works at the University of Salford. His new book Target Earth (Time Life) will be published shortly.

webTitle: With no space of your own

fields.headline: With no space of your own
fields.standfirst:
The biggest challenge for astronauts is living together, writes Sanjida O'Connell
Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: The biggest challenge for astronauts is living together, writes Sanjida O'Connell
fields.body:
I magine living in a very small cramped room with two or three people, constantly monitored like an inmate from Big Brother for months, maybe even years, at a time. It takes a certain sort of person to live like this. They are called astronauts.

Not only do they have to live with people for extended periods, almost without privacy, they must also cope with incredible isolation and loneliness, unable to see family and friends. Despite the glamour of space travel, in reality it is composed of tedium interspersed with crises.

The next shuttle launch on November 30 will be a 10 day trip, practically a vacation. But within the next 10 to 20 years, Nasa plans to fly to Mars, and this could take a minimum of two to three years.

Most of us know about the physiological problems of being in space: bone wasting, muscle loss, motion sickness and stomach aches. But psychological problems can be almost as bad. Apart from feeling bored, astronauts also experience insomnia, anxiety, depression, irritability and emotional hyper-sensitivity.

The psychiatrist Professor Nick Kanas of the University of California in San Francisco says: "The average person can't do it. Astronauts are living in an isolated and confined environment. It's like living in the arctic, or in a submarine, and they have to adapt. They have to tolerate seeing the same person day after day, and still deal with them on a professional basis."

The sort of person who can cope in this situation doesn't feel the need to please others, or crave their own space. Kanas, who has just published a paper on how the astronauts interacted during the shuttle and Mir space missions, believes such people are born, not made, but it is possible to enhance what is already there.

For instance, during a routine operation practised on the ground, the astronauts could be observed and afterwards told how well they dealt with the rest of the crew. If they were not open enough, or didn't listen to another member of the team, they would be asked to repeat the procedure, correcting their social faux pas. Most people would have difficulties with this kind of personal criticism, but Kanas believes astronauts would cope if they're told they are healthy people training for an unusual situation.

In his research, Kanas found the Americans seemed to have more emotional problems than the Rus sians. He thinks this was because two of the three crew were Russians, and the controls were in their hands, so the Americans may have felt they had less authority.

The Russians, in contrast, had financial problems. Their salary wasn't paid for months at a time. They also suffered asthemia, a kind of agitated depression, where they became irritable, couldn't sleep and started to withdraw from their colleagues. Kanas believes this is a normal response to a confined environment.

In general there was very little in-fighting between the crew, be they Americans or Russians. What tended to happen was that mission control was blamed instead. Kanas calls this displacement. "It's as if you or I had a bad day at work. We can't tell our boss he's a jerk, so we go home and kick the cat."

The astronauts have to deal with very stressful situations: if anything goes wrong with the shuttle, they have to repair it. On longer flights, even mission control may not be able to advise them. Kanas found both the astronauts and mission control took in their stride most situations that would be considered stressful by a normal person.

Overall, they perceived significantly less job pressure and stress than most other work groups. Again, a potential astronaut is likely to be someone who doesn't easily become stressed. But this quality can be enhanced.

P rofessor Patricia Cowings, director of the psycho-physiological research facility at Nasa's Ames research centre, was also an astronaut and is now developing AFTE, autogenic-feedback training exercise. Initially, this was designed to help the crew recover from motion sickness, but she realised it could also teach them, and civilians, to minimise their response to stress.

AFTE measures physiologi cal and behavioural responses, such as pulse, brain waves and breathing rate. Those wired up to this machinery can watch their own responses and learn how to bring their pulse and other measurements back down to a neutral level within six hours.

Research shows problems occur during the middle to the end of a space trip, normally because the novelty has worn off and boredom has set in. There are a number of ways of getting around the kind of psychological problems that astronauts may face. Apart from pre-flight training, it's a good idea to give them a varied diet so they're not eating monotonous fare every day.

In addition, they should be allowed to exercise, speak to their familes and listen to music. Kanas is pioneering the idea of surprise presents to relieve the monotony. For long term flights, he suggests having a counsellor on board: if anyone on a two year trip has a nervous breakdown they would not be able to pop back to see the therapist.

Ultimately, one of the most difficult tasks, and perhaps the most overlooked psychological problem, is what hap pens to the astronauts when they return. There can be nothing to beat the feeling of having flown to the moon. But on returning some do find it difficult to cope with mundane reality after being a famous cosmonaut; others experience marital problems faced with a non-virtual spouse. But he says there are others who gain whole new insights.

These are people who have looked at the earth from a unique perspective and realised in a very concrete way that there are no boundaries between countries, cities, religions, politics and peoples. Perhaps, after all, these are the people best able to love their neighbour in space where there is none.

fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: Animal census takes plunge | Recruits - it's a new formula
fields.body:
Animal census takes plunge
Blue whales grow to 80 feet and weigh in at 300,000 lbs, but nobody knows much about how they feed, breed or migrate. Blue sharks, albatrosses, yellowfin tuna, loggerhead turtles and squid also remain deep mysteries. But 60 marine scientists who met in California this week decided on a 10-year programme to count heads in the great oceans: the Census of Marine Life will tag and electronically track thousands of selected turtles, whales, seals, birds and sharks. "We don't like to tell anybody we're ignorant about the oceans, but we are," said Barbara Block, professor at Hopkins Marine Station, Pacific Grove. "We haven't spent enough time exploring our own planet."

Recruits - it's a new formula
Around 100 science museums across Europe are being offered new interactive, off-the-shelf science exhibits at reduced prices in a € 2m promotion. CHEMistry for Life is a collaboration between Ecsite, a European association that brings together science and technology museums, and the European Chemical Industry Council, CEFIC, which paid to develop the exhibits on display at the launch at Naples's city of science at the weekend. The industry hopes the displays, intended to entertain as well as educate, will improve chemistry's image among consumers and recruits. Some of the prototype exhibits were designed by Techniquest, the Cardiff science discovery centre.

Feathers claim won't fly
A blow for the scientists who thought they had found the first ever feathers: this may yet prove to be a flight of fancy. Longisquama insignis is a Triassic reptile found in Kyrgyzstan with what looked like fossil feathers on its back, according to reports that caused a flap in Science earlier this year. Two Toronoto palaeontologists report in Nature today that they have bad news: the discoverers were in fact looking at highly modified scales rather than feathers. The title of oldest known feathered tetrapod must go back to the favoured contender, Archaeopteryx.

fields.headline: Folders find a new wrinkle
fields.standfirst: Engineers know there's more to origami than paper boats, writes  Peter Forbes
fields.trailText: Engineers know there's more to origami than paper boats, writes Peter Forbes
fields.body:
What has a solar panel array in a space satellite got to do with negotiating the Tokyo subway and the way that leaves unfurl from the bud?

The unlikely answer is origami - the Japanese art of paper folding. Leaves and solar cells have the same basic function - to soak up as much sunlight as possible and to do this they need the maximum surface area. But while leaves are in the bud and the satellite is being launched, solar panels and leaves alike have to pack down as tightly as possible.

A folding technique developed in Japan over the past 30 years for solar-cell arrays is now emerging in work from the school of biomimetics at Reading University as the method used by beech and hornbeam leaves to unfurl. In the new science of biomimetics, which is looking at nature through the eyes of the engineer and vice versa, many such parallels are obvious.

In 1970 Koryo Miura, a Japanese space scientist with a strong interest in origami, proposed a novel folding pattern - named Miura-ori (ori means 'fold') by the British Origami Society in 1981 - which can be demonstrated in half an hour with a single sheet of paper. The paper is divided into equal parallelograms at an angle of about 6-10 degrees from square. It folds up in two dimensions at right angles so that the fully folded form takes up very little space.

But what is really intriguing about Miura-ori is that to unfold it completely, you need only grip the two ends and out it comes in one pull without having to twist or remove your hands or fold back any crease. You've guessed it: perfect for pocket maps! Until recently, limitations in machine folding prevented commercial use but an easy to deploy and retract A2 map of the Tokyo subway is now available.

Japan has an active space program, and Miura worked on what he called "two-dimensional arrays" throughout the 80s and early 90s. Solar panels are usually extended in only one direction; a two-dimensional array greatly increases the surface area. The panels are the same shape as the paper folds, and they fold in the same way. But they need joints and tension struts to manipulate them. Such an array went into space for the first time on the Japanese space flyer unit on March 18, 1995, and was retrieved by the Nasa space shuttle endeavour on January 13, 1996. Unidimensional arrays are sufficient for the relatively small arrays now required but Miura-ori is being developed for large solar-power satellites, solar sail spacecraft propulsion and large lens telescopes.

When Julian Vincent, co-director of the department of biomimetics at Reading, looked at the unfurling of beech and hornbeam leaves he discovered they mimicked a version of Miura-ori, with long, thin parallelograms radiating from a central rib. The unfolding of the two patterns is very similar.

This is not the first time simple paper folding has been an aid to engineers. In his classic Structures or Why Things Don't Fall Down (Penguin), James Gordon, the founder of biomimetics at Reading, tells how honeycomb panels came to be used in aircraft construction. In 1943 a circus proprietor called George May came to see him with a new turn. It was a paper honeycomb structure rather like a party paper-chain decoration. Gordon realised that stiffened with phenolic resin it would be strong enough for aircraft construction. It was widely used as such during the war and now finds its main use in the standard panel-doors used in houses and offices. Gordon was well aware that if you want a light structure a good idea is to fill it with holes. He might have gone straight to nature for the honeycomb idea but it was the paper chain that sparked it off.

Origami is taken increasingly seriously by engineers. It is a recognized part of the syllabus at some universities in France, and in March the third international meeting on origami, science, mathematics and education will be held at Asilomar, California.

The parallels between nature and engineering are not so surprising - the principles behind both are mathematical - but what is especially pleasing about Miura-ori is that, unlike the arcane and abstract maths that describe most scientific phenomena, it is simple, practical and realisable with the simplest material: paper.

Miura-ori is a gift to the armchair scientist. If folded solar panel arrays catch your imagination, you cannot knock one up in your garden shed. Nor, at this time of year can you do much by way of watching beech leaves unfurl. But you can copy the classic patterns if you have a spare evening. Go to www.ec-lille.fr/~u3P/textang/pliage1a.html to find the classic Miura-ori (it's in French but the folds translate well); or try http://library.thinkquest.org/28923/miuraori.html

You can use this pattern to create your own simple one-pull maps. The leaf pattern is even simpler: take a sheet of paper about twice as long as it is wide and fold in two down the long side, then follow the diagram. When it is unfolded some of the valleys have to be converted into ridges and vice versa - it will then fold up into its leaf-bud form and fan out into the leaf. To complete your hornbeam leaf, cut away waste to leave the desired shape.

At a more serious level, anyone who has an engineering problem that involves collapsible, folding structures could do worse than model it in paper, swot up on the origami, observe some natural structures that have similar folding patterns and let the imagination loose.

 Peter Forbes has translated Primo Levi's The Search For Roots, to be published by Penguin in June 2001.
