webTitle: Green regulators vote themselves £2m to spend as they see fit

fields.headline: Green regulators vote themselves £2m to spend as they see fit
fields.trailText: Directors of Britain's only private regulatory body, Entrust, responsible for the probity of £350m of environment grants, have quietly changed their constitution so they dispose of £2m as they see fit if Entrust is closed by the government, parliament was told yesterday.
fields.body:
Directors of Britain's only private regulatory body, Entrust, responsible for the probity of £350m of environment grants, have quietly changed their constitution so they dispose of £2m as they see fit if Entrust is closed by the government, parliament was told yesterday.

The scandal came to light when the Commons environment committee yesterday summoned a senior environmentalist to give evidence on a paper by him that seriously criticised Entrust, set up by John Gummer when Tory environment secretary.

Malcolm Aicken, who chairs the publicly funded environment council, wrote the paper, then decided to withhold it from the committee's inquiry into the government's waste strategy. A copy was passed to the committee chairman, Andrew Bennett, Labour MP for Denton and Reddish, by the Guardian. Yesterday he made it an official inquiry document, giving its contents parliamentary privilege.

The paper damns the running of Entrust, which monitors £350m given to environmental groups under the landfill tax by waste companies. It is already under fire for being dominated by the industry, which can avoid 20% of £1bn a year tax by donating to the environment.

In his paper Mr Aicken criticises the directors for changing their constitution in secret so they can divert £2m of Entrust's levies to any institution they choose, creating a potential abuse of power.

The change was made after the national audit office began inquiries into Entrust following an investigation by the Guardian this year. Ministers are also considering whether Entrust should continue.

Mr Aicken's paper said: "We do not believe that the potential temptation to divert such sums of money, levied from environmental bodies, should be placed in the hands of even the most upright, honourable and public spirited. We consider that the potential for abuse should be avoided."

It also revealed that regulations to pay out the £350m were "inadequate and inconsistent to the point of incompetence", involving environmental bodies in long winded applications and enormous audit scrutiny, while Entrust itself used light touch company legislation to avoid detailed auditing. It described the monitoring of environmental bodies as "needlessly duplicating work" and "wasteful of time and resources".

The report also said Entrust had no independent appeal for registering some 2,200 trusts - which have to be approved by Entrust before they can solicit cash from waste companies. Contrary to human rights legislation, they can only appeal to the chief executive, Richard Sills, who turned them down in the first place.

Mr Aicken admitted under questioning that "even people with halos round their heads should not have the right to change their rules at a whim". He withheld the document "not because it was wrong, but because I did not think it was part of the remit of the committee's inquiry. I also felt it might give the impression Entrust was fatally flawed, when I wanted it to improve."

He told MPs he had since taken a £140-a-day post as part time adviser to Entrust. Lord Cranbrook, Entrust chairman, gives evidence next week.

It is already under fire for being dominated by the industry, which can avoid 20% of £1bn a year tax by donating to the environment. In his paper Mr Aicken criticises the directors for changing their constitution in secret so they can divert £2m of Entrust's levies to any institution they choose, creating a potential abuse of power. The change was made after the national audit office began inquiries into Entrust following an investigation by the Guardian this year. Ministers are also considering whether Entrust should continue. Mr Aicken's paper said: "We do not believe that the potential temptation to divert such sums of money, levied from environmental bodies, should be placed in the hands of even the most upright, honourable and public spirited. We consider that the potential for abuse should be avoided." It also revealed that regulations to pay out the £350m were "inadequate and inconsistent to the point of incompetence", involving environmental bodies in long winded applications and enormous audit scrutiny, while Entrust itself used light touch company legislation to avoid detailed auditing. It described the monitoring of environmental bodies as "needlessly duplicating work" and "wasteful of time and resources". The report also said Entrust had no independent appeal for registering some 2,200 trusts - which have to be approved by Entrust before they can solicit cash from waste companies. Contrary to human rights legislation, they can only appeal to the chief executive, Richard Sills, who turned them down in the first place. Mr Aicken admitted under questioning that "even people with halos round their heads should not have the right to change their rules at a whim". He withheld the document "not because it was wrong, but because I did not think it was part of the remit of the committee's inquiry. I also felt it might give the impression Entrust was fatally flawed, when I wanted it to improve." He told MPs he had since taken a £140-a-day post as part time adviser to Entrust. Lord Cranbrook, Entrust chairman, gives evidence next week.

fields.headline: Narrow backbench victory for Soley
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The Blair loyalist, Clive Soley MP, last night won a fourth year as chairman of the Parliamentary Labour Party after a cliffhanger which saw him beat his main challenger by just six votes in the second round run-off.
fields.body:
The Blair loyalist, Clive Soley MP, last night won a fourth year as chairman of the Parliamentary Labour Party after a cliffhanger which saw him beat his main challenger by just six votes in the second round run-off.

Tonly Lloyd, the former minister, who had been widely expected to win after Mr Soley had failed to obtain a majority in Monday's first ballot, got most of the third runner, Andrew Mackinlay's 77 votes. But Mr Soley picked up 15 and won by 184 to 178 to the relief of Downing St which had been anxious to see him survive.

He immediately struck a conciliatory note praising his two challengers for "conducting themselves very well and discussing genuine issues. I will be listeneing very hard both to what those who voted for me say and those who did not," he promised.

The MP for Acton and Shepherd's Bush, who also said he would be taking up concerns with Tony Blair and other ministers, stressed how important it would be that the "PLP and government goes into the election to win." Mr Lloyd left without comment on what he called "an internal matter."

With a general election almost certainly months away, the contest was fought quietly against a background of concern that backbench worries are not being effectively communicated to ministers - including Mr Blair himself.

Mr Soley took the blame for these frustrations, though he shared some of them. His critics felt that in three years as PLP chairman the former probation officer had become too close to the Blairite establishment - No 10's conduit to the backbenches, not the other way around.

In the first ballot on Monday night, Mr Soley got 169 votes, 16 short of a clear majority, with Mr Lloyd, MP for Manchester Central, taking 121. But Andrew Mackinlay, the outside runner with the most outspoken views, picked up an unexpectedly strong 77 votes - which split 57 to 15 in Mr Lloyd's favour in last night's second round.

Only 362 of Labour's 414 eligible MPs voted, 7 fewer than on Monday. Whether there were deliberate abstentions was not clear.

There were complaints that the whips office, who police the system for the government of the day, had been making what MPs said were clumsy attempts to ensure that ministers - the so-called "payroll vote" - backed Mr Soley. That tactic will have both helped and hindered him.

Some disquiet was also expressed that ministers were allowed to vote at all for the man or woman whose job it is to be the backbenchers' shop steward to the government. "the rules aren't clear," said one older MP who claimed it had not been allowed when Labour was last in power in the 1970s.

webTitle: Thatcher's EU attack marks end of affair

fields.headline: Thatcher's EU attack marks end of affair
fields.standfirst:
Blair's flattery was calculated, and now she has served her purpose
Special report: the Thatcher era
fields.trailText: The end of Tony Blair's love affair with Margaret Thatcher has been a long time coming. In the opinion of many Labour MPs it was an affair which could not end too soon. Indeed they were horrified that it took place at all.
fields.body:
The end of Tony Blair's love affair with Margaret Thatcher has been a long time coming. In the opinion of many Labour MPs it was an affair which could not end too soon. Indeed they were horrified that it took place at all.

So yesterday's harsh words about her attack on his commitment of British troops to an EU rapid reaction force (RRF) - she called it "a piece of monumental folly" - were widely welcomed, especially on the 10th anniversary of her fall from power. Even some Tory moderates were quietly delighted.

In reality it was more an affair of convenience, not one of the heart, on either side. Praising Tony Blair as a serious player before the 1997 election was another way of undermining her discarded and despised ex-protege, John Major.

For Mr Blair's part, inviting Lady Thatcher in for talks at No 10 or phoning her up (he last did so during the 1999 Kosovo crisis) gave the young prime minister an aura of statesmanship, allowing him to bask in her reflected glory.

As with the Murdoch press, notably the Sun, it was calculated flattery. The Sun is now edging back to its gut anti-Labour stance. Significantly, it started yesterday's row by soliciting a soundbite from its beloved Maggie.

Why did the affair flourish in the first place? Partly because Mr Blair was the first Labour leader since the Iron Lady drove Jim Callaghan from office in 1979 to admit that the Tory economic revolution had done Britain some good.

He did so almost from the start of his leadership in 1994, part of his way of signalling to the Daily Mail and its middle England readers that New Labour really would be new.

Michael Foot, Neil Kinnock and John Smith always refused to acknowledge the possibility of her virtues. Mr Blair admired her leadership style, her focused approach to her goals (and her defining enemies). "It was a clear sense of an identifiable project for the Tory party that I did admire," he once explained.

A lingering admiration remained in Mr Blair's remarks at a Whitehall press conference yesterday. "I take nothing away from those things that were done in the 1980s that we have kept, but it really is time in my view that we move British politics beyond the time of Margaret Thatcher," he told reporters.

That is the key. Lady Thatcher has served her purpose and senior Blair aides are irritated with what they call "middle aged editorial writers who tell the British public what to think about politics and have a slightly romanticised view of her".

As Mr Blair put it yesterday: "We are in a new era. Today we have to deal with those problems that we inherited from that time - the boom and bust economics, the social division, the chronic under-investment in our public services. A sensible, modern attitude to Europe is what we need."

That is what he now thinks. As for her she has said several times in the past 18 months that the young man - 32 years her junior - to whom she sent a Christmas card in 1997 has proved a disappoinment and is (of all things) even "bossy".

The row over what she called the "judicial kidnapping" of her old Chilean ally, General Augusto Pinochet, was a serious rupture.

It would "do credit to a police state," she declared with no sense of irony.

Lady Thatcher, now 75 and still enjoying adulation from her intimates and huge audiences outside Britain, was also irritated by his "third way" talk.

"The third way leads to the third world," the ex-premier predicted on one occasion. Yesterday she also took a dig at his higher tax policies - not her legacy at all, she said.

But Europe, as for so many senior politicians for the past 40 years, was the defining schism.

In September, Lady Thatcher (who has rewritten her own Euro-history), accused him of seeking to "abolish Britain" by joining the single currency.

He had already taken issue with her. In his seminal speech at Ghent, a self-conscious echo of her famous Bruges attack on Euro-federalism, he conceded that some of her strictures in 1988 had been justified.

But withdrawing from influence and involvement in the EU had been the wrong response, he insisted. By a curious twist the Tory policy on Europe - Wiliam Hague influenced by Thatcherism and by "Thatcher's children" in the Commons - is as implausible to Britain's neighbours as Labour's was when it was in the mid-80s depths of opposition.

What Labour strategists really think is that Lady Thatcher is now helpful in a different way.

The long shadow she casts over her party will help make it unelectable in 2001. Thanks again, Margaret.

fields.headline: Irate Blair savages Thatcher
fields.standfirst:
Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: the Thatcher era
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday marked the 10th anniversary of Margaret Thatcher's fall from power by making his sharpest attack yet on her legacy and attempting to consign her era to history.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday marked the 10th anniversary of Margaret Thatcher's fall from power by making his sharpest attack yet on her legacy and attempting to consign her era to history.

In a calculated repudiation of "boom and bust" economics, social disharmony and under-investment in public services, Mr Blair gave his second signal in as many days that he is gearing up to confront Eurosceptic politicians and their media allies as the expected May 3 election day approaches.

After six years in which Mr Blair has courted the ousted Tory leader and tried to copy her forceful presidential style, he said: "I take nothing away from those things that were done in the 1980s that we have kept, but it really is time in my view that we move British politics beyond the time of Margaret Thatcher.

"We are in a new era. Today we have to deal with those problems that we inherited from that time - the boom and bust economics, the social division, the chronic under-investment in our public services.

"A sensible, modern attitude to Europe is what we need," he added.

Lady Thatcher triggered yesterday's confrontation by joining a chorus of criticism of Mr Blair's commitment of 12,500 British troops to the new European rapid reaction force (RRF).

"It is a piece of monumental folly that puts our security at risk in order to satisfy political vanity," she warned.

The prime minister was already furious with Eurosceptic "lies" about the role of the RRF and its implications for Nato and the "special relationship" with Washington. In brutal exchanges at question time he effectively squashed the Tory leader, William Hague.

Senior defence officials have backed the scheme. But even they privately admit that a crucial problem remains to be resolved: how exactly the EU forces will cooperate with Nato, especially when it wants to use Nato military assets, perhaps for a peacekeeping operation in the Balkans or further afield in Africa.

But it was the bust-up with Lady Thatcher that echoed around Westminster last night - coincidentally or not on the 10th anniversary of her enforced resignation.

Objection to the RRF - described by John Major as "blundering into a misconceived political proposal" - was linked by Lady Thatcher to her passion for the US over Europe.

Savaging the plans, she explained: "I prefer Nato and I prefer the great alliance between Britain, Europe and America... it is that which was of great benefit to the world. We lost a lot of people on the continent defending the liberty of our country and the countries of others and we must never forget."

Just as he sounded off against "fundamentally dishonest" reporting of the RRF during a visit to Moscow on Monday, yesterday Mr Blair used another press conference to hit back at Lady Thatcher - with interest.

Relations between the pair, mutually flattering during 1996-97, have gradually cooled to the point where Labour's refusal to release the ailing Chilean General Augusto Pinochet from his house arrest - pending full judicial review - enraged the former prime minister.

Mr Hague's intervention in a crowded Commons also produced blistering exchanges. The Tory leader's taunts about the creation of a 100,000 strong "European army" and a "European superstate" produced a withering description of Mr Hague's "six word" policy. This amounted to "Lady Thatcher - you lead, I'll follow," said Mr Blair, who claimed that the opposition so constantly falls back on the European issue because it has lost on the economy, public investment and the fight against poverty.

Mr Hague said France wanted to create a parallel EU defence structure to Nato. Mr Blair insisted he had thwarted that goal.

The defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, was also taunted by his Tory shadow, Iain Duncan-Smith, but seized on two of his strongest cards - that the RRF had been enthusiastically welcomed by the US and it had reversed declining defence spending in Europe, which will rise in 11 of Europe's 16 Nato states next year.

"Not a single senior figure in the US administration is opposed to these proposals," Mr Hoon told MPs.

The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, had described the move as "a strongly positive development we wholly support," he said.

Senior defence officials called this week's agreement in Brussels "good news for Nato, good news for the European Union and good news for the United States".

By increasing the military capacity of both the EU and Nato and offering non-military options - such as civilian police - that Nato lacks, "it is another golf club in the bag for dealing with crises" one official said.

In fact, it will take years before the Europeans will be in a position to catch up with the US, even on such basic tasks as troop carrying.

fields.headline: Key sciences gain £250m investment
fields.trailText: The government is to pump £252m in the next three years into three key scientific fields on which tomorrow's industrial empires will be built.
fields.body:
The government is to pump £252m in the next three years into three key scientific fields on which tomorrow's industrial empires will be built.

A total of £110m will go into the new world of genomics - to start turning hard-won knowledge of the machinery of life into diagnostic tests, drugs, vac cines, agricultural products, environmental care, industrial processes and new materials.

A total of £98m will go to what the government calls e-science - the handling of awesome quantities of data involved in scientific co-operations around the world. "Basic technology" - the hardware and processes needed to make tomorrow's sensors, detectors and nanomachines - will get another £44m. These three - all collaborations between the research councils that allocate science spending - are just the plums in a feast of measures unveiled by the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers.

The government had already introduced a £1bn programme, with the Wellcome Trust, to improve the infrastructure of science, and the government earlier this year announced that the science budget would grow on average by 7% per year in real terms. Yesterday the research councils learned that they would also share an additional £100m to spend in their own fields.

Ian Halliday, chief of the particle physics and astronomy research council, said the new money would keep Britain at the frontiers of international research.

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Veteran MPs Sir Edward Heath and Tony Benn - who are retiring after 50 years each in the Commons - were jointly made parliamentarians of the year at the annual awards organised by the Spectator magazine and Highland Park whisky. The awards were presented by the lord chancellor, Lord Irvine. Other winners were:

Top backbencher

Tory MP Andrew Tyrie, commended for his "formidable gasp of tax, the euro, and the issues surrounding reform of the House of Lords".

Minister to watch

Education minister Estelle Morris, praised by one judge for her refusal to wear "horrid New Labour chiffon scarves".

Inquisitor of year

David Davis, Tory chairman of the public accounts committee, said by the judges to have done more than any other - with the possible exception of Lord Falconer - to embarrass the government over the dome.

Top campaigners

Lady Young - "some have suggested that their lordships enjoy discussing buggery so much that the gay sex at 16 bill should never be allowed to leave the upper house" - and Labour's Lady Kennedy QC, a critic of the bill to curb the right to trial by jury.

Peer of the year

Attorney general Lord Williams of Mostyn, tipped as a future leader of the lords

Survivor of year

Ken Livingstone. The judges saluted his ability to recover from the "fatwahs of the Labour machine".

Today

Commons: Education and employment questions. Debate on European affairs

Lords: Countryside bill, third reading.

fields.headline: Labour boasts of spending upsurge
fields.standfirst: Society Unlimited
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday adopted an emollient tone towards public sector workers by conceding lack of government investment was the root cause of Britain's inadequate public services.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday adopted an emollient tone towards public sector workers by conceding lack of government investment was the root cause of Britain's inadequate public services.

A year ago he blamed forces of conservatism amongst public sector workers and bemoaned the "scars on his back" caused by their resistance to change.

Mr Blair was speaking yesterday at a Downing Street press conference designed to highlight plans to double net capital investment to £18bn a year by 2003-4.

This will double the proportion of GDP committed to public investment, but still leave it well below the figure of the mid-80s. In addition, ministers hope to sign private finance initiative projects over the next three years worth a further £12bn.

In pre-election mood, Mr Blair used the press conference to contrast his willingness to spend alongside the Tories' commitment to spend below the rate of economic growth.

He said: "Who can seriously doubt that Britain has been chronically under-invested in for over 20 years? We have the fourth biggest economy in the world. Yet we do not have the fourth best public services. I lay the blame for that firmly at the door of under-inevestment."

He admitted that the government had not put enough investment into public services in its first two years, but said the tight controls had been necessary to lay the foundations for growth.

But he claimed the government has now made its choice between spending and tax cuts. "We could have taken all this money and blown it on Treasury tax cuts, but look back at the late 80s and 90s, people had their tax cuts then and they were followed by tax rises."

The emphasis on the extra capital spending has been given added urgency by news that the public sector surplus was £11bn in the seven months to October, £1bn more than the Treasury forecast for the whole year.

Even the IMF in its review of the British economy called for extra spending, writing: "Certainly, we recognize that, after several years of fiscal tightening, increases in public spending are needed in some areas, particularly infrastructure and health care".

However, the commitment to extra spending has been hit by signs that Whitehall is not spending as fast as the Treasury wants.

Andrew Smith, the Treasury chief secretary, admitted a Whitehall culture created by Thatcherite hostility to the public spending may be leading government departments to under-spend on both capital and current account. Capital spend was £1bn under plans last year and current spend £2bn under target.

Treasury officials claim some of the lower than expected spending can be attributed national statisticians increasing the level of depreciated assets, so reducing the net value of capital investment. However, the officials admit they are puzzled as to why capital spending tends to be undertaken so late in each financial year.

Mr Smith said: "You don't turn round capital expenditure overnight and we were starting from a low base."

He said this year there are £800m more net public sector net investment this year and we are on course and we are on course to see an extra £4bn gross investment this year." The figures do not yet bear out this claim.

The shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, said:"Labour have been promising to improve public services from day one.

"But three and a half years later, taxes are up and Labour's spending is failing to deliver."

 Health £1.4bn extra spending in NHS capital spending over three years. This will lead to 100 major new hospital projects by 2010, 250 new scanners, modernisation of over 3,000 GP premises and 500 one stop primary care centres.

 Education Extra £1.6bn in capital spending for most urgent repairs in 7,000 schools and complete refurbishment in 650 schools.

 Transport 150% increase in transport public investment designed to produce 50% rise in rail passenger use, and 10% rise in bus use.

 Home Office Extra 20% for police capital spending, mainly on CCTV and information technology.

 Environment An extra £1.6bn a year by 2003-4 compared with 2000-1 to cut by a third the number of houses not of a decent standard.
fields.bodyText: Tony Blair yesterday adopted an emollient tone towards public sector workers by conceding lack of government investment was the root cause of Britain's inadequate public services. A year ago he blamed forces of conservatism amongst public sector workers and bemoaned the "scars on his back" caused by their resistance to change. Mr Blair was speaking yesterday at a Downing Street press conference designed to highlight plans to double net capital investment to £18bn a year by 2003-4. This will double the proportion of GDP committed to public investment, but still leave it well below the figure of the mid-80s. In addition, ministers hope to sign private finance initiative projects over the next three years worth a further £12bn. In pre-election mood, Mr Blair used the press conference to contrast his willingness to spend alongside the Tories' commitment to spend below the rate of economic growth. He said: "Who can seriously doubt that Britain has been chronically under-invested in for over 20 years? We have the fourth biggest economy in the world. Yet we do not have the fourth best public services. I lay the blame for that firmly at the door of under-inevestment." He admitted that the government had not put enough investment into public services in its first two years, but said the tight controls had been necessary to lay the foundations for growth. But he claimed the government has now made its choice between spending and tax cuts. "We could have taken all this money and blown it on Treasury tax cuts, but look back at the late 80s and 90s, people had their tax cuts then and they were followed by tax rises." webTitle: Can the games live up to the machine?

fields.headline: Can the games live up to the machine?
fields.trailText: Greg Howson looks at the software that matters most
fields.body:
So you've filled out the forms and waited patiently but what will you be able to play when you pick up your PlayStation 2 tomorrow?

Well, with 16 releases planned, you should not have too much trouble finding something that appeals, although it's worth bearing in mind that the first games on any new console are rarely perfect but usually simply graphically prettier renditions of older titles.

Perhaps the most interesting title is Timesplitters. Produced by members of the team that made the splendid Goldeneye for N64, the game is a Quake-style first person shooter (FPS). But unlike the Bond classic, Timesplitters dispenses with story and character development and instead concentrates on action, reflexes and some very pretty visuals.

Multiplayer is the biggest attraction, with split-screen carnage a mere multi-tap purchase away (the PS2 comes with only two 2 controller ports as standard).

Elsewhere, Konami's Gradius 3& 4 and Silent Scope are different takes on the shooting genre. While the former is a playable, if old-fashioned, blaster, Silent Scope is graphically impressive sniper sim that allows you pick off the baddies from afar.

The increasingly maverick Nintendo aside, it seems every games console launch must be accompanied by the roar of numerous racing games. PS2 is no different with at least four due out tomorrow.

Ridge Racer V is the best known release and while it is the same powersliding arcade game as before, it has spruced-up track and car visuals. Unfortunately, the two-player game is a mess, with horrendous graphical fogging marring what is, at least on your own, a fairly decent drive.

If you like your automobiles a little different then you could sample the offroad buggy thrills of Smuggler's Run or drive the varied terrain of Wild Wild Racing. Midnight Club lets you drive around London and New York but is streets away from the similarly styled Metropolis Street Racer on Dreamcast.

The fighting game, is well represented on PS2 launch day. Tekken Tag Tournament, the latest in the long running series, may be the best known. While little more than a pretty update, its looks at least set it apart from its dull rival, Streetfighter EX3.

If you are looking for a different type of combat then the comedy pugilism of Ready 2 Rumble Boxing may appeal. Dynasty Warriors was a big hit in Japan but while it impresses visually, with plenty of onscreen enemies, longevity is a problem.

For those who like a bit of plot with their combat then the Orphen is worth a look. It's no Final Fantasy but if you're seeking a Role Playing Game then this is the only launch day choice.

Sports fans are well catered for with a varied mix of silicon team games to enjoy. Football fans are in luck with two soccer games available from the off - FIFA 2001 and ISS. The latter is the purist's choice although smarter graphics can't hide the fact that this PS2 version lacks the subtlety and realism of Pro Evolution on the original PlayStation.

FIFA 2001 is the latest in EA's polished series and offers a decent kickabout, helped considerably by an increased skill level; scoring is now satisfyingly difficult. EA are also releasing the well-received ice-hockey game, NHL 2001, and Snowboard Supercross (SSX) - a topically wintry sporting challenge that has as much to do with style as it does with speed.

If you are looking for something a little more original than sport, driving and fighting then the last batch of titles may be of interest. The visually appealing Rayman Revolution is the only platform game available but if you fancy something a little more cerebral then Fantavision and Aqua Aqua: Wetrix 2 are worth a look. Fantavsion is a psychedelic Japanese oddity that lets you control a fireworks display while attempting to match up colours. No less unusual is Aqua Aqua - a water-based 3D version of Tetris that sees you building up enclosed areas to stop the liquid leaking.

Overall it's a typical launch-day mixed bag with good variety but no truly outstanding titles. However if you have managed to get hold of a PS2 then Time Splitters, FIFA 2001, Fantavision and Silent Scope are unlikely to disappoint.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst:
Send letters to online.feedback@guardian.co.uk
Please include a full postal address and telephone number. Short letters stand a better chance of being published. No attachments, please
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
Shopped
If, as Mark Price mentioned in his article (Online November 16), some retailers have had so little success with online shopping that they have withdrawn from the market, Tesco seems to be suffering from the opposite problem.

I use the Tesco Direct service, but after a frustrating experience today I'm beginning to wonder if it's worth the hassle. It took seemingly endless attempts before I could place an order.

This morning I either couldn't log on at all, or having logged on, couldn't access my list of previous purchases. This afternoon things were slightly better, in that I could access the list and order, but these stubbornly refused to appear in the basket.

When I did finally succeed, by a fluke, in persuading the system to accept that there were items in my basket, it needed several attempts before I managed to pay and get an acknowledgement.

If I, as a computer literate person, had so much difficulty, how many others simply gave up? Until retailers take e-commerce seriously, they are likely to be treated with suspicion by most customers, and justifiably so.
Richard Williams
rwilliams79@compuserve.com

Mark Price has hit on one of the problems that prevent people shopping on the net, but not all. I've been using PCs since 1986, went online with Compuserve in the late 1980s, have internet access both at home and work - and hardly ever bother to connect these days. And I wouldn't dream of shopping on the net.

Why? Not just because it's slow and not just because of the sheer amount of drivel, but mainly because websites appear to be designed by geeks for geeks: why use a single, simple, logical form when 10 - complete with dancing logos and a five-minute wait for the unnecessary .gifs to download - will bugger it up properly? Add to this the fact that fraud is rampant and that the vast majority of firms getting involved in e-commerce haven't a clue about security, and you begin to understand that it's still the wild west out there.

Of course, there's also the problem of actually getting your hands on the goods. Late last year I argued with my geeky friends (whose Christmas trees arrived in January) that not only was e-commerce's support infrastructure lacking, but that it was a paradise for crooks.

And quite apart from all that, there's no touchy-feely and no finding the marked-down bargains that actually makes shopping interesting rather than perfunctory.
Tony Slinn
tonyslinn@uk.dmgworldmedia.com

Packet mix
Richard Sarson hasn't quite got the full story.

Paul Baran, the American, was the first to conceive the idea of packet-switching, but Donald Davies, the Briton, first coined the phrase "packet-switching".

Many others, besides Baran, Davies and Berners Lee also contributed to the development of the internet. The wonderful book by my colleague John Naughton, A Brief History Of The Future, provides a summary.

Naughton points out that competition in the market place played very little part in the development of the internet, and that none of these contributors was motivated primarily by money.
Ray Thomas
r.thomas@open.ac.uk

Email advice
Dermod Quirke thinks Online is wrong to advise on secure internet use at work, believing this will only be used to send infantile emails or download porn.

Of course some employees may abuse IT facilities, just as they did phones or photocopiers. However, employees may need confidential contact with managers, human resources departments, occupational health, colleagues or union reps etc. You'd hope to talk to them privately at work without being videotaped. You'd expect to be able to phone them up without being eavesdropped. Why should the internet be different?

Firms that respond to a few incidents by preventing all employees from exploring, using and benefiting from the net are short-sighted. If reasonable internet use is banned, good employees circumvent the rules, or leave.

Some employers are developing policies to define acceptable IT use, and control surveillance at work. Unfortunately, many employers are struggling to keep up with the net, so their employees need your advice on the risks.
Ian Allinson
ian.allinson@iname.com

Clean code
Chris Gibson says HTML editors are rubbish (Feedback November 16). His remarks might apply to Microsoft's Frontpage but Macromedia's Dreamweaver 3 produces clean HTML and includes Javascript as well. Non-techies like me can create very reasonable web pages and people like Chris Gibson can use it to speed up some routine processes and then take over manually when they wish to put in their own code. Gavin Bullock
gavin.bullock@dial.pipex.com

I am a tyro granny-geek who is equally incompetent in HTML scripting and Frontpage. I feel that my experiences will stretch the motoring analogy beyond its elastic limit.

My programming forays are usually of the "Granny Engulfed in Fast Lane Juggernaut Pile-up Fireball Horror" variety.

On occasion I tinker under the HTML bonnet and manage to avoid a full-scale emergency services turn-out. However, when I've finally put everything back together I always seem to have pieces (see www.btinternet.com/~Learn2Live/General/PhotoAlbum4.htm) left over!
Jinty Batkins
jbatkins@altavista.com

Netscape bug
I read your report on the final release version of Netscape 6 with interest. Actually using Netscape 6 tells another story.

I encountered many problems. Despite its supposedly improved layout engine, Gecko, Netscape 6 makes a mess of style sheets (if it detects them at all), refuses to display layers correctly and mangles Javascript menus. Not to mention the continual crashing.

It seems Netscape has been so keen to incorporate gimmicks like skins and sidebars it forgot to produce a browser that actually works with the majority of web pages.

Don't believe the hype.
Ed Piper
aqua2@btconnect.com

fields.headline: Trojan PS2
fields.trailText: The original PlayStation was simply a games console. However, Sony has long harboured higher ambitions for the PS2. In a speech at the Comdex computer trade show last year, Sony Corporation's president, Nobuyuki Idei, said the company's ambitions went far beyond gaming.
fields.body:
The original PlayStation was simply a games console. However, Sony has long harboured higher ambitions for the PS2. In a speech at the Comdex computer trade show last year, Sony Corporation's president, Nobuyuki Idei, said the company's ambitions went far beyond gaming.

Idei presented the PS2 as a device which could be expanded to include "music, motion pictures and new forms of entertainment not yet developed".

The PS2 could be part of a network of Sony devices. To begin with, it will play games (supplied by Sony and others), audio CDs (Sony owns CBS) and movies on DVD (Sony owns Columbia Pictures). It could also be connected to a Sony television set, to a Sony hi-fi, and, through its built in i.Link port, perhaps to a Sony digital still or video camera.

There is also the prospect of connecting a PS2 to the internet, like a Sega Dreamcast games console, but this is not part of the system Sony is shipping tomorrow.

Sony does have a grand design for connecting equipment: a networking system called HAVi (Home Audio Video Interoperability). The company has a huge mish-mash of electronics products and HAVi can tie them together.

But the battle may be harder than expected, and roughly twice as many PCs will be sold this year as Sony PlayStations have been sold in the past five years. PCs have also been networked devices for almost two decades, with wireless networks becoming important during the past decade.

With Wi-Fi standard wireless networks already connecting home PCs, and Bluetooth (short range wireless) PC Cards starting to arrive, being locked out of the living room may not be to the PC's disadvantage. And Sony's own desktop and notebook PC salesmen are not going to pass up this profitable market.

There is the risk that the idea that the PS2 is just a Trojan horse for Sony's home networking system idea may confuse the PS2 market. In fact, both Nintendo and Microsoft have spent the past six months hammering home the fact that their next-generation consoles, the Gamecube and the Xbox, are being designed solely to deliver great games.

It remains to be seen whether there is a market for a system that tries span both the games and the home network market, especially if it fails to do any of them sufficiently well.

fields.headline: What's new
fields.trailText: Spys like us | Krafty keyboard
fields.body:
Spys like us
Here's another good reason not to misbehave at your upcoming works Christmas party. Scheduled to go on sale next week is the SpyPen, a tiny digital camera squeezed into a slim upright frame not a great deal larger than an average ball-point.

The SpyPen takes and archives low resolution (352x288 pixels) images which can then be transferred to a PC via its accompanying software and USB cable. It will also record a few seconds' worth of moving images.

Blackmailing opportunities should ensure that the £70 outlay for one is easily recouped.

More details are available from www.spypen.com To buy one visit www.digital-ps.co.uk.

Krafty keyboard
Good news for handheld PC owners who still can't get their heads round their device's handwriting recognition systems. Coming next year is a fabric keyboard accessory for palmtops which can be rolled up for easy storage.

Developed by UK company ElectroTextiles, the Elektex keyboard can apparently be folded, washed and even sprayed with coffee and still continue to function. The design the company recently paraded at the IT Expo exhibition at Cannes actually wraps around a palmtop to provide a protective case.

Although ElectroTextiles hasn ot yet signed on the dotted line with any of the handheld PC operating system owners, it remains confident that the Elektex will be on sale in spring or summer. It is quoting a price for the keyboard as $65 (or around £40).

DVD double-act is a Christmas cracker

Christmas will come three days early for Japanese video fans. Slated to go on sale on December 22 is the RD-2000, the world's first pairing of a DVD recorder with a hard disk drive.

The unit allows users to make temporary video recordings on to its 30 gigabyte hard disk and then, if they find something they want to archive, transfer the footage to a DVD-RAM disc.

There's also a Just mode, where image quality is determined by the amount of space left on the DVD-RAM disc. Other facilities include pausing and instantly replaying live TV, the option of creating on-screen thumbnail images for each programme recorded and playback of pre-recorded DVDs and CDs.

The price for the unit is expected to be 270,000 yen (£1,750). Toshiba currently has no plans to sell the RD-2000 in the UK.

A unit that combines a hard disk drive with a S-VHS recorder from JVC went on sale in Japan last week.

Slated to go on sale on December 22 is the RD-2000, the world's first pairing of a DVD recorder with a hard disk drive. The unit allows users to make temporary video recordings on to its 30 gigabyte hard disk and then, if they find something they want to archive, transfer the footage to a DVD-RAM disc. There's also a Just mode, where image quality is determined by the amount of space left on the DVD-RAM disc. Other facilities include pausing and instantly replaying live TV, the option of creating on-screen thumbnail images for each programme recorded and playback of pre-recorded DVDs and CDs. The price for the unit is expected to be 270,000 yen (£1,750). Toshiba currently has no plans to sell the RD-2000 in the UK. A unit that combines a hard disk drive with a S-VHS recorder from JVC went on sale in Japan last week.

fields.headline: Games reviews
fields.trailText: Legend of Zelda: Majora's Mask | The World Is Not Enough | Sheep
fields.byline: Greg Howson, Jack Schofield and  Andy Bodle
fields.body:
Legend of Zelda: Majora's Mask

N64 £49.99 Nintendo *****

Two years ago Nintendo released an epic game called Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time. It was a bit good. Actually, it was sleep-disturbingly tremendous and deservedly won as many awards as it could.

Now, the game has a sequel (actually it's the sixth in the long-running series but who's counting?).

Called Majora's Mask, the game is, on the surface, more of the same, with that familiar mix of action, adventure and inventive puzzles coupled with slightly improved graphics. However, the big twist is that you have only three days to save the world before the moon crashes into the earth.

This doesn't give you long and time plays a crucial part in proceedings, especially when you learn how to manipulate it.

As in the movie Groundhog Day, the player is able to constantly relive the three days and will get to know the comings and goings of the characters, which is essential.

In another innovation the player can wear a variety of masks that change your form as well as your ability. So, if you need to swim underwater, you simply need to slip on the Zora mask.

Zelda traditionalists will be pleased to hear that the dungeons are as well-designed as ever, with the player thwarted by the ingenious puzzles and not the controls or camera (which are both excellent).

In fact, the only real problem is the frustration caused by turning back time at the wrong point and having to re-do solved challenges. It may lack the wonderfully epic nature of its predecessor - it just isn't as big - but Majora's Mask is another Zelda triumph. (GH)

The World Is Not Enough
Sony PlayStation £29.99 Electronic Arts ***
Bond is back, and our favourite agent is packing some entertaining weapons: a mobile phone, a fountain pen, a miniature torch and a watch.

Naturally these gadgets do remarkable things. The mobile phone, for example, delivers an electric shock powerful enough to stun opponents several feet away.

But as you progress through the game, you quickly pick up more traditional alternatives, including a double-barrelled shotgun.

Twine (The World Is Not Enough) is a Goldeneye 007-style first person shooter for the PlayStation, though it will actually be a multi-format release. And if you can run any of the forthcoming Nintendo 64, PlayStation 2 or PC versions of the game, they will probably provide a more satisfying experience.

Maybe in some of them, you will be able to make the controls more like Quake 3, and turning won't take quite so much time. (That should be a safe bet because EA has licensed Id Software's Quake 3 Arena game engine for the PC and PS2 versions.)

This 15-rated version is said to stay pretty close to the film, which I haven't seen. Certainly there are plenty of scenarios, with more than a dozen missions to keep you busy, plus a cheats screen for special options. What Twine lacks is a multiplayer mode. However, it looks better put together than Black Ops' last Bond effort, Tomorrow Never Dies. And considering how well that sold, this could become a huge hit.

Sheep
Mind's Eye £29.99 Productions/ Empire Interactive **
It must have looked like a no-lose formula. Take a cute, harmless animal. Animate it cartoonishly, give it an absurd back story, and place it in situations that may cause it to undergo a bloody and violent death. By all rights, you should have a cult post-pub hit on your hands.

Alas, the programmers of Sheep left one vital ingredient out of the mix: fun.

The absurd back story, for what it is worth, goes like this: alien sheep have returned to earth to pick up their terrestrial brethren, and it's your job to round up the troops.

Run at them, creep up to them, shout at them, pick them up and throw them if necessary - whatever it takes to get the woolly wallies to safety. Needless to say, there are no end of hazards between you and your goal: allow them to stray into a minefield or too close to the jaws of a crab and splat, mint sauce time.

Herding is a fiddly, slow, frustrating pastime, and Sheep would appear to be a fairly accurate re-creation of the experience. Its newness makes it challenging, but it is no white-knuckle ride. Second, it has limited multiplayer appeal. The two-player option is a frenetic game of sheep football, in which you have to herd your sheep in such a manner that they manoeuvre the ball into the opponent's goal, but it's more a demonstration of Brownian motion than a tense tactical head-to-head.

Finally, while no one expects state-of-the-art graphics from a novelty title, this looks like it was written on an Amstrad for the ZX81.

If I wanted to watch teeny, tiny blurry things moving around slowly, I'd pour tea leaves in my eye.

In its defence, Sheep is, at least, original. Except for the fact that it's a bit like lemmings. And worms.

fields.headline: Reviews
fields.trailText: Oxford Pop-up English Language Reference Shelf (CD-rom) | HipZip Digital Audio Player
fields.body:
Oxford Pop-up English Language Reference Shelf (CD-rom) £29.99
Windows 95 onwards. 32 Mb ram

Commercial suicide though this may conceivably be for the publisher, it's devilishly handy for the user. OUP has bundled four of its top-selling reference titles, worth £88 in bookshops, into a £29.99 CD-rom in a format that enables you to look up a word or name faster and with less interruption than the time it would take you to pull down a volume from a shelf.

Double-click the word in a Windows document or rest the cursor on an internet page; and there, in a pop-up box, you get relevant, expandable entries from the New Oxford Dictionary of English, the New Oxford Thesaurus, the flagship Oxford Dictionary of Quotations and the Oxford Paperback (herere- titled the Oxford World) Encyclopaedia, all compressed and fully installed into 80Mb of your hard disk.

One novelty is the instant way a plug-in developed by OUP's partner, the London-based, Norwegian-backed iFinger, throws up the box from its database on to your screen. The English dictionary and encyclopaedia are serious but fairly cut-down affairs, meant primarily for language students; you can search only by single word; and the device did, slightly and so far manageably, throw out one or two other programmes running on my PC.

In theory, you can also browse through the full text of each dictionary, though the small size of the box doesn't make this tempting.

Later versions are due to add a box that pronounces words in sound for the language market. For general users, it is already both a delightful toy and (with the above reservations) a genuine benefit as a combined, finger-light reference tool. (JE)

HipZip Digital Audio Player Iomega £289.99
MP3 files may be free but storing them is anything but. You can buy an MP3 player for under £80 but with high-quality MP3 files taking up a megabyte a minute, you will find that your dinky little player has only a dinky little repertoire. And if you get stuck in a traffic jam or a delayed train for a couple of hours, those 20 minutes or so of tunes stored in its tiny memory are going to become awfully repetitive.

You can expand the range but Sony's memory sticks, for example, are expensive: a Sony Internet personal hi-fi costs around £300 and comes with 64 MB of memory. But another 64MB memory stick will set you back another £150.

This is a gap in the market that Iomega, makers of the Zip drive disks, are hoping to exploit with the HipZip digital audio player.

This compact device (about 4in x 2 1/2 in x 1in) stores its music on PocketZip disks (originally launched as click disks). These are smaller versions - about 2in wide - of the familiar 100MB and 250MB Zip disks.

The HipZip sits snugly in the pocket and although it is a disk reader, not a solid state device, it is remarkably resilient. It easily passes the jogging test - it doesn't skip a beat even should you choose to shake it like a pair of maracas while grooving to Salsa tracks.

It comes with software to create and play MP3 files on your CD or Mac. The demo version I used would not work but this was not vital because you can use whatever virtual jukebox you like.

However, you do need the supplied IomegaWare disk, which takes up a hefty slab of your hard disk. But it does make downloading files very simple.

Just hook up the HipZip to your USB port and it appears on Explorer or Finder as a removable drive. Then drag and drop the files you want on or off the player.

Then you're up and away with about 10 hours' life on the HipZip's rechargeable battery. It's easy to operate, has good-quality sound and comes in a neat case with a belt clip. Each disk holds 40MB - about 40 minutes at high quality.

The demo of the HipZip came with two disks, each with a selection of prerecorded tunes that you can delete or pop on to your hard drive for later use.

Iomega says it is going to include four disks in future. Extra disks cost between £8 and £10 each - cheap compared with memory sticks but expensive compared with minidiscs, which can be bought for between £1 and £2 and will hold 74 minutes of music.

However, minidiscs work on Sony's Atrac 3 format and will not accept MP3 files unless you play them as audio tracks from your computer through the earphone socket - which is slower than downloading MP3 files and can reduce sound quality.

Sharp is tackling the problem with its Voquette adaptor, a £49 device that allows you to store MP3 files on a minidisc (but it appears that this is compatible only with Sharp minidisc players).

The HipZip does have one advantage in that it will also act as a convenient portable external file store. I dropped a couple of digicam files on it along with the MP3 files.

The player worked happily, ignoring the digicam files. But I was able to open the pictures when I hooked the Hipzip up to my laptop's USB port.

So if you are thinking of investing in a Zip drive as well as an MP3 player then the HipZip is a good option (a freestanding PocketZip drive alone costs £249).

The only quibble could be with the size of the disks. As file sizes grow ever larger, I have found my 100MB Zip disks are filling up fast.

If Iomega could at least double the capacity of PocketClick disks, it could be on to a winner.

That is, of course, if Sony doesn't come up with a way to store all types of files on the far cheaper minidiscs. (JE)

fields.headline: Organising your hard drive
fields.trailText: Start here
fields.body:
There's a simple way to measure your "computer intelligence": divide the number of folders or directories on your personal computer by the number of files and multiply the result by 1,000. If you have, on average, a hundred files in each folder, your CIQ will be 100, which is enough to function properly. If you have up to 500 files in each folder then it is time to re-organise your hard drive.

Hard drive organisation is important, not just so that you can find things easily, and back them up, but to keep Windows running smoothly. Windows keeps a "swap file" on the hard drive where it stores things when it runs out of real memory. When it starts to run out of this "virtual memory" (swap space), Windows' performance declines dramatically.

Organising a hard drive is like planning a library: you want to have the right number of shelves for different types of book, and you want to be able to find individual books quickly. It makes sense to reserve different folders - or different drives, or different drive partitions - for the operating system, your applications, and your data. You may also want separate sections for any particularly large collections of data, such as MP3 files.

You can then subdivide these main areas by creating folders for different applications and different types of data.

Microsoft has tried to encourage this approach in recent versions of Windows. The system files are stored in the Windows directory, and applications programs in a folder called Program Files. There's also a folder called My Documents where you can store your data (files created with word processors, spreadsheets, paint programs and other applications). This may also include subdirectories such as My Library, My Music, My Pictures, and My Webs.

Highlight the My Documents folder in Windows Explorer, then select File|New|Folder to create as many subdirectories as you like, such as My Downloads and so on. And if you don't like Microsoft's approach to directory names, you can do the same thing independently somewhere else, such as D:\Data.

Keeping all your personal data together makes it much easier to take back ups (security copies) in case of a hard drive failure. The operating system and applications can be re-installed from original copies, but if your data is lost, it has gone for good.

Unfortunately, not many of Microsoft's applications programmers, and very few outsiders, have got the message. Outlook and Outlook Express, for example, do not store your vital mail files in My Mail. They hide them away where you can't see them in files with extensions such as .dbx, .mbx and .pst. My OE5 mail, for example, is stored in C:\WINDOWS\ Application Data\Identities\ {C333B700-C32C-11D3-8602-B49B824D1277}\ Microsoft\OutlookExpress\Inbox. dbx , and how rational is that?

Also unfortunately, Windows is incapable of keeping track of files so you can't easily move them. However, you can make a habit of copying them to (say) My Mail and backing them up regularly.

But many programs can be set up to save files in a particular directory by default. You could, for example, store Word files in a My Word folder in My Documents. And many files - documents, images, MP3 files etc - can be stored anywhere. You can send these to the My Documents folder by right-clicking on the file name in Windows Explorer and selecting Send To then My Documents. Go to My Documents and sort them out later, creating new subfolders whenever a directory gets too big. The aim is to have enough sub-folders so that you can find files easily.

It can, of course, be tedious to navigate to very deep folders. However, you can always add your most frequently used folders to your Favorites list. This was designed to store web links, but you can add folders to the My Computer section.

fields.headline: That's show business
fields.trailText: Karlin Lillington at Comdex
fields.body:
There's only one way to arrive in Las Vegas, and that's by plane. Flying in - at least by daylight is the required mode of transport because it places in context this expensively kitsch temple of artifice. Las Vegas, surreal home to downsized Eiffel Tower and Empire State Building replicas, enormous black glass pyramids, Roman temples, French rococo overstatement, gambler's avarice and showgirls' breasts. Everything least pleasant about human nature luxuriates in Vegas, hidden behind the fabulous and costly interiors and exteriors of extravagant hotels built on money gambled and lost.

But flying high above the desert, the visitor has an achingly beautiful view of some of the most stunning and desolate scenery in the US.

Below are the ancient lands of the Navajo and Hopi tribes and the cliff-side dwellings of the legendary Anasazi, who were there first. Then comes the real heartstopper: the southern rim of the Grand Canyon.

Arriving in Vegas, you lose all sense of context and reality and enter the heavily hyped land of the unnatural. And that's doubly true of Comdex, which heaves with 250,000 technology aficionados, 2,000 exhibitors, and a motley army of journalists waiting to hear about the Next Big Thing.

Vegas has been the home of Comdex, which stands for Computer Dealers Exchange, for more than two decades. At first, the contrast between 1970s-era bewhiskered geeks and big-time Vegas gambling, glitz, showgirls and legalised prostitution must have been pleasing. The cliched image of guys eternally without girlfriends went so humorously well with the city where flesh was easily purchased and vice a civic virtue.

Nowadays, perhaps no city anywhere on earth more suitably, lovingly, pairs with the technology industry. Las Vegas, meet IT: new money, squandered money, money and reputations gambled and lost, vast riches questionably or skillfully or riskily won, bloated clouds of hype, a surface veneer of glamour, a desire to spend and spend and spend some more, the desperate longing of the not-yet or never-will-be successful, the self- satisfaction of Those Who Have Made It. Stretch limos (and this year, weirdly, stretch Humvees, those odd flat little vehicles used in the Gulf War), scantily clad women, enormous parties, live entertainment, and a fixed, sometimes grim, determination to have fun, fun, fun!

And Comdex, too, is great fun if you have a sense of context, a well-developed sense of irony, a good dash of skepticism, and a willing suspension of disbelief at crucial moments. You will be shown demos of things that do not work. You will be subjected to a non-stop barrage of marketers. You will fall in love, over and over, with the possibility of certain products, certain visions - the wireless revolution! The connected home! Ubiquitous computing! The entire Las Vegas Convention Center is inside a reality distortion field of epic proportions.

J ust go back and read the coverage of previous Comdexes, the excited babble back then about products and trends and sexy tech futures that never materialised.

But very little eventually gels in the world of gadgets or computing that didn't make its first stage appearance at Comdex in some way. This is why it's so utterly addictive - Comdex is the opportunity to see the future, to hear the talk, to meet the names, to watch the demos, to try the products that will shape tomorrow. If only the way were clearer and the hype not so overwhelming. If only one didn't have to battle a quarter of a million people all looking for a shuttle bus back to their hotel at precisely 5pm when the exhibit hall closes. But that's the IT industry and that's Las Vegas and it's just as well always to have that 34,000 foot perspective in your mind's eye because it's the only way to keep your feet firmly on the ground.
fields.bodyText: There's only one way to arrive in Las Vegas, and that's by plane. Flying in - at least by daylight is the required mode of transport because it places in context this expensively kitsch temple of artifice. Las Vegas, surreal home to downsized Eiffel Tower and Empire State Building replicas, enormous black glass pyramids, Roman temples, French rococo overstatement, gambler's avarice and showgirls' breasts. Everything least pleasant about human nature luxuriates in Vegas, hidden behind the fabulous and costly interiors and exteriors of extravagant hotels built on money gambled and lost. But flying high above the desert, the visitor has an achingly beautiful view of some of the most stunning and desolate scenery in the US. Below are the ancient lands of the Navajo and Hopi tribes and the cliff-side dwellings of the legendary Anasazi, who were there first. Then comes the real heartstopper: the southern rim of the Grand Canyon. Arriving in Vegas, you lose all sense of context and reality and enter the heavily hyped land of the unnatural. And that's doubly true of Comdex, which heaves with 250,000 technology aficionados, 2,000 exhibitors, and a motley army of journalists waiting to hear about the Next Big Thing. Vegas has been the home of Comdex, which stands for Computer Dealers Exchange, for more than two decades. At first, the contrast between 1970s-era bewhiskered geeks and big-time Vegas gambling, glitz, showgirls and legalised prostitution must have been pleasing. The cliched image of guys eternally without girlfriends went so humorously well with the city where flesh was easily purchased and vice a civic virtue. Nowadays, perhaps no city anywhere on earth more suitably, lovingly, pairs with the technology industry. Las Vegas, meet IT: new money, squandered money, money and reputations gambled and lost, vast riches questionably or skillfully or riskily won, bloated clouds of hype, a surface veneer of glamour, a desire to spend and spend and spend some more, the desperate longing of the not-yet or never-will-be successful, the self- satisfaction of Those Who Have Made It. Stretch limos (and this year, weirdly, stretch Humvees, those odd flat little vehicles used in the Gulf War), scantily clad women, enormous parties, live entertainment, and a fixed, sometimes grim, determination to have fun, fun, fun! And Comdex, too, is great fun if you have a sense of context, a well-developed sense of irony, a good dash of skepticism, and a willing suspension of disbelief at crucial moments. You will be shown demos of things that do not work. You will be subjected to a non-stop barrage of marketers. You will fall in love, over and over, with the possibility of certain products, certain visions - the wireless revolution! The connected home! Ubiquitous computing! The entire Las Vegas Convention Center is inside a reality distortion field of epic proportions. J ust go back and read the coverage of previous Comdexes, the excited babble back then about products and trends and sexy tech futures that never materialised. But very little eventually gels in the world of gadgets or computing that didn't make its first stage appearance at Comdex in some way. This is why it's so utterly addictive - Comdex is the opportunity to see the future, to hear the talk, to meet the names, to watch the demos, to try the products that will shape tomorrow. If only the way were clearer and the hype not so overwhelming. If only one didn't have to battle a quarter of a million people all looking for a shuttle bus back to their hotel at precisely 5pm when the exhibit hall closes. But that's the IT industry and that's Las Vegas and it's just as well always to have that 34,000 foot perspective in your mind's eye because it's the only way to keep your feet firmly on the ground.

fields.headline: Philip Beales
fields.standfirst: Visionary surgeon who championed deaf children and workers exposed to excessive noise
fields.trailText:
Philip Beales, who has died aged 84, was a visionary ear nose and throat surgeon and a worldwide authority on the middle ear, and on the social problems of noise and deafness. 
Through his books and his practices came changes in attitudes to the deaf, to general standards and to policies to prevent the increase of industrial deafness.
fields.body:
Philip Beales, who has died aged 84, was a visionary ear nose and throat surgeon and a worldwide authority on the middle ear, and on the social problems of noise and deafness. Through his books and his practices came changes in attitudes to the deaf, to general standards and to policies to prevent the increase of industrial deafness.

He was the eldest of three children of the social historian Lance Beales. After a happy early childhood in Lancashire, he grew up in north London, attending Haberdashers' school, and disconcerting the academic ambiance of his family by using a motor bike.

In the intellectual climate of the 1930s he acquired the convictions which later became the cornerstone of his dedication to the National Health Service. Although his father had hoped he would move into academic life, Philip again went against family tradition by studying medicine at Guy's Hospital.

After early experience in general medicine (including service as a RAF doctor) and later experience in plastic surgery, he decided to specialise in ear, nose and throat surgery, and became ENT surgeon at Doncaster royal infirmary. At Doncaster he built up a thriving NHS practice in the north of England.

From his arrival in Doncaster in 1953 to his retirement in 1981, he was awarded many distinctions and prizes. He invented a speculum used for microsurgery of the middle ear, and the Beales instrument, as it came to be known, is widely in use today. He was president of the otology section of the Royal Society of Medicine, 1978-79.

In 1961, he published his first book Otosclerosis, a seminal text on microsurgery of the middle ear, and in 1965 came his Noise, Hearing and Deafness. This was the first comprehensive treatment of both the physical and social aspects of deafness, and brought the immediate impact of modern (and particularly industrial) noise on workers, and indeed all citizens, to the attention of the public.

He reviewed the social problems faced by deaf children, at a time when deafness was termed "the most severe of all social handicaps", and argued that the deaf child should be educated in mainstream schools.

He was a tireless advisor to the School for the Deaf in Doncaster, and supported children and their parents struggling with the social and physical impact of deafness. For some years after retiring from surgery, he continued to assess damage to the hearing of miners and other industrial workers, his expert evidence assisting with difficult claims of workers disabled by unprotected exposure to loud noise.

Besides his work, his energies and enthusiasm were vested in his family - his wife Valerie (author of the children's book Emma and Freckles), children and grandchildren. He loved his garden at Rossington Bridge House, the restored coaching inn where he and his family lived throughout their time at Doncaster; and he was a keen sailor, potter, painter and amateur cook. He had a lifelong love of music.

To the end, he provided inspiration, joy and humour to those who were close to him. His wife died in 1994, and he is survived by his four children, David, Martin, Julia and Sylvia.

Philip Hulme Beales, surgeon, born March 2 1916; died November 8 2000

webTitle: Women: Do women age better than men?

fields.headline: Happy greys
fields.standfirst: Women, we've been told this week, come into their own as they age. Old men, on the other hand, are a miserable lot, likely to live out their last days drunk, alone and unhappy. Derek Malcolm, sixtysomething, doesn't see it that way
fields.trailText: Women, we've been told this week, come into their own as they age. Old men, on the other hand, are a miserable lot, likely to live out their last days drunk, alone and unhappy. Derek Malcolm, sixtysomething, doesn't see it that way.
fields.body:
Hollywood seldom attempts any but the most droolingly sentimental of stories about old people, who are either possessed of the wisdom of ages or showing clear signs of senility. What they never do is have sex. And especially not in full view on the screen.

Paul Cox, an Australian director, has just made a film, appropriately called Innocence, that dares to fly in the face of this cinematic convention that says no sex, please, we're pensioners. He suggests not that life begins at 40 but that sometimes it starts again at 70-plus. And in bed at that.

Innocence is a full-blown if bittersweet romance in which a reasonably happy old couple have their life totally upended when the equally aged former lover of the wife comes to visit and stays for sex.

Having started the affair all over again, the lovers decide to do what they now realise they should have done 50 years ago. The wife asks for a divorce, not because she hates her husband - she's actually quite fond of him - but because she wants to marry the man she has fallen in love with.

She, of course, is taking the kind of risk women, bent on reinventing themselves even if generally at a younger age, are said to handle better than men. But it is the man in this film who makes the running. He is retired, has lost his wife and suddenly sees a chance to change his life for the better by simply doing what he should have done years ago, and thereby starting a new one.

He thus does not fall into the dark side of the "grey panthers" category conjured up by researchers describing the increasing number of middle-aged or elderly men living alone and falling into depression and alcoholism. He is that rare bird, the man who dares and wins.

Is this just a charmingly made fairy tale, a kind of Australian answer to Brief Encounter with a bolder view of sex and a more audacious ending? Or does it tell us an often disguised truth: that men are as good as women at taking their lives by the scruff of the neck in middle or even old age?

Perhaps it is neither but merely a plea to us wrinklies to follow our hearts, regardless of the consequences. Cox, a film-maker who goes against most trends and has often set about trying to redefine male-female relationships, says he is telling it like it should be, but only sometimes is.

"Men," he says, "are just as likely as women to fight against the dying of the light. More so, in fact, because they often have the greater financial means to help them do it. The only trouble is that they have more illusions about themselves as well as more money, so get into terrible difficulties. They search for the impossible: young women, a life like they wanted to live when young but didn't, the elixir of youth and all that. When they don't find it, they relapse into not trying at all.

"In my film, the old man who visits his former lover becomes totally convinced he can still win her. Nine times out of 10, he probably couldn't. It would be a painful illusion on his part. He knows this but he doesn't give up and, though she is the one who doubts, in the end he convinces her. She doesn't just have to trundle along in an averagely boring marriage until the end of her days.

"The other man in the triangle, on the other hand, is more typical. He simply can't understand what's happened. It seems inconceivable to him that she'd give up everything on an absurd romantic whim. But then that's the other side of the coin. Some men remain blissfully unaware of what's happening to their relationships till the end of their lives. I doubt if as many women do. Yes, they are much more capable of managing their emotional lives."

Viewing the film, one doubts whether too many men would take such a risk. Or that many women either. But if you made the lovers 50 instead of 70, it seems likely that more women than men now have the courage to break loose. We are told one man in 10 over 60 lives alone and that by 2020 it could well be one in three - a fair number doubtless in a state of quiet desperation, beset by financial difficulties and social and emotional problems.

But the line between desperation and fulfilment is often difficult to gauge. The truth, Oscar Wilde said, is rarely pure and never simple. A friend of mine, for instance, has reached his mid-60s minus his wife after a divorce, retired as a teacher and with a pension that is only adequate. He'd like a new life, and especially a new relationship, but, as he admits, he hasn't the courage to go out and find one.

"I'm not miserable," he says. "I've got nice children, good friends and I love my tennis and golf. I'm not exactly bored. But there are times when I think it's all a bit meaningless unless I can find someone to share it with."

Another friend of the same age, who was retired early by his firm, bitterly regrets being unable to work, even though he is happily married and has enough money for most of the things he wants to do. "I have a good life compared with most people, who would probably kill to be in my position. But I feel completely useless because I want to contribute something and I can't."

I've heard variants of these stories several dozen times. For every man in late middle age who works himself to death, there's another who is dying to work. For every veteran male who is tied to a long-lasting but unsatisfactory relationship, there is another who searches for a liaison of any sort. It is almost certainly women rather than men who can get themselves out from under such constraints in what to them is now laughingly called the evening of their lives.

On the other hand, I went to a village market in Kent recently. There, the mostly elderly men and women stallholders and their costumers seemed to have reversed roles with surprisingly satisfactory results. The women, many of them widows and relieved of the responsibilities of caring for husbands and children, were happily discussing busy lives they could never have contemplated before, lives unconnected with the usual family chores.

And the men? They were swapping recipes and gardening hints like, well, a lot of old women. It seemed as if male and female lifestyle roles had been conveniently reversed. Just possibly, that might be the answer to the problem of growing older gracefully.

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.trailText:
"You can earn good money as a woman writer but what you're expected to do is something trite"
Author Anna Davis, Nova
fields.body:
"You can earn good money as a woman writer but what you're expected to do is something trite"
Author Anna Davis, Nova

"People made up those rumours. They just couldn't believe that four women could work together and get on really well - but we did"
Joan Collins on her latest collaboration with Liz Taylor, Shirley MacLaine and Debbie Reynolds, Hello!

"I've been married pretty much all my adult life ... I used to absorb the life of whoever I was with - all the time I was married I probably didn't know who I was"
Patsy Kensit, People in Fashion

"Today girls start tweaking their looks in their 20s and thinking about toxins to freeze their frowns almost before life has given them anything to frown about. How long before a collagen injection (which, after all, only costs the same, and probably lasts as long, as an expensive pot of cream) to fill the merest suspicion of a wrinkle becomes commonplace? ... As rare as the woman who has never dyed her hair, the natural woman, like the natural blonde, will become a priceless exhibit before you can say 'antioxidant' "
Kathy Phillips, Vogue

"I lost my virginity at drama school. It was over before the girl even started to enjoy it"

Keith Chegwin, Heat

"It was all over so quickly, I got nothing out of it and felt a bit stupid"
Victoria Beckham, Heat

"I waited until I was married (age 31). My virginity was an honour that I was bestowing on a man - he had to be worthy of it"
Lisa Kudrow, Heat

"During the after-sex chat she told me some horrific things about her childhood - I don't really mind, but I find it difficult to see someone again and pay for this type of service when I feel sorry for them. It made me feel a bit like an abuser"
Report on a prostitute by "Hornyboy" on www.punternet.com

"I can remember when I thought about sex every four seconds. Now I find it's food"
Andrew Davies, screenplay writer of BBC 1's new Take A Girl Like You, Independent on Sunday
