fields.headline: Children pioneer 'bionic' hand
fields.standfirst: World's first partial hand replacement small enough to be used by youngsters is hailed as a success after a six month trial
fields.trailText: A bionic hand, designed specifically for children as young as two who were born with parts of their hands missing, has transformed the lives of five youngsters.
fields.body:
A bionic hand, designed specifically for children as young as two who were born with parts of their hands missing, has transformed the lives of five youngsters.

The children, who have just finished a six-month trial of the Prodigits device at Nottingham city hospital, demonstrated the electronically powered prosthesis yesterday.

It is the first time scientists have created a prosthetic partial hand small enough for children. Previously, patients had to rely on devices created for those lacking a whole hand.

Designed in Scotland, Prodigits allows children to carry out the simple two-handed tasks that most of us take for granted. Its creators, who fitted a bionic arm to an adult two years ago, believed children would benefit most from the prosthetic. Previously there were no such prosthetic hands for children under nine - but patients are able to make more use of the devices the earlier in life they are fitted with them."It's brilliant," said Jeremy Driver, from Aspley, Nottingham, at 11 the oldest child in the trial. "I just press a button and my hand opens and closes. Now I can use my Playstation - and throttle my younger brother," he joked. "It took me a few months to get used to it, but now I can do loads of things."

The other children in the trial were Oliver Jackson, five, from Skegness, Lincolnshire; Daisy Harriman, five, of Heanor, Derbyshire; Philip Moss, seven, of Pinxton, Derbyshire; and Tia Campbell, from Aspley and at two the youngest of the group.

"We try not to use the word 'bionic' because people tend to associate it with Lee Majors," said David Gow, who invented the device. "It conjures up superhuman powers, not average human powers, which is what we are trying to achieve.".

A director at the Lothian Primary Care Trust's bio engineering centre in Edinburgh, he has worked on prosthetics for years, Mr Gow was convinced there had to be a way to build a hand small enough to be used by children.

"The only inspiration we needed was that we saw a lot of kids that we couldn't do anything for," he explained. The other problem was that some children have functioning wrists and partial palms, yet most prosthetic hands are attached above the wrist.

The Prodigits are separate artificial fingers so can be used together or individually. The user touches an electrode within the hand using his or her residual limbs, and tiny motors and gear boxes cause the fingers to open and close.

Once the hand is finished it is shaped with foam and covered with a silicone "skin" to make it look realistic. Its designers also hope to make a version for adults who would be better served by Prodigits than by a whole hand device.

Once in production, Prodigits should be more cost effective for the NHS than conventional devices. With about £50,000 of funding the hands could be available within a year. But timing is of the essence because the children are likely to grow out of the prototypes they are using within a couple of years.

"It's a plug and play hand. It's like a kit of parts; half a dozen pieces you can assemble into a two-year-old's hand or an adult's hand," said Mr Gow.

"Unlike a conventional artificial hand, the digits are separate and are not for the left hand or right hand. It's much more versatile. "

John Ronald, whose firm developed the design, said the potential was immediately obvious when Mr Gow brought the idea to him.

"People don't realise that a hand is one of the most complex things around. It's got movement, strength, sensitivity and is even self repairing. A square inch has around 1,300 sensors."

"People don't realise that a hand is one of the most complex things around. It's got movement, strength, sensitivity and is even self repairing. A square inch has around 1,300 sensors."

webTitle: MoD reveals 4,000 in nerve gas tests

fields.headline: MoD reveals 4,000 in nerve gas tests
fields.trailText: Up to 4,000 servicemen have been subjected to nerve agent experiments at the chemical and biological warfare establishment at Porton Down, Ministry of Defence officials disclosed yesterday.
fields.body:
Up to 4,000 servicemen have been subjected to nerve agent experiments at the chemical and biological warfare establishment at Porton Down, Ministry of Defence officials disclosed yesterday.

The figures - a third more than previously released - relate to servicemen who are among more than 20,000 human guinea pigs to be offered new medical assessments. The move follows an increasing number of complaints by volunteers that their health problems were caused by the experiments, which also involved mustard gas and LSD.

Of all the substances tested on humans at Porton, in Wiltshire, where chemical and biological warfare experiments have taken place since 1916 and are continuing today, the nerve agents are potentially the most dangerous.

An inquiry by the Wiltshire police force is looking at the way the tests were conducted, and at allegations including those saying that elderly people suffered dementia after germ warfare experiments.

Lewis Moonie, the junior defence minister, told the Commons this week that he took "seriously" volunteers' claims that their ill health was a result of their participation in the trials. The MoD said it would seek independent advice for an epidemiological study although it had seen "no scientific evidence to support the belief".

Yesterday, MoD officials reiterated that they had seen no scientific or medical evidence linking the health problems of veterans to their participation in nuclear tests or the Gulf war.

Alan Care, the lawyer for the Porton volunteers, said the MoD's new assessment programme was insufficient. "We will still demand a full independent inquiry," he said.

fields.headline: Lego wheels for overfed tortoise
fields.trailText: A cure for the modern life of luxury which is crippling hundreds of pet tortoises has been found by a vet, with the help of his children's toys.
fields.body:
A cure for the modern life of luxury which is crippling hundreds of pet tortoises has been found by a vet, with the help of his children's toys.

The vet has stuck Lego wheels on to the shells of tortoises to get the grounded reptiles moving again, in an operation in Leeds where up to 10 similar applications could be carried out in the next year.

Stuart McArthur, who specialises in tortoises, and who searched for ideas in Darwin's work, Voyage of the Beagle, and Gilbert White's diary of Timothy, the pet tortoise of Selborne, said yesterday: "I tried a very large range of Lego wheels to get the right combination of size and balance."

Yesterday, Mr McArthur completed his second successful operation, on a 2kg pet that had been unable to move properly. Its wheels, which were fixed with a powerful glue, have independent suspension to help cornering, and promise to counter the effects of too much well-intentioned pampering.

Mr McArthur warned that what he was doing should not be tried by pet keepers themselves and that it was for incapacitated animals only.

"We see some tortoise hatchlings which are just too well looked after when young. As a result, they get too heavy at a time when their carapace is still soft and forming. It sets too low [producing too deep a shell] and they have great difficulty moving - an awful prospect, when a tortoise can live for 100 years."

The operation could help tortoises with spinal injuries, including the female operated on yesterday whose back legs were too damaged to let her struggle along. Only a small number would need this treatment, Mr McArthur stressed, and it was no substitute for correct care and feeding.

Tortoises, in fact, are used to moving fairly fast occasionally - and particularly when on heat, as Gilbert White observed in June 1780. "Timothy's exertions are remarkable, walking on tiptoe and stirring at five in the morning. His fancy becomes intent on sexual attachments, which transport him beyond his usual gravity and induce him to forget for a time his usual solemn deportment."

webTitle: Britons go abroad in record numbers

fields.headline: Britons go abroad in record numbers
fields.trailText: Last year, for the first time, departures of British nationals travelling abroad outnumbered arrivals of foreigners visiting this country by more than two to one, according to figures published today by the office for national statistics.
fields.body:
Last year, for the first time, departures of British nationals travelling abroad outnumbered arrivals of foreigners visiting this country by more than two to one, according to figures published today by the office for national statistics.

UK residents made a record 53.9m visits overseas, up 3m on the year before. Officials said the increase was largely due to extra holidays abroad encouraged by the favourable exchange rate of sterling.

By contrast, visits by people overseas to Britain fell by 350,000 to 25.4m as the strength of the pound made it more expensive for foreigners to travel here. It was the first decrease in visitors since the Gulf war in 1991.

The outcome was a record £10bn balance of payments deficit on the travel account. Britons spent £22bn during their visits abroad, a sum up 13% on 1998 and more than double the total for 1991. Visitors from overseas spent £12.5bn, 1.4% down on the year before.

The most prolific spenders were Egyptians, who averaged more than £2,000 on visits that typically lasted nearly two weeks. The lowest spenders were Belgians, averaging £200 during three-day trips.

Most of the growth in outward travel was among holidaymakers who accounted for 2.7m more trips and who spent £2.1bn more than in 1998. Exotic locations in Central America, South America and the Caribbean were the holiday destinations growing fastest in popularity for Britons. Visits to these countries have more than doubled over the past four years to nearly 1.2m during 1999.

The most popular of the destinations abroad remained France, with 11.9m visits from UK residents last year. It was the top country for short breaks and business trips.

Spain was the most popular holiday spot, accounting for more than a quarter of all visits. Other favourite destinations were the Irish Republic, US and Greece, which had an increase in the number of visits from British holidaymakers of nearly a third last year. The popularity of Turkey, however, waned.

UK residents made more than 4.5m day trips last year, spending £100 on average on each visit.

Three-quarters of the day trips were to France, including 2m by shoppers who spent £140 per person per trip.

Although more people took short breaks abroad, 70% of visits by UK residents lasted four nights or more. Most visitors to the UK last year were from the EU, but the US was the largest individual country of origin. On visits to the UK last year, Americans spent nearly three times as much money (around £2.5bn) as the second highest spending nation, Germany.

London continued to be the most popular place for travellers from overseas. More than half of the visitors spent at least one night there and the capital had more than 13 times as many visits as the next most popular city in the UK, Edinburgh.

More than two-thirds of all overseas visits were made by air last year, with Heathrow in west London accounting for more than half of those travelling by plane. The Channel tunnel, which was the second most popular gateway for overseas visitors coming to the UK, accounted for 11% of total visits by UK residents going abroad and 12% of overseas residents' visits to Britain last year.

Iain MacLeay, editor of National Statistics Travel Trends, said that the growth in foreign travel by British residents slowed in the second half of last year. Abolition of duty-free shopping on trips between EU countries may have contributed to lower levels of sea and Channel tunnel traffic over this period.

Provisional figures for the first nine months of this year show the growth in the outward travel market was down to 3%, while the figures for inward travel fell 1.2%.

webTitle: Parents unaware of role of room heat in cot death

fields.headline: Parents unaware of role of room heat in cot death
fields.trailText: Two thirds of parents of babies were unaware of the correct room temperature to reduce risk of cot death, the Foundation for the Study of Infant Deaths reported yesterday.
fields.body:
Two thirds of parents of babies were unaware of the correct room temperature to reduce risk of cot death, the Foundation for the Study of Infant Deaths reported yesterday.

Its survey of 214 parents with children under one found 30% of fathers did not know 16C to 20C (65F) was best, although 41% of mothers did; 62% of parents had no thermometer in the nursery, though 41% could guess room temperature correctly.

Cot death kills eight babies a week in the UK. The reason is as yet unknown, but studies have pointed to a link with temperature. Sara Levene, a paediatrican who advises the foundation, said: "It's an old wives' tale that you have to keep babies very warm."

She said there were a number of theories on the link between body temperature and cot death.

One theory is that over-heating could disrupt a baby's ability to control body heat. An other is that heating encourages bacterial growth releasing toxins that could lead to septic shock.

The best way to check, she said, is by touching a baby's stomach, not its hands and feet. They should sleep away from windows, radiators and direct sunlight.

As much as 85% of babies' excess heat is lost through their heads, so these should not be covered by bedclothes.

Duvets, quilts and pillows should not be used. Instead Dr Levene advised layers of lightweight blankets which can be removed if a baby feels hot or seems to be sweating. Outdoor clothes, should be removed as soon as a baby enters a warm vehicle or shop, she said.

The numbers of cot deaths has been falling for a number of years. In 1969, there were 1,200 sudden infant deaths in England and Wales.By the start of the 1990s, that figure was 500, thanks largely to the Back to Sleep campaign, which encouraged parents to place babies on their backs rather than their stomachs.

webTitle: Wet and forlorn, a village's misery continues

fields.headline: Wet and forlorn, a village's misery continues
fields.standfirst:
Flood warnings have abated across Britain but in an East Yorkshire village only the publicity has dried up
Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Stuck in a forlorn lagoon by the Aire in Yorkshire, with sewage-polluted water still in ground floor rooms, the people of Gowdall, near Goole, are planning a new road sign saying: "Welcome to the Forgotten Village."
fields.body:
Stuck in a forlorn lagoon by the Aire in Yorkshire, with sewage-polluted water still in ground floor rooms, the people of Gowdall, near Goole, are planning a new road sign saying: "Welcome to the Forgotten Village."

While mops and plucky returnees in nearby Selby and York have replaced media flood pictures, Gowdall is unchanged from three weeks ago - and fed up at feeling ignored.

"It only affects 250 people so maybe they write it off," said Ellen Lund, whose farm looks out over acres of sugar beet and winter wheat which are now almost certainly ruined. "Maybe they say: it's not such a big thing."

Gowdall's flood is patently a big thing for anyone needing to walk along Main Street, past the village hall whose sign saying 'Meeting cancelled due to flood alert' only just emerged from the water. Beyond the smudged writing, the street sign is in an inaccessible island and the new "Lake Gowdall" stretches to Eggborough power station on the eastern horizon.

Villager Erika Haines said: "We've no electricity, no telephone and we reckon it will be eight months before we can get things back to normal. We'll be forgotten about again by then."

The problem, said Darren Cleave, pausing from discussion with a loss adjuster about how far up his stairs the Aire reached at its peak, is that Gowdall's flood defences are keeping the water in, rather than out. Breached on one 400-yard stretch at the height of the floods, they held everywhere else and so form a dam, with the 250 villagers in the huge, shallow pond behind. "It's that and the fact that we're where the plughole of the Aire floodplain should be," he said. "This is the lowest point, the ground's saturated and the water's got nowhere to go."

The state of paralysis was summed up, according to other villagers, when an emergency pumping operation sluiced water back into the Aire, which took it downstream as far as another breach, where for more than a day it poured back into the village again.

Before entering her family home, Julia Cleave warned of the smell. "We all know that smell in Gowdall now. None of us'll ever forget it."

The loss adjuster is still doing his sums, and aghast - even in his unsentimental trade - over a 74-year-old villager up the road whose ground floor is a heartbreaking picture of flood damage. While others have dumped every ruined thing in skips, her possessions are all in place; but smeared with brown slime, saturated, worthless and still partly under water.

Mr Cleave, whose ruined machinery from his home-based butchery equipment firm was worth £30,000, told of universal anger in Gowdall that the village lost out from a lopsided defence system on the Aire. He says: "Last time this happened, in 1947, Gowdall on this bank and Snaith on the other side were flooded equally. This time, Snaith stayed dry and we've ended up like this."

The environment agency is checking dykes on both sides of the Aire, to assess why Gowdall's burst while the Snaith barriers held firm. The agency's chairman, Sir John Harman, who grew up by the Aire in Castleford, 15 miles east, has been to the village in response to the "forgotten" claims, and has authorised fresh emergency measures.

Beyond the roof of a marooned commuter house - once worth over £200,000 - a controlled breach in the flood dyke is now letting some water out of the Gowdall pond. A more powerful pump has been ordered, to shift five tonnes of water a second, and two sluices are being hastily dug at Heck Ings to drain the lowest-lying parts of the flood on to the Aire's water meadows.

Daily meetings with the villagers' own emergency committee, East Riding of Yorkshire council and the agency, are preparing for the very real risk of the Aire rising again. Five railway arches have been dammed and temporary defences will be built along the ruined stretch of Dyke before Christmas. Even so, "No one is counting on staying dry this winter," said Mrs Cleave.

Gowdall was the only place in Britain with a severe flood warning last night, but the environment agency warned of an increase in lower-risk flood warnings - in place on 16 stretches of river nationwide.

Monitors are keeping a close eye on the rivers Lavant and Rye in West Sussex, after a forecasted inch of rain in the south east over the next 24 hours. The agency also repeated warnings about the danger of building new houses on flood plains and called for a firmer line from planning appeal inspectors.

Geoff Mance, the agency's water management director, told a Commons select committee on the flood disaster that another 342,000 homes could be added to the threatened list by 2021 if present building trends were not stopped.

webTitle: Not a glass of water but an oak tree - and like all modern art it's here to stay

fields.headline: Not a glass of water but an oak tree - and like all modern art it's here to stay
fields.standfirst:
Tate director attacks critics and bemoans people's lack of understanding

Sir Nicholas Serota profiled
fields.trailText: Sir Nicholas Serota, the driving force behind Tate Modern and the Turner prize, yesterday mounted a head-on attack against the detractors of modern art - warning them that "materials such as brick, plastic rubbish and even elephant dung" are here to stay and must be accepted. He gave them blunt notice that, despite their protests, setting the clock back to non-abstract, realist or classical work was impossible. He declared: "We are not going to return to an era in which 'art comes to its senses'."
fields.body:
Sir Nicholas Serota, the driving force behind Tate Modern and the Turner prize, yesterday mounted a head-on attack against the detractors of modern art - warning them that "materials such as brick, plastic rubbish and even elephant dung" are here to stay and must be accepted. He gave them blunt notice that, despite their protests, setting the clock back to non-abstract, realist or classical work was impossible. He declared: "We are not going to return to an era in which 'art comes to its senses'."

Delivering this year's Richard Dimbleby lecture on BBC1, Sir Nicholas, director of the Tate gallery and chief Turner prize judge, emphasised that "to argue that art can get back on track is a delusion".

But he also conceded that, almost a century after the onset of modernism, the valid insights of contemporary art were still "impassable" and "apparently intractable" to very many people. The public feared it was being tricked or fooled by emperors parading in new clothes, who were in reality supported only by an inner circle of critics, curators and collectors.

He laid the keenest blame for this at the door of the Blair government for allowing city art galleries such as those in Leeds and Glasgow to wither from lack of resources. Outside London and Edinburgh, collections of modern art were almost dormant, which meant most people had no chance to grow familiar with it, as they had been able to do with Picasso, Henry Moore and Barbara Hepworth.

Sir Nicholas, regarded as a friend of the government, said: "Two years ago the prime minister promised that the arts are to be written into the core script of government. I have to say that in the visual arts we are still waiting for many of the words of that script.

Successive governments have gradually cut visual arts and design from the secondary national curriculum. "Visual awareness is not incidental," Sir Nicholas said. "The visual is no less important than the three r's.

"Chris Smith has taken the courageous decision to use most of his available resources to defend and extend the principle of free admission to our national museums, but otherwise there is little to cheer, especially for those who live outside London."

The 5,000-word lecture was one of the most forthright discussions of the subject for many years, both in defending modern art and in admitting its unpopularity.

Sir Nicholas's theme was that "new art becomes the reference point for the future". But he confessed he had found the argument inadequate when faced by two persistent questions: "But is it art?" and "How do we decide which art is good?"

Enthusiasm for Tate Modern and the Angel of the North at Gateshead had been taken as evidence of a recent sea change in public appreciation of visual arts.

Among the counter-evidence was last year's Turner prize headlines: Eminence without merit (Sunday Telegraph); Tate trendies blow a raspberry (Eastern Daily Press); For 1,000 years art has been one of our great civilising forces. Today, pickled sheep and soiled bed threaten to make barbarians of us all (Daily Mail).

Sir Nicholas asked: "Are these papers speaking the minds of their readers? I have no delusions.

"People may be attracted by the spectacle of new buildings, they may enjoy the social experience of visiting a museum, taking in the view, an espresso or glass of wine, purchasing a book or an artist designed T-shirt. Many are delighted to praise the museum - but remain deeply suspicious of the contents".

Dealing directly with three of the most recently reviled art works, he called Damien Hirst's cow and calf installation Mother and Child Divided "an unforgettable image, at once raw and tender, brazen and subtle". Rachel Whiteread's House was "a work of art of great vulnerability and haunting beauty" and Michael Craig-Martin's An Oak Tree (showing not an oak but a glass of tap water on a glass bathroom shelf) required an act of faith comparable to a belief in religious transubstantiation.

Definitions of art did not depend on materials alone. "There is no intrinsic reason why art cannot be made from new materials, including low materials such as brick, plastic rubbish or even elephant dung.

"Essentially, this account is a plea for patience," Sir Nicholas said. "Your scepticism will gradually diminish and your fear will turn to love...

"For the late 20th century museum director there is no more certain prospect for audience acclaim and sponsor success than those Impressionist and Post-impressionist artists who were so reviled a century earlier.

"Art does break new ground and reveal new truths and such lessons are not confined to the art of the 20th or 21st century. All art was modern once.

Tracy Emin, artist:

webTitle: Ex-manager of child soprano settles for £2m

fields.headline: Ex-manager of child soprano settles for £2m
fields.standfirst: Row between Charlotte Church family and sacked employee entitled to 40% of her royalties ends with out-of-court agreement
fields.trailText: Charlotte Church's former manager was yesterday set to receive up to £2m of the child soprano's fortune after settling his multi-million pound claim for damages out of court.
fields.body:
Charlotte Church's former manager was yesterday set to receive up to £2m of the child soprano's fortune after settling his multi-million pound claim for damages out of court.

Jonathan Shalit had been claiming £4m of the teenager's £10m estimated earnings from her singing career, after being sacked by Ms Church's mother.

The case at the high court, which was expected to be one of the bitterest involving the music industry, was adjourned on its second day after the two sides reached a deal.

Mr Shalit, 38, had claimed that the mother of Ms Church, Maria, had fired him without warning in January because her aim in life was "the pursuit and retention of money" and that she had also quibbled over expenses.

The court heard that under a three-year deal Mr Shalit was entitled to 40% of the 14-year-old's recording royalties.

It is believed that Mr Shalit settled for a compensation package that could amount to £2m, plus costs. He will receive a one-off payment of almost £1.1m, and royalties from Ms Church's first two albums and her current one, Dream a Dream, which could add another £900,000 to the amount he is finally paid.

The case had descended into a bitter row between Mr Shalit and Ms Church's parents, and turned into a public relations disaster for the singer's record company, Sony UK.

Paul Burger, head of Sony UK, had been in talks with Mr Shalit until the eve of the trial and over the weekend is believed to have offered £1m to settle the case. After a morning of legal wrangling between the parties, Charlotte returned to the court to throw her arms around her barrister, Robert Englehart QC, and kiss him in gratitude. She said outside the court: "I am really happy that we have been able to come to a settlement. This has been a horrible year for me and the rest of the family. I am really glad it is all over."

Mr Justice Evans-Lombe, the judge, returned to announce that the hearing was being adjourned until Friday so that lawyers could finalise the details of the settlement "with a view to disposing of this without further recourse to this court".

Charlotte, who was wearing an orange woollen turtleneck jumper and full-length blue silk skirt, walked out of the court building, her arms linked with her mother and her adoptive father, James. She signed autographs inside the Royal Courts of Justice before emerging on the steps in the Strand in London to say: "I am very happy that it is over. I would like to thank my family - my parents in particular - for being strong and supporting me through everything. I am really happy to just get on with my singing which is what I do best."

Mr Shalit, who appeared equally relieved at the out come of the case, said: "I'm very happy, we won. I completely support what Charlotte has said today. As the New York Post wrote, she is the best voice in the world, and may the public enjoy that for many years to come. I am also delighted with the outcome."

Mr Shalit's counsel, John Mill QC, had told the court on Tuesday that his client had encouraged and also helped develop Charlotte from an unknown 11-year-old Cardiff schoolgirl to an international singing star in just three years.

Mr Mill said that his client had been sacked from his job because he had "stood in the way of Charlotte Church's mother, Maria, amassing as much money as possible".

Charlotte, who has sung before the Pope, the Queen and Bill Clinton, and sold millions of her albums all over the world, switched on the lights of London's Oxford Street on Tuesday evening.

Yesterday it was announced that she would also be turning on the Christmas lights at the White House in Washington on December 11.

webTitle: Leader: The spending targets are right. But can they be hit?

fields.headline: Spend and deliver
fields.standfirst:
The targets are right. But can they be hit?

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The Blair government is at last redeeming the promise it made in May 1997 to move the country away from the Tory heritage of private affluence and public squalor. Travellers by bus, rail and tube, parents and patients have long been aware of the imbalance.
fields.body:
The Blair government is at last redeeming the promise it made in May 1997 to move the country away from the Tory heritage of private affluence and public squalor. Travellers by bus, rail and tube, parents and patients have long been aware of the imbalance.

Investment promises made in Labour's 1998 spending review turned out to be a false dawn; one reason why the chancellor's coffers are bulging is because of underspending by public bodies that had simply lost the habit of authorising big spending projects. After the prime minister's statement yesterday the public sector knows it has at least four years of stability in which to plan and invest - provided, of course, that Labour is still around after May next.

No one should get too excited. Net public sector investment in 2003-4 will total only some 1.7% of GDP, a lot better than this year's 0.7% but puny in comparison with needed improvements in transport. Or take health: CT scanners do not come cheap. Or housing: the government is committing some £2.6bn a year to council housing (by 2003-4), but experts cost the needs of the social rented stock at £19bn and there have been recent reminders of the scale of refurbishment needed in the private sector - for which grants will be needed. The public sector is still living, like an ageing rentier, off the huge investments in concrete and high rise made by Harold Wilson's first government.

Unlike the splurge in investment under John Major, these plans are not meant to bail out a recession-bound economy. In fact one difficulty is going to be the launch of this £18bn into an economy operating (certainly in the south of England) somewhere near capacity. Investment depends critically on people, and the supply of engineers, architects and planners to town halls depends in turn on attractive-enough public sector pay. Public authorities have got rusty - like much of the infrastructure itself - and lost the knack of project appraisal and management; they veer on the side of caution, which delays things.

If it is returned to power, Labour faces a task for which politicians congenitally lack the appropriate skills. It is management. Ministers will have to deliver. Yet both Mr Blair's speech and Treasury papers have ducked the tricky question of how this increase in investment is to be processed through the system. In the past week we have seen just how hard it is going to be to ensure that Railtrack performs - returning a profit to shareholders while maximising socially necessary investment, on the back of a large amount of public money.

The government, pig-headed, insists on its "public private partnership" for the London Underground yet it too relies on a strange game in which profit-making companies are bribed into making urgent investment, the wherewithal coming from the taxpayer.

Yet yesterday's official documents, read closely, shoot a large hole in the case made for these private finance initiatives (PFI). From now on, the public sector is having to account for its £500bn worth of assets by showing depreciation and rates of return just like a commercial balance sheet.

This move to "resource accounting" is hugely welcome since it will, in time, lead public bodies to make a much clearer declaration of why they need to hold assets. Yet this innovation cuts the ground from under the PFI. Once public investment is fully costed and justified, what need is there for the sleight of hand of the PFI - for which revenue payments are going to have to be made for decades to come?

webTitle: Leader: The darker side of the Thatcher legacy

fields.headline: The tears and the truth
fields.standfirst:
The darker side of the Thatcher legacy

Special report: the Thatcher era
fields.trailText: Amid all the lachrymose blather offered to mark the 10th anniversary of the fall of Margaret Thatcher, it was always going to be refreshing to hear someone cut through the guff. How much more heartening that this someone should be the present prime minister, Tony Blair.
fields.body:
Amid all the lachrymose blather offered to mark the 10th anniversary of the fall of Margaret Thatcher, it was always going to be refreshing to hear someone cut through the guff. How much more heartening that this someone should be the present prime minister, Tony Blair.

For much of the commentariat's musings had dwelled on the notion of Mr Blair as the son Mrs T never had, with New Labour her truest legacy. How appealing, then, that the heir should so dramatically disavow his inheritance. Admittedly, Mr Blair was provoked. He was infuriated, it seems, by the lady's intervention in the row about a so-called "European army," which she condemned in the Sun as "monumental folly" and "political vanity". Tired of the Europhobic papers inventing a demon where none exists, and angered by the former PM's fuelling of their paranoia, he unleashed some fire of his own yesterday.

Rather than offer an anniversary bouquet, he told the truth. He said Margaret Thatcher had done much that was necessary in her time, but that she also bore responsibility for four great errors which hurt Britain badly: boom-and-bust economics, social division, the neglect of our public services and a stubbornly hostile attitude towards Europe. "I take nothing away from those things that were done in the 1980s that we have kept," said Mr Blair, "but it really is time... that we moved British politics beyond the time of Margaret Thatcher."

Amen to that, and bravo. For in those few well-chosen words Mr Blair cuts to the heart of the Thatcher legacy. She solved some problems, but she created a good few more - many of which we are still dealing with today. His plea to move on may seem obvious, but it is surely necessary in a political culture which has the shadow chancellor boasting that he (not William Hague, you understand) is the lady's true heir. Maybe Mr Blair had to be provoked into his attack, but we welcome it no less enthusiastically for that.

webTitle: Letters: RRF is not a simple question

fields.headline: All too rapid responses
fields.trailText: The Guardian has shown a tendency recently to use its front page lead to tell its readers what to think. Ian Traynor and Michael White carry on the bad work today (Angry Blair lambasts anti-EU 'nonsense', November 22).
fields.body:
The Guardian has shown a tendency recently to use its front page lead to tell its readers what to think. Ian Traynor and Michael White carry on the bad work today (Angry Blair lambasts anti-EU 'nonsense', November 22). "No 10 distinguishes between the complex issues behind the single currency controversy and the relatively simple question of enhanced European military cooperation," they write.

The rapid reaction force (RRF) is by no means a simple question; apart from the huge costs, and the geopolitical implications, defining its purpose would be very difficult, especially since it would not be able to do anything without the agreement of all the countries which made troops (conditionally) available. Presumably it is because your correspondents accepted this Campbell spin that they were happy to report his master's voice telling us about the "fundamentally dishonest" distortions (in the media) which Mr Blair "denounced".

The real story about the visit to the ex-KGB Butcher of Grozny was that Mr Blair, like John Major and Harold Wilson, is becoming obsessed, not with events and the real world, but with the reporting of those events.
Andrew Anderson
Edinburgh

 The mission objectives for the European RRF include peacemaking and reconciliation. On a visit this June to the Nato HQ in Brussels with the Churches' Peace Forum we found that Nato had learned one lesson in Kosovo - that the work of peacemaking and reconciliation is best done by experts in this field - civilians trained in conflict resolution. Are there plans for the EU to recruit a parallel body of civilians trained in peacemaking techniques? Peace building in a situation of conflict is much cheaper than peace enforcement after the conflict has turned into violence.
Norman Kember
Pinner, Middlesex
bathtub@surfaid.org

 Those who object to Britain's contribution to a European army would do well to reflect that Wellington's army at Waterloo consisted largely of men from Hanover and Leipzig, and not from the UK. And it was Blucher's late arrival with more German troops that saved the day.
John Partington
South Wingfield, Derbyshire
J.A.Partington@sheffield.ac.uk

 Your leader on Tony Blair's visit to Moscow (November 22) contains enough of the facts. Mr Blair likes President Putin. Putin is the commander of an army that has committed gross violations of human rights in Chechnya, including widespread torture and brutal massacres of civilians, atrocities that have earned him the title of the Butcher of Grozny.

But nowhere does your article register the abhorrence that should be felt by people who care about human rights for Mr Blair's behaviour. Your most cutting criticism of him is that he is "starry-eyed".

It is salutary to contrast this warmth towards a major violator of human rights to the approach taken by Mr Blair towards the president of Iraq.

Those who care about human rights want neither warmth towards the perpetrators of atrocities nor the punishing of innocent people. We want an end to hypocrisy and the pursuit of British business interests to the exclusion of all morality and humane principle. Russian atrocities in Chechnya must be opposed by all diplomatic means available, starting with forthright and unequivocal condemnation by Mr Blair. And the economic sanctions which are so devastating to the people of Iraq must be lifted.
Fay Dowker
London

And the economic sanctions which are so devastating to the people of Iraq must be lifted. Fay Dowker London

fields.headline: Down on the farm
fields.trailText: With reference to reports on the White v White divorce case, I wish to state that I am saddened, disappointed and astonished that none of the judges, including those in the House of Lords, has awarded me one of the two farms which represent the life's work of myself and Mr Martin White during our marriage and formal business partnership since 1941.
fields.body:
With reference to reports on the White v White divorce case, I wish to state that I am saddened, disappointed and astonished that none of the judges, including those in the House of Lords, has awarded me one of the two farms which represent the life's work of myself and Mr Martin White during our marriage and formal business partnership since 1941.

In 1994 when the marriage ended I used the law to divide the assets generated by the partners since 1961. These comprised two large farms totalling between 700-800 acres, two large farmhouses, nine cottages and other assets. In 1994 I had complete confidence that this division would be fair by the British legal system. I explained the equal role I had played in the partnership which had generated these assets.

Had I had the justice I then confidently expected, all the properties would have been kept in the family and passed to the next generation as if there had been no divorce. I have not had justice. Why should I be pleased that after more than six years of enormous effort on my part and that of some of my friends, I, an equal partner, have been awarded a sum of money which is insufficient to buy even one of these farms?

Throughout my life my aim has been to use only the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth. Sometimes I found I was misled and made mistakes which I quickly corrected. I am pleased if my case truly helps avoid sexual discrimination for other women in divorces. Sadly it has not been avoided for me.

I am pleased these horrendously expensive and disappointing years of litigation are over.
Pamela White
Cullompton, Devon

fields.headline: Helplines for health
fields.trailText: Nicholas Watt reports (NHS phone service rolls out, November 20) that health minister Alan Milburn will announce that NHS Direct will be handling "5m calls a year by 2004 ... All patients, except those in need of emergency care, will be encouraged to telephone NHS Direct as a first step."
fields.body:
Nicholas Watt reports (NHS phone service rolls out, November 20) that health minister Alan Milburn will announce that NHS Direct will be handling "5m calls a year by 2004 ... All patients, except those in need of emergency care, will be encouraged to telephone NHS Direct as a first step." As Mr Milburn knows, there are about 52m people in England, all eligible for NHS care. Each year, each of these consults a GP 2.5 times on average, making a total of 104m contacts - a bit more than 5m.

An important feature of the NHS is lifelong personal medical records, which though held by family doctors, follow patients all their lives, wherever they live and with whichever doctor they register. This means that although consultation times average less than 10 minutes, caring professionals can just about cope because they seldom have to start from scratch. Not "first steps" in treatment, but next steps in what should be a continuing sequence, centred on patients' life stories. This is the direction in which the NHS needs urgently to move: more continuity, more respect for the evidence patients provide, more consultation time for all these things to be done thoughtfully.

English experience with NHS Direct so far has been positive, even though there is no access to accumulated data about patients. This could be solved fairly easily with simple computer held records: patients could then hold a copy themselves, updated annually, available for any health professional they see. The minister would improve his standing if duplicate patient-held records, 10-minute booking intervals, and the resources to bring these about were all included in the next election manifesto.
Prof Julian Tudor Hart
University of Glamorgan

fields.headline: How home can be a four-letter word for workers
fields.trailText: Most senior managers are male, work long hours and are proud of it. They don't take kindly to their wimpish male underlings who want to go home to help bathe their children and put them to bed (Excessive overtime causing havoc to families, November 21).
fields.body:
Most senior managers are male, work long hours and are proud of it. They don't take kindly to their wimpish male underlings who want to go home to help bathe their children and put them to bed (Excessive overtime causing havoc to families, November 21). My 30-plus son-in-law was recently "let go" from his role as a senior graphic designer because he was "not a team player" - meaning he rarely went to the wine bar after work. He refused to work Sundays and was not even grateful when invited to work most nights until 11pm.

Here was a man who had declared on his CV that one of his major interests was spending time with his baby daughter - very suspicious.

My company conducts employee opinion surveys. The most valuable benefit to the huge number of respondents (both male and female) this year has been flexible working hours, over and above pensions, company car and bonuses.

Workers appear to be crying out for support in balancing their work and home commitments and yet, when results are presented to senior management, flexible working is usually ignored in favour of the quick fix: more social events or gym membership.

Employers just don't get it. They are paying high accommodation costs so that their staff can commute miserably back and forth by car or train to sit in front of an office computer and phone and gather for hours around the vending machine to moan about their journeys to work.

The reason this madness continues is because they don't trust their employees, the people they recruited, to work 40 hours a week from home.
Name and address supplied

 One action the government can take to help reduce working hours is to set up a labour inspectorate to monitor working time regulations and other employment legislation. At present it is left to individual workers to enforce their rights in work and, of course, any attempt to do so carries the risk of the sack.

Bad employers know that compensation for unfair dismissal or other malpractice is usually meagre and difficult to obtain. If they faced prosecution by the government agencies for bad employment practices they would know that the government is serious about protecting workers' rights and would think twice before forcing their workers to damage their health by excessive hours.
Jim McCracken
Director, Low Pay Unit (Ireland)

 I have been quite taken with the debate about working at home (Should I stay or should I go?, G2, November 22). How can people who do useful work, such as dustmen, nurses, fishermen, miners and so on, work from home? The rule seems to be that the less useful the job the easier it is to work from home, the higher the wage and the more likely to need a computer or, hopefully, be replaced by one.
Peter Chadwick
Cheltenham, Glos

fields.headline: In the iron lady's wake
fields.trailText: Ed Vaizey compares the Kennedy mystique and legacy with Thatcher's (Mods and mockers, November 22). Whatever his flaws, Kennedy spoke to the better side of people: "Ask what you can do for America, not what America can do for you"; "Ich bin ein Berliner".
fields.body:
Ed Vaizey compares the Kennedy mystique and legacy with Thatcher's (Mods and mockers, November 22). Whatever his flaws, Kennedy spoke to the better side of people: "Ask what you can do for America, not what America can do for you"; "Ich bin ein Berliner". He created the Peace Corps and supported Martin Luther King. Thatcher will be remembered for: "I want my money," "Rejoice!" and her opposition to sanctions against South Africa. Gore Vidal and Truman Capote were guests in the Kennedy White House; Thatcher's Downing Street had Jeffrey Archer and Frederick Forsyth.
Mercedes Gould
London

webTitle: Computing on the move gets running

fields.headline: Computing on the move gets running
fields.standfirst:
Palmtops, pads and pocket PCs were very much in the spotlight at the big computer show in Las Vegas, while digital cameras and chips jostled for attention
Net news
fields.trailText: Jack Schofield at Comdex: Palmtops, pads and pocket PCs were very much in the spotlight at the big computer show in Las Vegas, while digital cameras and chips jostled for attention
fields.body:
When Bill Gates showed a tablet PC during his keynote speech at the opening of the Comdex computer trade show in Las Vegas last week, Jon-Erik Prichard was well pleased. Microsoft does not make tablet PCs, but Prichard's Californian company, Aqcess, does.

"We applaud [Microsoft's] effort, because it legitimises the tablet space, so we have less of an argument to convince buyers. But what Gates showed was a stripped down version of what we have today," said Prichard.

Pads and tablets
The first version of Aqcess's Qbe ("cube") personal computer tablet was a Best of Comdex award winner last year. This year the company unveiled a smaller, lighter model, the Vivo (see www.qbenet.com). This runs Windows Me or Windows 2000 and therefore lacks the "digital ink" feature that allows handwriting to be manipulated like word processed text, while retaining the annotations people typically make in paper notebooks. (They put words in boxes, or ring them, and add links or arrows.)

Naturally, the Qbe will get "digital ink" when it is added to Windows. In the meantime, it has handwriting recognition, voice recognition, wireless networking, and a built-in camera. The Qbe models are not available in the UK but Prichard says the company is talking to European distributors.

Tablet or pad-style computers have been around for more than a decade, GRiD's GridPad being a notable example. However, they have not been successful with consumers, though they have been used for industrial and commercial applications, including the police and health services.

More recently there have been attempts to sell tablet computers as mobile "internet appliances" (IA). This trend started at Comdex two years ago, when National Semiconductor unveiled a reference design for the WebPad as a way of encouraging sales of its Intel-compatible Geode processor (see http://ia.national.com). It was continued last year, when Gates demonstrated "MSN companions" during his keynote speech, using a Compaq device.

Most of these tablets are not PC-compatible but use an operating system requiring fewer, cheaper hardware resources. Examples include Linux, Be's BeOS, and Windows CE. But the market has yet to take off.

Honeywell launched its version of the WebPad only last month (Online, October 26), but at Comdex, NatSemi unveiled a revised version, the Geode WebPad Metro. This has been co-developed by Metricom, which runs the Ricochet wireless network, and has a built in 128kbps Ricochet wireless modem.

The WebPad Metro measures 19.8 x 24.3 x 2.8cm and weighs 2.5lbs. It runs Windows CE 3.0, though Be's BeIA and Linux will available next year.

Sweden's RSC also showed a new variant of the NatSemi design in its second-generation RSC WebPad. This is also cordless (wireless) but can use a DECT PadCard, wireless network card (802.11b) or Bluetooth or GPRS (General Packet Radio Service) connection.

Ezex showed a string of similar pad-like WebBooks, offering a choice of Intel StrongArm, Mips, and Transmeta Crusoe processors. All run Windows CE 3, with the option of Linux to follow. The WebBooks are targeted at the traditional markets: healthcare, hospitality (eg ordering systems), sales and manufacturing. See www.ezex.net.

The advantage of PCTs (Personal Computer Tablets) such as the Qbe Vivo is that they offer the full power of a standalone PC running Windows Me/2000 in a mobile package. They are also easy to connect to other PCs and compatible devices. WebPads have the advantages of being simpler and cheaper. Both types of device are limited by the lack of wireless networks and the high price and slow connection speeds of cellular (mobile phone) networks. Sales seem unlikely to take off until cheap, fast mobile services become widely available.

Palmtops
Gerry Purdy, founder of the Californian research company Mobile Insights, billed it as the Battle of the Century. The fact that Comdex took time out to debate whether Palm-compatibles were better than PocketPCs showed palmtop computers were being taken seriously. Far more significant was the fact that a dozen similar machines were on show in the halls from a wide range of Asian companies, including Acer, from Taiwan, and China's giant PC supplier, Legend.

The three major stands - Palm, Handspring, and Microsoft's PocketPC arena - were all mobbed. Handspring's partner companies were showing a very impressive range of plug-in modules for its Springboard expansion slot (not available on Palm's systems). But when it came to new devices, Microsoft's PocketPC/Windows CE 3 was the only system to score.

Leading the way was the Cyberbank Multipalm from Korea. This includes a palmtop with a built-in mobile phone and unlimited wireless internet access. The 4in colour screen provides full VGA graphics with 640x480 resolution, which is four times as good as a PocketPC and more than 10 times what you get on a Palm's 160x60 screen. Like other new CE-based devices, it also includes MP3/Windows Media Audio software.

PC-EPhone, which will sell the Multipalm in the US, says it expects the device to be manufactured by Samsung in the first quarter of next year.

InViso, an optical design company, also showed its remarkable eCase handheld with a small viewfinder that used advanced optics to provide a sharp, legible display that looked like a full-sized screen - particularly useful with the built-in Internet Explorer browser. The display meant giving up the touch-screen operation of most CE devices but Steve Timmerman, InViso's vice president of sales and marketing, said the built-in microphone provided "the ideal interface: speech in, web out".

The InViso device could be in production by next summer (estimated price about $600). Pictures of the device are at www.inviso.com.

Casio showed a range of PocketPCs running the palmtop version of Windows CE 3. The newest model, the E-500, should be slower than Compaq's popular iPaq, but the fast screen redraw made it feel very responsive. It was also available in a range of colours. The Japanese company also showed the E-125V, an updated version of the E-115, and two rugged industrial models: the IT-700, featuring a 10-key numeric pad, and the EG-800.

Legend, which has been selling Tianji Windows CE-based palmtops in mainland China since July 1998, now has an even bigger range, with seven models. Two include pager facilities that enable the systems to download stock prices every 20 seconds. Legend also showed a Linux-based palmtop: a spokeswoman said the CE machines were targeted at the high end, and the Linux version at the low end of the market.

Linux was used in the lightweight Agenda VR3 palmtop mentioned earlier in Online, and in Mobile Data Processing's DAT500 industrial handheld (See www.4p-online.com). Agenda is selling systems to software developers now, and will have a finished version for consumers next year.

Penbex Data Systems, from Taipei, Taiwan, is also hoping to benefit from a boom in palmtop computers, and has adapted its Penbex OS operating system for the task. Palmtops using Penbex OS include the Cadmus Billionton, and the Procomp, sold in China by TCL.

Gerry Purdy's Comdex debate between the PocketPC and the Palm had ended with forests of hands. More than two thirds of the audience voted that the PocketPC team, led by Microsoft's Phil Holden, had won the argument, though more than half felt that Palm-compatible machines would still be the market leaders two years from now. No-one voted for Penbex OS, but with Asian languages favouring a stylus rather than a keyboard, there could soon be more palmtop users in China, Korea and Japan than there are in Europe and the US.

Transmeta
Most people don't really care very much what kind of processor their computer uses, as long as it is fast and runs the software they want. David Ditzel's Transmeta Corporation, based in Califor nia, is trying to change that with its power-saving Crusoe chip, which was at the heart of a dozen machines shown at Comdex 2000. Sony, NEC, Hitachi, Fujitsu, Casio and Gateway were among the companies using it.

The Crusoe's selling point is that lets manufacturers produce portable devices with much longer battery life.

But how much longer is open to debate. Sony's C1VE ultraportable PC running Windows Me, reviewed here on November 9, managed more than three hours, compared with half that for the earlier PCG-1, though it also ran somewhat slower than notebooks with 600MHz Intel processors.

At Comdex, Casio claimed its Cassiopeia FIVA subnotebook PC, shown in prototype form, would be able to keep going for "between six and nine hours when equipped with a large-capacity, long-life battery". This compares with three to six hours for the FIVA MPC-102, which is based on the National Semiconductor Geode processor, originally developed by Cyrix.

The Crusoe-based FIVA is A5 sized, less than an inch thick, and weighs 2.1lbs. It has an 8.4in colour LCD screen, and will be launched in the first half of next year.

Hitachi hedged its bets with a more powerful notebook PC that can be supplied either with a Transmeta Crusoe or with an Intel Pentium III with SpeedStep power-saving features. Hitachi's Mini-Notebook has a 12.1in screen and weighs 3.7lbs, and has a bay that can be used for a CD or DVD drive, a second hard drive, or an extra battery.

Hitachi also showed a 2.6lb webpad based on a Transmeta Crusoe chip and Mobile Linux. A spokesman said it was already on sale in Japan but there were "no plans at the moment" for a European launch.

However, IBM, which manufactures all Transmeta's chips under contract, was not sure David could beat the Goliath known as Intel. IBM had customers try the Crusoe in test versions of its ThinkPad 240 ultraportable PC before deciding not to support the chip at the moment. A week or so later, IBM appeared at Comdex with a ThinkPad 240 sporting a power-saving Intel Mobile Pentium that will not be launched until next year.

Transmeta spent five years developing its chip, and claimed it had a five-year lead over Intel. If it is just a year ahead, or less, this is one battle that David could lose.

And the rest
Olympus grabbed the attention of digital photography buffs at Comdex by showing the world's first 4 megapixel camera. The Camedia E-10 is a black, professional-looking system with a 4x 9-36mm zoom lens (equivalent to 35-40mm on a 35mm camera).

It offers a range of exposure systems and can be used in manual and autofocusing modes. It should be available in the US next month for $1,999.

InViso showed a headset that was much smaller and provided a much sharper image than rival systems such as the Olympus EyeTrak and Daeyang E&C's Cy-visor (See www.personaldisplay.com). It can be used with any operating system and any device that provides a digital RGB colour output, such as a portable DVD player.

When it goes into production, InVisio expects the initial market will be among America's 7.5 million frequent flyers who want to use their notebook PCs or watch movies in privacy.

Both Iomega and Photela showed devices that plug into a TV set to display images without requiring a computer. Iomega's FotoShow has the edge because it can use high-capacity 100MB and 250MB Zip disks. You can also connect the FotoShow to a personal computer and use it as a normal drive. Photela's TV Slideshow is a similar device but based on a floppy disk drive.

And finally, for the family that has everything else, the e-alarm clock. Simple Devices showed the SimpleClock internet alarm clock which lets you go to sleep listening to your favourite MP3 tracks or an internet radio station, and wake up to updated information from the web and your personal information manager. The SimpleClock has a colour LCD screen, and a wireless connection to your home internet network.

Sea Star Clock International's E-clock is a simpler device that links to a Windows PC and lets you download up to 50 seconds of sound for use by the alarm. If you want to wake up to the sound of, say, a cock crowing, this will do the job.

The WebBooks are targeted at the traditional markets: healthcare, hospitality (eg ordering systems), sales and manufacturing. See www.ezex.net. The advantage of PCTs (Personal Computer Tablets) such as the Qbe Vivo is that they offer the full power of a standalone PC running Windows Me/2000 in a mobile package. They are also easy to connect to other PCs and compatible devices. WebPads have the advantages of being simpler and cheaper. Both types of device are limited by the lack of wireless networks and the high price and slow connection speeds of cellular (mobile phone) networks. Sales seem unlikely to take off until cheap, fast mobile services become widely available. Palmtops Gerry Purdy, founder of the Californian research company Mobile Insights, billed it as the Battle of the Century. The fact that Comdex took time out to debate whether Palm-compatibles were better than PocketPCs showed palmtop computers were being taken seriously. Far more significant was the fact that a dozen similar machines were on show in the halls from a wide range of Asian companies, including Acer, from Taiwan, and China's giant PC supplier, Legend. The three major stands - Palm, Handspring, and Microsoft's PocketPC arena - were all mobbed. Handspring's partner companies were showing a very impressive range of plug-in modules for its Springboard expansion slot (not available on Palm's systems). But when it came to new devices, Microsoft's PocketPC/Windows CE 3 was the only system to score. Leading the way was the Cyberbank Multipalm from Korea. This includes a palmtop with a built-in mobile phone and unlimited wireless internet access. The 4in colour screen provides full VGA graphics with 640x480 resolution, which is four times as good as a PocketPC and more than 10 times what you get on a Palm's 160x60 screen. Like other new CE-based devices, it also includes MP3/Windows Media Audio software. PC-EPhone, which will sell the Multipalm in the US, says it expects the device to be manufactured by Samsung in the first quarter of next year. InViso, an optical design company, also showed its remarkable eCase handheld with a small viewfinder that used advanced optics to provide a sharp, legible display that looked like a full-sized screen - particularly useful with the built-in Internet Explorer browser. The display meant giving up the touch-screen operation of most CE devices but Steve Timmerman, InViso's vice president of sales and marketing, said the built-in microphone provided "the ideal interface: speech in, web out". The InViso device could be in production by next summer (estimated price about $600). Pictures of the device are at www.inviso.com. Casio showed a range of PocketPCs running the palmtop version of Windows CE 3. The newest model, the E-500, should be slower than Compaq's popular iPaq, but the fast screen redraw made it feel very responsive. It was also available in a range of colours. The Japanese company also showed the E-125V, an updated version of the E-115, and two rugged industrial models: the IT-700, featuring a 10-key numeric pad, and the EG-800. Legend, which has been selling Tianji Windows CE-based palmtops in mainland China since July 1998, now has an even bigger range, with seven models. Two include pager facilities that enable the systems to download stock prices every 20 seconds. Legend also showed a Linux-based palmtop: a spokeswoman said the CE machines were targeted at the high end, and the Linux version at the low end of the market. Linux was used in the lightweight Agenda VR3 palmtop mentioned earlier in Online, and in Mobile Data Processing's DAT500 industrial handheld (See www.4p-online.com). Agenda is selling systems to software developers now, and will have a finished version for consumers next year. Penbex Data Systems, from Taipei, Taiwan, is also hoping to benefit from a boom in palmtop computers, and has adapted its Penbex OS operating system for the task. Palmtops using Penbex OS include the Cadmus Billionton, and the Procomp, sold in China by TCL. Gerry Purdy's Comdex debate between the PocketPC and the Palm had ended with forests of hands. More than two thirds of the audience voted that the PocketPC team, led by Microsoft's Phil Holden, had won the argument, though more than half felt that Palm-compatible machines would still be the market leaders two years from now. No-one voted for Penbex OS, but with Asian languages favouring a stylus rather than a keyboard, there could soon be more palmtop users in China, Korea and Japan than there are in Europe and the US. Transmeta Most people don't really care very much what kind of processor their computer uses, as long as it is fast and runs the software they want. David Ditzel's Transmeta Corporation, based in Califor nia, is trying to change that with its power-saving Crusoe chip, which was at the heart of a dozen machines shown at Comdex 2000. Sony, NEC, Hitachi, Fujitsu, Casio and Gateway were among the companies using it. The Crusoe's selling point is that lets manufacturers produce portable devices with much longer battery life. But how much longer is open to debate. Sony's C1VE ultraportable PC running Windows Me, reviewed here on November 9, managed more than three hours, compared with half that for the earlier PCG-1, though it also ran somewhat slower than notebooks with 600MHz Intel processors. At Comdex, Casio claimed its Cassiopeia FIVA subnotebook PC, shown in prototype form, would be able to keep going for "between six and nine hours when equipped with a large-capacity, long-life battery". This compares with three to six hours for the FIVA MPC-102, which is based on the National Semiconductor Geode processor, originally developed by Cyrix. The Crusoe-based FIVA is A5 sized, less than an inch thick, and weighs 2.1lbs. It has an 8.4in colour LCD screen, and will be launched in the first half of next year. Hitachi hedged its bets with a more powerful notebook PC that can be supplied either with a Transmeta Crusoe or with an Intel Pentium III with SpeedStep power-saving features. Hitachi's Mini-Notebook has a 12.1in screen and weighs 3.7lbs, and has a bay that can be used for a CD or DVD drive, a second hard drive, or an extra battery. Hitachi also showed a 2.6lb webpad based on a Transmeta Crusoe chip and Mobile Linux. A spokesman said it was already on sale in Japan but there were "no plans at the moment" for a European launch. However, IBM, which manufactures all Transmeta's chips under contract, was not sure David could beat the Goliath known as Intel. IBM had customers try the Crusoe in test versions of its ThinkPad 240 ultraportable PC before deciding not to support the chip at the moment. A week or so later, IBM appeared at Comdex with a ThinkPad 240 sporting a power-saving Intel Mobile Pentium that will not be launched until next year. Transmeta spent five years developing its chip, and claimed it had a five-year lead over Intel. If it is just a year ahead, or less, this is one battle that David could lose. And the rest Olympus grabbed the attention of digital photography buffs at Comdex by showing the world's first 4 megapixel camera. The Camedia E-10 is a black, professional-looking system with a 4x 9-36mm zoom lens (equivalent to 35-40mm on a 35mm camera). It offers a range of exposure systems and can be used in manual and autofocusing modes. It should be available in the US next month for $1,999. InViso showed a headset that was much smaller and provided a much sharper image than rival systems such as the Olympus EyeTrak and Daeyang E&C's Cy-visor (See www.personaldisplay.com). It can be used with any operating system and any device that provides a digital RGB colour output, such as a portable DVD player. When it goes into production, InVisio expects the initial market will be among America's 7.5 million frequent flyers who want to use their notebook PCs or watch movies in privacy. Both Iomega and Photela showed devices that plug into a TV set to display images without requiring a computer. Iomega's FotoShow has the edge because it can use high-capacity 100MB and 250MB Zip disks. You can also connect the FotoShow to a personal computer and use it as a normal drive. Photela's TV Slideshow is a similar device but based on a floppy disk drive. And finally, for the family that has everything else, the e-alarm clock. Simple Devices showed the SimpleClock internet alarm clock which lets you go to sleep listening to your favourite MP3 tracks or an internet radio station, and wake up to updated information from the web and your personal information manager. The SimpleClock has a colour LCD screen, and a wireless connection to your home internet network. Sea Star Clock International's E-clock is a simpler device that links to a Windows PC and lets you download up to 50 seconds of sound for use by the alarm. If you want to wake up to the sound of, say, a cock crowing, this will do the job.

webTitle: D-Day as Ferdinand heads north for talks

fields.headline: D-Day as Ferdinand heads north for talks
fields.standfirst: West Ham go for Anfield's Song at £2.5m
fields.trailText: After nearly a year on the trail of Rio Ferdinand, David O'Leary will finally get his man today when the defender moves to Elland Road in a deal worth £18m.
fields.body:
The blow of European defeat last night should be softened today when Leeds United move closer to signing the West Ham defender Rio Ferdinand.

Ferdinand is due at Elland Road this morning for talks about the £18m deal that will make him the most expensive defender in the world.

All that remains is for the 22-year-old to agree personal terms and, with a contract worth around £1.8m a year on offer, plus a seven-figure signing-on fee, Leeds do not envisage any late hitches.

"It's D-Day for me," Ferdinand said last night. "This is easily the biggest decision I've had to make in my career. I won't be rushing into a decision."

The Leeds manager David O'Leary said: "I hope we get him," but added: "I don't think any footballer, as my wife says, for kicking a silly white ball around, is worth that amount. But I don't pay it. All I do is recommend the player I think will add to the future of what we are trying to achieve at this club."

If everything goes to plan, Ferdinand, who is eligible for the Champions League, will make his debut in Sunday's Premiership match against Arsenal at Elland Road.

webTitle: West Ham go for Anfield's Song at £2.5m

fields.headline: West Ham go for Anfield's Song at £2.5m
fields.trailText: With £18m soon to be burning a hole in his pocket, Harry Radknapp was yesterday negotiating the purchase of Liverpool defender Rigobert Song for £2.5m.
fields.body:
The first beneficiary of West Ham United's new-found wealth is likely to be the Liverpool defender Rigobert Song.

West Ham's manager Harry Redknapp, who is expecting to bank £18m from the sale of Rio Ferdinand, was negotiating a £2.5m deal with the Merseyside club yesterday and Song is expected to sign within 24 hours. The Cameroon defender, aged 24, is last night understood to have flown to London from Athens, where he had been preparing for Liverpool's Uefa Cup tie against Olympiakos.

Song arrived at Anfield from the Italian club Salernitana for £2.4m two years ago but has been surplus to requirements since this season's arrival of the Germany pair Markus Babbel and Christian Ziege.

Rangers expect to complete a Scottish-record £12m move for Tore Andre Flo today on a 4-year deal. The Norwegian is expected to make his debut in Sunday's Old Firm game against the former record holder Chris Sutton, Celtic's £6m signing and a team-mate of Flo's at Chelsea last season.

Flo, now 27, was in Glasgow yesterday and underwent a stringent medical. "Everything appears to be in order," a club statement said. "But the results of a few tests are awaited."

Rangers, who are being extra cautious after Wimbledon's John Hartson and Espanyol's Raul Tamudo failed to satisfy the Ibrox medics, are confident of completing the deal, however. "The player will train with the team in the morning, and a press conference will be held in the early afternoon," the statement added.

Aston Villa have had a club- record £8m offer for Benni McCarthy turned down by Celta Vigo, who want £12m for the South African striker. "Well out of our reach," according to Villa's manager John Gregory.

The FA has asked Oxford United and Macclesfield for their versions of events after Oxford fans twice pulled down a goal net during Saturday's FA Cup first-round victory at Moss Rose. The second instance came moments after a penalty was awarded to the home side. Lee Glover eventually missed and the visitors won 1-0.

fields.headline: A man of detail dubbed 'the Trotsky of the arts'
fields.trailText: It was an exhibition at the Tate gallery that persuaded the student Nicholas Serota to drop his Cambridge degree in economics and take up history of art.
fields.body:
It was an exhibition at the Tate gallery that persuaded the student Nicholas Serota to drop his Cambridge degree in economics and take up history of art.

Twenty-two years later, he completed the circle by becoming the gallery's director, a man whose gimlet eye for detail won him notoriety as "the Trotsky of the arts".

His flair for organisation revealed itself early. At his prep school, Haberdashers' Aske's in north London, Sir Nicholas was head boy.

His mother, Beatrice - now Baroness Serota, Labour life peer and deputy speaker in the House of Lords - once awarded him a medal for not tidying his room. Sir Nicholas's father, Stanley, was a civil engineer.

After graduating in history of art, Sir Nicholas won an MA at the Courtauld Institute under the tutelage of Anita Brookner.

The 54-year-old's style of management developed during the 1970s when he progressed through a series of steadily more demanding jobs that taught him how to juggle the roles of part-critic, part-bean counter and part-seducer - all required of the director of a public gallery.

His first position was as an exhibition organiser at the Arts Council, then as director of the Museum of Modern Art in Oxford and, in 1976, director of the Whitechapel art gallery, a position he held until landing the directorship of the Tate in 1988.

It was in this capacity that Sir Nicholas's meticulousness found its fullest expression - and condemnation.

"He's a very single-minded person," said Norman Rosenthal, the exhibitions secretary of the Royal Academy who ran against Sir Nicholas for the Tate job. "'How do I get there as correctly and as quickly as possible?' is how he thinks."

"Nick is always the final arbiter," said an insider at the gallery, "even on what crisps we serve in the restaurants."

His major acquisitions at the Tate included classic English works but as the man with the deciding vote on the Turner Prize jury, he has flashed a more radical streak.

Nonetheless, he has been accused by Brian Sewell of being "dangerously narrow in tastes and interests, too exclusive, too readily prepared to use the Tate Gallery as his personal instrument", for which the art critic has labelled him "the Trotsky of the arts".

Sir Nicholas's success at fundraising, however, identifies him as a man of considerable charms.

While at the Whitechapel, he raised enough money to rebuild the entire gallery. One private collector received a letter from him that, he recalls, he "wanted to have made into a T-shirt it was so flattering".

Sir Nicholas was knighted last year and, in 1997, two years after his marriage to the ballerina Angela Beveridge was dissolved, he married Teresa Gleadowe, former head of information at the Tate. He has two daughters.

fields.headline: Liverpool well prepared though Houllier registers official concern
fields.trailText: After some obsessive preparation, Gérard Houllier can now only hope that his team rediscover a ruthless streak - and that a strong referee will officiate at tonight's game.
fields.body:
Liverpool's Gérard Houllier yesterday became the latest in a long line of managers to cast a suspicious eye over the enviable home record of the Greek champions, Olympiakos.

Houllier is uneasy about the apparent ease and the regularity with which the Piraeus club transforms home advantage into success. "I won't tell you what I think; but I think they have a good home record," said Liverpool's manager ahead of tonight's Uefa Cup third-round first leg.

The Olympiakos record to which Houllier was referring is curious when considered against their away form.

Over the past three seasons the Greeks have staged 14 Champions League ties at the Olympic stadium, avoiding defeat in all of them. In their 14 away legs, Olympiakos failed to win a game. This season they defeated Valencia, Lyon and Heerenveen at home but failed to reach the Champions League second phase because they lost the away games.

"It is not the team I fear, it is the referee," said Houllier. "We need a good referee, a strong referee."

The Dutchman Rene Temmink has been handed the match. He last officiated for Uefa two weeks ago when Rosenborg were held 1-1 by Bayern Munich and he showed two yellow cards.

In the week that Victor Meldrew perished beneath the wheels of a speeding car it is probably only right and proper that Houllier is struggling to believe what is happening to his team, or what might happen to them tonight.

An unshakeable faith in the durability of the human spirit apart, Meldrew and Houllier have little in common except perhaps a desire to deliver wholesome entertainment to an ever-fickle public.

For Houllier football has never been a more serious business than it is now. Liverpool's preparations for this tie have been thorough to the point of obsession.

For the first time in 36 years of largely uninterrupted European combat, the Merseysiders will spend three days and nights camped in enemy territory, the fear of fatigue prompting a departure from their Liverpool homes 52 hours before they kick off in front of a sell-out crowd of 66,000.

Although his side have won seven of their previous nine games, Houllier is concerned about an inability to display the ruthlessness that invariably separates the good from the exceptional.

He has concerns, too, about a defence that last season was tight and mean but that is now proving to be sloppy and generous.

"It is proving to be frustrating because we are constantly opening the scoring in games but then failing to protect our advantage," Houllier said. "If we could do that then we would be several points better off in the Premiership and up at the top with Manchester United.

"I do think we have improved as a team. We are scoring more goals and creating more chances. What we have to do now is cut out the errors, get rid of them."

Though he is understandably desperate to claim an away goal, Houllier may well decide to play safe this evening by utilising Emile Heskey as a lone striker. Such a move would seem logical with Michael Owen still not match-fit after a month on the sidelines with a head injury and Robbie Fowler struggling with another knee problem.

"We will be aiming to score at least once," Houllier added. "A goal away from home can make all the difference."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk
