fields.headline: Satoko Fujii/Remote Viewers
fields.standfirst:
Purcell Room
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Purcell Room
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Satoko Fujii, the diminutive, cascade-haired young Japanese musician, looks set to mirror the many-sided career of her famous jazz compatriot Toshiko Akiyoshi. Fujii is on the way to making the same global impression Akiyoshi did from the 1950s on - as a virtuoso piano improvisor, an original composer and a bandleader who gets the best collaborators to deliver.

Fujii wound up a short UK tour at the Purcell Room, sharing the bill with Remote Viewers, the sax/vocals/electronics trio that is a descendent of the unorthodox 1980s improv outfit B Shops for the Poor. Though Fujii has made fine recordings with powerful partners (such as her former teacher Paul Bley and Tim Berne's ruthlessly inventive drummer, Jim Black), economics dictated her show was mainly a solo flight. But for part of her performance Fujii did bring on her trumpeter husband Natsuki Tamura, a player with formidable technical resources echoing Fujii's own.

Appearing in the week after London's jazz festival, and having next to no local reputation, did nothing for the size of the house. But Fujii played as if she were in a packed hall, filling the room with thundering chord-runs, dissonant lava-like eruptions suggestive of Cecil Taylor and Don Pullen, spinning melodies within melodies - and then whispering into the same silent space with a hypnotic command of the most delicate sonics of the instrument. Her soft sounds dropped to the barely audible, and her fleeting caresses of the strings inside the instrument fluttered like soft winds.

Sometimes her uptempo playing was reminiscent of early Abdullah Ibrahim in its pumping, seamless lines over a repeating heartbeat of left-hand chords, sometimes it had the staccato melodies and rigorously timed tempos of contemporary classical music.

A Jimmy Giuffre tune caught both Giuffre's typical, quiet obliqueness and Fujii's fertility and fluidity of melodic invention. She apologised for her partnerless circumstances obliging her to play the part of soloist, bassist and drummer all at once, but she was so effortlessly on top of things that it was superfluous.

Her duet with her husband in the later stages of the performance, veering between tumultuous intensity and laterally-conceived pieces played with double-taking silences between events, was an indication of just how independent a line some young jazz-based improvisors (the ones who feel they do not have to repolish "classic jazz") are pursuing today.

Though the influence of Miles Davis and Lester Bowie were apparent in his work, Tamura unpacked a bag of growls, sidelong slurs, shimmering brass-band dignity, tumbling freebop runs and percussive sound effects that were all his own. Cutting-edge improv from an eclectic contemporary environment, but accessible enough to have enthralled a much bigger audience than it did.

Her soft sounds dropped to the barely audible, and her fleeting caresses of the strings inside the instrument fluttered like soft winds. Sometimes her uptempo playing was reminiscent of early Abdullah Ibrahim in its pumping, seamless lines over a repeating heartbeat of left-hand chords, sometimes it had the staccato melodies and rigorously timed tempos of contemporary classical music. A Jimmy Giuffre tune caught both Giuffre's typical, quiet obliqueness and Fujii's fertility and fluidity of melodic invention. She apologised for her partnerless circumstances obliging her to play the part of soloist, bassist and drummer all at once, but she was so effortlessly on top of things that it was superfluous. Her duet with her husband in the later stages of the performance, veering between tumultuous intensity and laterally-conceived pieces played with double-taking silences between events, was an indication of just how independent a line some young jazz-based improvisors (the ones who feel they do not have to repolish "classic jazz") are pursuing today. Though the influence of Miles Davis and Lester Bowie were apparent in his work, Tamura unpacked a bag of growls, sidelong slurs, shimmering brass-band dignity, tumbling freebop runs and percussive sound effects that were all his own. Cutting-edge improv from an eclectic contemporary environment, but accessible enough to have enthralled a much bigger audience than it did.

fields.headline: Cipri and Maresco
fields.standfirst:
Lux
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Lux
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Italian cinema - what little we've seen of it - has seemed staid and uneventful for the last few decades. But often in national cinemas it takes real outsiders to shake things up, and as with Almodovar in Spain, so in Italy with the Sicilian cynicism of Daniele Cipri and Franco Maresco. Exactly what this duo mean by cynicism is hard to gauge, but their retrospective at the Lux is entitled The Cynical Feeling for Life, and feeling for life - in its craziest, ugliest, most anarchic forms - is there in plenty.

Cipri and Maresco - as indivisible a directing double act as the Coens or the Tavianis - started out making videos and experimental shorts for a Palermo TV station, and some early work is collected in this season as two packages of "Cinico TV". But their features are surely the weirdest to emerge from European cinema in years.

In The Uncle from Brooklyn (1995), a family of middle-aged brothers is entrusted by two dwarf Mafia dons with the care of a mysterious, cadaverous visitor. In between moments of farting and belching, and extended poker-faced sight gags, there are long stretches of silence and bleak Antonioni-like views of Palermo architecture, before the city is overrun by dogs and the whole cast is carried off to heaven.

Totu Who Lived Twice (1998) is a portmanteau of three tall stories, culminating in the tale of the two Totus, one a vengeful mafioso, the other a cantankerous God figure. Totu was the cause of much scandal in Sicily, not surprisingly - it features copious masturbation and scatology, and a scene in which a grinning idiot enthusiastically rogers a statue of the Virgin Mary. Throughout, grisly old men perform bizarre drag acts. The effect is neither camp nor queer, but almost medievally grotesque.

Unsettlingly, Cipri and Maresco's taste for the grue some has as its flip side a very polished aestheticism. While their cast and their bodily habits outdo Fellini, Luca Bigazzi's classically stark photography harks back to the severity of Pasolini. But even the beauty seems part of a self-conscious, Monty Python-ish wind-up. Perhaps you have to know Palermo culture to get what Cipri and Maresco are really up to, but the dialogue has its own bilious verve, even for those of us whose Sicilian dialect is a bit rusty.

I can't wait to see what these Sicilian cynics do next, although I suspect that they won't be nearly cynical enough to play the conventional art-house game.

 Ends Sunday. Box office: 020-7684 0201.

webTitle: Theatre review: Long Day's Journey Into Night

fields.headline: Jessica Lange's magnificent journey
fields.standfirst:
Long Day's Journey Into Night
Lyric Shaftesbury
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Long Day's Journey Into Night
Lyric Shaftesbury
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Jessica Lange at first seems surprising casting as Mary Tyrone in Eugene O'Neill's great family drama. Lange has a feisty, resilient quality whereas one thinks of Mary as a pathetic victim of morphine and her husband's miserliness. But one of the surprises in Robin Phillips's excellent revisionist production is to show Mary to be as much emotional vampire as helpless addict.

O'Neill's play was famously written "in tears and blood". Set in a gaunt New England house in 1912, it offers a thinly disguised portrait of the author's own family. James Tyrone is a penny-pinching actor who wasted his precious talent on a profit-making potboiler. His wife, Mary, became drug-dependent after the traumatic birth of her youngest son, Edmund, who is now an aspiring, consumptive poet. And Edmund's brother Jamie is a cynical wastrel visibly contemptuous of his skinflint father and hophead mother.

One tends to see the play as a painful study of a family bound together by guilt, recrimination and resentment, and to some extent it is. But Phillips's beautifully sensitive production makes us see it from a fresh angle. He reminds us O'Neill is dealing with the two great themes of modern drama: the stranglehold of the past over the present and the battle between truth and illusion. But he also suggests the moral blame for the family's misery stems as much from the mother as the father.

Lange, in a magnificently unsentimental performance, reminds us that Mary is a woman who constantly twists the knife in the family's wounds. You can argue that her addiction is to blame; and Lange captures astonishingly Mary's transition during the day from nervous, hankie-twisting tension to dreamy narcotic escape. But, without judging the character, Lange shows it is her endless picking at the familial scabs that is the real source of agony.

Correspondingly, Charles Dance suggests that James Tyrone's parsimony stems from childhood poverty and his Dickensian sweatshop experience, and he brings out superbly the man's muted despair and quiet love.

Even if Paul Rudd as the self-loathing Jamie and Paul Nicholls as the sensitive Edmund offer more familiar performances, you have the exhilarating experience of rediscovering the great American dramatic classic. You go in expecting an endurance-test; you emerge as if having seen O'Neill's play for the first time.

 Until March 3. Box office: 020-7494 5045.

fields.headline: Does my boss discriminate?
fields.trailText: The problem
fields.body:
The problem

I am 54 years old and the oldest worker in my shop - it seems that my boss finds fault with every little thing I do and lectures me. At the same time he does not lecture others except for a black man on my shift.

The solution

At the moment, I do not believe that there is any specific legislation to prevent your boss discriminating against you on the grounds of age. However, there are various other pieces of legislation that could, in theory help you. For instance, if you were to leave because of your boss's treatment, then you might be able to take your employer to an industrial tribunal for constructive dismissal. But, you would really need to seek advice about your position - try the citizen's advice bureau or ACAS.

In the meantime, I suggest that you keep a diary detailing the time, place etc of every incident that you feel amounts to discrimination or harassment. Write down what happened and also keep notes of similar incidents involving colleagues that went unpunished.

Your black colleagues would have to do the same if he felt he was being discriminated against on the grounds of his race. Obviously there is legislation to protect him, but he would need to pursue this separately from you. Having said that, it is possible that at a later stage you could bring a joint complaint, but you would each need to seek advice on this.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes to Work (Purple House) and Managing Your Boss in a Week (Hodder & Stoughton).

fields.headline: Half a Sixpence
fields.standfirst:
West Yorkshire Playhouse
Leeds
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
West Yorkshire Playhouse
Leeds
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Kipps, H G Wells's Edwardian comic novel about a draper's assistant who inherits a fortune and only finds himself and true love again when he loses it all, was turned into a stage musical in 1963, and filmed four years later as Half a Sixpence, with Tommy Steele in the lead role of Kipps. It is not long into this revival before you realise why the show, by Beverley Cross and David Heneker, is now revived largely by amateur groups.

There are some memorable songs, including the title number, Flash, Bang, Wallop and I Don't Believe a Word of It, but the book - Cross's, not Wells's - is in need of a major overhaul to keep it moving. For all the inventiveness of Jude Kelly's production, there are times when the evening just drags.

But it is a tribute to Stephen Mear's nifty choreography and Kelly's skill as a director that the production succeeds in moving things along, finally sending you out of the theatre feeling reasonably happy, as well as engaging with issues of wealth and class. The use of Edwardian photos provides a counter to the picturesque stage images of jolly working-class people skating, singing and dancing with gusto after 12-hour shifts.

Kelly has innovative touches, including the introduction of a Vesta Tilley figure, and she uses the big, difficult space in all its depth as well as breadth. Even so, you can't help feeling there is something a mite overblown about the evening. If Half a Sixpence was being revived in a small space, we'd probably all be raving about a little lost musical gem, but for all her cunning Kelly can't hide the fact this is a small show on a big stage.

Mind you, it is good to see the theatre that brought us that cautionary pools winner tale Spend, Spend, Spend keeping up the offensive against easy money in these Who Wants To Be a Millionaire?, lottery-mad times.

As Helen Walsingham, the apparently kind toff with her own motives, Sara Griffiths suggests the better woman she might have been, and Ken Bradshaw, a Playhouse regular, gives another fine performance as Helen's chinless wonder of a gentleman swindler brother. But Jonjo O'Neill lacks the warmth and sense of humour necessary to make Kipps lovable, even when he has had his head turned and is behaving despicably towards sweetheart Ann, and Samantha Seager's stagey performance as Ann fails to convey why he fell in love with her in the first place.

 Until January 20. Box office: 0113-213 7700.

fields.headline: Kelly Jones, unbuttoned
fields.standfirst:
Kelly Jones
Opera House
Huddersfield
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Kelly Jones
Opera House
Huddersfield
Rating: **
fields.body:
The defining moment of this performance comes very early on. Stereophonic's vocalist Kelly Jones has already strutted on to the stage, wrapped up in the sort of fluffy parka that the Gallagher brothers made grimly fashionable many years ago. He has plodded through the first in a sequence of worthy acoustic strum-alongs, and he is now unbuttoning the coat and pulling it up over his head.

Underneath the coat he is wearing a sleeveless black tank-top, and the place erupts with high-pitched screams. Thus Jones finally confirms that he is indeed the vital missing link between Ronan Keating and Ocean Colour Scene, a "serious" musician who hates the Spice Girls and sings "proper" songs, but whose audience is as likely to applaud the sight of his bare arms as they are his rather uninspiring music.

Jones sings earnest ditties in a droning voice that obviously comes very easily to him. Some of his tunes are quite pretty but the arrangements - mostly acoustic guitar and piano - are ordinary. The subject matter of the songs varies greatly. Have a Nice Day is about an interesting taxi driver who once said some interesting things to Jones while driving him somewhere. Caravan Holiday is about being stuck in a caravan. It is evident that he wrote one of the songs when he was 19.

Each song is preceded by hysterical giggling and followed by rapturous applause, the female shrieks bizarrely anchored by the bellowing of a tiny contingent of middle-aged dadrock fans, who are touchingly unembarrassed at being surrounded by screaming children and who seem to think that they are at a Paul Weller concert.

It's a shame about Jones because when he isn't singing he comes across as a lovely, intelligent and funny bloke. But as soon as he launches into one of his gargling epics his personality disappears like a light-bulb being switched off. Perhaps he just needs more time to mature and develop, to realise that the elusive quality called soul means more than closing your eyes and getting the phlegm rattling. He might yet make it.

Jones is quite right when he derides his critics in Mr Writer. Bitterness and cynicism have no place in the wonderful world of teen-pop. We must stoically accept that there will always be complacent heart-throbs such as Kelly Jones playing this kind of music to this kind of audience and getting this kind of reception. Good luck to him and all his future imitators.

 Kelly Jones plays the Coal Exchange, Cardiff (029-2033 0220), tomorrow.
